A brief article on Tuesday about the effectiveness of a malaria drug in fighting two viruses that recently jumped from animals to humans referred incorrectly to the invention of the drug, chloroquine. It was synthesized 75 years ago, in 1934 — not 50 years ago.

An article on Tuesday about the role of physicists in finance misstated the affiliations of three economists at the time they figured out a way to price stock options. In 1973 when their groundbreaking papers were published, Myron S. Scholes and Robert C. Merton were at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Fischer Black was at the University of Chicago. They were not, respectively, at Stanford, Harvard and Goldman Sachs. (Those were later affiliations.).

An article in some editions on Sunday about the Knicks’ loss to the Charlotte Bobcats, coached by Larry Brown, omitted the name of a current Knicks player who was on the team in January 2006, when Brown was the head coach. Besides David Lee, Nate Robinson and Quentin Richardson, Eddy Curry was also on the roster.
General Electric, which lost its AAA rating Thursday, had maintained a high overall rating until now because of the steady cash thrown off by the industrial side of its business.

The Talking Business column on Saturday, about an erosion of investor confidence in General Electric, referred incorrectly to G.E.’s acknowledgment of potential losses in its GE Capital financial unit. In addition to acknowledging $4 billion in “embedded losses” from real estate assets that it continues to manage, the company has also estimated $35 billion in losses for all assets in the unit. G.E. has not failed to acknowledge the losses for all assets.

The Big City column in some editions last Friday, about the void left for former patrons and bartenders of Fubar after a crane demolished it, referred incorrectly to the military slang term Fubar. In its polite form, it stands for Fouled Up Beyond All Recognition (not Repair). Some sources indicate “Repair” is used, but “Recognition” is considered the original and most commonly accepted usage.

An article on Thursday about the acceleration of newspaper shutdowns in major American cities referred incorrectly to the bankruptcy filing affecting The Star Tribune in Minneapolis. The newspaper filed for bankruptcy protection — not the private equity group Avista Capital Partners, which owns the paper. The error was repeated in a picture caption with the continuation of the article.

President Marc Ravalomanana went on national radio on Thursday and appealed to the armed forces to remain neutral in the island's political crisis. Some in the military have mutinied, and on Wednesday the proclaimed leader of the mutineers announced that he was assuming the job of army chief of staff. There had been hopes that a conference of political, religious and civic leaders would find a solution to the turmoil that has already led to more than 100 deaths in the past few months. But that meeting was canceled Thursday when President Ravalomanana's rival, Andry Rajoelina, pulled out.

A.C.C. TOURNAMENT Georgia Tech, which was just 2-14 in the conference in the regular season, stunned No. 17 Clemson, 86-81, in an opening-round game in Atlanta. Lewis Clinch had 32 points for the Yellow Jackets, 12-18 over all. It was in the Georgia Dome last March that Tech's rival, Georgia, came into the Southeastern Conference tournament as a bottom seed and won the tournament championship. ... Virginia Tech, the No. 8 seed, brushed aside No. 9 Miami, 65-47. RAY GLIER

GURAL--Aaron. With overwhelming sadness, the partners and entire organization of Newmark Knight Frank mourn the loss of our founder and chairman emeritus, Aaron Gural. A salute to this dedicated philanthropist and real estate pioneer with the vision that built our company to greatness, we remember the honorable and accomplished life Aaron lived and the number of lives he impacted in his 92 years. Aaron was an inspiration to our entire organization and we will cherish our memory of him. We extend our sincerest and deepest condolences to his family and friends, including his son and our chairperson, Jeffrey Gural, his daughters, Jane and Barbara, and his ten grandchildren, Aileen, Eric, Roger, Brian, Jennifer, Anny, Nikki, Perri, Lily and Noah and his nine great-grandchildren.

GURAL--Aaron. We mourn the loss of Aaron, our dear friend of 50 years. He was a leader in his industry and a man of honor and integrity. He possessed a unique sense of humor and was universally respected for his numerous philanthropic endeavors. Our sincere condolences to Jeffrey, Jane and Barbara and the entire family. We shall always remember him. Joan and Martin Rosen

GURAL--Aaron. The entire organization of Excel Security mourns the passing of Aaron Gural. We extend our sincerest condolences to our Partners Jeff, Jane and Barbara as well as the entire Gural family.

GURAL--Aaron. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with deep sadness the passing of Aaron Gural, a cherished leader and friend who was greatly admired for his extraordinary generosity and compassion. Aaron displayed true dedication as a leader with our Real Estate Executive Committee, enabling us to carry out our mission to rescue those in need. His devotion to social and humanitarian causes enriched the lives of many in New York, in Israel, and around the world. His legacy will continue through his son, Jeffrey, who alongside his father was a former honoree at our Real Estate & Allied Trades Division Luncheon, and through his daughter, Jane Gural-Senders, a past president of the JCC of the Greater Five Towns, a UJA-Federation beneficiary agency. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his son, Jeffrey, and his wife, Paula; to his daughter, Jane, and her husband, William; to his daughter, Barbara, and her husband, Tom; to his grandchildren, Aileen, Eric, Roger, Anny Rose, Perri, Nikki, Lily, Noah, Brian, and Jennifer; to his great-grandchildren, Neith, Kephra, Sophia, Miriam, Mia, Ellis, Harlan, Ethan, and Ava; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

GURAL--Aaron. The Board and staff of Starlight Children's Foundation express great sadness at the passing of Aaron Gural, friend and devoted philanthropist. We send heartfelt condolences on his father's passing to longtime Board President Jeff Gural and his family.

SCHWARZ--Carl A.,K.M.Ob., 72, on March 11. Labor, employment, and benefits attorney. Survived by wife Maryellen McGoldrick, son Peter, daughter Elizabeth, son-in-law Gregory Boison, pride and joy granddaughter Willow Anne, and three sisters Bernadette Modica, Mary Leggette, and Rosalie Edes. Fordham College '57, Fordham Law School '06, Captain, USAF, JAG and officer-liaison to NATO in France '61-64. Knight of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta, led relief efforts in Haiti, served the sick on pilgrimages to Lourdes, and was active in the organization's leadership. Partner in law firms Finley, Kumble & Wagner, and Lord, Day & Lord, and Schwarz & DeMarco LLP. Counsel to pension and benefit funds, hospitals, educational, and cultural institutions. Catholic Charities Board Member, Chairman of the Board, New York School of Interior Design, and Commodore, Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph Church, Garden City, NY, March 14 at 9:30am.
GURAL--Aaron. With sincerest and heartfelt condolences to the Gural family from everyone at the Museum at Eldridge Street.

KRAUSS--Alan, 51, of Maplewood, NJ, died March 8 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. He leaves his dear wife, Zsofia, and their daughters, Maya (six) and Nina (three). He was the brother of the late Frank Krauss, Margaret Rosenthal of Los Angeles, and Steven Krauss of Newton, MA, and the son of the late Alex and Marianne Krauss of Denver and Budapest. A veteran journalist, Alan was an editor at The New York Times for more than 12 years. He was also with The Budapest Sun, Investor's Business Daily, UPI and Newsweek. Alan was an honors graduate of Swarthmore College and held an M.S. from Northwestern. In lieu of flowers, donations for the children's education may be made in the name of Zsofia Krauss and sent to Zsofia Krauss c/o D. F. Moore Craig, Esq., 1129 Bloomfield Ave., West Caldwell, NJ 07006.

Villanova's victory in the quarterfinals of the Big East tournament on Thursday afternoon was so full of wild swings, emotions and back-breaking shots that it had Villanova Coach Jay Wright steering clear of Marquette's locker room afterward. Then it had him pulling his losing counterpart, Buzz Williams, to the side for some words of encouragement. The fourth-seeded Wildcats had just fended off a comeback by the Golden Eagles, winning by 76-75 on a layup at the buzzer by Dwayne Anderson. Wright led a horde of reporters through a winding trail of Madison Square Garden tunnels.

FINKEL--Elaine S. On Tuesday, March 10, 2009; Born in Pittsburgh in 1924, Elaine attended Allderdice High School. She was one of the first girls ever to become a Bat Mitzvah at Beth Shalom Synagogue. Her parents, Rose and Michael Shapiro, were prominent in the movie theatre business in Pittsburgh and led the local Variety Club chapter. Elaine graduated from the University of Michigan in 1945 and went on to receive a Masters degree in Speech Pathology at Columbia University Teacher's College, where she served as a paraprofessional under the President of Columbia, Dwight Eisenhower, and worked at Bellevue Hospital under Dr. Howard Rusk. She was active in anti-defamation activities led by Eleanor Roosevelt. She also was an assistant to a fashion publicist in New York, working with Vogue and Mademoiselle. To learn more about Elaine's life in New York City, please refer to the following web link http://www .tc.columbia.edu/news/ article.htm?id=4846. She returned to Pittsburgh and married David K. Finkel II (who passed away 5 years ago) in 1951, and raised three children. Among other things, she was an accomplished harpist, dedicated Cub Scout den mother, supported dance and music in Pittsburgh, and was an active member of Rodef Shalom Synagogue, Westmoreland Country Club and Concordia Club. Elaine was a die-hard Steelers and Pirates fan, and loved film, reading and crosswords. Elaine is survived by her three children Dr. Richard S. (Dr. Terri) Finkel of Philadelphia, B.J. (C.R. "Bob") Holmes of Manhattan Beach, CA and James K. (Karen) Finkel of New York, NY. Six loving grandchildren, Kirby and Michael Penner, Valerie and Paul Finkel and Madeline and Lydia Finkel. Also survived by nephews Bruce and Benji Hadburg. Services at Rodef Shalom Temple, 4905 Fifth Avenue (at Morewood) on Friday at 11AM. Visitation one hour prior to services at Temple (10 11AM). Interment Beth Shalom Cemetery. Contributions may be made to Western Pennsylvania School for the Blind, 201 N. Bellefield Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213 or Rodef Shalom Temple, 4905 Fifth Avenue, Pittsburgh, PA 15213. Services by Ralph Schugar Chapel, Inc. Services entrusted to Ralph Schugar Chapel, Inc. (412)621-8282.

FELDMAN--Lawrence S. Farrell Fritz, P.C. deeply regrets the passing of Larry Feldman, their partner and friend for many years. Larry was born on February 6, 1958. He was educated at Drew University and received a law degree from Touro Law School in 1983. Larry joined Farrell Fritz in 2002 as a partner in the Real Estate and Land Use Groups. Throughout his years as an attorney, Mr. Feldman was a trusted adviser to real estate owners and developers as well as business owners, tenants and real estate professionals alike. He served as counsel to the Commercial Industrial Brokers Society ("CIBS"), where he developed an excellent working relationship with every major brokerage house and substantially every active member of CIBS. Mr. Feldman was involved in the Men's Division of the Schneider's Children's Medical Hospital, and, from 1997 through 2002, served on the board of directors of the Huntington Arts Council. He was most recently involved with some of the most exciting and innovative commercial real estate development projects on Long Island. Larry was a distinguished lawyer, an astute businessman, a thoughtful mentor, and a wise and compassionate human being. He will be sorely missed and fondly remembered. Larry is survived by his wife, Blaire; a son, Cooper; a daughter, Mallie; and three sisters, Alisa Secofsky, Jane Ornato and Karen Antuzzi.

Leonore Annenberg, the society doyenne who was President Ronald Reagan's first chief of protocol and who, with her late husband, the ambassador and publisher Walter H. Annenberg, gave away billions to philanthropic causes, died early Thursday in Rancho Mirage, Calif. , where she had a home. She was 91. Her death, at Eisenhower Medical Center, was of natural causes, according to a family spokeswoman, Kathleen Hall Jamieson, director of the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania.

ANNENBERG--Ambassador Leonore. The Trustees and staff of the University of Pennsylvania are deeply saddened by the death of Leonore Annenberg, an Emeritus Trustee and founding member of the Joint Committee of the Trustees of the Annenberg School for Communication. Lee was associated with the University - her adopted alma mater - for over 40 years. She and her husband, the late Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg, provided extraordinary leadership, invaluable counsel, and contributions of profound importance to Penn and to society. Their appreciation and support of excellence in education, the arts, and public policy inspired Penn to strive toward ever greater distinction. The Annenbergs were dedicated benefactors whose extraordinary financial contributions transformed Penn. The impact of their generosity is beyond measure. In 1958, they founded the Annenberg School for Communication. In 1993, they added substantially to the School's founding endowment to support, among other things, the Annenberg Institute for the Study of Democratic Institutions and Government and the Institute for Adolescent Risk Communication. They created the Annenberg Public Policy Center and through generous additional support made possible the construction of its new building. Lee and Walter established 24 endowed professorships at Penn and also established the Annenberg Scholars to provide tuition assistance for undergraduate students. The Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts at Penn was named in their honor. Lee was awarded an honorary degree from Penn in 1985, and she and Walter were also recognized in 1994 with the University of Pennsylvania's Medal for Distinguished Achievement. Lee's profound dedication to education and citizenship has created a legacy which will continue in the many wonderful programs she and Walter established and in the individuals whose lives they touched. We will miss Lee's grace, determination, and most importantly, her friendship. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lee's entire family and many friends. James S. Riepe, Chairman Amy Gutmann, President

SHAIR--David Ira, passed away on March 11 at the age of 87. He was a WWII veteran who was awarded the Purple Heart after being wounded while serving in France in 1944. After recuperating from his injuries, he married Hortense "Horty" Spitz in October, 1947. Married almost 60 years, Davis and Horty enjoyed traveling, dining out and attending the theater and other cultural events. The couple were never blessed with children of their own, but David leaves behind many nieces and nephews: in Garnerville, NY, Wendy, Ivan and Lee Micklin; in Fair Lawn, NJ, Bob and Gayle Sobel; in Baltimore/Owings Mills, MD, Sue, Gail, Matt, Jeremy and Sean Pelovitz; Joyce Spitz; David, Margery, Ilana and Max Spitz; in Clarksburg, MD, Bill, Charity, Cindy, Craig and Andrew Spitz. Service Sunday, 1:00pm at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. David will be interred at Arlington National Cemetery where he will spend eternity with his beloved wife Horty, who passed away August 24, 2007. Donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

The Transportation Security Administration has opened a review into reports that Senator David Vitter threw a tantrum last week when he arrived at Reagan National Airport to catch a United Airlines plane after the gates had closed. A report in Roll Call, a newspaper covering Capitol Hill, quoted someone anonymously describing events at the airport in a fairly detailed fashion. It indicated that Mr. Vitter, Republican of Louisiana, had become incensed that airport personnel would not let him through, despite his insistence that he was a senator, and said he had set off an alarm trying to get through a door to the plane.

Dr. Ian Alger, a New York psychiatrist who pioneered the use of innovative therapeutic techniques, including video, in family and couples therapy and was an early proponent of teletherapy, in which therapist and patient communicate remotely by videoconferencing, died on Feb. 21 at his office on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. ANNENBERG Leonore. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn deeply the passing of Lee Annenberg, who shared with her late husband Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg a great passion for art and for this institution. Over the past nearly 50 years, she played many crucial roles in support of the Met generous donor, benefactor, and trustee, as well as treasured advisor and friend. Walter and Lee were spectacularly generous, both personally and through their foundation, and their landmark gifts enhanced the collections in ways that will enrich all who pass through our doors now and in the future. The centerpiece of their philanthropy to the Metropolitan is The Walter H. and Lee Annenberg Collection the sumptuous collection they amassed of 53 Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, watercolors and drawings that are on view permanently in the Annenberg Galleries within the Museum's Nineteenth-Century European Paintings and Sculpture Galleries. Speaking of this outstanding gesture, Lee said simply that the gift was meant "for the benefit of all those who care about art as we do." She will be profoundly missed, and we extend our most heartfelt condolences to the entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

The three-man crew of the International Space Station climbed into the Soyuz spacecraft lifeboat for 11 minutes Thursday afternoon as a small but potentially dangerous piece of an old rocket motor whizzed past. The space debris was about five inches wide and although the odds of a collision were small, ''It's enough we were worried about the crew, and they were taking an abundance of caution,'' said Josh Byerly, a NASA spokesman.

Outside the Ford Center in near-freezing temperatures Thursday night, there were groans among ticket scalpers when they heard that second-seeded Oklahoma had been upset by Oklahoma State, 71-70, in the Big 12 tournament. Earlier in the day, top-seeded Kansas was shocked by No. 9 seed Baylor, 71-64. Plenty of tickets will be available for the semifinals and finals.

ANNENBERG--Leonore A. The Metropolitan Opera Association deeply mourns the passing of Leonore A. Annenberg, a member of our board since 1974 and a Managing Director at the time of her death. Individually and through The Annenberg Foundation, Lee and her late husband, Walter, were among the most generous donors in the Met's entire 125-year history. In addition to their long tradition of underwriting new productions, the Annenbergs made important leadership gifts to strengthen the Met's general endowment and, most recently, to create the Annenberg Principal Artist Fund. We will forever be thankful to Lee for The Annenberg Foundation's immediate and extraordinary gift in 2005 to help continue the Saturday afternoon radio broadcasts. We cherish the memory of our dear friend, whose dignity, charm and graciousness on her many visits to the Opera House will long be remembered and greatly missed. We send our sincere condolences to her family. Christine F. Hunter, Chairman of the Board William C. Morris, President and CEO Mercedes T. Bass, Vice Chairman Peter Gelb, General Manager

8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAP Don your tin-foil antenna and tune in. In October ABC asked viewers which families from past episodes they would like to see undergo a new swap in honor of the series's 100th episode. The result is an exchange between the Heenes, above, a family of storm chasers from Colorado who look for extraterrestrials and have built a flying saucer to send into the eye of the storm, and the Silvers, a Florida family with a psychic matriarch who speaks to the dead and believes that she can control her husband and children as well as the weather. In a first, the children from the two families will face off in a table meeting. 7 A.M. (ABC) GOOD MORNING AMERICA Michelle Obama gives her first network television interview as first lady.

ChinaPresident Obama told China's foreign minister on Thursday that their two countries needed to raise ''the level and frequency'' of military dialogue ''in order to avoid future incidents'' like the high-seas confrontation between naval vessels this week, the White House said. The two met in the Oval Office in the highest-level contact since a tense encounter Sunday involving a United States Navy survey vessel and five Chinese ships escalated into what the chief American intelligence officer called the ''most serious'' military incident with China since 2001. China's foreign minister, Yang Jiechi, above, spent two hours at the White House meeting first with the national security adviser, Gen. James L. Jones, and then with Mr. Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Mr. Yang made no statements to reporters as he departed the White House.

My Sunday column looks at the way we're destroying the efficacy of antibiotics by using them as a routine, non-therapeutic supplement to livestock feed. There's lots to read on the subject for those who are interested. A brand-new book by Nicolette Hahn Niman, "Righteous Pork Chop," looks at the broad issues involving industrial hog farms -- and the alternatives. It's a good read. Many of the journal articles on this topic are available only by subscription, but the Save Antibiotics website has a compendium of material, as does Keep Antibiotics Working. This article argues that animal use of antibiotics may have more impact on resistance than hospital use. The author, Glenn Morris, head of the Emerging Pathogens Institute of University of Florida, was very helpful in my reporting, as was Dr. David Wallinga of IATP, but I ran out of space and had to cut their quotes.

I'm in Yurp for a week, spending some time on other peoples' problems (although in a way it's all part of the same problem.) And one has to say that Europe has gotten itself into one heck of a mess, worse even than ours -- because they have intractable adjustment problems on top of the general crisis.

I'm reading Liaquat Ahamed's fascinating Lords of Finance, about the central bankers who made the Great Depression so great. And all along the way are reminders about how small a world it really was, even then (smaller, actually, than it was going to be again until around 1980.) One tidbit: Hjalmar Schacht, who oversaw the expansion of Hitler's economy, was actually named Horace Greeley Hjalmar Schacht -- his father had emigrated to America, but was unsuccessful there, and moved back.

ANNENBERG--Leonore. The Chapin School community is deeply saddened by the death of Leonore Annenberg, a Chapin grandmother and the school's friend and most generous benefactor. Mrs. Annenberg and her late husband Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg made many gifts to the school, including Chapin's beautiful, spacious library and multimedia center, which is named in their honor. Mrs. Annenberg, by her commitment and generosity, helped to ensure our school's mission to always provide the highest-quality education for our students. She will be greatly missed, but her influence on Chapin will be felt for generations to come. We extend our profound sympathy to her daughter, Elizabeth Kabler, a Chapin trustee from 1992 to 2005; to her granddaughter Elizabeth, a member of Chapin's Class of 2001; and to the entire Annenberg family. Ella M. Foshay, Chair of the Board of Trustees Cera B. Robbins, Trustee Emerita Dr. Patricia T. Hayot, Head of School

ANNENBERG--Leonore. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Leonore Annenberg, wife of the late Walter H. Annenberg. Mrs. Annenberg served as Chairwoman and President of the Annenberg Foundation for more than six years. The generosity of Mrs. Annenberg, the entire Annenberg family, and their Foundation have had a profound and meaningful impact on our institution. She will be remembered forever for her warmth, her dedication to the community, and her commitment to philanthropy. We extend our deepest heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman, The Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Mary Manning Walsh Home of New York City.

Michelle Obama says she was moved by the struggles of the military families she met Thursday during her visit to Fort Bragg, N.C., and was particularly concerned when she heard that some families had to rely on food stamps to get by. ''It hurts,'' Mrs. Obama said in an interview broadcast Friday on the ABC News television program ''Good Morning America.'' ''These are people who are willing to send their loved ones off to perhaps give their lives, the ultimate sacrifice. Yet they're living back at home on food stamps. It's not right, and it's not where we should be as a nation.''

Fordham Law School records with profound sadness the passing of Jack Vaughan '64, a dear friend and devoted alumnus, a superb lawyer and adjunct faculty member, and a past President of the Fordham Law Alumni Association. His remarkable service to the Law School was recognized in 1986 when he received the Alumni Association's highest honor, the Medal of Achievement. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Jack's wonderful spirit will not be forgotten and he will always remain in the heart of the Fordham Law community. William M. Treanor, Dean

MGM Mirage, the casino giant whose investors include the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, has hired a bankruptcy and restructuring adviser as it considers options to stave off default, people briefed on the matter said. MGM Mirage is working with Evercore Partners as it seeks to negotiate with lenders on potentially revising the terms of its debt load. Analysts have said that the company may agree to give its banks liens on its properties, including casinos like the Bellagio. The company has already agreed to sell its Treasure Island casino for $775 million. With the recession sapping away customers, Las Vegas casinos have struggled to meet their debt obligations, much of which was racked up during large expansions when times were flush. Beyond meeting its debt payments, MGM Mirage needs about $1 billion to complete its City Center project, a giant residential and casino complex in the middle of Las Vegas.

WISNIEWSKI--Dr. Bronislaw (born Bernard Waxman in Warsaw, Poland in 1909) died quietly in his sleep on March 10th. He experienced and accomplished much during his 99 years of life. He survived Nazi occupation in hiding to become a hospital ward director and a professor at the Medical School of Internal Medicine Institute in post war Warsaw. In his late forties he arrived in America settling in New York with wife Cecylia and son Marian. Here he contributed his skills as an attending physician at NYU and in private practice. He is survived by his second wife, Dr. Maria Wisniewski; by son Dr. Marian Waxman and his wife Dr. Jenny Waxman; grandchildren Dorothy and Robert, their spouses and six great- grandchildren. He is mourned by his family and many friends and colleagues. Funeral service at Schwartz Bros. Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills on March 15, at 11:30am.

ANNENBERG--Leonore. The Trustees, members and staff of the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust express great sadness at the passing of long-standing Trustee, Leonore Annenberg. Mrs. Annenberg, with her husband, Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg, during their tenure at the Court of St. James's and in the years following, earned the deep affection and admiration of British society for their understanding and appreciation of British Culture and their magnamous efforts to preserve and promote it. In May of 2002, HM Queen Elizabeth II formally named the forecourt of Burlington House, the home of the Royal Academy of Arts, the "Annenberg Courtyard" in honor of the Annenbergs, whose generosity made possible the renovation of this magnificent public space. We are privileged that Leonore Annenberg served as a Trustee of the American Associates. She enriched us with her presence and commitment. Leonore and Walter have left a legacy at Burlington House that will forever be a part of the Royal Academy of Arts. C. At last, President Obama can say he is following in the footsteps of Grover Cleveland. He is skipping the first Gridiron Dinner of his presidency, becoming the first president since Cleveland to do so. The Gridiron Club, for those unfamiliar with Washington's traditions, is the city's oldest and most exclusive journalistic organization. Its annual dinner is one of the few white-tie events in official Washington, and features campy song-and-dance numbers and, typically, remarks by the president of the United States.

GARLICK--Howard Stanley, 88 years old. With great sorrow we announce the passing of Howard Garlick, cherished husband of Phyllis ne Deligtisch, daughters Elyse, Pamela, and Brooke, sons-in-law Samuel and Carlos, and grandchildren Rebecca, Molly, Emily, Gabriel, and Matias. Howie was born September 28, 1920, in New York City, son of Albert and Eva. He adored his deceased older brother Lewis and cousin Marcia Friedman. An honors graduate and football star from Franklin and Marshall College, he served four years in the Pacific as a captain in the Marine Corps. Howie co-founded Garlick and Hoffman, a certified public accounting firm, which later merged with Edward Isaacs and Company. Deeply loved by a circle of friends, colleagues, and family whose lives he touched, Howie was a man of great integrity and compassion who gave generously to Israel and civil rights causes. A diehard Giants and Yankees fan, Civil Rights buff, lover of poetry, and world traveler, Howie will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be on Sunday, March 15, at 12:45pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, 212.362.6600. The family will be sitting shiva on Monday and Tuesday, 7:30-9:30 pm, at 7 Pond View Lane, Titusville, NJ. Contributions can be made to the Sarasota Memorial Healthcare Foundation, 1700 S. Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, FLA 34239.

9 P.M. (HBO) WILL FERRELL: YOU'RE WELCOME AMERICA. A FINAL NIGHT WITH GEORGE W. BUSH That's all, folks. This live broadcast follows Mr. Ferrell, left, into the Cort Theater on Broadway, where he is currently channeling the persona of the 43rd president and offering insight of sorts into Mr. Bush's childhood in Texas and Connecticut, his academic and social career at Yale, his time as owner of a major league baseball team and his emergence as a political figure. Reviewing the stage production in The New York Times, Ben Brantley said that Mr. Ferrell ''now presents George W. Bush in the White House as the ultimate sequel to 'Dumb and Dumber.' '' 6 P.M. Among those interviewed are former President George W. Bush; his Treasury secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr.; Joshua B. Bolten, Bush chief of staff; Jared Bernstein, economics adviser to the Obama administration; Representative Steny H. Hoyer, House majority leader; and Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, House banking chairman.

Comcast and the NFL Network have exchanged offers that would extend their deal beyond its April 30 expiration as they await a legal decision in their long-running distribution fight. The league said it would extend the deal beyond April 30 if Comcast would move the network to a far broader digital tier that has nearly nine million subscribers and does not require an extra monthly fee, which the sports tier does. The N.F.L. is insisting that the channel return to where Comcast carried it before the network added eight regular-season games and raised its monthly subscriber fee. That is the focus of the dispute in the Federal Communications Commission and in a lawsuit in Manhattan Supreme Court. The league says Comcast has violated federal laws by relegating it to a sports tier. nflnetwork The Sports Museum of America, which opened in lower Manhattan last May and closed last month, filed a Chapter 7 liquidation petition Friday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. It cited $55.5 million in assets and $177.1 million in liabilities. Philip Schwalb, the museum's founder, said he was still hopeful of a sale to a ''good, credible buyer.'' He said the assets could be bought for $5 million or less. sportsMuseum RICHARD SANDOMIR

The organization cut its staff by nearly 25 percent this winter, citing the economy.

President Barack Obama has established a staff position in the White House to oversee arts and culture in the Office of Public Liaison and Intergovernmental Affairs under Valerie Jarrett, a senior adviser, a White House official confirmed. Kareem Dale, right, a lawyer who last month was named special assistant to the president for disability policy, will hold the new position. Mr. Dale, who is partly blind, previously served as national disability director for the Obama campaign. He also served on the arts policy committee and the disability policy committee for Mr. Obama when he was a senator from Illinois. Bill Ivey, who served as the administration's transition-team leader for the arts and humanities, said he was encouraged by the appointment and would meet with Mr. Dale next week. ''It's a big step forward in terms of connecting cultural and government with mainstream administration policy,'' Mr. Ivey said in an interview on Friday. The White House declined to describe the position in detail, since Mr. Dale's appointment has yet to be formally announced. Mr. Ivey, a former chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, said he expected that the job would mainly involve coordinating the activities of the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Institute of Museum and Library Services ''in relation to White House objectives.'' Although there have been staff members assigned to culture under past presidents, they usually served in the first lady's office, Mr. Ivey said.

Austin, Tex. — The South by Southwest Festival here is a great place for a person of sprawling interests, or, as in the case of this humble correspondent, someone with the attention span of a gnat. With separate streams of programming for interactive matters, film and, starting Wednesday, a tsunami of music seminars and gigs (Jon Pareles, Ben Sisario and Melena Ryzik will join the blog then), you never run out of things to look at or hear. If “The Future of Visual Storytelling” is not floating your boat, you can always pop over to “From Script to Screen.” There’s a kind of info-frolic afoot that can boggle the mind.

A Saturday morning fire at Totonno's has shut down the great Coney Island pizzeria, one of the oldest and most beloved in New York. Images broadcast on NY1 did not show extensive damage and the station said the owners hope to reopen in six weeks. The cause is not clear.

In response to last week's column on neoliberalism and higher education, Sobriquet writes that neoliberalism, like neoconservatism, is "an opaque catchphrase coined by wannabe pundits" that doesn't "refer to anything." That judgment finds support in an essay soon to be published in Studies in Comparative International Development. The authors, Taylor Boas and Jordan Gans-Morse (political science researchers at UC Berkeley), report that while in recent years "neoliberalism has become an academic catchphrase," its use "remains a puzzle" because it is "left undefined . . even by those who employ it as a key independent or dependent variable."

Puzzles get harder through the week. Monday is easiest, Wednesday or Thursday is challenging, and Friday and Saturday are next to impossible for most people. This graduated difficulty is the single most important fact for potential solvers and for most them, it's a secret. Sudoku or KenKen puzzles typically come with a difficulty rating. Crossword solvers are just supposed to know.

Ticket sales for "Watchmen," the Warner Brothers film about misanthropic superheroes, plummeted 67 percent during its second weekend in theaters, indicating a steep battle to profitability and placing it second to newcomer "Race to Witch Mountain."

A review last Sunday of “To Kill a Mockingbird” at Hartford Stage misidentified the actor playing Walter Cunningham, the poor boy with no table manners. He is Jacob Entenman — not James DeMarse, who plays Walter Cunningham Sr.

A picture caption last Sunday with an obituary about Sydney Chaplin, an actor who was a son of Charlie Chaplin, misstated the setting of the photograph. It showed Mr. Chaplin, the actress Judy Holliday and the choreographer Jerome Robbins at a rehearsal for the musical “Bells Are Ringing”; the picture was not of a scene from the show.

The list of moves with the Chess column last Sunday, about a game between Alexander Grischuk of Russia, who was White, and Wang Yue of China, who was Black, misidentified the one who resigned. It was Black, not White.

An article on Page 40 this weekend about plans for the George W. Bush library at Southern Methodist University refers incorrectly to the former president’s departure from Washington on Jan. 20. He left from the Capitol, not the White House. And though he was aboard a Marine helicopter, it was not “Marine One.” (A Marine helicopter uses that call sign only when the incumbent president is on board.).

The Q&A column on March 1, about visiting the Grand Canyon in February, referred incompletely to driving to the North Rim of the Grand Canyon at that time of year. While visitors can usually reach the North Rim on Highway 67, the highway is often closed during the winter months because of snow, and with little or no notice.

In Matt Bai’s March 1 cover article, Newt Gingrich succeeds again at what he does best: charming otherwise serious people, like Bai, to suspend their critical thinking and run interference for his tireless self-promotion. Gingrich had his turn. While his showy intellect is often entertaining, it’s best confined to G.O.P. conferences and talk-radio blather, not governing.

David Leonhardt (The Way We Live Now, March 1) presents a well-balanced discussion of “bank nationalization” — until he comes to the issue that nationalizing the whole U.S. banking system “would probably cost a whole lot of money.” Here the Obama administration supposes that even if only a few banks were taken over initially, “shareholders might abandon others . . . banks would then need government support.”.
A San Francisco retrospective for a South African artist who has drawn, acted, directed, designed, animated and filmed.

I kept hoping Bathsheba Monk’s essay would have a different ending (Lives, March 1). Maybe she would call that local locksmith, install an alarm system, adopt a pound puppy, build a stockade fence, join a neighborhood patrol. Maybe all of the above. I was sure that when Jimmy told her the .22 would not make a “nice big hole” it would give her pause. But no. A two-minute transaction and Monk had the necessary hardware to use deadly force. “All we have to fear is fear itself” is still true with the addendum “and pistol-packing suburbanites.”.

The Mugrabi family is a case study of not only what is wrong with the art world but also what is wrong with the moneyed classes in general (Eric Konigsberg, March 1). Instead of owning art for the enjoyment and aesthetic pleasure it brings, they see it as a market commodity to be manipulated to serve their own financial interests. Their habit of buying large quantities of art by designated artists and hoarding it, using their power as potential buyers to drive up prices paid by others, is repugnant. It’s this sort of selfish greed, from the subprime-mortgage market to the ponzi scheme of Bernard Madoff, that helped usher in our current global recession. Art can transform one’s interpretation and understanding of the world. The Mugrabis don’t seem to comprehend that.

An article on March 1 about Newt Gingrich and his reascendance in the Republican Party misidentified the building in Washington where the Ways and Means Committee was marking up the Democratic stimulus bill in January and where the writer interviewed Eric Cantor, the Republican whip. It was the Longworth Building, not the Rayburn Building. The article also misidentified an English writer mentioned by Gingrich. He was Arnold J. Toynbee, who wrote “A Study of History,” not Arnold Toynbee, the economic historian and Arnold J. Toynbee’s uncle.
Will George W. Bush’s presidential center be for scholars or for the pursuit of the former president’s policies?

A review on Feb. 8 about “A World of Trouble,” a study of Middle East policy by Patrick Tyler, referred incorrectly to Arthur Krim, who along with his wife, Mathilde, was a supporter of Israel and a friend of Lyndon Johnson’s. It was not he, but Mathilde Krim, who once worked with the Irgun, the underground militia.
Nakameguro, once famed mostly for its cherry tree-lined river, has gained a reputation as one of the city’s liveliest neighborhoods.
In a city where every hotel brand has been rushing in, this is the place to be, offering design, comfort and service without the big-hotel fussiness.

ANNENBERG--Leonore. The Trustees, members and staff of the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust express great sadness at the passing of long-standing Trustee, Leonore Annenberg. Mrs. Annenberg, with her husband, Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg, during their tenure at the Court of St. James's and in the years following, earned the deep affection and admiration of British society for their understanding and appreciation of British Culture and their magnamous efforts to preserve and promote it. In May of 2002, HM Queen Elizabeth II formally named the forecourt of Burlington House, the home of the Royal Academy of Arts, the "Annenberg Courtyard" in honor of the Annenbergs, whose generosity made possible the renovation of this magnificent public space. We are privileged that Leonore Annenberg served as a Trustee of the American Associates. She enriched us with her presence and commitment. Leonore and Walter have left a legacy at Burlington House that will forever be a part of the Royal Academy of Arts. C. Hugh Hildesley Acting Chairman On behalf of the Trustees of The American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust

OPEN THE DOOR TO LIBERTY A Biography of Toussaint L'Ouverture. By Anne Rockwell. Illustrated by R. Gregory Christie. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $18. (Ages 9 to 12) The story of L'Ouverture, who led a successful rebellion in the French slave colony of St. Domingue -- now Haiti -- is full of cruel reversals. An eloquent leader (John Adams was an admirer), L'Ouverture resisted unnecessary violence, but failed to build on his victory and died in a French prison. Rockwell succeeds admirably in explaining a complicated life, and the American-primitive-style drawings are a good match. But there is no simple or uplifting moral to the story of this tragic hero. Julie Just

Address: 30 Burling Avenue The Property: This 6,500-square-foot three-story home has eight bedrooms, four baths and 10-foot-high ceilings. DALRYMPLE--Dennis M.,died Thursday, March 5, in New York City of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 67. He is survived by his wife, Jamie Raab, and their children, Ian and Lola Dalrymple. In a forty year career in book publishing as a literary contracts expert, he consulted with hundreds of authors, publishers and literary agents and worked for many publishing companies, including Warner Books where he met his wife, who is currently Publisher of Grand Central Publishing. He was born in Waterloo, Iowa to Dwight Dalrymple and Bette Rasche, and grew up in Sarasota, Florida, before moving to New York. A longtime anti-war activist who never met a war he wasn't prepared to protest, Dennis was a founding member of the Youth International Party (Yippies), and at the 1968 Democratic Convention nominated Pigasus the Pig for President. Mr. Dalrymple was an avid news junkie, an expert cook, a loyal friend, and, above all, a devoted husband and father. Mr. Dalrymple is also survived by his sister, Sandra Scanlan; his stepmother, Marion Dalrymple; his four half sisters Jennifer Heit, Julie Rexford, Jere Gilbert and Jane Murphy. A memorial services will be held on Thursday, March 19th at 4pm at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South.

ENGELHARDT--Kenneth, 85, died on March 7th. He had been suffering from lymphoma. He was born in Hoboken, NJ. He attended NY Military Academy and joined the Army at the age of 17. He served his country as one of the youngest members of the infantry throughout WWII. Once the war was over, he played minor league baseball before returning to New York to join the family business, Gray Line Tours of New York. In 1970 he became the President of Gray Line and Director of the New York Visitors and Convention Bureau. In 1982 he was elected Chairman of the Board of Gray Line. The past 22 years of his life he lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. A great athlete, he was known to play tennis and beat men half his age in matches that could last all afternoon. Eventually he became president of the Home Owners Association of St. Andrews in Hastings. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Roberta Engelhardt, his children Vicki, Philip, Linda, Marci, his sister Thelma Leaton, two step-daughters, Nancy and Elizabeth, 15 grandchildren, and one great-grandson. He lived a full life and will be greatly missed. To leave a note of condolence online, please contact, edwardsanddowdle.com. A private service will be held. Donations can be made to the Make a Wish Foundation or the UJA.

THE NEWS After China stepped up security patrols in Tibet to prevent protests on the 50th anniversary of a failed uprising against Chinese rule, the Dalai Lama told Tibetan exiles in a speech in Dharamsala, India, that Chinese rule had made Tibet a ''hell on earth.'' BEHIND THE NEWS The Dalai Lama, who is 73, has long sought autonomy for Tibet, but many other Tibetans want outright independence, and have criticized the spiritual leader for being too conciliatory toward Beijing, especially after the violent suppression of protests a year ago. The anniversary was marked by demonstrations around the world, but no reports emerged of any within Tibet.

ESSEX--Winfield Scott Jr.,known to his friends as "Skip", was the first trader to have seats on both the New York and London Stock Exchanges. He was also a professional white hunter in East Africa, a partner in Hunters Africa and had a coffee farm in Rhodesia, before independence. He died suddenly February 20th at his home in Wellington, FL where he lived with his fiancee, Helene Jackson ("Danny") Magill. He was 66. Mr. Essex was an honorary member of the East African Professional Hunters' Association, an organization in Kenya that governs big game hunting and a partner in Philadelphia Investors in Pennsylvania. He was a member of the Brook Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club, and the Holland Lodge all in New York City and also the Racquet Club and Philadelphia Club in Philadelphia, PA. Mr. Essex was admired for his impeccable dress, gourmet cooking, wit, intelligence, and eye for the fairer sex. Mr. Essex grew up in Columbus, Ohio. He attended Washington and Lee University and received his BA degree from the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. Three children survive him from his first marriage to Brenda Teagle Callaway: Lee Essex Doyle of Boston; Amanda Teagle Essex of New York; and Winfield Scott III of Westport, Conn. He has a fourth son, William David Scott Essex, of Dublin, Ireland, from his second marriage to Victoria Thompson Essex. Survivors also include his brother Richard Essex and his daughters Helena and Isabella of London and five grandchildren: India Lee Doyle, Wyatt Addison Doyle, Hunter Scott Essex, Sydney Essex and Campbell Essex. A toast to Mr. Essex will be held at the Brook Club in New York City on April 16th at 6pm. His ashes will be scattered over the plains of his beloved Botswana by his family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust, PO Box 15555, Nairobi, Kenya.

MAGIC NUMBER The Memphis seniors Robert Dozier, left, Antonio Anderson and Chance McGrady have won an N.C.A.A.-record 135 games. If they reach 141 victories, they will be national champions. NEW AND OLD Binghamton earned its first N.C.A.A. tournament berth by winning the America East, while Utah won the Mountain West to return to the tournament for the first time since 2005.

There will no doubt be some suspense before the four No. 1 seeds are announced Sunday for the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament. The string of potential top seeds losing in their conference tournaments -- North Carolina (28-4), Connecticut (27-4), Oklahoma (27-5) and Pittsburgh (27-4) -- muddied the picture. Those losses have probably helped Louisville (28-5), which beat Syracuse, 76-66, in the Big East title game Saturday, sneak into a No. 1 despite early-season losses to Western Kentucky, Minnesota and Nevada-Las Vegas.

GARLICK--Howard Stanley, 88 years old. With great sorrow we announce the passing of Howard Garlick, cherished husband of Phyllis ne Deligtisch, daughters Elyse, Pamela, and Brooke, sons-in-law Samuel and Carlos, and grandchildren Rebecca, Molly, Emily, Gabriel, and Matias. Howie was born September 28, 1920, in New York City, son of Albert and Eva. He adored his deceased older brother Lewis and cousin Marcia Friedman. An honors graduate and football star from Franklin and Marshall College, he served four years in the Pacific as a captain in the Marine Corps. Howie co-founded Garlick and Hoffman, a certified public accounting firm, which later merged with Edward Isaacs and Company. Deeply loved by a circle of friends, colleagues, and family whose lives he touched, Howie was a man of great integrity and compassion who gave generously to Israel and civil rights causes. A diehard Giants and Yankees fan, Civil Rights buff, lover of poetry, and world traveler, Howie will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be on Sunday, March 15, at 12:45pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, 212.362.6600. The family will be sitting shiva on Monday and Tuesday, 7:30-9:30 pm, at 7 Pond View Lane, Titusville, NJ. Contributions can be made to the Sarasota Memorial Healthcare Foundation, 1700 S. Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, FLA 34239.

RICHARD--Mae (nee Blank). Lyricist Mae Richard, a resident of Manhattan, died peacefully in her sleep on March 4, 2009, at the age of 86, although in spirit she was 39. She is survived by her loving husband of 66 years, Howard Richard, an attorney, and her two loving children, Larry and Barbara. She attended West Philadelphia High School, and earned a B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. In mid-life, not content to remain a suburban housewife, she blazed new trails and ensconced herself in New York, determined to bring her immense creative talents to the world of musical theater. Her earliest successes came in the field of industrial theater, where she won accolades for musicals at DuPont, RCA, and Lehigh Valley Dairies. Building on this experience, she began a prolific period of song-writing. Credits from this period include Sesame Street, PBS's Punchinello, and NBC's Emmy-award-winning Unicorn Tales. She spent most of her professional career as a lyricist in the New York professional theater community. She was responsible for the lyrics and concept of Tallulah!, a musical about Tallulah Bankhead, which was presented off-Broadway. Mae also conceived and wrote the lyrics for the off-Broadway musical Cut the Ribbons, which explored the mother-daughter relationship. Her efforts were honored when the show was nominated for a MAC Award and an Outer Critic's Circle Award. Mae was a member of the Dramatists Guild, and served on many Boards and panels including Vice President and Board member of her favorite organization, the League of Professional Theatre Women, an organization to which she brought enormous personal dedication and energy. She also served as a member of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, awarding the Emmy Awards. At her death, she was working on an original musical based on a short story by Mark Twain. Donations in Mae's honor may be directed to: League of Professional Theatre Women PO Box 2292 New York, NY 10108

CARROLL--John D.,46, an Assistant District Attorney for the Special Victims Bureau in Queens, died at his home in Brooklyn, New York on Thursday March 5, 2009. Born in Wilmington, Delaware, John attended Tower Hill School, Franklin and Marshall College, the University of Delaware and Vermont Law School. After graduating from law school, in 1996, he worked for over ten years as a dedicated prosecutor within the Special Victims Bureau. He was an accomplished trial attorney, continually advocating for women and children's rights. A remarkable athlete, in 1981, he set the Delaware state high jump record with a jump of six feet, eleven and a quarter inches - a record that has never been broken. A basketball player as well, he was one of 10 individuals nominated for Delaware's high school athlete of the year. John had a great passion for music and was a self-taught guitarist and singer/song writer. He was an original member of the rock bands; The Knobs in Delaware, The Bailiwicks in Vermont and later in New York with The Macaulays. John is survived by his wife, Lauren Macaulay of Brooklyn, his mother Marie T. Carroll of Virginia, his brothers Charles S. Carroll and Paul Carroll both of California, Jack Carroll of New York, and his sisters Christina Carroll-White and Denise Schwandt both of Virginia, as well as many nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the First Unitarian Congregational Society of Brooklyn, 50 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, NY at 3:30pm on Sunday, March 22nd. A celebration of John's life will immediately follow at The Bell House, 149 7th Street, Brooklyn, NY at 6:00pm. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to either: Safe Horizon / 212.577.8293/ www.safehorizon.org or American Melanoma Foundation /858.882.7712/ melanomafoundation.org *We ask that any donations reference the memory of John.

DALRYMPLE--Dennis M.,died Thursday, March 5, in New York City. He was 67. He is survived by his wife, Jamie Raab, and their children, son Ian Dalrymple and daughter Lola Dalrymple. The cause of death was a cerebral hemorrhage. In a forty year career in book publishing as a literary contracts expert, he consulted with hundreds of authors, publishers and literary agents. He worked with such companies as Avon Books, Dell Publishing and Harper and Row (now HarperCollins), and then joined Warner Books as Director of Contracts where he stayed for 17 years. There, he met his wife, Jamie Raab, who is currently Publisher of Grand Central Books (formerly Warner Books). He was born in Waterloo, Iowa to Dwight Marion Dalrymple and Willa (Bette) Rasche, and grew up in Sarasota, Florida, before moving to New York City. Dennis loved New York City with the passion of a transplant, living first in Greenwich Village and in recent years on the Upper West Side. Mr. Dalrymple was a longtime anti-war activist who never met a war he wasn't prepared to protest. He was a founding member of the Youth International Party, its members known as Yippies, formed in 1967 by leftists and cultural icons Jerry Rubin, Abbie Hoffman and Paul Krassner to radicalize hippie youth to protest the Vietnam War. He also nominated Pigasus the Pig for President at the 1968 convention. Mr. Dalrymple was an avid news junkie, an expert cook, a loyal friend, and, most of all, a devoted husband and father. Mr. Dalrymple is also survived by his sister, Sandra Scanlan; his stepmother, Marion Dalrymple; his four half sisters Jennifer Heit, Julie Rexford, Jere Gilbert and Jane Murphy. A memorial services will be held on Thursday, March 19th at 4 pm at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South in New York City.

CUTHBERTSON--Ian M. Senior Fellow of the World Policy Institute and Director of its Counterterrorism Program, died February 26, 2009, after complications from surgery. He was 51 years old. Born in Glasgow, Scotland, on June 9, 1957, Mr. Cuthbertson began his career in the United Kingdom's Foreign & Commonwealth Office. He came to the United States in 1986 as a Resident Fellow at the Institute for East-West Security Studies and remained at the Institute, becoming its Vice President of Programs in 1992. He later served as Editorial Director and Executive Vice President of the publishing company TV Books. His work at the World Policy Institute, which he joined in 1994, and as a consultant to businesses and philanthropies worldwide, focused well before September 11 on the imminent threats posed by both international and domestic terrorism and Islamist terrorist networks in particular. Mr. Cuthbertson was the author and editor of numerous books and articles on American and European foreign and defense policy, Russian and transatlantic security issues, and military history, and was a sought-after commentator on television and radio programs around the world. A graduate of the University of Stirling and the University of Aberdeen, Mr. Cuthbertson is survived by his wife, Helen Wen, and sister, Susan Cuthbertson Shaw, as well as several nieces and nephews. He will be deeply missed by many friends and colleagues in the United States and Europe. The family will announce the date of the memorial service.

AT THE DECHEN PHODRANG MONASTIC SCHOOL IN THIMPHU, BHUTAN, MARCH 27, 2008 Mike Rogers, a 27-year-old documentary filmmaker from Singapore, shows novice monks what he just shot. ''I grew up in Singapore, and one of the reasons I moved back there was simply because of the travel opportunities in Asia. There are so many cultures, such a rich history of those cultures, so many nuances: a Buddhist in Bhutan is different from a Buddhist from Thailand or Cambodia. We were at the monastic school when the dinner bell went off, and this flood of kids came out of their classrooms and down a hill, probably 100, 150 of them. I had set up the tripod at the bottom, to catch them coming down the footpath. But once they saw I was down there, they decided to run down the more treacherous way, and I captured them all in slow motion. When you show a digital image to kids from a place where they don't see that so often, they get really excited. But this time it was in slow motion, so I was bending time right there in front of them -- and they were ecstatic.'' As told to Seth Kugel
Art Roberta Smith

DINOTHESAURUS Prehistoric Poems and Paintings. Written and illustrated by Douglas Florian. Atheneum. $17.99. (Ages 6 and up) Florian's whimsical rhyming text contains helpful lessons: for example, how to pronounce ''Micropachycephalosaurus,'' for ''small, thick-headed lizard,'' or ''Plesiosaur'' -- ''we always say PLEASE before we might bite.'' A bit of dinosaur lore follows: ''What kept the Spinosaurus warm / When it was colder than the norm? / Spines much like a solar panel. / (And long underwear of flannel.)'' The underwear part might be misleading, but Florian's art -- in gouache, collage, colored pencil, stencils, etc. -- is gorgeous and fun.

THE news isn't that we're driving less -- vehicle miles traveled, also known as V.M.T., has been declining for 13 straight months. In December, the country's V.M.T. was down 1.6 percent (compared to the same month last year), which translates to 3.8 billion miles not traveled. But the interesting question is why we're driving less, with gas costing about half what it did last June (when prices reached $4 a gallon, according to AAA, the automobile association). It's anecdotal, but the evidence suggests that the recession is a prime factor.

CAMPBELL--John P.,85, a prominent attorney in New York City and later in Maine, died peacefully in York, Maine, March 10 after a long struggle with complications following cardiac surgery. He is survived by his loving wife of almost 60 years, Eleanor, sons Samuel of Manchester, MA and Frederick of Manhattan, daughters Louisa of Brooklyn and Camilla of Manhattan, five grandchildren and two step-grandchildren. He was a partner for 35 years from 1959 to 1994 to Curtis, mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle in New York, and upon his move to Maine in the early 1990s was a founding partner of Erwin, Ott, Clark, Orso & Campbell in York. He remained affiliated with both until his death. A longtime trustee of the Middlesex School in Concord, MA, he also served on the boards of Clarkson College and the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York City in the 1980s. He was a decorated aviator in the United States Army Air Corps in World War II. A navigator, he twice survived his B-24 being shot down and parachuting to the ground. In the second incident in the fall of 1944, he escaped from a German train en route to prison camp. Partisans aided Lieutenant Campbell's route out of Silesia and South to Italy where he was reunited with Allied forces. A memorial service in New York will take place April 24, 11am at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY. A service in York, ME will take place in May. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Veterans of Foreign Wars post in York, ME.

ROLLINS--Charles Cortlandt. Born June 12, 1914 in a cold-water flat on East 5th Street in Manhattan. He died on March 10, 2009 in the Southampton home he loved so much. The cause was congestive heart failure. Charlie graduated from New York University in 1937, a business major. He won the 1937 Inter Collegiate Fencing Association Team Championship in Epee. He worked in advertising into his seventies, and felt lucky to be in at the beginning of the "fun days" at Doyle Dane Bernbach, now Omnicom. There he was account Vice President for the British Government Tourist Authority, El Al Airlines, Israel Government Tourist Authority and Jamaica Tourist Board. He also met his loving wife of 43 years, Nancy, at DDB. Charlie was a true student of life who never stopped his quest for discovery and the sharing of knowledge. He enjoyed reminiscing about the incredible changes he witnessed in his almost 95 years. He liked unraveling the complicated aspects of life as much as watching birds and enjoying the garden his wife created. Charlie is survived by his loving extended family; wife Nancy; daughter Pamela and son-in-law Alex Camacho, adored grandchildren Julian, Isabel, Charlotte and Simon Camacho; brother Norman and sister-in-law BJ Robbins; brother-in-law and sister-in-law Tom and Ann Gaudreaux; nieces Carolyn Stanton and Cindy McGuire. He was predeceased by his daughter Abbe and his brother Dale. In lieu of flowers please raise a celebratory glass to Charlie, a wonderful, forthright man with an edge of "sandpaper charm" and quick retorts. Memories of him will always be brightly lit by the smiles he engendered. A memorial gathering will take place this summer.

Bob Dylan will release his first album of new music in almost three years, “Together Through Life,” on April 28, Columbia Records announced. In an interview on his Web site, bobdylan.com, Mr. Dylan likened its sound to the music on Chess Records in the 1950s, the home of Muddy Waters, Howlin’ Wolf and Willie Dixon. “I like the mood of those records — the intensity,” he told his interviewer, Bill Flanagan, adding later, “The whole vibration feels like it could be coming from inside your mind. It’s alive. It’s right there. Kind of sticks in your head like a toothache.” Mr. Dylan’s last album of new songs, “Modern Times”, opened at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, won two Grammy Awards and has sold 2.5 million copies around the world, Columbia said.

The J. Paul Getty Trust, which operates the Getty Center and Museum in Los Angeles, will cut its budget for the coming fiscal year by almost 25 percent following drastic declines in its endowment, The Los Angeles Times reported. The Getty Trust’s portfolio declined by a corresponding 25 percent to $4.5 billion, down from $6 billion, in the second half of 2008. James Wood, the president of the trust, told The Los Angeles Times that its core operating budget for the fiscal year would be $216 million, down from $284 million in the previous fiscal year; Mr. Wood said the Getty museum’s stability could “fall off a huge cliff” if it did not make cuts and its economic prospects worsened. The museum has been reducing staff and operating hours since the fall. Mr. Wood declined to specify what further cuts might be made.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Monday morning.
Normally politics doesn’t really get to sit at the big kids’ table at South by Southwest, what with all the music, movies and interactive pursuits.

Updated | 4:59 p.m. The broadcaster Don Imus said that he has prostate cancer, the Web site of New York’s WCBS television station reported. Mr. Imus, 68, made the remarks during the Monday morning broadcast of his syndicated “Imus in the Morning” radio program, which in New York is broadcast on WABC-AM radio; he said that he had stage II prostate cancer, giving no further details of his prognosis, but added that he was confident his doctors would beat it.

Updated | 11:32 a.m. A vintage “Star Trek” episode about the perils of time travel has created unpleasant present-day repercussions for the CBS Paramount studio, which produced the original television series. Harlan Ellison, the author and screenwriter of the “Star Trek” episode “The City on the Edge of Forever,” has filed suit against CBS Paramount, saying that the studio has not paid him merchandising and publishing revenue it earned from the episode, Variety reported. The episode, which was first broadcast in 1967, follows Captain Kirk as he travels back to the Great Depression and falls in love with a social worker played by Joan Collins. In his suit, Mr. Ellison said he had not been paid for merchandise based on the episode, including a series of books and a talking Christmas tree ornament. Under the terms of a master contract with the Writers Guild of America, Mr. Ellison is entitled to 25 percent of revenues from derived from the licensing of publication rights. Mr. Ellison is also suing the Writers Guild, for $1 plus court costs, for not acting on his behalf.

Is there a Gaelic equivalent for “woo-hoo”? A coming episode of “The Simpsons” will be the first to be shown in Ireland and England before it has its debut on American television, BBC News reported. The show, to be shown Tuesday on the Sky1 network, is a Saint Patrick’s Day-themed episode titled “In the Name of the Grandfather,” in which Homer Simpson and family travel to Ireland, visit several landmarks including the Guinness brewery, and end up buying an Irish pub. Describing the plot of the episode to the BBC, the “Simpsons” executive producer Al Jean said: “Homer and Grandpa get drunk. They buy the bar and then they find, as it turns out, in Ireland, pubs aren’t so popular anymore because you can’t smoke in them. So they’re really up a creek.” The episode is to be shown in the United States on Sunday.

Gary Vaynerchuk, a Jersey-proud dude who vlogs at Wine Library TV, appeared in the interactive program of South by Southwest on Sunday, shouting from the stage like some kind of profane evangelist, riling up the room and urging people to do what they love or just pack it in. “If you live for the weekend and vacations,” your stuff, he said, “is just wrong.” He said about 70,000 people tune into his vlog and that he mows through 1,500 emails a day. Mr. Vaynerchuk, who came to vlogging by way of a wine retailing background, scoffed at purists who were afraid to make deals on their sites. “Sure, stay pure and go out of business,” he said, adding later, “you have to go and get the money.” Amid whoops and yelling, he advised a woman who was considering jumping off on her own with a vlog: “Go to your hotel room and look in the mirror and decide. And I mean right now. Don’t wait for the end of the session.” He hopes to make enough money selling hooch to one day own the New York Jets because he “realized in second grade that it was more likely that I would own the New York Jets than play for them.”

Clay Shirky, a professor at the Interactive Telecommunications Program at New York University, ended up on a rather dreary panel called “New Think for Old Publishers” that did not include a lot of new thinking from his fellow panelists, most of whom were from the book industry. It drew a great deal of antagonism from the audience by the time it was over. But Mr. Shirky is a fan favorite here, in part because he wrote “Here Comes Everybody,” a seminal tract on social networks and disruptive media, and in part because his former students are in the thick of things everywhere you look here.

Updated | 2:18 p.m. The mother of the rapper Tupac Shakur has filed a countersuit against the production company that sued her over a proposed film about the life of her son, who was killed in 1996, The Hollywood Reporter said. Afeni Shakur and her company, Amaru Entertainment, filed a cross-complaint on Monday in Los Angeles County Superior Court against the production company Morgan Creek, saying that Morgan Creek sought the rights to Tupac Shakur’s life story “by concocting a nonexistent ‘agreement’ and engaging in heavy-handed threats,” according to court documents. In February, Morgan Creek sued Afeni Shakur, saying that her company reneged on an agreement. At that time, a lawyer for Amaru Entertainment had said, “There is no agreement with Morgan Creek, there never was, and there never will be.”

The producers of the Broadway play “reasons to be pretty,” by Neil LaBute, canceled the show’s Sunday matinee, and have canceled coming matinees on Wednesday and Saturday, because the director and one of the actors had television commitments that conflicted with rehearsals. The director, Terry Kinney, and the actor, Steven Pasquale, both faced shifts in shooting schedules this week, for “The Unusuals” and “Rescue Me,” respectively, resulting in “virtually no time to rehearse the play during this preview week,” said a statement released Monday by the show’s publicist. This is Mr. LaBute’s first play to be produced on Broadway. Theatergoers who have already purchased tickets can exchange their tickets at the point of purchase. The show is scheduled to open April 2 at the Lyceum Theater.

The press was ushered past a long line of hopefuls at the Alamo Draft House on Sunday night for a sneak peek (22 minutes) of Sacha Baron Cohen’s “Bruno,” another exercise in faux-cumentary in which a disgraced fashion reporter from Austria takes America by a storm of his own making. (The film is scheduled for a July release.) Your humble correspondent is professionally impaired when it comes to stunts involving the media, but he has to admit that when the final prank came – a bunch of hardcore wrestling fans are invited to a cage match that devolves into a very public erotic display between the male antagonists – he set down his notebook and had a single good belly laugh. And then he picked up his notebook and rewrinkled his nose. The rest of the cringefest includes stage mothers volunteering their babies as crash test dummies and little Nazis. You get the picture.

Having previously struck gold for HBO with his mobster series “The Sopranos,” the writer and producer David Chase is returning to the cable channel with a new mini-series about men who swear relentlessly and resort to ruthless tactics to get ahead, only this time, it’s set in Hollywood. In a release, HBO said that Mr. Chase’s mini-series would be called “A Ribbon of Dreams” (taken from Orson Welles’s famous metaphor for film) and would follow two characters through the birth and development of the American motion picture industry. The two protagonists, a mechanical engineer and a cowboy, will begin working for D.W. Griffith, and encounter the likes of John Wayne, Bette Davis and Billy Wilder as they rise through the business. No casting or premiere date was announced.

"Defend me from friends, I can defend myself from my enemies," is an old European saying, but it's certainly applicable to many United States presidents. Rebellious conservative Democrats whom Franklin Roosevelt tried unsuccessfully to purge effectively called a halt to the New Deal in 1938. Loyal Republicans voted for Ronald Reagan's budget in 1981 but joined Democrats in larding it with so much pork that it greatly expanded federal budget deficits. Now, there are signs that President Obama, for all his early success, could have difficulty keeping Democrats united on his budget proposal and other economic measures in the face of growing public unease with bank bailouts and the prospect of budgets unbalanced to an extent hitherto unimagined.

The decisive Game 5 of the Ak Bars-Avangard quarterfinal was played on Monday, Jaromir Jagr's underdogs trying to knock off the No. 2 team in Russia, just as they had already knocked off No. 1 Salavat. But Ak Bars proved to be a stubborn team. It was an incredible finish.

Jimmy Rollins won a World Series ring with the Philadelphia Phillies last year. Derek Jeter has won four rings with the Yankees. Since they are teammates on the United States in the World Baseball Classic, Rollins decided to quiz his fellow shortstop.

Over the last few days, Facebook users have been gradually upgraded to a new layout for the fast-growing social network site. The company's goals are twofold: First, simplify and expand the tools to manage the ever-increasing volume of friends' messages, links, photos and videos. Second, experiment with new forms of advertising.

My laptop is my all-in-one entertainment center. I surf the Web. I watch videos. I play games. I Facebook. All on my laptop. And while (for the most part) I have no problem in getting access to the Web at work or at home thanks to Wi-Fi, I feel that being offline should be a choice, not something you're forced into for lack of a Wi-Fi connection.

The Senate took another stab at the omnibus lands bill, grafting it onto a commemorative battlefield bill in order to ship it back to the House in a form proponents hope will get it passed. The measure cleared a procedural hurdle by a vote of 73 to 21 tonight, and the Senate is expected to vote on final passage soon.

You might remember Marc and Amy Vachon, who I have written about, and who have written guest blogs for Motherlode. They live what they call "Equally Shared Parenting" - in which Mom and Dad do every thing down the middle, not as a way "to help Mom out" but as a way to balance a relationship, a household and a life.
