Paris fashion show invitations typically value the traditional (calligraphy, gold edging, heavy card stock) over the wacky (balloons, plants, scraps of fabric). Nevertheless, there's always creativity at work - last season Alexander McQueen sent out a hologram! This time, our favorite minitrend can be wrapped in one word: plastics. The Japanese label Tsumori Chisato sent us an inflatable figure, while Kenzo slipped its tiny Russian doll invitation inside a plastic blow-up pillow. How do these stack up against the Milan and New York invitations? You tell us.

The Rocky Mountain News is dead. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer will publish its last issue Tuesday. The Detroit Free Press has cut home delivery to three days a week. The Star Tribune in Minneapolis and the Inquirer and Daily News in Philadelphia have all declared bankruptcy.
Former Representative Rob Simmons of Connecticut announced that he plans to challenge Senator Christopher Dodd next year.

A few weeks ago, we released a still-unnamed article skimmer prototype. We told you our mission: to provide an online approximation of the pleasure of reading the Sunday Times. We asked you to tell us what you thought, and you obliged. Along with positive feedback, we received several suggestions and bug reports. We appreciate your enthusiasm and your candor, and we're responding with an updated version of our article skimmer prototype.

Perhaps remembering what happened to Herbert Hoover when he supported efforts to keep people from drowning their sorrows during the Great Depression, British Prime Minister Gordon Brown rejected a new proposal on Monday by England's chief medical officer, Sir Liam Donaldson, to combat binge-drinking by introducing a minimum price for alcohol, which would have doubled the price of many beers and spirits.

Whole Foods fired Ralph Reese for taking a tuna fish sandwich. But was it misconduct? It is a question that matters. Anyone fired for misconduct is denied unemployment benefits.Whole Foods argued that Mr. Reese, 57, of Queens, tried to steal a sandwich by taking it from the trash at the end of his shift as a deli clerk at the Union Square Whole Foods on Nov. 9. The company's policy is that food cannot be taken without being paid for, though employees receive a 20 percent discount.

March Madness has officially returned! While we are getting ready to put on our dancing shoes for the second consecutive year after watching the N.C.A.A. Selection Show last night, we should probably pack some running shoes on our trip to beautiful Boise, Idaho, too.
Some of the stately formality that marked the Tudor era has found its way into the fall 2009 collections.
From Cara Buckley at City Room:

When even the Metropolitan Museum of Art is laying off staff, what do you do if your financial base is less Fifth Avenue than Queens Boulevard? The Queens Museum of Art has come up with a creative way of weathering the downturn and its attendant drop in donations to cultural institutions: Capitalizing on a unique piece of New York real estate.The museum's most famous asset is its 9,335-square-foot scale model of New York City, originally built for the 1964 World's Fair. The Panorama of the City of New York has 895,000 structures, replicating every street, bridge and skyscraper in the five boroughs.

Dried mushrooms are a great source of flavor. Sometimes they can even be good to eat; their character depends a lot on their variety. Dried porcini (a k a cepes or boletus edulis) -- the classic dried mushrooms, whether they come from Italy or from China -- add enormous umami/savoriness to sauces, soups, meatloaves (or non-meat loaves), stews and many other dishes, but I never feel I need to pick up a spoon and eat a plateful of them unless they're mixed with fresh mushrooms of some kind.

On Wednesday, you will find us at a new address: raisingtheroof.blogs.nytimes.com. We are migrating to NYTimes.com as part of a larger integration effort to give the International Herald Tribune a broader presence on the Web site of its parent company, The New York Times. You'll see a slightly different look for the blog, but our goal of providing information about great homes, investment trends and property markets around the world remains the same. Join us there.
From Eric Dash, a DealBook colleague:

The coming F1 season - less than two weeks away - will be the fourth in the life of this blog, and I am really delighted to announce that the blog will be moving from the IHT site to the New York Times site. Same blog, different address, but the whole archive of the blog moves along with it, so if you have any favorite comments you posted within the last three years and you want to show them to your children and grand children, you can still do so. (Same applies to all my previous posts, of course.) I do not plan to change anything in my approach to the blog either, so if you like what I do, you should find the same thing on the NYT site.

Mobile innovators are making the most out of the hordes of digerati in Austin. The interactive portion of South by Southwest -- there is a music portion too -- included announcements of custom versions of nightlife games and iPhone applications to dazzle tech-savvy attendees.

Pete Thamel, college sports reporter for The New York Times, is currently appearing on ESPN's "Outside the Lines" to discuss his recent articles about the Binghamton basketball program and its star player, D.J. Rivera.

Bill Carter, who covers television for The New York Times, has a story in Tuesday's Arts section about the new mini-series that David Chase is going to do for HBO, the cable network where his "Sopranos" made its home. "A Ribbon of Dreams" will follow generations of related characters through the entire history of the movie industry, from the earliest days of the silents through the slapstick comedies of the '20s, the talkies, the height of the studio system, the advent of color and widescreen, the autueur years of the '70s and up to the present day. Along the way, they encounter John Wayne, D.W. Griffith, Bette Davis and others.

After getting hold of Blake Bailey's new biography of John Cheever (reviewed by Geoffrey Wolff in yesterday's Book Review), I looked up Ned Rorem in the index, wondering if Bailey had included one of my favorite scenes from Rorem's diaries. Indeed he had.

The celebratory mood in Pakistan after mass protests succeeded in getting the country's chief supreme court justice reinstated was dampened by news of a bombing and an arson attack.

Updated | 5:40 p.m. On Monday, Pakistanis celebrated on the streets, and in tweets, the success of a mass protest that persuaded their government to reinstate the chief justice of the country's supreme court, who was fired by former President Pervez Musharraf in 2007. But as a Pakistani newspaper's live blog on the protest declared simply, "Mission Accomplished," a bomb blast in one city and an arson attack in another underlined how far the situation is in the country still is from being settled.

Each week I get solicitations in the mail from tourism interests in Arizona inviting me to please come visit. It's a beautiful state and a personal favorite. Over the years, I have visited dozens of times. But Arizona shouldn't expect me to come again any time soon. Why not? I just don't feel it is safe to drive there anymore. And if the Office of Tourism is wondering why I feel this way, I suggest it ask the Arizona Department of Public Safety.

No surprise: Paris remains disarmingly beautiful. And a trip to the market at Richard-Lenoir (near Bastille) yesterday reminded me that although Paris is not magic (avocados were from Mexico, tomatoes from Israel -- what can you expect?), it's pretty terrific: cauliflower, carrots, potatoes (even the no-name ones are sensational), artichokes, real wild mushrooms, asparagus (some) - and more - were local. Fish was gorgeous. I was happy. Not surprising.

Every March 17 for the last few years, New York's political establishment has always asked the same question: what will City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn do? After all, when Ms. Quinn, an openly gay Irish American, became speaker in 2006, the organizers of the city's signature St. Patrick's Day Parade, down Fifth Avenue, made it clear that while she could march as an individual and as a city official, she could not display anything hinting at gay pride -- not a pin, not a button, not a sash. So she boycotted the event.

A legal tussle is underway over the right to make a film about the life of rapper Tupak Shakur, who was killed in a drive-by shooting in Las Vegas in 1996. His mother, Afeni Shakur, and Morgan Creek, the Hollywood production company, have filed cross suits in Los Angeles over the proposed film.
Agrium stepped up its hostile bid for CF Industries on Monday by unveiling an exchange offer, escalating an unusual three-way battle in the fertilizer industry.

After a steady diet of red wine for the last couple of weeks, I was desperate for a white, even though my wife had prepared beef stroganoff for dinner. With its mellow flavors of mushrooms, beef and cream, beef stroganoff would have been a natural for a pinot noir or myriad other reds, but no, my mind and body screamed out for a white.

Every era gets the clichés it deserves. Only a year ago, style scribes were still writing trend pieces that reveled in the language of new money and good times: "models and bottles" was the favorite catchphrase of "I-bankers" who "rolled" in the nightclubs and called everyone "brah."

If you have not yet heard the chatter about Hanna Rosin's article in The Atlantic this month, you will. Called "The Case Against Breast-Feeding," Rosin examines how nursing became gospel, a measure of committed mothering, and asks whether the science behind the belief that "Breast is Best" is really as definitive as we all seem to believe.

Saag paneer -- cubes of freshly made cheese in a sauce of spicy, slow-simmered spinach -- is a standard in Indian restaurants and has long been a favorite of mine. Paneer is nearly impossible to find here, but there is a superb substitute: tofu, which, like paneer, is supremely bland and delicate.

A team-wide illness forced the Spokane Chiefs to extend the regular season through Tuesday. But the Edmonton Oil Kings and the Prince Albert Raiders will need an extra game on Tuesday to determine the team that gains the final playoff spot in the Western Hockey League.

Representative Barney Frank, the Democratic chairman of the House Financial Services committee, kicked off what's likely to be a loud refrain this week on Capitol Hill, when he aimed fire this morning at American International Group for the bonuses it doled out to employees at the same time it has been propped up by hundreds of billions of dollars in bailout money. Mr. Frank's remarks followed a torrent of criticism this past weekend from Obama administration officials, who had demanded that A.I.G. should renegotiate the packages totaling hundreds of millions of dollars.

The Fortress Investment Group, the beleaguered private investment firm, said Monday that it lost $258 million in its fourth quarter, amid investment losses and withdrawals from investors. Its assets under management dropped 10 percent, to $29.5 billion.

On our virtual refrigerator today is a self portrait by Hannah Berg, a junior at Millburn High School. Hannah's painting was chosen to illustrate an invitation sent to high school parents for the reception on March 24 (6:30 to 8:30 p.m.) at the Education Center to showcase the artwork of high school and middle school students. The township's elementary school students will have an opportunity to show off their artwork at another reception on March 26 (also 6:30 to 8 p.m.) Approximately 120 pieces of student artwork will be on display and may be viewed through the end of April.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. - Jose Reyes is back with the Mets, or maybe you hadn't noticed. Since rejoining the team Thursday afternoon, Reyes has played exactly once - Saturday - and will not make the four-hour round trip tomorrow to face the Braves in Lake Buena Vista. Before Reyes returns to the lineup, Jerry Manuel wants him to regain his timing. He has had a combined 21 at-bats in Grapefruit League and World Baseball Classic competition this spring. In other words: not enough.

The steel framework for the south core of 1 World Trade Center has reached more than 100 feet above Vesey Street. And by the end of the month, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey expects to have placed an order for 22,000 tons of steel to build the World Trade Center Transportation Hub.

There are two important meetings tonight, the South Orange/Maplewood School District will discuss an extension of Superintendent Brian Osborne's contract for three more years, plus a 3.25 percent raise for him (lower than the annual 5.8 percent cost of living adjustment used by the feds). Also on the agenda for discussion: next year's budget. The meeting begins at 7:30 at 525 Academy Street in Maplewood, and looks to be a long one, as new business isn't scheduled until 10 p.m. A contingent of residents opposed to cuts to home economics is expected, according to Maplewoodian.

Federal investigators are looking to freeze the assets of Ruth Madoff, the wife of jailed swindler Bernard L. Madoff, because of fears she might flee the country or otherwise spirit away some of the $93 million in her name, James Doran reported in The New York Post, citing unidentified people.

Yes, Bernard L. Madoff went to jail on Thursday after pleading guilty to a gargantuan Ponzi scheme, and yes, he may face the rest of his life in prison when he is sentenced to as much as 150 years on June 16.

Tuesday, 11 a.m. Buried beneath the celebration there is - as always - misery on St. Patrick's Day. That's how it happens in America, terra optimista, where a bloody revolution is transformed each summer into fireworks and hot dogs, and the saint day of a Christian youth sold into slavery by marauding Irish raiders is turned into a Guinness-fueled parade. But you don't care about the history, of course. You just want to get drunk like everybody else. Good thing you didn't give up alcohol for Lent. Jenny Wolf of Germany won gold in the women’s 500 meters for the third straight year at the world speedskating championships in Richmond, British Columbia. Wolf posted a combined two-run time of 1 minute 15.75 seconds. Kang-Seok Lee of South Korea clocked 1:09.73 to win the men’s 500. skate.

Luis-León Sánchez won the Paris-Nice race on Sunday, a day after taking over the overall lead. Antonio Colom won the final stage, outracing Alberto Contador, a fellow Spaniard, down the famed Promenade des Anglais, completing the 73.9-mile trek around Nice in 2 hours 47 minutes 49 seconds. In the overall standings, Frank Schleck of Luxembourg was a minute behind in second. Paris.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the role of physicists in finance may have left an incorrect impression about the timing of an episode recounted by Nigel Goldenfeld. It was more than 10 years ago that Dr. Goldenfeld was told by salespeople to remove scholarly articles critical of financial models from the Web site of NumeriX, a company he founded. The episode did not involve the current management or clients of the company.

A picture caption in some editions on Wednesday misidentified the costume a boy in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, wore for the Jewish holiday Purim. He was dressed as Mordecai, not a king. (Mordecai, a Jew, was dressed in royal clothing and a crown and put on a royal horse as a reward for having prevented the king’s assassination, according to the Book of Esther.).

Two up-and-coming singers from São Paulo, Mariana Aydar and Jair Oliveira, made their New York solo debuts at the World Music Institute’s two-night Brasil Fest.
Plans to erect a statue of Charlie Chaplin for use in a movie being filmed in India have drawn protests from Hindu activists, The Associated Press reported.
The comedian Steve Martin has offered to pay for an off-campus production of one of his plays because its performance was banned by an Oregon school.
The United Nations and the Sci Fi Channel will present a panel discussion Tuesday evening on the social and political issues raised by the Sci Fi series “Battlestar Galactica.”
Lincoln Center Theater will present a return engagement of John Lithgow’s one-man show, and Town Hall announces the latest edition of “Broadway by the Year.”
A series of 1974 portraits of Yves Saint Laurent by Andy Warhol has been pulled from a forthcoming Warhol show at the Grand Palais in Paris.
Ticket sales for “Watchmen” plummeted 67 percent in its second weekend in theaters, placing it second over the weekend to newcomer “Race to Witch Mountain.”
A play about a former Guantánamo Bay detainee who visits his Army interrogator 15 years after his detention has won the Yale Drama Series award for playwriting.
The New York Theater Workshop and two theaters in Washington will hold staged readings this month of Caryl Churchill’s provocative new play.
At the American Contract Bridge League’s Spring North American Championships, the winners of the Silodor Open Pairs were David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla.
Julia Angwin has done prodigious digging into the shady business practices and trailer-park aesthetics that have allowed MySpace to tap into the American psyche.
The proposals in the competition for the Slussen project, which aims to replace bridges, underpasses and boat locks in Stockholm, offer a snapshot of contemporary urban planning ideas.
It was with a good deal of jitters that the European Fine Art Fair opened in the Netherlands with a record 239 exhibitors from 15 countries.
Resident Evil 5 is violent and gorgeous and gory all at the same time. It just isn’t racist.
The Arts of Pacific Asia Show showcases all forms of Asian art: sculpture, porcelain vessels and even a few contemporary drawings and photographs.
The continued centrality of Beethoven within the concert sphere was a theme in the three concerts the conductor Mariss Jansons presented with the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra.
The former vice president said the administration’s changes to detention and interrogation programs would hamper intelligence gathering.
This genial but bumpy new revival of Noël Coward’s “Blithe Spirit” stars Angela Lansbury in her juiciest role in years.
The soldiers were killed in a roadside explosion on Sunday, the United States military said, in the worst of several attacks by insurgents around the country.
There were many felicities in the three-week season of Paul Taylor choreography that ended on Sunday.
Some countries have begun raising questions about the risks and requirements if they accept prisoners.
This HBO documentary is an animal-rights tract and legal drama that is primarily a snapshot of the American cultural divide.
It will take time for the administration’s rescue efforts to gain serious traction, a top Obama adviser acknowledged.
New releases from Bonnie “Prince” Billy, the Branford Marsalis Quartet and Cucu Diamantes.
Fears about the global economy outweighed calls for a more aggressive stance to prop up prices.
Obama administration officials and Republicans alike offered nearly universal condemnation of the $165 million in bonuses that A.I.G. is planning to dole out to top executives.
Children receiving daily doses of peanuts under medical supervision were able to build a tolerance.
After a weekend of protests, the Pakistani government agreed to reinstate the former chief justice of the Supreme Court, a stunning concession to the opposition leader Nawaz Sharif.
Police officers saw a gunman who was firing from the street into a Papa John’s outlet, the authorities said. No one was killed.

Two Israeli police officers were shot dead in their patrol car in the Jordan Valley area of the West Bank on Sunday night, police officials said. Although the identities of the gunmen were not immediately clear, Israeli security officials said they were treating the killings as a probable nationalist attack by Palestinians. The attack, along the Jordanian border near the Jewish farming settlement of Massua, came as Israel began easing travel restrictions for Palestinians around Nablus, a Palestinian city northwest of the settlement.

Let's get this out of the way: Resident Evil 5 is not a racist game. For at least a year some black journalists have been wringing their hands about whether the game, the latest in the seminal survival-horror series, inflames racist stereotypes because it is set in Africa. The answer is no.

ROSENFIELD--Nancy. You were a wonderful friend, gracious and caring. We will miss you terribly and you will always be remembered. With love, our deepest sympathy to Jim and the family. Jean and Ralph Baruch

DEAR DIARY: One Saturday afternoon, after returning from some errands downtown, my wife and I parked our car in a space on 89th Street, two blocks south of our building. We left it there for the rest of the weekend.

No catchy title or explicit program was attached to the three concerts the conductor Mariss Jansons presented with the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall over the weekend. Still, intended or not, a theme of sorts emerged on Friday and Saturday nights: the continued centrality of Beethoven within the concert sphere. Beethoven's ghost passed through two works on Friday's program, Jörg Widmann's ''Con Brio'' and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 4. Saturday's ended with one of Beethoven's towering peaks, the Ninth Symphony. Sunday's program, not reviewed here, included Brahms's First Symphony and ''Beethoven's Heiligenstädter Testament,'' a new work by the Russian composer Rodion Shchedrin, both assuring that Beethoven's shade would linger.

As part of its ''Best of Slamdance'' series tonight, the IFC Center presents ''Heart of Stone,'' which won the audience award for best documentary this year. Set in Weequahic High School in Newark, it follows a tough-love principal who turns his gang-loving students around, with the help of some older, Philip Roth-era alumni. It's moving because it's true. And it screens with ''Undone,'' which won the Grand Jury Award for best animated short.

Jay Stewart lumbered down the driveway, past the Mercedes and away from the home overlooking Westlands Park near the southern edge of Denver. ''We get any coyotes today?'' a woman shouted from across the street.

Angela Wu Cen, 19, knew many details about her parents' 13-year migration from China to Panama to New York. But she had never known much about a more intimate aspect of her parents' lives: their courtship. So when Ms. Wu, who was born in Panama and was 12 when the family came to the United States, sat down to interview her mother for an honors seminar at Hunter College last month, she was surprised to learn that her parents' marriage had not been the fruit of a long romance, as she had assumed, but had come about in a matter of weeks.

Robby Andrews, a senior from Englishtown, N.J., closed out his final indoor season undefeated with a national 800-meter record of 1 minute 49.21 seconds at the National Indoor Scholastic Championships at the New Balance Track and Field Center in Manhattan. run
To the Editor: Re ''Try a Little Tenderness,'' by Steven Kleinman and Matthew Alexander (Op-Ed, March 11):

What began as a peaceful Sunday afternoon for a Yonkers woman took a bizarre twist when she was shot with an arrow outside a nursing home in the Bronx, the police said. The woman, Denise Delgado Brown, 51, was struck in the abdomen by the arrow, which came rushing through the sky above the Schervier Nursing Care Center on Independence Avenue in Riverdale about 2 p.m., the police said.
To the Editor: Re ''Obama Puts His Own Spin on the Mix of Science With Politics'' (news article, March 10):

A play about a former Guantánamo Bay detainee who visits his Army interrogator 15 years after his detention has won the third annual Yale Drama Series award for playwriting. David Hare, the British playwright and judge of the series, is to announce on Monday that Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig won for ''Lidless.'' The play, chosen from 650 submissions, is about a former detainee who demands half a liver from his former female interrogator for the damage she inflicted on him. The play will be performed as a staged reading at the Yale Repertory Theater in September and published by Yale University Press. Ms. Cowhig, a graduate of Brown University and the International School of Beijing, will also receive $10,000 from the David Charles Horn Foundation as part of the award.

The Tibetan government in exile in India said over the weekend that it welcomed further talks with China over policies in Tibet, but reiterated that it was still seeking autonomy for Tibetans as outlined in the Chinese Constitution. Meanwhile, the first anniversary of widespread Tibetan riots and protests against Chinese rule passed this weekend without any reports of large-scale protests.

After a month of delays, the space shuttle Discovery and its crew of seven had a spectacularly uneventful liftoff on Sunday evening, rising into a cool, clear Florida twilight en route to the International Space Station. The Discovery is carrying a last set of solar arrays for the space station and a replacement part for a water recycling system, needed to transform urine into drinkable water. NASA would like the recycling system fully functional before the station crew is expanded to six members from three, a move planned for late May.

''He gets the puck, five guys on their team want to kill him,'' Scott Gomez said after the Rangers' 4-1 victory against the Philadelphia Flyers on Sunday. Gomez was speaking of Sean Avery, who scored two power-play goals and has four goals in six games in his latest stint with the Rangers.

Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, the former Pakistani chief justice whose reinstatement was announced Monday, is a popular, independent-minded jurist whose dismissal became a national symbol of President Pervez Musharraf's abuse of power and helped lead to his removal from office. When Mr. Chaudhry was fired in March 2007, he was considering cases involving the questions of whether Mr. Musharraf, who was also head of the military, held office legally and could run for re-election.
SHULBERG--Richard, also known as Citizen Kafka. Husband of Annie Rech, father of Sarah, friend to thousands.

BRANFORD MARSALIS QUARTET ''Metamorphosen'' (Marsalis Music/Decca) The Branford Marsalis Quartet has been together in its current form for a decade, long enough to develop a common intuition and a strong collective voice: the elusive goal of any band in the ever-mutating postbop mainstream. Taking its lead from Mr. Marsalis, a saxophonist of obstinate candor, the band has become both looser and more imposingly self-assured. ''Metamorphosen,'' its new album, captures that dynamic almost perfectly.

Advertising spending across all media was down 2.6 percent from 2007 to 2008, according to Nielsen. Almost every category, led by the print media and business-to-business segments, was down. Local newspapers and Sunday supplements lost more than 10 percent each, and national newspapers had a 9.6 percent drop. Even Internet display advertising fell. Only two categories gained, partly at the expense of network television: cable TV, which rose 7.8 percent, and Hispanic cable TV, which led all categories with a 9.6 percent gain.

No sooner had President Obama lifted the Bush-era restrictions on financing embryonic stem cell research than critics began urging that any federal support be limited to work with stem cells derived from surplus embryos at fertility clinics. That would be a mistake. The guidelines should define the eligible research as broadly as possible to allow the greatest potential for advances. Some of the most important research requires stem cells genetically matched to patients with specific diseases, such as Parkinson's or diabetes. These can rarely be identified in the huge stock of surplus embryos.

''Rent'' isn't the only show proving to be too provocative for some parents of high school students. A month after controversy over a production of ''Rent'' at a high school in Newport Beach, Calif., the comedian Steve Martin, left, has offered to pay for an off-campus production of one of his plays because its performance was banned by an Oregon school, The Associated Press reported. Parents at La Grande High School objected to what they called adult content in Mr. Martin's 1993 play, ''Picasso at the Lapin Agile,'' about an imagined meeting between Albert Einstein and Pablo Picasso in a Paris bar. The school board halted rehearsals after receiving a petition signed by 137 people. In a letter published on Friday in The La Grande Observer, Mr. Martin offered to pay for the production because, he wrote, he wanted to keep the play ''from acquiring a reputation it does not deserve.''

With energy consumption falling sharply as the global financial crisis worsens, the OPEC oil cartel said on Sunday that it would not seek to reduce its output, as fears about the world economy trumped calls to raise prices. Instead, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said it would press its 12 members to ''comply fully'' with earlier agreements to curb crude output. After dropping from a high of $147 last summer to a low of $33 a barrel in December, oil prices have stabilized in the range of $40 to $50 a barrel.

RICHARD--Mae (nee Blank). Lyricist Mae Richard, a resident of Manhattan, died peacefully in her sleep on March 4, 2009, at the age of 86, although in spirit she was 39. She is survived by her loving husband of 66 years, Howard Richard, an attorney, and her two loving children, Larry and Barbara. She attended West Philadelphia High School, and earned a B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. In mid-life, not content to remain a suburban housewife, she blazed new trails and ensconced herself in New York, determined to bring her immense creative talents to the world of musical theater. Her earliest successes came in the field of industrial theater, where she won accolades for musicals at DuPont, RCA, and Lehigh Valley Dairies. Building on this experience, she began a prolific period of song-writing. Credits from this period include Sesame Street, PBS's Punchinello, and NBC's Emmy-award-winning Unicorn Tales. She spent most of her professional career as a lyricist in the New York professional theater community. She was responsible for the lyrics and concept of Tallulah!, a musical about Tallulah Bankhead, which was presented off-Broadway. Mae also conceived and wrote the lyrics for the off-Broadway musical Cut the Ribbons, which explored the mother-daughter relationship. Her efforts were honored when the show was nominated for a MAC Award and an Outer Critic's Circle Award. Mae was a member of the Dramatists Guild, and served on many Boards and panels including Vice President and Board member of her favorite organization, the League of Professional Theatre Women, an organization to which she brought enormous personal dedication and energy. She also served as a member of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, awarding the Emmy Awards. At her death, she was working on an original musical based on a short story by Mark Twain. Donations in Mae's honor may be directed to: League of Professional Theatre Women PO Box 2292 New York, NY 10108
Skipping Some Visits to the Doctor The waiting rooms in doctors' offices rank right up there with bus stations as places to avoid. They are typically filled with cranky people, feeling lousy.

American bankers are fighting -- for the right to be zombies. You wouldn't know it by last week's rally in bank stocks. But it's one plausible interpretation of comments by the chief executives of Citigroup and Bank of America playing up the earnings power of their respective institutions. Vikram Pandit, Citi's chief executive, boasted of $19 billion of revenues in the first two months of the year in a memo to his staff. Annualized, that would be $114 billion -- impressive given the state of financial markets and not far from 2007. That sparked the ''Pandit rally'' in the market. Citi alone surged 75 percent last week.
ROSENFIELD--Nancy S. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York mourns the death of our cherished member and extends deepest sympathy to her family.

The Obama administration is increasingly concerned about a populist backlash against banks and Wall Street, worried that anger at financial institutions could also end up being directed at Congress and the White House and could complicate President Obama's agenda. The administration's sharp rebuke of the American International Group on Sunday for handing out $165 million in executive bonuses -- Lawrence H. Summers, director of the president's National Economic Council, described it as ''outrageous'' on ''This Week'' on ABC -- marks the latest effort by the White House to distance itself from abuses that could feed potentially disruptive public anger.

In a college basketball season defined by its unpredictability and volatility, the dominance of the Big East Conference proved one of the rare constants. So it was fitting that when the N.C.A.A. unveiled its 65-team tournament field Sunday, the Big East earned a spot in history. With Louisville, Connecticut and Pittsburgh joining North Carolina as No. 1 seeds, the Big East became the first conference to place three teams on the top line of the N.C.A.A. tournament field.

Dennis Crowley's last big project, a location-based messaging service called Dodgeball, was just shut down by Google, its owner. But Mr. Crowley got back in the game Friday with Foursquare, a free mobile application that aims to turn nightlife into a game, complete with points and awards. Mr. Crowley and a co-developer, Naveen Selvadurai, took the wraps off Foursquare at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex.

El Salvador's F.M.L.N., the leftist party of the country's former guerrillas, took the lead according to partial results in the presidential election Sunday, in what appeared to be a turning point for the country's politics after two decades of rule by the right. The electoral tribunal said that with votes from 73 percent of polling places counted, the F.M.L.N. was leading with 51.6 percent of the vote compared with the right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance's 48.4 percent.

One way to make me happy is to show me a dance company in which everyone can turn to both the right and left. Dancers discover early that they pirouette more easily to one side or the other, and it's astonishing how many dull-minded companies indulge them by letting them turn only in the most comfortable direction. When you see a dancer who revolves both ways, it shows not just facility but control, even wit. And when you see a whole company turning both ways, you feel you're in a bright-minded climate. In the ''California Dreamin' '' section of Paul Taylor's ''Changes'' (2008), all the dancers do double pirouettes to the right and left. You hardly notice; an incidental feature, it's just one of many felicities in ''Changes'' and in the three-week season of Paul Taylor choreography that ended on Sunday at City Center.

My picks stem from three ideas: strong perimeter play, rebounding and the ability to make defensive adjustments. The first two are nearly equal in importance; the Pat Riley rule that rebounds equal rings has always resonated with me, and if you look at most recent N.C.A.A. champions, they tend to have very talented guards. You can win without a stellar center, but if your guards can't start your offense in crunch time, you're done. The exception to this would be teams with bigger players who can create their own shots from nearly anywhere, like Carmelo Anthony or Danny Manning. The ability to adjust defensively is a much fuzzier idea, since some teams are not tested enough during the season for one to know whether they possess this skill. In assessing relatively equal teams, the one that I know can switch to a zone or a trapping defense tends to get my pick. Learning on the job is not something I'm looking for in a tournament team. That's why, for example, I picked Louisville to advance to the Round of 8 last year in a bracket that included Oklahoma and Tennessee. But when it came to playing North Carolina for a Final Four bid, I felt that the Tar Heels had better rebounding and perimeter play than the Cardinals, outweighing Louisville's defensive agility.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.19 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.41 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.08 percent.

WILD--Stanley, 83, of Alpine, NJ, on March 14, 2009. Cherished husband of Barbara, beloved father of Jeffrey and Susan, David and Fran, Wendy and David. Dearest twin brother of Lee Barrie. Loving grandfather of Daniel and Alisson, Andrew and Alec and Justin. Adored step-father of Cliff and Alyssa Greenberg, Karen and Craig Sheer and their children Josh, Jamie and Mikey, Aaron, Josselyn and Gary. A legend in his industry. Services Tuesday, 1pm at Temple Sinai, Tenafly, NJ. For information "Eden Memorial Chapel" Fort Lee, 1-888-700-3336.

José María Gómez Jimenez thought his days of toiling in the Andalusian countryside were over. For much of the past eight years, Mr. Gómez, 29, earned about $1,900 a month plastering walls and working weekend shifts as a chef in this prosperous, strawberry-farming town. He bought an apartment, often went to parties after work and splurged on trendy sneakers. A year ago, Mr. Gómez lost his construction job. Now he is harvesting strawberries for $1,100 a month on a farm outside Lepe, in the Andalusian province of Huelva.

As General Motors and Chrysler struggle to remain solvent, the railroad bailout of a generation ago could offer a template to the Obama administration -- one in which the federal government would run the auto companies until they are back on their feet. That was a different age, of course. Congress was very much on board, supervising the reorganization of the bankrupt Northeastern railroads and then forming Conrail, in 1976, to run them. The auto companies, in contrast, are being pushed by the White House and Congress to reorganize themselves and remain private corporations, owned by shareholders.
The Team No One Wants to Play

Three years ago, Massachusetts enacted perhaps the boldest state health care experiment in American history, bringing near-universal coverage to the commonwealth with Paul Revere speed. To make it happen, Democratic lawmakers and Gov. Mitt Romney, a Republican, made an expedient choice, deferring until another day any serious effort to control the state's runaway health costs.

INTERACTIVE: AN ASSIGNMENT CLOSE TO HOME The freshmen enrolled in a Hunter College honors seminar called ''The Peopling of New York'' were asked to interview a close relative and write about their families' immigration history. Most were either immigrants themselves or the children of immigrants. Excerpts from the oral histories of 20 students.

Accounts Anheuser-Busch, St. Louis, part of Anheuser-Busch InBev, ended a 14-year relationship with Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, which created campaigns for beer brands like Budweiser and Rolling Rock that featured characters like talking lizards and a donkey that believed it was a Clydesdale. Goodby, Silverstein, in a statement, attributed the decision to ''cost-cutting through a reduction of the number of agencies'' with which Anheuser-Busch InBev will work. Keith Levy, vice president for marketing at Anheuser-Busch, said cost-cutting ''wasn't the driving factor'' in the decision, attributing it to a ''strategic initiative'' to work with fewer agencies. ''The brand gets re-created every time another agency handles the brand,'' he said. Agencies that will continue to create campaigns for Anheuser-Busch beers include the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of Omnicom.
Coach Who Could Be Ready To Move On From Here

The Big East, the Atlantic Coast Conference and the Big Ten each have seven teams in the N.C.A.A. tournament field, the most of any conferences. And while the Big East and the A.C.C. have been powerhouses this season, the Big Ten has not, despite its second-place ranking in the Ratings Percentage Index.

To the Editor: According to ''5 Years After It Halted Weapons Programs, Libya Sees the U.S. as Ungrateful'' (news article, March 11), Libyan officials are ''dissatisfied'' with the perceived failure of the United States to reward Libya fully for ending its nuclear and chemical weapons programs in late 2003.

RICHARD--Mae (nee Blank). Lyricist Mae Richard, a resident of Manhattan, died peacefully in her sleep on March 4, 2009, at the age of 86. She is survived by her loving husband of 66 years, Howard Richard, an attorney, and her two loving children, Larry and Barbara Richard. She led a life full of joy and accomplishment, filled with loving relationships including her beloved sister, Marjorie Gelber, and her late sister, Evelyn Lessin; her daughter-in-law, D'Arcy Lyness Richard; her son-in-law, the late LaMar Pugh; and many other loving family, friends and colleagues.

TRAUM--Daniel M.,age 34. Beloved son of Lynda and the late Jerome. Brother of David, Norman and Teddy. Brother-in-law of Deirdre and Lauren. Devoted uncle and friend. Services will be held Monday, March 16 at 12:45pm at "The Riverside" at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory can be made to The Dalton School, New York, NY.

A medically supervised daily dose of peanuts may help children with peanut allergies greatly increase their tolerance to the food, according to two new studies that raise the possibility of a cure for this potentially life-threatening condition. The findings, presented on Sunday at a meeting of the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology in Washington, suggest that a treatment for peanut allergy may be developed in two or three years, said Dr. Wesley Burks, the chief of the division of pediatric allergy and immunology at Duke University Medical Center, who helped conduct the research.

Saul Linares, a factory worker from Hempstead, N.Y., sat down at dinner on Feb. 7 with pen, paper and a story to tell. Then he did what similarly equipped Mexicans have done since the 1800's. He wrote a corrido. ''In the left hand I was eating, and with my right hand I was writing it down,'' he said. He was done in 20 minutes.

The longstanding disgrace of mountaintop mining is now squarely in President Obama's hands. A recent court decision has given the green light to as many as 90 mountaintop mining projects in Appalachia's coal-rich hills, which in turn could destroy more than 200 miles of valleys and streams on top of the 1,200 miles that have already been obliterated. The right course for the administration is clear: stop the projects until the underlying regulations are revised so as to end the practice altogether.

The trip that rekindled and prodded the Knicks' flickering playoff embers ended Sunday with a noticeable thud, although its finale was a somewhat surprising and mostly competitive showing. It came against a Cavaliers team that is as close to an immovable object for a road team as there is in the N.B.A., although the Knicks did budge Cleveland for most of a 98-93 loss at Quicken Loans Arena.

IN ITS EARLY DAYS, the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament bore little resemblance to what has become March Madness. Eight teams were invited to play at sites around the country, and the tournament played second fiddle to the National Invitation Tournament, which drew teams primarily from the Northeast to play at Madison Square Garden. But by the 1960s, the N.C.A.A.'s national marketing strategy had served it well as the N.I.T. became a secondary player in postseason college basketball. Here are the teams that made the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. tournament and the changes in the basketball landscape from decade to decade. Sources: N.C.A.A.; Peter Bjarkman, sports historian

The coffee shop-and-bookstore credited with kindling the social scene on Cortelyou Road in Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, cannot sell coffee. Beer? Sorry, no beer, either. Salads? No. The health department shut down the food-and-beverage operation at the shop, Vox Pop, in January, because of $29,000 in unpaid fines going back to 2007.

DAVIDSON--William. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the death of Bill Davidson, devoted friend of the institution and father-in-law of JTS Trustee Jon Aaron. A lifelong philanthropist, his gift in 1994 to create the William Davidson Graduate School of Jewish Education at JTS transformed the field of Jewish education in North America. JTS conferred upon him an honorary degree in 1996, recognizing his commitment to ensure the transmission of Judaism from one generation to the next. Mr. Davidson was a man of vision and action, of independence and responsibility, of gentleness and determination, of play and purposefulness. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Karen, his children Marla (and Cyrus), Ethan (and Gretchen), Mary (and Jon), Elizabeth, Emily and the entire Davidson family. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

ST. JOHN'S GETS C.B.I. BID St. John's will make its first postseason appearance under Coach Norm Roberts. The Red Storm (16-17) will play in the 16-team College Basketball Invitational, heading to Richmond to play the Spiders on Wednesday. It is the first postseason appearance for St. John's since 2003, when it played in the National Invitational Tournament. The Red Storm has not played in the N.C.A.A. tournament since 2002. St. John's upset Georgetown in the opening round of the Big East Tournament on Tuesday before falling to Marquette, 74-45 .PETE THAMEL

Obama administration officials and Republicans alike were nearly universal in condemning the $165 million in bonuses that the American International Group, which has received more than $170 billion in taxpayer bailout money from the Treasury and Federal Reserve, is to pay executives in the business unit that brought the company to the brink of collapse last year. ''There are a lot of terrible things that have happened in the last 18 months, but what's happened at A.I.G. is the most outrageous,'' said Lawrence H. Summers, President Obama's chief economic adviser, during an appearance Sunday on ABC's ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos.'' ''What that company did, the way it was not regulated, the way no one was watching, what's proved necessary -- is outrageous.''

For Yahoo's original video strategy, this will be Take Two. On Monday, the Web portal will announce the latest in a series of niche Web shows. The short segments about celebrity mothers, titled ''Spotlight to Nightlight,'' are a stark departure from the company's initial forays into TV-style production for the Internet. This time, Yahoo's executives say they have found a sustainable model for making original video online, in part by explicitly not competing with television.

European countries that have offered to help the Obama administration close the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, have begun raising questions about the security risks and requirements if they accept prisoners described by the Bush administration as ''the worst of the worst,'' according to diplomats and other officials. The concerns, and a deep suspicion of whether the American intelligence community will share full information on the prisoners, are likely to complicate the resettlement effort, which is critical to President Obama's fulfilling his pledge to close Guantánamo within a year of his taking office.
KLINGER--Herbert. Beloved husband, father, father-in-law and grandfather. Devoted brother and uncle, respected teacher, loyal friend. We miss him.

When Kirsten Major and three friends decided they were going to go ahead and make a short film she had written, she asked if they thought they might all be able to find some time to shoot in the next few days, even though that would mean taking time out of the workweek. The four collaborators looked at one another at the coffee shop and realized that, yes, as a matter of fact, they were all free the very next day, and every day after that for the foreseeable future. Whatever problems unemployment may create, scheduling conflicts are not among them. Adam Lehman, a 27-year-old executive assistant who lately cannot even find temp jobs, was pretty sure he could squeeze in a meeting whenever it was convenient for everyone else, even if it cut into the time he and his roommate (also newly unemployed) were spending perfecting the moves to Beyoncé's ''Single Ladies'' dance. Josh Koll, who is also 27 and had been laid off from a lighting design firm a few months earlier, knew his regular Bravo reality television regimen could wait. Ms. Major, 42, whose previous day jobs had been with nonprofit organizations, and who had been looking for work for months, could give herself permission to take time off from the musical she was writing on spec.

ROBINSON--Arline (Bakal), 80, of Scarsdale, on March 14, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Dr. George Robinson, mother of Marjorie Williams, Susanna Kaminsky, and James Robinson. A son, Kevin Robinson predeceased her. She is survived by eight grandchildren, Cheyenne, Andrew, Lauren, Jasper, Jeffrey, Sara, Jessica, and Sally. Mother-in-law to Bruce Kaminsky and Subha Robinson. Funeral services at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, Westchester Ave Rye, NY Monday, March 16, 2009 at Noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her memory to Camp Sunshine, 35 Acadia Road, Casco, ME 04015.

Both golfers in the final pairing Sunday played with chills, Phil Mickelson because he was ill, Nick Watney because he was thrilled to be in a head-to-head battle for the World Golf Championships-CA Championship title. Each took his time on the back nine of Doral's Blue Monster course, Mickelson because he was trying to conserve energy, Watney because he was trying to contain his excitement.

CUCU DIAMANTES ''CuCuLand'' (Fun Machine) There's always a touch of sass when CuCu Diamantes sings, whether she's bemoaning a lover's lies, playing the gold digger or touting her inner strength. ''CuCuLand'' is the solo debut album by Ms. Diamantes, the Cuban co-founder and singer of Yerba Buena, an irrepressible Latin alternative band from New York. (She can rap at high velocity too, as she does in ''Alguien.'')

President Hugo Chávez ordered the navy on Sunday to seize seaports in states with major petroleum-exporting installations, part of his effort to assert greater control over infrastructure that had come under the dominion of political opponents in regional elections last year. The move points to a spreading radicalization by Mr. Chávez, as he responds to a slowing economy and the gains made by his opponents. Economic growth slowed in the last quarter to its most sluggish pace in five years, 3.2 percent, weighed down by low oil prices.

''Cybersquatting,'' the practice of maliciously snapping up a Web site with someone else's trademark in its domain name, is illegal in the United States. It is also an easy way to make money; a cybersquatter can impersonate the trademark's owner, sell ad space to the victim's competitors, or extort a payment in return for turning over the Web site. A recent report from MarkMonitor, a company that sells domain names to large companies and protects them from online misuse of their brands, suggests the practice is increasingly popular in the United States -- despite laws that allow trademark holders to sue. Over 2008, MarkMonitor tracked an 18 percent rise in incidence of cybersquatting, which it calculated by examining every new domain name created, checking for a trademark in the URL, and then seeing whether the trademark's owner also owned the Web site.

The same scene of heartbreak played out over and over on Sunday on a ragtag patch of Neptune Avenue in Coney Island, where the word ''scrappy'' may be better suited to describe the metal in the auto shops than any sort of community spirit.
NEW YORK DAYBOOK

With the formerly highflying Irish economy now in an even deeper tailspin than the American one, the Irish prime minister's annual St. Patrick's Day visit to the United States has an unusually somber feel about it. In a speech Sunday night at the American Irish Historical Society on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, Prime Minister Brian Cowen of Ireland said he would urge the Obama administration to expand visas for Irish workers and allow them to stay two years here instead of the current one.

LESSINGER--Leslie, age 65, died peacefully at home March 13, 2009 after a long struggle with pancreatic cancer. Professor of Chemistry at Barnard College and resident of Brooklyn. He is survived by his wife Hanna, his mother Minnie, his brother Eric and by nephews and a niece. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Barnard College Scholarship Fund. A memorial will be held at a later date.

The computer industry has hit upon its Next Big Thing. It is called a phone. Emboldened by Apple's success with its iPhone, many PC makers and chip companies are charging into the mobile-phone business, promising new devices that can pack the horsepower of standard computers into palm-size packages.

GLASER--Muriel Weiss, of Warwick, NY on March 14, 2009. Beloved mother of Jonathan and his wife Stacey. Devoted grandmother of Andrew. Former copywriter at Young & Rubicam. Services today 1pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY.

HILTON--Murray M.,Dentist, musician and bon vivant, passed away Thursday March 12, 2009 in Tamarac, Florida, one month before his 89th birthday. He was the beloved husband, for 66 years of Edith, cherished father of Ken (Meri), and adoring grandfather of his pride and joy grandsons, Mike, Rob, and Corey. He was pre-deceased by his son Tommy.
To the Editor: Re ''The Looting of America's Coffers,'' by David Leonhardt (Economic Scene, March 11):

MARKS--Ellen Simon, on March 14, 2009. We all deeply regret the passing of Ellen, beloved sister, aunt, and stepmother. For 97 years she led a wonderful life and she will be missed by all. The family will be receiving at Frank E. Campbell at 81st St. and Madison Ave. on Monday and Tuesday from 5pm to 8pm. Services will be on Wednesday at 11:30am at the same location. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th St. NY, NY 10022.

DISCLOSURES FROM A.I.G. With public anger rising, the American International Group disclosed some financial institutions that benefited from the federal bailouts meant to prop up the troubled insurance giant. G.M. UNDER MICROSCOPE More than two dozen officials traveled to Detroit to scour records at General Motors and assess for the United States whether the company needs more aid or a managed bankruptcy. [B1.]

DAVIDSON--William. The Friends of the Israel Antiquities Authority mourn the loss of William "Bill" Davidson, Honorary Citizen of Jerusalem, Founder of the Davidson Center, the Second Temple Period Park, and the Jerusalem Archaeological Park, whose passion and monumental generosity transformed the landscape of Jerusalem. Shelby White, Chairman Adam Emmerich, President Jacob Fisch, Executive Director

GRAUBART--David, diamond dealer, dies at 100. Born in Sanok, Poland in 1908; immigrated to the US in 1942. Mother, Feiga Schoenfeld (Great Grand daughter of Tzvi Eli-Melech of Dinov a prominent Chasidic Rabbi) perished, along with over 70 of Graubart's family in Nazi concentration camps. Graubart's father died before WWII. Mr. Graubart is survived by his companion of twenty years, Cynthia Gottlieb and by several distant relatives in the US, Australia, Belgium and Brazil, and his passing is mourned by many close friends.

The annual spring extravaganza known as Asia Week is under way, but like so much else it's been downsized. The New York International Asian Art Fair is no more, leaving collectors and browsers with just one centralized marketplace: the New York Arts of Pacific Asia Show, in a new home across from the Empire State Building. Local galleries that specialize in Asian art are picking up some of the slack. Sixteen New York dealers from past Internationals have formed a temporary alliance, Asian Art Dealers of Upper Eastside New York, and have organized a series of exhibitions on the Upper East Side (information at aadueny.com). And, as in years past, more Asian art can be found among the galleries in the Fuller Building on 57th Street.

Generation after generation samba courses through Brazilian pop. Two up-and-coming singers from São Paulo, Mariana Aydar and Jair Oliveira, made their New York solo debuts at Symphony Space at the World Music Institute's two-night Brasil Fest, grounding themselves in samba before adding their own personal twists. ''They said I sang the samba,'' Mr. Oliveira sang in Portuguese in his concert on Saturday night. ''But the samba sang me.''

An article on Saturday about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's campaign spending referred incorrectly to the law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher. The firm worked for Mr. Bloomberg's two previous campaigns; it is not one of the new companies working on his 2009 campaign.

With oil consumption falling sharply as a result of the global financial crisis, the OPEC oil cartel said on Sunday that it would not seek a new cut in production targets, as fears about the global economy outweighed calls for a more aggressive stance to prop up prices. Instead, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said it would press its 12 members to ''comply fully'' with earlier agreements to curb production. OPEC said it would meet again in two months to review these actions and consider further production cuts.

City officials here have yet to announce the winning design for the Slussen project, which aims to replace a tangle of traffic circles, bridges, underpasses and boat locks in the heart of this city. But they have already done us a major public service. The five proposals in the competition, on view at stockholm.se/slussen, offer a snapshot of contemporary urban planning ideas. They include a breathtaking design by Jean Nouvel, a head-scratching proposal by Norman Foster and some intriguing work by younger talents who are still mostly unknown internationally.

No matter what the economic climate, art fairs are always a gamble for the exhibiting dealers. The cost of renting a booth, shipping precious artworks, insuring them and keeping a sales staff housed and fed in a foreign city can add up to hundreds of thousands of dollars. So in these rough times it was with a good deal of jitters that the European Fine Art Fair -- one of the world's foremost art and antiques events -- opened here with a preview on Thursday of a record 239 exhibitors from 15 countries.

An article last Monday about a conference in New York at which more than 600 skeptics of global warming challenged the prevailing scientific views on the issue misstated the middle initial of a climate scientist who decided not to attend. He is John R. Christy, not John H.

When the speedy Carlos Gómez of the Minnesota Twins stood at first base with two outs in the first inning Sunday afternoon, it was the perfect time for Yankees catcher Jorge Posada to test his surgically repaired right shoulder. ''I was just hoping that he took off,'' Posada said. In his first game behind the plate since last July, Posada wanted, he said, to ''just make a throw and see how it felt.'' But Andy Pettitte, good at holding runners, kept Gómez close and retired Jason Kubel on two pitches.
