DAVIDSON--William. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society mourn the loss of William Davidson of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., a visionary supporter of the Technion. Mr. Davidson was a transformational industrialist and philanthropist. Chairman and president of Guardian Industries Corp., he was one of the largest private investors in Israeli enterprise. Following his belief that education and good management are the best tools for promoting economic growth, Mr. Davidson established the William Davidson Faculty of Industrial Engineering and Management and the William Davidson Chair in that faculty at the Technion. Among the most generous ATS supporters, Mr. Davidson was a Technion Guardian who had reached the highest level of support. He was an honorary life member of the Technion International Board of Governors. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife Karen and the entire Davidson family. American Technion Society Joan Seidel, President Stephen A. Laser, Chairman of the Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

Memorial donations in his name can be sent to the Greek Orthodox Metropolis of New Jersey.

Anne Brown, a penetratingly pure soprano who literally put the Bess in ''Porgy and Bess'' by inspiring George Gershwin to expand that character's part in a folk opera that originally was to be called ''Porgy,'' died Friday in Oslo. She was 96. Her daughter Paula Schjelderup announced the death.

ANNENBERG--Leonore. The Board and Staff of Creative Time mourn the loss of the visionary Leonore Annenberg. Her creativity and generosity will remain a potent inspiration for us all. We send our deepest condolences to her family, in particular, Elizabeth and Liz Kabler and Steven and Ann Ames.

DUBIN--Jack Dr. The Board of Governors and Members of Inwood Country Club record with sorrow the passing of Dr. Jack Dubin, beloved husband of Elizabeth Small and we extend deepest sympathy to the family. Sandor Engel, President Beverly Nassau, Secretary

SMITH--David, died on March 14. Penn South Social Services Inc. and the NORC Supportive Services Center Inc. with deep sorrow remember David as a forceful and committed leader in the development of an entirely new program for older Americans called naturally occurring retirement communities. He was chairman and co-founder of the first NORC program at the Penn South Co-op and was also a co-founder and chairman of the NORC Supportive Services Center, a national organization. In his marathon life's work, he was a caring leader in the cooperative movement, a fearless proponent of health and social services and, with his late wife Esther, stood strong in their beliefs for social justice and peace. We offer our love and condolences to his loving daughters, Karen and Abbey, his son-in-law, Martin DeKadt, his grandchildren, Jessie and Sonja, his entire family and many friends. Nat Yalowitz, President and Co-Founder, PSSS, Inc. & N-SSC, Inc.

DAVIDSON--William. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the death of William "Bill" Davidson. The owner of the Detroit Pistons and his wife Karen donated $75 million on behalf of Guardian Industries towards building an inpatient tower at the Hadassah Medical Center in Ein Kerem, Jerusalem. The tower will be named for his late mother Sarah Wetsman Davidson, also of blessed memory. Mr. Davidson was proud to be the third generation in his family to support Hadassah's goals and achievements, and we, too, are proud to be forever linked to his life and his memory. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion .

SMITH--David L.,died on March 14, after a year of declining health. Visionary leader, president and chairman of the board for over 20 years of Penn South, where he led the successful fight to maintain it as a limited equity housing cooperative in Chelsea, and thus maintain it as affordable housing, one of the last of its kind. He was the innovator behind the building of the cogeneration plant, helped organize a senior center, promoted a naturally occurring retirement community within the complex, and was instrumental in organizing the Coordinating Council of Cooperatives, a meeting ground for cooperative housing leaders citywide. He fought against racial discrimination in housing in Stuyvesent Town in the late 1940s/early 1950s. Was active in the nation's cooperative movement for which he was inducted to the National Cooperative Business Association Hall of Fame in 1995 and honored by the National Association of Housing Cooperatives in 2008. Devoted husband for 56 years to Esther Smith who died in 2001, he is survived by his two daughters, Karen and Abby Smith, his son-in-law Maarten de Kadt his grandchildren Jesse Campoamor and Sonja de Kadt, sister-in-law Elleanor Tilson and the Tilson family and his companion from 2002 to his death, Tess Sacher. Dave spent his entire life fighting for social justice. He was an innovator, a leader and a kind and generous man. He will be greatly missed. A memorial to be held on Saturday, May 9, from 3:30 to 5:30pm at the Haft Auditorium at Fashion Institute of Technology, on 27 Street near 7th Avenue.

We extend our heartfelt condolences to Madeleine and Allen; to Ellen's daughter, Betty Semel; and to Ellen's many grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Panoramic photos show the South Ferry subway station, which re-opened Monday, before and after its $530 million renovation. The station was outfitted with an art installation and full-length platforms, which allows riders on the No. 1 train to exit from any car. nytimes.com/nyregion

KOEPPEL--Adolph, 85, attorney and founder of the law firm, Koeppel, Sommer, Martone, Leistman, a pioneer in the real estate tax certiorari and condemnation law passed away on March 14, 2009. Koeppel received his LLB from NYU Law School in 1948, and his LLM from NYU in 1953. He ran for Town Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead in 1953. He was former assistant Nassau County Attorney from 1963 - 1967, and former Village Attorney of the town of Lake Success from 1968 - 1977. He served in the Navy during World War II and received a medal for his service on D-day and also served at Okinawa and the Philipines on the Destroyer USS Barton. He was a known fiscal philatelist who wrote several books including The Stamps that Caused The American Revolution in 1976, and The Stamps of the Princely States of India for which he received the Earl of Crawford Award by the Royal Philatelic Society. Koeppel was a great humanitarian and patron of the arts. He was one of the early sponsors of the opera night at the Tilles Center at C.W Post College. He supported many charities including The National Children's Defense Fund and the Southern Poverty Law Center. He was born on April 11, 1923. He was a great amateur golfer, and an avid reader. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Rhoda Koeppel, his daughters Lesley Hirsch, Pamela Koeppel, his granddaughters Melissa Grubb, Jennifer Parham, Tara Robinson, his great-grandsons Parker Doyle, and Etienne Parham, his son-in-law Michael Hirsch, and his grandson-in-law Steven Parham, and Kenny Doyle, his great-grandson's father. He is, also, survived by his younger sister Seena Ostroff, his brothers-in-law Herbert Ostroff and Herbert Rubin, Martine Arnoux, his nieces, nephews, friends, assistant Susan Shapiro and his confidant Richard Reichler. Funeral services will be held at Riverdale Chapel in Great Neck on Wednesday, March 18, at 10am.
STEIN--Anita. Beloved wife of Lewis. Loving mother of Debra, Jeffrey, and Jonathan. Dear sister of Joan Doyle. Services "Boulevard-Riverside", 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30pm, Tuesday.

ROSENFIELD--Nancy S. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague Nancy S. Rosenfield. For nearly two decades, Nancy played a vital role at Carnegie Hall, as a Trustee beginning in 1990, as Co-Chair of the Patron Council since 1998, and as an Honorary Trustee since 2007. A driving force behind the establishment of the Special Events Committee at Carnegie Hall, Nancy served as its chair from 1991 until 1998. Under her leadership, Carnegie Hall instituted a number of traditions that have become fixtures in New York City's cultural calendar, including the annual luncheon to support Carnegie Hall's education programs, and the annual Opening Night Gala. All of us at Carnegie Hall have greatly valued Nancy's presence in our lives, and we will always remember her for her genuine warmth, good natured humor, and consummate grace. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to her husband James, her children Laurie and James Jr., and her entire ex- tended family. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director

TROSKY--Helene, passed away peacefully on March 15 at age 91, following a brief illness. She lived an extraordinary life of art, music, travel, love and friendship. An accomplished print and paper maker, her work is in numerous private and public collections. During her lifetime of support for the arts she served as board chairwoman of the Westchester Art Society, a director of Music for Westchester, an executive of the Sleepy Hollow Theater and on various committees of the Regional Plan association and many educational and arts organizations. She was a well known art restorer, writer and lecturer and frequently led art tours in Europe. More than her accomplishments, she will be remembered for her extraordinary flair, humor and warmth, which drew and held friends and family for life. She is survived by countless nieces, nephews and cousins, all of whom she touched and hold dear their memories of this great lady. Graveside services will be held on Wednesday, March 18 at 2pm at the Daniel Webster Benevolent Society section of Mount Zion Cemetery in Maspeth, Queens, NY. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date.

Loving grandmother of Patrick and Jennifer. Former staff member of New York Public Library, former member of National Council of Jewish Women and volunteer for Reach for Recovery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the New York Public Library: http://www.support.nypl.org/

Former Representative Rob Simmons, Republican of Connecticut, announced plans to challenge Senator Christopher J. Dodd next year. Mr. Simmons, who worked for the Central Intelligence Agency in the 1970's, was first elected in 2001 to represent the Second Congressional District, a Democratic-leaning area in southeastern Connecticut. He was defeated in 2006. A recent Quinnipiac University poll showed him leading Mr. Dodd, a Democrat first elected in 1980, among Connecticut voters, 43 percent to 42 percent. RAY HERNANDEZ

Oklahoma forward Blake Griffin would have been a lottery pick in last year's N.B.A. draft, but he opted to return for his sophomore season. By doing so, he established himself as college basketball's best player and the probable first pick this June if he leaves, as expected.

As the Jay Cutler soap opera continued to rage in Denver on Monday, leading to speculation that the quarterback will play elsewhere next season, the Jets surfaced as a potential, albeit unlikely, destination. The Jets cannot comment on Cutler, who has requested a trade, because he remains under contract with the Broncos. But if the track record of Jets General Manager Mike Tannenbaum serves as any indication, he will look into the possibility of obtaining Cutler, who is entering his fourth season and passed for 4,526 yards in 2008.

A MORE ASSERTIVE POWER China is becoming a more assertive and capable rival of the United States as it exploits its unusually flush position and strong banking system while much of the rest of the world wallows in a financial crisis. A CRASH-PRONE WORKHORSE More than a third of Predators, the unmanned planes the military uses for reconnaissance and attacks, have crashed in either Iraq or Afghanistan. Nevertheless, they have become one of the military's favorite weapons despite that and other deficiencies. [A1.]

MARKS--Clement E. The Department of Medicine of the NYU Langone Medical Center is saddened by the passing of our colleague, Clement Marks, M.D. Dr. Marks had been affiliated with NYU since 1962 and was Clinical Professor of Medicine. A physician of towering intellect and a devoted teacher, Clem was beloved by patients, colleagues, housestaff and students, alike. He was both team player and iconoclast, and his warm presence will be missed by all. We extend our deep condolences to his family and friends. Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center

The actress Tovah Feldshuh played the title role in “Yentl” on Broadway — and then Barbra Streisand starred in the part in the movie. Ms. Feldshuh played the title role in “Golda’s Balcony” — and then Valerie Harper played the part, of Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir, in the movie. Now Ms. Feldshuh is preparing to open in “Irena’s Vow” on Broadway on March 29 — but will she make the cut for the movie?
Crocodiles: Stylish wall of throb.

The American Society of Magazine Editors announced finalists for its National Magazine Awards on Wednesday, with perpetual honoree The New Yorker leading the number of nominees.The New Yorker, the most decorated magazine in award history, had 10 nominations, including in the coveted general excellence category. It was followed by GQ with eight nominations, a new record for the men’s magazine.
The bands may be playing weird and noncommercial music, but between the sets, the P.A. systems of Austin are pumping out some of the blandest stuff ever to play on 1970s and ’80s soft-rock radio.

Colin Meloy of the Decemberists had just begun to strum his guitar and sing the forlorn lines he adapted from Dylan Thomas (“In Pembroke City when I was young/I lived by the Castle Keep”) when he broke character and addressed the crowd of 400-odd people crammed into Pangea in downtown Austin late Tuesday night.

The dearth of blush-inducing signage around Times Square will soon be rectified when the Sarah Ruhl play “In the Next Room (or the vibrator play)” comes to Broadway in the fall. Lincoln Center Theater announced that it would present Ms. Ruhl’s play, about a group of women in a New York spa town in the late 1800s, at a Shubert Theater to be announced. Les Waters, who directed the play at the Berkeley Repertory Theater in California will also direct the Broadway production. Previews are scheduled to begin on Oct. 22, and the play’s opening is scheduled for Nov. 19. Lincoln Center Theater said it would also present “Broke-ology,” a new play by Nathan Louis Jackson, at Lincoln Center’s Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater; previews are to begin on Sept. 10 with an opening planned for Oct. 5. No casting was announced for either play.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Wednesday morning.

The actress Parker Posey will take a break from her schedule of what seems like 50 movies a year to appear in a new stage work at Playwrights Horizons, the theater company announced. Ms. Posey, of “Best in Show” and “Waiting for Guffman,” will be featured in “This,” a new comedy by Melissa James Gibson about a widow and her circle of friends. The play, directed by Daniel Aukin, will make its debut as part of Playwrights Horizons’ 2009-2010 season. Other new plays scheduled include “The Retributionists” by Daniel Goldfarb (of Broadway’s “Martin Short: Fame Becomes Me”); “Circle Mirror Transformation” by Annie Baker; and “Clybourne Park” by Bruce Norris. Playwrights Horizons is expected to announce a new musical as well as a sixth production for the season soon.

The spring and summer music seasons continue to offer options for hippies of all ages. The concert promoter Live Nation announced that it would produce a show to celebrate the 90th birthday of Pete Seeger on May 3 at Madison Square Garden. Live Nation said that the show would be a benefit for Mr. Seeger’s Hudson River Sloop Clearwater organization, which promotes the conservation of the Hudson River, and would feature more than 40 artists including Bruce Springsteen, Joan Baez, Dave Matthews, Ani DiFranco, Emmylou Harris and Eddie Vedder. Also, Billboard reported that Phish has added 12 additional dates to its summer tour, the first the band has played since 2004. The new dates include performances in Darien Center, N.Y. (on Aug. 13) and Saratoga Springs, N.Y. (on Aug. 16); the tour is scheduled to begin on June 4 in Wantagh, N.Y.

The convention center in Austin got a slight make over yesterday. Film posters started to get swapped out for music posters. The Loud Cloud information center became the Koss information center through a change in signage. And a really big, scary guy was walking around the escalator wearing a sandwich board that said, “Hire My Band.” The sign didn’t say, “or else,” but the look on the cat’s face did.

The interactive keynote address by Chris Anderson on Tuesday was jammed and it took forever to get out of the place. When I got to the entrance it was clear what the problem was. You know that twit who is always walking slowly in the middle of the sidewalk, staring into his iPhone and wandering back and forth so you can’t pass him? And how you secretly wish he would get clipped by a street sign? Well, that guy and all of his friends were here. During the digital conference, walking was a companion activity to messaging, and the long parade out of the keynote was one geek after another checking his pal’s tweets before making his next move.

Free is a nice word, a friendly word, unless it happens to be the price of what people are willing to pay for your product. Chris Anderson, the editor of Wired, who was knighted by the digerati for “The Long Tail,” has set about making free a workable business. (Unless it’s his book, “Free: The Past and Future of a Radical Price.” That you can preorder on Amazon for $17.81.) Mr. Anderson was interviewed at the keynote on Tuesday by the always entertaining Guy Kawasaki, a venture capitalist who had fun taking some air out of Mr. Anderson, in a genial way.

In daylight, Tuesday was like any other day in Austin, with nary a wisp of St. Patrick’s Day anywhere. But the leprechauns in Austin are apparently vampires and they come out at night. They also drink a lot. For one evening, the festival of the Irish mixed with the festival of the invading hordes. The mix was convivial enough, but the badge-sporting types for South by Southwest were busy making the transition from film and Web to music while having a few drinks along the way, while the local Irish-for-a-day concentrated on the drinking part. Out in front of the Chugging Monkey, a woman was bent over her pal, holding back her green hair while she returned some of the fruits of the earth from whence they came. It was sorta cute and gross at the same time.

Kelly Clarkson is back on top. Her critically praised new album, “All I Ever Wanted” (RCA), opens at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, with 255,000 in sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. “Love vs. Money” (Def Jam) by The-Dream, with guest appearances by Mariah Carey, Kanye West and Lil Jon, took second place with 151,000 in its first week at stores. U2‘s new album, “No Line on the Horizon” (Interscope), fell to No. 3 in its second week out with 132,000 sales, a drop of 73 percent from its opening week. J. Holiday’s new “Round 2″ (Capitol) sold 55,000 to reach No. 4, and Taylor Swift‘s “Fearless” (Big Machine) was No. 5 with 52,000 in its 18th week out. Chris Cornell, the former lead singer of Soundgarden and Audioslave, opened at No. 10 with 26,000 sales of his third solo album, “Scream” (Interscope), produced by Timbaland.
Daniel Francis Doyle: Spasmatic, atonal, yet precise.

It has been a busy few days for literary honors: The Orange Prize for fiction, given annually to a female writer, announced on Wednesday its long list of 20 contenders, including Marilynne Robinson (for her novel “Home”), Toni Morrison (for “A Mercy”), Allegra Goodman (“Intuition”) and Curtis Sittenfeld (“American Wife”); finalists will be announced on April 21 and a winner will be named on June 3. The New York Public Library announced that Salvatore Scibona had won its Young Lions Fiction Award for his novel “The End”; the novel was also a finalist for the National Book Award. The Associated Press reported that the finalists for the Man Booker International Prize, a lifetime achievement award given out every other year, have been announced: the nominees include E.L. Doctorow, V.S. Naipaul, Joyce Carol Oates, Mario Vargas Llosa and Alice Munro. A winner will be announced in May.

Saturday’s matinee of “Reasons to Be Pretty,” Neil LaBute’s debut play on Broadway, is back on after the producers initially canceled it — along with matinees Wednesday and last Sunday — because the director and one of the actors had television commitments that conflicted with rehearsal time.

Updated | 10:38 a.m. Just bumped into the Harlem rapper Charles Hamilton in an elevator, wearing a hot pink tie. He said that flight shenanigans had forced him to take a $300 taxi from Houston, 180 miles away. That’s dedication — it’s also perhaps a benefit of being on a major label, Interscope.

A painting that was to be auctioned Wednesday by Sotheby’s in a sale of items from the villa of the fashion designer Gianni Versace was withdrawn by the auction house under suspicion that the artwork was stolen, Reuters reported. The painting, “Portrait of Major George Maule,” is a work from 1783 by the German artist Johann Zoffany, and was expected to sell for as much as $83,000. A descendant of the painting’s subject had contacted the Art Loss Register, an international organization that tracks stolen art and verifies the legitimacy of works, after a photograph of the portrait was published in The Evening Standard. The descendant’s family also sent the Art Loss Register a photograph of the painting hanging above its mantle before it was stolen. In a statement, Sotheby’s said it had withdrawn the item from the sale because of “a question over title,” according to Reuters.

UPDATED: The American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California filed a lawsuit today in state Superior Court charging that an Orange County high school has allowed a hostile environment to develop against gay and female students there, and cited the brief cancellation of a school production of the musical “Rent” as one piece of evidence.
Edward M. Liddy told a House committee that he had asked employees who received bonuses of more than $100,000 to return half the money.
Despite a continuing turf war between rival drug cartels that threatens the security of many in Mexico, the Indios soccer club and its fans soldier on.
The debate over gay marriage in Vermont intensified Wednesday when more than 500 people came to the State House in Montpelier for an emotional public hearing.
Habitat for Humanity volunteers in Saginaw, Mich., plan to demolish two vacant, dilapidated houses here once every week over the next two years.
A natural gas explosion two weeks ago delivered a deep psychic blow to Bozeman, Mont., which was already going through some difficulty because of the declining economy.

My Thursday column is about something that I've long wondered about: whether the Web will enable us to filter out dissonant news and opinions, allowing us to flood ourselves with news and views that confirm all our prejudices. For now, mainstream TV and newspapers periodically force readers to confront facts and views that distress them. As we gain the ability to construct our personal architecture for our news diet, the distress goes away and we get only news that reassures us. No?

At a time when more than 4 million Americans have lost their jobs and a wobbly nuclear Pakistan is acting like a drunk with the car keys, why should anyone care whether the Zags beat the Zips on Thursday? Or, for that matter, why should the fate of Robert Morris and Stephen F. Austin - colleges? or WASP fashion labels? - concern a country at the depth of its worst economic crisis since the Great Depression?

In the last few years, whenever I ran into Matt Tyrnauer, a special correspondent for Vanity Fair, I'd ask him how his Valentino movie was going. I remember when he started the project in Rome, shortly after writing a profile of Valentino and his business partner Giancarlo Giammetti and their extraordinary relationship. Matt's cameras were at Wideville, Valentino's chateau outside Paris, during the couture shows. Well, if you've seen the documentary, which is at the Film Forum for at least two weeks (the movie opens in Chicago on March 27, and then on April 3 in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Dallas), you know the cameras were always close to Valentino and Giammetti.

Washington is filled with outrage over the $165 million in bonuses given out by the American International Group. Kevin Youkilis of the Boston Red Sox has a sore left ankle and will not play again for the United States in the World Baseball Classic. "We Live in Public," Ondi Timoner's documentary winner of the Sundance Grand Jury Prize, traces the wacky life of Josh Harris, the "greatest Internet pioneer you've never heard of." In the downtown Manhattan circles of the '90s, Harris was the "Internet Guy" who supported cutting-edge artists and threw great parties. But in Timoner's film he was also a social visionary. After making millions with Jupiter Communications, Harris founded Pseudo.com, the world's first Web TV network, in 1994. The media christened him the "Warhol of the Web" for his Factory-like studio, but Pseudo.com ultimately collapsed thanks to Harris's oddball antics, which included dressing up for business meetings as Luvvy, an alter ego based on his mother and a character from "Gilligan's Island."

Two interesting bits of news arrived from Tokyo. The author of "Style Deficit Disorder: Tokyo Street Fashion," Godoy knows a lot about the heart and soul-and history-of genres broadly connected with Harajuku. She and the writer Ivan Vartanian have a new book, "Japanese Goth," due out in May (Universe: $27.50), which looks at the strange aesthetic blend of rococo and heavy metal. I laughed when she said in her email that Goth Lolitas will be drooling over Marc Jacobs' ruffles at Vuitton.

When I first moved to New York I lived in one of the worst apartments of all time - no joke. One morning this past January, somewhere in Campania - the region of Southern Italy that includes Naples - a farmer milked his buffalo. After curdling the milk and draining the whey, he ground up the solids, put them into a mold and stirred them in a hot bath until the solids combined and turned rubbery. Then he kneaded this proto-cheese, lopping off fist-size balls and soaking them in brine. By the next morning, the balls had become the famed mozzarella di bufala, and some were sent northwest, to the Milan branch of Obikà (Via Mercato, 28; 39-02-86-450-568; www.obika.it), a rapidly expanding chain of hip mozzarella bars, where chefs sliced the cheese into small pieces and set them out on a buffet.

A review of records shows about 300 injuries in elevator-related mishaps since 2001 in New York City public housing, including lost fingers tips, missing toes and a broken nose. Of those, 170 injured people were treated at hospitals, by private physicians or by paramedics and firefighters. Nearly 200 of the reports involved inner or outer elevator doors, which tenants have complained close too quickly or too forcefully.

Anyone who has visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art is familiar with the pay-what-you-want concept that has obvious appeal to those unwilling or unable to handle full price.Now that practice is coming to another cherished cultural tradition - summer camp - with a twist. The Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York will allow families to choose among three prices for its sleepaway camps in Huguenot, N.Y., this year, based on what they feel they can afford to pay. No paperwork required. No questions asked.

How much does it cost to own a car? Wheels readers debated that question after I posted an article about how the recession has helped to decrease driving. I have since found that the cost of car ownership is probably a whole lot more than you think. If your estimates are based on what you paid for your vehicle, plus the cost of gas, oil and repairs, you're forgetting about insurance, depreciation, parking fees, tolls and registration, among other things.
The mining group Rio Tinto has appointed Jan du Plessis, the chairman of British American Tobacco, to head its board as well, the company said on Tuesday.

John Wray is the author of the novels "The Right Hand of Sleep," "Canaan's Tongue" and "Lowboy."As a novelist, I used to be tormented by envy when I visited artist friends at their studios - the bright, high-ceilinged workspace ("necessary" for their art, or so they claimed), the Pollock-like mess, the paint- or resin-spattered outfits, and, most sick-making of all, their ability to blast whatever ridiculous music they wanted while they made their immortal contributions to our cultural heritage. If I sound bitter, it's because I am. I'm a hardcore music freak, but for the first seven years of my life as a writer I couldn't work to any kind of music at all, let alone something with a prominent beat, or - heaven forfend! - actual human voices raised in song. My office was as silent as a Jesuit's cell, and almost as depressing.

Less than two weeks before the start of the 2009 Formula One season the series faces its first crisis with a set of radical rules change decisions from the World Motor Sport Council of the International Automobile Federation. Two of the decisions are particularly controversial. One allows some teams to take part in a budget cap system to reduce their budgets to $42 million per season in exchange for technical freedoms that could allow them to beat teams with budgets that are nearly 10 times that amount; the other one awards the drivers' title to the driver who wins the most races, as opposed to the one who has the most points.

Houston Rockets forward Carl Landry was shot in the leg about 2:30 a.m. Tuesday, a few hours after the Rockets returned from a 95-84 victory in New Orleans. The Houston police said Landry, 25, was driving his sport utility vehicle southbound on a city street, when a northbound car swerved into his path and collided with his vehicle. Landry and the driver of the other vehicle made U-turns, the vehicles collided again and Landry’s S.U.V. hit a utility pole. The police said Landry got out of his S.U.V. to inspect the damage, and was shot by one of the two occupants of the car. The suspects then fled the scene, while Landry ran to get help, the police said. Landry was expected to be out one to three weeks. shooting ¶Milwaukee Bucks forward Charlie Villanueva got a talking-to from Coach Scott Skiles after he learned Villanueva posted a message to his Twitter feed from his mobile phone during halftime of Sunday’s home victory over Boston. “We made a point to Charlie and the team that it’s nothing we ever want to happen again,” Skiles said. Using the screen name CV31 — Villanueva’s initials and jersey number — Villanueva, who had a team-high 19 points, posted the following message: “In da locker room, snuck to post my twitt. We’re playing the Celtics, tie ball game at da half. Coach wants more toughness. I gotta step up.” Twitter.

The Jets matched the Cleveland Browns’ offer sheet to safety Abram Elam, keeping him in their secondary. Elam was an unrestricted free agent who started nine games last season, his second with the Jets. Browns Coach Eric Mangini already has signed four of his former Jets players, and Cleveland signed Elam to an offer sheet last week.

The Vancouver Whitecaps are expected to be introduced soon as the second Canadian M.L.S. franchise. Bob Lenarduzzi, the Whitecaps’ president, said he expected an announcement before the M.L.S. season opening Thursday night in Seattle. Will Kuhns, director of communications for M.L.S., said the league had indicated it would like to have the new franchises named before the 2009 season.

Novak Djokovic, the defending champion, defeated Tommy Haas, 6-2, 7-6 (1), in their third-round match at the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif. A 21-year-old Serb who also made the final two years ago, Djokovic served well and hit crisp, accurate groundstrokes to beat the 30-year-old Haas.

Florida State will appeal part of an N.C.A.A. punishment that would strip the university of victories in 10 sports, including as many as 14 in football. T. K. Wetherell, the university president, called the penalty “excessive and inappropriate.” Bobby Bowden, the football coach, has 382 career victories — one fewer than Penn State’s Joe Paterno, the major college leader. Having 14 victories subtracted from Bowden’s total could ruin his chances of retiring as the N.C.A.A. leader. The university accepted the loss of scholarships in 10 sports and a four-year probation that the N.C.A.A. announced March 6 in response to an academic cheating scandal.

Sara Jane Olson, the 1970s radical who assumed a new identity as a Minnesota housewife while spending a quarter century as a fugitive, was released from prison in Chowchilla. Ms. Olson, 62, served seven years — half her sentence — after pleading guilty to placing pipe bombs under Los Angeles Police Department patrol cars and participating in the deadly robbery of a bank near Sacramento. The crimes took place while she was a member of the Symbionese Liberation Army. She was released by mistake a year ago after California corrections officials miscalculated her parole date, joining her family for five days before she was re-arrested. The authorities now say she has served the proper seven-year sentence. Ms. Olson was released to her husband, Dr. Gerald Peterson, a corrections spokeswoman said.

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who had surgery last month for pancreatic cancer, said she would undergo a “precautionary” course of chemotherapy. Justice Ginsburg, 76. who has not missed any of the Supreme Court’s public sessions, said she did not expect the treatments to affect her schedule. The treatments will start late this month at the National Institutes of Health, she said. “Thereafter, it is anticipated that I will require only routine examinations to assure my continuing good health,” Justice Ginsburg said.

Federal prosecutors said they would not bring charges against Brian Nichols, the Atlanta courthouse gunman who avoided the death penalty last year after he was convicted of murdering four people. A United States attorney, David Nahmias, said there were too many hurdles to securing a death sentence against Mr. Nichols, 37, who was sentenced to life without parole in December for the 2005 killings. But Mr. Nahmias did not rule out a federal prosecution, saying he would reconsider bringing charges if Mr. Nichols challenged his sentence or “if his security situation changes.”.

The Humane Society of the United States has accused the Petland pet store chain of scheming to sell sick puppies bred in filthy conditions to thousands of unsuspecting people. Petland intentionally misled thousands of customers into believing the puppies came from the finest breeders and were healthy, the Humane Society said in a lawsuit against the company, which is based in Chillicothe. The group said an investigation showed that many of the puppies sold by Petland in its 131 stores in the United States were bred in mills in horrific conditions or through brokers. The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Phoenix by lawyers for the Humane Society and pet owners who say they were sold sick puppies. Petland called the accusations false.
The space shuttle Discovery has arrived at the International Space Station to deliver one last set of solar wings that should boost the orbiting complex to full power.
The investor, known for piquant and unsparing criticism of his own performance, has not spoken much on the Moody’s credit rating agency, of which he owns a 20 percent stake.

An Air Force nurse has been charged with giving lethal amounts of medication to three terminally ill patients in his care, military officials said. The nurse, Capt. Michael Fontana, 35, was formally charged in military court with deliberately giving three patients at Wilford Hall Medical Center lethal amounts of medication, and with conduct unbecoming an officer for allegedly changing a medical document. Wilford Hall, at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio, is the Air Force’s largest hospital. An Article 32 hearing, the military equivalent to a grand jury proceeding, will be conducted, and the commander will decide whether the case goes to court-martial.

A former leader of the New Mexico Senate was sentenced to five and one-half years in prison for his role in a scheme to defraud the state of $4 million in a courthouse construction project. The ex-official, Manny Aragon, Democrat of Albuquerque, had served 29 years in the Senate. He and seven others were accused of conspiring to use inflated and false invoices to skim public money meant for construction of the Bernalillo County Metropolitan Courthouse in Albuquerque. All have pleaded guilty. Mr. Aragon, accused of pocketing $650,000 in the scheme, pleaded guilty last year to conspiracy and mail fraud. Aside from the prison sentence, he was fined $750,000 and ordered to pay at least $649,000 in restitution.

The operator of the first passenger-vehicle ferry between major Hawaiian islands will stop its service after a court ruled it unfairly was allowed to bypass an environmental review. Hawaii Superferry said it had decided “to cease operations for the present” in the wake of the State Supreme Court ruling. The Superferry, a car and passenger service that links Oahu and Maui and hopes to expand, has been under fire from critics who argue the use of 350-foot catamaran could harm whales and contribute to overcrowding in the area.
A Texas man pleaded guilty in Federal District Court to three counts of making and possessing a Molotov cocktail during the Republican National Convention in St. Paul in September.

The Postal Service said economic woes were forcing it to delay the release of several new stamps scheduled for this year. The Postal Service lost $2.8 billion last year and is facing even larger losses this year, despite a rate increase — to 44 cents for first-class mail — scheduled to take effect May 11. A spokesman, Roy Betts, said the fourth set of the “Flags of Our Nation” series had been postponed until 2010. The set includes the flags of Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New Mexico, New York and North Carolina. It was not clear if the flag stamps originally planned for 2010 will also be delayed. In addition, a stamp honoring the painter Edward Hopper and a holiday stamp featuring an angel playing a lute have been dropped from the 2009 plans.

Week 2 of “Dancing With the Stars” remained atop the ratings on Monday night, garnering 21.1 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The network easily led Monday night over all even as its new crime show, “Castle,” (11.5 million), trailed CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (13.3 million) during the 10 p.m. hour. “Castle” did show slight improvement over its debut last week. Fox was runner-up for the night with “House” at 8 (12.8 million) and “24” at 9 (11.3 million). CBS finished a close third thanks to “CSI: Miami” and its comedy lineup, which included “Two and a Half Men” at 9 (14 million) and “Rules of Engagement” at 9:30 (11.4 million). NBC ranked a distant fourth with repeats.

The coming season finales of the ABC comedies “Scrubs” and “According to Jim” are expected to be the last episodes of both shows, Variety reported. “Scrubs,” the hospital comedy starring Zach Braff, below, and Sarah Chalke, which moved to ABC this year after a seven-year run on NBC, will conclude its eighth season on May 6. “According to Jim,” which stars Jim Belushi and is one of a dwindling number of traditional multicamera situation comedies still on network television, will end its eighth season on May 5. A spokeswoman for ABC said that neither series had been officially canceled and that the network would announce its fall lineup in May. ABC also announced that “Lost” would conclude its fifth season with a two-hour finale on May 13, as would “Desperate Housewives” on May 17, and that “Ugly Betty” would return to its schedule on May 7.

EMI Music Publishing said that it had signed a deal with the estate of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to represent the civil rights leader’s intellectual property. In a news release, EMI, which handles publishing rights for musical artists like Beyoncé and Kanye West as well as songs like “Over the Rainbow” and “I Heard It Through the Grapevine,” said it would represent the use of Dr. King’s words in recordings and music as well as his words and image in online and digital media. EMI said it would also work with Intellectual Properties Management, an Atlanta company that licenses Dr. King’s image, likeness and recorded voice for nonmusical works. In recent years samples of Dr. King’s speeches have turned up in songs like “Long Way to Go” by Gwen Stefani and “Madagascar” by Guns N’ Roses.

After her lawyer apologized for her late arrival, Ms. Winehouse appeared in the City of Westminster Magistrates’ Court, where she confirmed her name and date of birth and entered her plea. A judge released her on bail and ordered her to return for a hearing on July 23.

For Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez, a cover story and eye-opening photo shoot for Details magazine could hardly have come at a less opportune time. He agreed to the project in late December, when it may have seemed like a good way to raise his fashion profile. Instead, he sat for the interview on Feb. 5, the day he found out that his positive test for steroids in 2003 would soon be publicly disclosed. For Details, the timing was splendid.

philippine clashes Clashes between government troops and the terrorist group Abu Sayyaf continued in the southern Philippines on Tuesday, killing at least 3 soldiers and wounding at least 19 people, officials said. The fighting in Sulu Province entered a second day as the Philippine military tried to rescue three Red Cross workers who were kidnapped in January by Abu Sayyaf. Lt. Col. Leonardo Teodoro said that the hostages had not been harmed.

CARPENTER--Harlow, co-founder and Vice President of the Sugarbush Ski Area and Sugarbush Golf Club in Warren, Vermont and grandson of Harlow E. Bundy, founder of the Bundy Time Recording Company which later became IBM, died on March 13, 2009 in Exeter, NH, where he lived. He was 82 years old. The cause was lung failure. Born in Los Angeles on October 20, 1926, Carpenter was a noted Modernist sculptor and architect. He received a Master of Architecture degree from Harvard University's Graduate School of Design in 1956. At his suggestion, his parents, Alfred and Helen Bundy Carpenter, donated the building known as the Carpenter Center for the Visual Arts in 1961 to Harvard University, which is to this day the only building in the United States designed by the Swiss-French Modernist architect, Le Corbusier. In the late 1950s, Carpenter moved to Vermont where he became the largest financial investor of the founding team for the Sugarbush Ski Area and Sugarbush Golf Club in Warren, Vermont. With his strong vision for bringing the arts to rural Vermont, he later founded, designed and curated for the Bundy Art Gallery in 1962 in Waitsfield. In addition to housing his private Modern and contemporary art collection, the Gallery promoted the work of younger artists as well as provided the venue for the Vermont Symphony's summer concert series. The Bundy also served as a small, experimental school for K-6th graders during the academic year. Carpenter's early commitment to the environment was evidenced by the installation of the area's first wind generator, built on the Gallery's property. Carpenter was a renowned Modernist sculptor in New England, the subject of two television documentaries whose work was exhibited in numerous shows and exhibitions. His medium of choice was welded metal, composed mostly from used farm equipment. Carpenter served in the US Army during World War II where he was based in the Marshall Islands at the time of first atomic bomb tests. He was an avid horseman, founding the Sugarbush Polo Club in Vermont as well as the Green Mountain Hounds Fox Hunt. Later when he moved to Massachusetts and New Hampshire, he was an active participant in the Myopia Hunt and Myopia Polo in Hamilton, MA as well as several hunts in the Orange, VA area. He is survived, loved and missed by his wife, Barbara Carpenter, his stepson Nicholas Parker, his son Sebastian Carpenter, daughter Julia Carpenter, and three grandchildren. He is also survived by stepdaughter Lily Minas and stepson Matthew Esmiol. A celebration of his life will take place at his farm in Kensington, NH on April 26th at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to OdysseyNH.

ROASTS should be fairly simple, but that doesn't mean you're limited to shoving a hunk of meat into the oven and cooking it until it's done. The incredible truth is that you can make an impressive roast without any complicated butchery. I found this out 40 years ago (gulp) while following a recipe I found in the Time-Life cooking series, a wonderful cooking school in print, at least of the era. I shoved the narrow end of a wooden spoon through the center of a pork roast horizontally, filled the cavity it created with a combination of apricots and prunes, and roasted it.

SEGUI--Charles Joseph, age 79 died on February 19. The son of Carlos Mateo Segui and Margaret Hennessy, brother of Jeanne McBee. Charles was born in New York City on December 31, 1929 and grew up in Great Neck, New York. He attended La Salle Military Academy then continued to Lehigh University. He graduated from Lehigh in 1951, entered the Counter Intelligence Corps serving in Japan. He joined Paine Weber in 1953 advancing to Vice President. He left to join E.F. Hutton in 1985 and retired from Morgan Stanley as Senior V.P. in December 2008. He was an avid skier and loved the arts, biking, fishing, travel, Japan, his family and friends. A kind gentleman, loyal friend and the most devoted and loving father and grandfather anyone could have. He is survived by daughters, Sabrina and Cynthia Segui, Desiree Girifalco, his son-in-law Michael Girifalco and two adored grandchildren, Joseph and Ann Girifalco. He is also survived by his dear and beloved friend and companion Catherine Schnee. Donations may be made in his honor to Lehigh University, Bethlehem, PA 18015

SMITH--David L.,died on March 14, after a year of declining health. Visionary leader, president and chairman of the board for over 20 years of Penn South, where he led the successful fight to maintain it as a limited equity housing cooperative in Chelsea, and thus maintain it as affordable housing, one of the last of its kind. He was the innovator behind the building of the cogeneration plant, helped organize a senior center, promoted a naturally occurring retirement community within the complex, and was instrumental in organizing the Coordinating Council of Cooperatives, a meeting ground for cooperative housing leaders citywide. He fought against racial discrimination in housing in Stuyvesent Town in the late 1940s/early 1950s. Was active in the nation's cooperative movement for which he was inducted to the National Cooperative Business Association Hall of Fame in 1995 and honored by the National Association of Housing Cooperatives in 2008. Devoted husband for 56 years to Esther Smith who died in 2001, he is survived by his two daughters, Karen and Abby Smith, his son-in-law Maarten de Kadt his grandchildren Jesse Campoamor and Sonja de Kadt, sister-in-law Elleanor Tilson and the Tilson family and his companion from 2002 to his death, Tess Sacher. Dave spent his entire life fighting for social justice. He was an innovator, a leader and a kind and generous man. He will be greatly missed. A memorial to be held on Saturday, May 9, from 3:30 to 5:30pm at the Haft Auditorium at Fashion Institute of Technology, on 27 Street near 7th Avenue.

Honor guards with a picture of Mohammad Daoud Khan, Afghanistan's first president, marched Tuesday in a ceremony in Kabul to give him and those who died with him a proper burial. Mr. Daoud Khan and 17 family members were killed during a coup in 1978 and buried in secret. The remains of all but one of them were discovered in a mass grave last year and unearthed.

As I tasted the reds from Bierzo, I wanted food that was dark, rich and earthy. Why not morcilla -- Spanish blood sausage? A plate of nicely seared morcilla, or French boudin noir, would be enough alongside these wines. But in this dish of chicken on a bed of cannellini beans, the morcilla provides just an accent, albeit forceful, like a spoonful of horseradish on boiled beef. Another kind of sausage -- or none at all -- could be used, though it would change the dish's character and color.

In his blog, the Pour, Eric Asimov discussed a problem of ordering wine in restaurants: When I'm in a restaurant, I want to receive the wine list and menu simultaneously. I want the option of looking at the wine list first -- yes, sometimes I like to choose the bottle and then design the menu around the wine -- or the food first. Then I would like to have the option of discussing choices with my dining partners.

FOR generations, vacationers in Maine and visitors to Pennsylvania's Amish country have found a simple black and white snack in restaurants and convenience shops and on nearly every gas station counter: whoopie pies. They were found in other pockets of the country, too, from New England to Ohio. But in most of the United States, people could be forgiven for not knowing that the whoopie pie is not, in fact, a pie at all. (It is sometimes described as a cookie, but that is not quite right, either. The closest description may be a cake-like sandwich, or perhaps a sandwich-like cake.)

DALRYMPLE--Dennis M.,died Thursday, March 5, in New York City. He was 67. He is survived by his wife, Jamie Raab, and their children, son Ian Dalrymple and daughter Lola Dalrymple. The cause of death was a cerebral hemorrhage. In a forty year career in book publishing as a literary contracts expert, he consulted with hundreds of authors, publishers and literary agents. He worked with such companies as Avon Books, Dell Publishing and Harper and Row (now HarperCollins), and then joined Warner Books as Director of Contracts where he stayed for 17 years. There, he met his wife, Jamie Raab, who is currently Publisher of Grand Central Books (formerly Warner Books). He was born in Waterloo, Iowa to Dwight Marion Dalrymple and Willa (Bette) Rasche, and grew up in Sarasota, Florida, before moving to New York City. Dennis loved New York City with the passion of a transplant, living first in Greenwich Village and in recent years on the Upper West Side. Mr. Dalrymple was a longtime anti-war activist who never met a war he wasn't prepared to protest. He was a founding member of the Youth International Party, its members known as Yippies, formed in 1967 by leftists and cultural icons Jerry Rubin, Abbie Hoffman and Paul Krassner to radicalize hippie youth to protest the Vietnam War. He also nominated Pigasus the Pig for President at the 1968 convention. Mr. Dalrymple was an avid news junkie, an expert cook, a loyal friend, and, most of all, a devoted husband and father. Mr. Dalrymple is also survived by his sister, Sandra Scanlan; his stepmother, Marion Dalrymple; his four half sisters Jennifer Heit, Julie Rexford, Jere Gilbert and Jane Murphy. A memorial services will be held on Thursday, March 19th at 4 pm at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South in New York City.

KOEPPEL--Adolph, 85, attorney and founder of the law firm, Koeppel, Sommer, Martone, Leistman, a pioneer in the real estate tax certiorari and condemnation law passed away on March 14, 2009. Koeppel received his LLB from NYU Law School in 1948, and his LLM from NYU in 1953. He ran for Town Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead in 1953. He was former assistant Nassau County Attorney from 1963 - 1967, and former Village Attorney of the town of Lake Success from 1968 - 1977. He served in the Navy during World War II and received a medal for his service on D-day and also served at Okinawa and the Philipines on the Destroyer USS Barton. He was a known fiscal philatelist who wrote several books including The Stamps that Caused The American Revolution in 1976, and The Stamps of the Princely States of India for which he received the Earl of Crawford Award by the Royal Philatelic Society. Koeppel was a great humanitarian and patron of the arts. He was one of the early sponsors of the opera night at the Tilles Center at C.W Post College. He supported many charities including The National Children's Defense Fund and the Southern Poverty Law Center. He was born on April 11, 1923. He was a great amateur golfer, and an avid reader. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Rhoda Koeppel, his daughters Lesley Hirsch, Pamela Koeppel, his granddaughters Melissa Grubb, Jennifer Parham, Tara Robinson, his great-grandsons Parker Doyle, and Etienne Parham, his son-in-law Michael Hirsch, and his grandson-in-law Steven Parham, and Kenny Doyle, his great-grandson's father. He is, also, survived by his younger sister Seena Ostroff, his brothers-in-law Herbert Ostroff and Herbert Rubin, Martine Arnoux, his nieces, nephews, friends, assistant Susan Shapiro and his confidant Richard Reichler. Funeral services will be held at Riverdale Chapel in Great Neck on Wednesday, March 18, at 10am.

arms verdict A Palestinian-born businessman was convicted in New York on Tuesday on charges that he conspired with the Syrian arms dealer Monzer al-Kassar in a plot to sell weapons, including 15 surface-to-air missiles, to a Colombian terrorist organization. The businessman, Tareq Mousa al-Ghazi, was told that the arms would be used to kill American military officers, the evidence showed. Mr. Ghazi is the third man found guilty in connection with the plot.

Eight-year-old Jason Burke marched with the Roisin Dubh Irish Pipe Band of East Islip, N.Y. during the St. Patrick's Day parade in Manhattan. The annual parade drew tens of thousands of people, who lined up along Fifth Avenue, bottom right, including Meggan McQuillan, bottom left, and her grandmother, Rita Royle. The festive mood of the procession, believed to be the 248th, was tempered somewhat by the deteriorating economy in both the United States and Ireland. More photographs are at nytimes.com/ cityroom.

KARIM--Sayyid Anwarul, 81, of Riverdale, NY passed away on March 17 of cancer. Born in 1928, S.A. Karim was a career diplomat, international civil servant, and author. He became a member of the Pakistan Foreign Service in 1950 and was serving in New York as the Deputy Permanent Representative of Pakistan to the United Nations when the Bangladesh liberation war broke out. He left the Pakistan Foreign Service to join the liberation movement and became Bangladesh's first Foreign Secretary in 1972 after Bangladesh gained its independence. Soon after, he was named the first Permanent Observer for Bangladesh to the UN, helping secure entrance for Bangladesh into the UN in 1974 and becoming the country's first Permanent Representative and Ambassador to Myanmar. He went on to serve at the UN as a development adviser to certain African nations. In 2005, S.A. Karim authored "Sheikh Mujib: Triumph and Tragedy", the definitive biography on the life of Sheikh Mujib, Bangladesh's founding father. He studied at the Universities of Calcutta (Presidency College) and Dhaka as well as the London School of Economics. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Ayesha; three sons; four grandchildren; and two brothers, S.A. Azim and S.A. Hafiz. A religious service will be held today, 10am at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, NY 10704 (914)375-1400 www.ruggieroandsonsfh.com. Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, NY.

TROSKY--Helene, passed away peacefully on March 15 at age 91, following a brief illness. She lived an extraordinary life of art, music, travel, love and friendship. An accomplished print and paper maker, her work is in numerous private and public collections. During her lifetime of support for the arts she served as board chairwoman of the Westchester Art Society, a director of Music for Westchester, an executive of the Sleepy Hollow Theater and on various committees of the Regional Plan association and many educational and arts organizations. She was a well known art restorer, writer and lecturer and frequently led art tours in Europe. More than her accomplishments, she will be remembered for her extraordinary flair, humor and warmth, which drew and held friends and family for life. She is survived by countless nieces, nephews and cousins, all of whom she touched and hold dear their memories of this great lady. Graveside services will be held on Wednesday, March 18 at 2pm at the Daniel Webster Benevolent Society section of Mount Zion Cemetery in Maspeth, Queens, NY. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date.

Left, a worker at Lee Spring in Brooklyn inspects a spring; right, wire for making springs is run into a machine from large spools. Lee Spring has been in Brooklyn since its founding in 1918. When the company planned to move its operation last year, it was courted with incentives to go to New Jersey or Connecticut, said its chief executive, Steve Kempf. But it stayed in Brooklyn and moved its headquarters and production plant only as far as the Brooklyn Army Terminal, in recognition of its history in the borough and to retain a skilled work force of more than 100 people. The Brooklyn operation produces millions of springs a year, and the company has sites in several other states and countries. In the current Lens series, Richard Perry is scouring the five boroughs for the Made in New York label: nytimes.com/cityroom.
ROSENFIELD--Nancy. Thanks for the memories, Nupp. Mike, Jeanny, Micheline, Bart, Catherine and Michael
JOYCE--Michael. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael Joyce, associated with The New York Times from December 1, 1969 until retiring on January 1, 2006.

10 P.M. (Discovery) GLOBAL WARMING: THE NEW CHALLENGE WITH TOM BROKAW In this follow-up to his Emmy Award-winning 2006 program, ''Global Warming: What You Need to Know With Tom Brokaw,'' Mr. Brokaw (above right, with Michael Oppenheimer, a climate scientist), interviews experts about what Americans should be prepared for in the coming years and how climate change is shaping the inner workings of the nation, from New York City to Yellowstone National Park and the Everglades. The program also looks at promising scientific, technological and economic advances in the fight against global warming. 11 A.M. (NBC) THE MARTHA STEWART SHOW It's dogs today with Martha. There will be a dog show and new pet products, and training questions will be answered.

ROSENTHAL--Lester, D.D.S.,on March 15, 2009. Past president of Greater NY Academy of Prosthodontics, Professor at Columbia University, NY University, Albert Einstein College of Medicine and NY VA Hospital. Beloved husband of Elissa; loving father of Iris, Randi, Kara, Maxine and father-in-law of Robert and Howard; cherished grandfather of Jason, Ashley, Lucas, Rachel, Cory and Alexa. Services Wednesday, 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

VALLE--Luis A. 1907-2009. Beloved uncle and family patriarch. Graduate of New York University, St. Johns University Law School. World War II Naval intelligence veteran. Worked 50 years as assistant treasurer at the Alvin Theater (now the Neil Simon). A lifelong member of the Treasurers and Ticketsellers Union, Local 751, an affiliate of AFL/CIO. He loved life and was loved by all. Will be deeply mourned by family and friends.

TURETSKY--Noemie. Temple Israel Center of White Plains mourns the passing of Noemie Turetsky, wife of our late beloved Rabbi Emeritus Arnold Turetsky. Noemie was a model of elegance, compassion, and devotion to family, community, and the Jewish people. We will never forget the gifts that she lovingly gave to our synagogue for nearly four decades. Our heartfelt condolences go to Justin, Jonathan and Wendy, Daniel and Andrea, David and Jill, sister Lilly Tempelsman, and the grandchildren. May her soul be bound up in the bond of life. Gordon Tucker, Senior Rabbi Neil Zuckerman, Rabbi Mark Zeichner, President
The Wheel: Stark, eloquent Cash echoes.

With only two shows in Austin, the singer-songwriter St. Vincent — born Annie Clark — has had the luxury of actually seeing other bands. She turned up at the Decemberists on Wednesday night and checked out her friends the Dirty Projectors at the NPR showcase on Thursday afternoon, a pretty enviable schedule. But she also has the benefit of festival experience: for several years she toured as part of the blissed-out collective the Polyphonic Spree. Before her solo show on Wednesday at the Central Presbyterian Church, she talked in the green room — if a church can have a green room — about how performing with them turned her into a guitar nerd. And don’t be fooled by the confluence of setting and stage name: Though St. Vincent is the patron saint of charity, Ms. Clark said her inspiration was not the patron saint of charity but the hospital where Dylan Thomas died. (Though she did notice a typo in the Ten Commandments poster hanging in the church: “You shall no other gods before me.”)

An unfortunate consequence of seeing so many shows so quickly is that your mind goes into compartmentalization overdrive. This group is retro-electro-funk, that one is Velvet Underground-meets-Spacemen 3, another is hipster Appalachia, and so on. You yearn for a band that can’t be reduced so easily, that isn’t retro anything, that can truly dazzle you with mystery and originality.

On this week’s Popcast, Ben Ratliff reviews the album “Beware” by the singer-songwriter Will Oldham’s alter-ego Bonnie “Prince” Billy; Jon Pareles on “Cuculand”, a new solo album from the Yerba Buena frontwoman CuCu Diamantes; and the Danish pop singer Tina Dico talks to Ben Sisario and performs the song “No Time to Sleep” in our studio.

There’s nothing like a jolt of post-punk dissonance to start South by Southwest, so I went for a double dose, in two distinct forms. The first was from Abe Vigoda, a California band that definitely knows how to tangle guitars. Its songs take an insistent, slightly asymmetrical guitar line, usually in a major key, that would be bright and pointed on its own. Then they throw on another line, equally jaunty but ending up dissonant where it scrapes up against the first riff. Those are driven by galloping drumbeats in lockstep with a peppy bass line, and topped with eagerly unkempt vocals and lyrics like “Tell us the future.” In their high-octane minimalism, the songs hurtle forward, neatly constructed but still reckless.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Thursday morning.

There’s something prosaically magical about music under a tin roof. Austin, with a tolerable public and an even more tolerable climate, tends to push music outside, behind many of its bars. There are some fancy decks here and there, but many are not more than pads of concrete, some chairs and yes, a tin roof. It’s probably not the most sonically subtle material, but yesterday, with the sun beating down and South by Southwest heating up, many corrugated canopies rattled and hummed.
“Some people freeze when they get their big shot here and others just step up and take it.”— Louis Black, a founder of South by Southwest, last night

At South by Southwest, the Central Presbyterian Church is almost always going to be a tough ticket. The bookings are carefully curated, the acoustics are great and the space is finite. But it was a whole order of tough outside the M. Ward gig last night. Wristbands and badges, the coin of the realm here, were all nigh useless as a crowd surrounded the church like a moat. And as it turned out, there was good reason to try and fight your way in. The violinist and vocalist Anni Rossi, who was signed by 4AD Records out of Minnesota – embraced the churchy vibe, sending ethereal sounds up into the rafters as people sat quietly before exploding with applause. And the reverence went up a notch when M. Ward came out. A huge cross was the only splash of light in the dimly lit church, apart from the flashes of cameras. The singer said very little, but played an exquisite set, including a Neil Young cover and guitar work that demonstrated that all those great words come from a very musical place. On “Sad, Sad Song,” he sang, “the hardest thing in the world to do is to find somebody believes in you.” Less hard, it should be pointed out, when you are in a church full of believers.

What happened to the rock star, the kind who sets about profane mischief? At the Club Deville yesterday, it seemed like he had a sex change and came back as a girl group. In a world of emo-boys and reluctant band leaders, Those Darlins, country-punk pals from Murfreesboro, Tenn., had a comically leering sexuality and the kind of abandon that seems scarce these days. Their punk hootenanny sensibility reminds us that you don’t have to act serious to be taken seriously. South by Southwest, with its quick set ups and tear downs, is always technically challenged, but when these girls blew an amp, they vamped with the kind of jokes and entreaties that can’t be rendered here. Their feature slot at the Brooklyn Vegan party was probably a big deal, but they didn’t act like it, mixing it up with one another and the crowd. After they borrowed an amp from their friends and tour mates in Deer Tick, they borrowed the whole band as well, with the boys serving as accessories as the girls sang a kind of homage to a bird:

While we continue to wait for the white smoke to rise from the chimney of Andrew Lloyd Webber, alerting us that “Love Never Dies,” his long-promised sequel to “The Phantom of the Opera,” has found its theaters, its stars and its opening dates, a casting notice on the Web site of Actors’ Equity Association offers more details about the new musical.

Once, “Behind the Music” was a high-flying VH1 television documentary series, with a tried-and-true formula about the dramatic ascents and abrupt declines of popular musicians told through bombastic narration and soft-focus interviews. Then, it all came crashing down. But now it’s back: The Hollywood Reporter said that VH1 would order about 10 new episodes of “Behind the Music,” which would chronicle the ups and downs of performers like Scott Weiland and Lil Wayne. “We always hear about the show, even now,” said Jim Olde, VH1’s executive vice president for original programming, according to The Hollywood Reporter. “It’s amazing how much affection viewers have for it.” Jim Forbes, who provided the show’s distinctive voiceovers in its original run, will return as the narrator of the series.
Four-word reviews, Wednesday night.

Who says the traditional multi-camera sitcom and its accompanying laugh track are endangered species? Over at TV Decoder, Brian Stelter reports (in front of a live studio audience) that CBS has renewed its hit comedy “Two and a Half Men” for three additional seasons. He writes:

Workers of the world, unite and sing! A Chinese director is preparing an operatic adaptation of “Das Kapital,” Karl Marx‘s treatise on economy, capitalism and the alienation of labor, The Telegraph reported. The production will borrow elements from Broadway and Las Vegas musicals, and will add a plot to Marx’s text, first published in 1867, about a business whose workers discover they are being exploited. After turning to Marxist theory, some of the workers rebel against their employer, while others turn to collective bargaining. According to The Telegraph, the opera’s director, He Nian, told the Chinese newspaper Wen Hui Bao, “The particular performance style we choose is not important, but Marx’s theories cannot be distorted.” The opera is planned to open in Shanghai next year.

Can you wear 3D glasses with your micro-bikinis on the ultra-trendy beaches of Cannes? Disney-Pixar announced that a 3D presentation of its coming animated feature “Up” has been selected as the opening night premiere of this year’s Cannes Film Festival. In a release, the studio said that the film, directed by Pete Docter (“Monsters, Inc.”), about a 78-year-old man who embarks on a journey by tying thousands of balloons to his house, would be shown at the festival’s opening night ceremony on May 13. Disney said it was the first time that either an animated feature or a 3D feature had been selected as the opening night film, though animated movies including “Dumbo,” “Fritz the Cat” and “Waltz With Bashir” have previously been shown at Cannes. “Up” is scheduled to open in the United States on May 29.
With all the music played, heard and appreciated at SXSW, it’s easy to forget that the festival is also a stress test for songs and performers.

SXSW and NPR have a good thing going. They team up to Webcast a full set by a well-known band, which in turn takes the opportunity to introduce an entire new album on the eve of its release. This year it was the Decemberists, from Portland, OR, on Wednesday night in the backyard amphitheater at Stubb’s, playing through their album due for release March 24, “The Hazards of Love” (Capitol). (The Webcast is available for a free download at nprmusic.org, and presumably the band considers it no threat to sales of the studio album. A second live NPR Webcast, including another Portland band, Blitzen Trapper, along with Dirty Projectors from New York and the South African progressive rockers BLK JKS, begins Thursday at 1:30 p.m. Eastern time).
When, if ever, will American theaters see the release of Natasha Richardson‘s last movie? Over at the Carpetbagger, Michael Cieply reports that even the studio that produced it isn’t sure:

“Vetiver will be making the pilgrimage to that drunken orgy of musical mayhem fondly known as SXSW,” Andy Cabic wrote on the his band Vetiver’s blog recently. In the midst of a tour supporting their forthcoming album, “Tight Knit,” the group will be playing eight shows in Austin in the coming days. Outside of Emo’s, preparing for their second show, Mr. Cabic shared his thoughts about the festival. No drunken mayhem for him: between sets, he plans to “be mindful” and drink water. “Water is relaxing,” he said.

There were long-haired dudes in the altars for the Department of Eagles show at the Central Presbyterian Church on Wednesday night, and they were appropriately reverential: comparatively few people were checking their phones or Twittering. Well, except for Ed Droste, the frontman of Grizzly Bear, a hot ticket band which shares some members with Department of Eagles, who updated his feed: “Department of Eagles aced it, love that last one,” he Tweeted around midnight. “Getting into church Shows=crazy security.”

John Haddad watched as two masters rolled cigars at his smoke shop on Sixth Street yesterday, the epicenter of much of the music here in Austin. He stepped in when an interviewer’s Spanish proved insufficient.

Broadway theaters will dim their marquees at 8 p.m. Thursday for exactly one minute to honor the life and acting career of Natasha Richardson, the Tony Award-winning actress who died Wednesday. Ms. Richardson, who was 45, won a Tony for best actress in a musical for her turn as Sally Bowles in “Cabaret” in 1998 and also drew high praise on Broadway for her lead performances in revivals of Eugene O’Neill’s “Anna Christie” and Tennessee Williams’s “Streetcar Named Desire.” In a statement, Charlotte St. Martin, executive director of the industry group the Broadway League, said: “The Broadway community is shocked and deeply saddened by the tragic loss of one of our finest young actresses, Natasha Richardson. Her theatrical lineage is legendary, but her own singular talent shined memorably on any stage she appeared.”
It’s not the live performance he was hoping for, but as close as he can get.
A few stray bands:

The BLK JKS (pronounced black jacks), a quartet from Johannesburg, South Africa, sound a little like Mars Volta and started off sort of jammy at NPR’s afternoon showcase at the Parish on Thursday. But by their second song, the drummer was thrashing his dreads – how often does public radio bring that out? (Vermont listeners excepted.)

A relative of John Dillinger waged a court battle, forcing changes in an exhibit about the alleged killer.
Exhibits for Lincoln celebrating the bicentennial year of his birth have sprouted all over the United States.
In the spring, the Norman Rockwell Museum will reopen the artist’s studio on the grounds of the museum, and it will look just as it did in October 1960.
“Abraham Lincoln in New York” is an exhibit at the Federal Hall National Memorial presented by The Rail Splitter, a national organization of Lincoln Scholars.

Opposition leaders in Zimbabwe have made strides in reviving the country’s school system but warn that the progress will be short lived without more aid.

MINNEAPOLIS -- Until a bout of pneumonia and a mild form of mononucleosis interrupted his season in mid-January, Michigan State's Raymar Morgan was leading the Spartans in scoring and shooting 60 percent from the field.

Evan Longoria, a third baseman for the Tampa Bay Rays, has agreed to join the injury-ravaged United States team for the semifinal round of the World Baseball Classic this weekend. Longoria is expected to be in Los Angeles on Friday. The Americans will play the winner of Thursday's South Korea-Japan game on Sunday.

The Quad will be providing commentary and updates throughout the first day of the N.C.A.A. tournament from reporters in each region. Aside from winning the Horizon Conference tournament, the highlight of Cleveland State's season came from beating Syracuse, 72-69, on a 60-foot shot in December. So how hard is it to drill a shot from the opposite foul line?
Authoritarian leaders all over the world take steps to create a veneer of democracy. Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi outdoes almost all of them.

Since Israel ended its assault on Gaza, Palestinians and international rights groups have accused it of using excessive force that resulted in a high number of civilian casualties. The Israeli military has denied these charges, but now testimony is emerging from soldiers, indicating that some of these claims have merit.

TAMPA, Fla. -- Jorge Posada has been batting first lately, to get as many at-bats as possible before leaving the game when he reaches a set number of innings behind the plate. That means the "Hip, hip, Jorge!" chants start early around Steinbrenner Field.
Pioneer's highly regarded plasma TVs are leaving the scene as the company exits the television business. But with Panasonic's new plasma lineup, few may notice.

LOS ANGELES - When he was a candidate for president, Barack Obama's advisers often cautioned him not to be too wonky when he went on television talk shows. He was having none of that on Thursday, when he appeared as the sole guest on "The Tonight Show," with Jay Leno.
Moving from the endangered-species list to extinct is the British International Motor Show in London.
Millions of Americans are discovering talk isn't cheap, at least on their mobile phones.

An auction of items from the late fashion designer Gianni Versace's Lake Como villa raised £7.4 million (about $10.7 million) in an auction Wednesday, far exceeding expectations.

We recently detailed UConn's ability to avoid fouls (it averaged a national low of 12.1 fouls per game during the regular season) and its ability to force fouls on the opponent. On average, UConn was called for 8.5 fewer fouls than the opponent.

Madrid | Though born in Barcelona, Julio González seems right at home in Madrid's Reina Sofia Museum. The museum has just opened a major retrospective of this influential sculptor's works, which have a sense of freedom and inventiveness -- especially his pioneering steel sculptures from the 1930s -- that fit right in alongside the likes of Picasso, Dalí, and Miró.

The Senate, by unanimous consent, has approved the nominations of John Holdren as President Obama's science adviser and Jane Lubchenco as the administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, according to the office of Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader. I'll be posting a short interview here later with Dr. Lubchenco, a biologist from Oregon State University who has also worked to improve the communication skills of young scientists.

I had previously pointed out that many of the new features in Apple's 3.0 iPhone software upgrade, scheduled for release this summer, add functions that should have been on the phone long ago, like cut-and-paste and a landscape keyboard.

The Senate voted 61-31 to confirm Elena Kagan, who had been dean of Harvard Law School, as the solicitor general of the United States.

Marc S. Dreier, the prominent Manhattan lawyer accused of cheating hedge funds out of hundreds of millions of dollars, is likely to forgo a trial and change his plea to guilty, his attorney told a federal judge on Thursday.

Like restaurants less gilded, Per Se has been feeling the effects of the recession, and has been feeling the need to adjust.

Updated, 7:07 p.m. | On the eve of the sixth anniversary of the United States invasion of Iraq, hundreds of protesters in New York City made it clear on Thursday that while they welcomed the change in American political leadership, they would not relent in urging President Obama to accelerate the withdrawal of combat forces from Iraq.

And she knows -- most of all -- that now maybe is not the best time to begin paying tens of thousands of dollars a year in tuition at a private university.

Hevesi, the former New York State comptroller, were charged on Thursday in a 123-count indictment that said they had turned New York's $120 billion pension fund into a criminal enterprise that netted them and other Hevesi associates tens of millions of dollars in kickbacks from firms investing the fund's money, including the Carlyle Group.

Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein has announced the location of three new citywide gifted programs that will open in September to kindergartners and first graders who earn top scores on entrance exams.

A tsunami was generated after a 7.9 magnitude earthquake struck at 2:17 p.m. Eastern time beneath the sea near the volcanic eruption in waters near Tonga. A tsunami alert for areas outside the immediate region was canceled six minutes after an initial bulletin was issued.

Those French do know how to get under their leaders' skin. Apparently, President Nicolas Sarkozy's well-known hatred for "La Princesse de Clèves" has inspired thousands of readers to reacquaint themselves with Madame de La Fayette's 17th-century classic.

The Senate passed the omnibus public lands bill today, on a vote of 77-20, virtually ensuring that the bill creating new national parks and designating millions of acres as wilderness will become law sometime soon.
