Updated, 5:24 p.m. | Citing "unprecedented financial challenges," the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation announced on Thursday a plan to lay off 200 workers and eliminate another 200 positions through attrition, part of a move to close a $316 million budget gap. Faced with growing public anger over its executive bonuses, the American International Group warned its employees to be careful about their safety during a protest on Thursday afternoon at its headquarters at 70 Pine Street in Downtown Manhattan.

Human rights groups and an American-financed radio station report that an Iranian blogger, Omidreza Mirsayafi, who had been sentenced to two years in prison for insulting the country's leaders, died in Tehran's Evin Prison on Wednesday.

Chrysler said Thursday that it would no longer pay retention bonuses to key executives and that its proposed partner, Fiat of Italy, would assume 35 percent of its debt to the United States government.

Just got back from Montreal, where hockey is so exhaustively and smartly lived, breathed and covered. It's a real pleasure to be in a place like that -- but of course, not everything that's said there is entirely smart. Like the radio commentator who complained on Wednesday that the night before a recent game against Boston, he actually saw a Hab and a Bruin out together at a Montreal club. Unthinkable! What is wrong with today's players?!!

William Zinsser worked as a journalist for years before coming to Yale in 1970. In the winter term of 1971, he offered a course called simply "nonfiction workshop." Teaching from his own experience and concentrating on the common forms of nonfiction, Zinsser recognized that crafts are best learned through practice. So every week his students wrote papers, and every week he turned them back with comments and corrections.

The pop sensation Lady GaGa may have just started her "Fame Ball" tour, but we've already got a case of fashion plagiarism on our hands. We've known about her penchant for wearing big-shouldered blazers with no pants - à la Maison Martin Margiela - but this latest bubbly ensemble is nearly identical to a Hussein Chalayan number from a few years back. Check out GaGa's outfit and then take a look at the original from Chalayan's Spring 2007 runway show. Maybe she banks on the fact that her fan base doesn't keep up with fashion the way we do. But if GaGa, who says she takes her fashion cues from nobody but herself, is going to wax poetic about being an "artist" in a sea of pop drones, we couldn't help but burst her bubble.
PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- Brian Schneider, the Mets' veteran catcher, has a strain of the posterior capsule and calf in his right leg and will be out on a day-to-day basis, the team announced Thursday.

The House passed a bill that would impose a 90-percent tax on big bonuses handed out to corporate employees at firms receiving major bailouts, in a sharp response to this past week's revelations about the $165 million handed out to employees at American International Group, the insurance titan. But the proposal is facing loud objections from Wall Street firms because it would alter the culture of executive compensation.

DAYTON, Ohio -- The last time Pittsburgh guard Levance Fields played on the court here, he fractured the fifth metatarsal bone in his left foot in late December 2007. And now that Fields has returned to the scene of his injury, he must confront questions about another injury, this time to his groin.

The five Arctic countries that are bound by a 36-year-old treaty to protect polar bears issued a joint statement today concluding that climate change is the chief threat to the future welfare of the ice-loving predators.

Rome | This Sunday, March 22, Rome will host its 15th annual marathon, an event marked by a long weekend of citywide celebrations. Though it's too late to sign up for the race, you can watch the runners sweat it out from the sidelines -- which just happen to be in close proximity to some of Rome's most famous landmarks, including the Trevi Fountain, the Roman Forum, St. Peter's Square, the Spanish Steps and the Colosseum, the last of which is the run's official starting line.

Mess and clutter have new meaning for Diane LeBleu. She was a guest blogger here on Motherlode back in December, when she wrote of her new diagnosis of breast cancer, wondering whether to include that news in her holiday letter. She's been undergoing chemo for three months now, tolerating it well, though she misses her hair. As spring arrives this weekend (its already in full-bloom in Austin, where she lives) and she finds herself going through the familiar rhythms of spring cleaning, she writes in this week's guest blog how cancer gives these rituals new meaning.

Todd Eberle's "America," a mini retrospective of the photographs he has taken of the country from 1995 to 2006 now on view at Light & Sie Gallery in Dallas (through April 4), shows what a visual splendor the United States is. Eberle documents all sorts of architectural styles, from the designer Tony Duquette's over-the-top house in Malibu, Calif., to the modernist arches of Philip Johnson's Kentmere House in Dallas to Yale University's sinister-looking Skull and Bones Club. The show goes beyond building exteriors, however, with images of other American landmarks, including a bronze statue of Walt Disney and Mickey Mouse in Orlando, Fla., Dolly Parton and Holly Woodlawn, the New York City drag queen and former Warhol star. But even with the kitschier images, Eberle keeps America looking beautiful, infusing each photo with a sense of balance and control.

Each year, members of New York City's 59 community boards were asked to rank the most important services in their district. For the 2010 fiscal year, which starts on July 1, the boards chose among 90 services -- ranging from sidewalk repair to child care -- provided by 24 agencies. The results are published in a report called "Community Board Service Program Rankings."

In addition, the size of the plan announced yesterday represents a near "doubling all of the Fed's measures in the last year."

Today we relaunch the Ideas blog as "Idea of the Day." It wasn't until a trip to his father's native Germany at the age of eighteen that the Brazilian landscape designer Roberto Burle Marx discovered the tropical flora of his homeland. After visiting the Botanical Garden in Berlin, of all places, Burle Marx quickly abandoned the dahlias and gladioli of his youth for the sculptural bromeliads and stilt palms of his family's adopted home. Soon, he was incorporating endemic vegetation into public projects in Rio, Caracas and in monumental plantings for Oscar Niemeyer's buildings in Brasilia.

Monologue | Aired Wednesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: In worthless-drain-on-taxpayer-money news, insurance giant A.I.G. is on the hot seat because after they took billions of dollars in bailout money, they gave $165 million out in bonuses to their executives. So now, lawmakers are demanding that they give the money back. The problem, though, is that legally they're entitled to the money so it's a dilemma. But I have an idea I think might satisfy all of us and also adhere to the letter of the law. I say, instead of mailing the bonus checks to their houses, we put rocks on them and we put them at the bottom of an enormous piranha tank. We set it up in the middle of Times Square. You want the money, swim. There it is.

New York City parks are a lot more than just patches of green in the middle of the proverbial concrete jungle. Citigroup said Thursday it planned to propose a reverse stock split for its common shares, as well as an increase in its authorized shares outstanding, as the troubled bank moved ahead with a previously announced plan to convert preferred shares to common equity.

The Royal Bank of Scotland and Citigroup have canceled orders for private jets for top executives in the aftermath of the financial crash and a public backlash over corporate perks, the French plane maker Dassault Aviation said on Thursday, according to Reuters.

Looking past the ongoing stand-off between the Screen Actors Guild and Hollywood's movie and television companies, one person deeply involved with the labor game - who spoke on condition of anonymity, because that's mostly how it's done here - suggested recently that the next round of talks could turn on some unexpected issues. Beginning with the writers strike back in 2007, the wrangling has been mostly about new media: Who gets paid what, when and how for the use of entertainment digitally delivered.

The chief at JPMorgan Chase, Jamie Dimon, received about $19.7 million in total compensation for 2008, down from about $34 million in 2007, Reuters said, citing materials filed with United States regulators ahead of its annual shareholder meeting.

Boutique investment firms and top hedge funds are slowly lapping up the cream of global banking talent as the financial crisis forces banks to cut staff and limit the pay of their top risk-takers, Reuters says.

Citigroup and Morgan Stanley will in the next few weeks announce plans to authorize or repurpose shares so it can have enough stock to compensate employees, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

Valero Energy, the country's largest independent refiner, said Wednesday that it would buy seven ethanol plants from VeraSun Energy for $477 million, giving the biofuel industry a lift at a time when it is suffering from excess production capacity and falling gasoline consumption, The New York Times's Clifford Krauss reported.

The British financial regulator proposed several sweeping changes Wednesday, calling for stricter capital rules for banks, greater scrutiny for hedge funds and new compensation policies, The New York Times's Julia Werdigier reported.

A number of cash-starved private equity firms are putting their assets on the block, creating a potentially lucrative deal-making market for firms that specialize in secondary buyouts, The Wall Street Journal reported.

China's rejection of Coca-Cola's bid to buy the country's top juice maker, China Huiyuan Juice Group, marked no retreat from government policies welcoming foreign investment, the government said on Thursday.
Private equity firms are trying harder to please their powerful investors as dollars for new commitments become harder to come by, Reuters says.

The Marsh & McLennan Companies said Wednesday it has priced a public offering of $400 million in 9.25 percent senior notes due 2019 and will use the proceeds to repay $400 million of senior notes due this year, The Associated Press reported.

The Federal Reserve's decision to buy $1 trillion of government debt and mortgage-backed securities jolted Wall Street on Wednesday. Within moments of the announcement, stocks and Treasury prices soared while the value of the dollar tumbled, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported.

Federal authorities have widened their criminal investigation into UBS concerning offshore tax fraud to include independent lawyers and accountants from Switzerland and the United States who worked with the bank, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported, citing people briefed on the matter.

UniCredit, one of the biggest Italian banks, said Wednesday that it would seek new government funds, and analysts at JPMorgan Chase predicted that Deutsche Bank would need billions more in capital, the latest signs that European financial institutions were continuing to struggle.

The N.F.L. will look into changing instant-replay rules in hopes of avoiding a repeat of the blown call by the referee Ed Hochuli that helped cost San Diego a game last season. The competition committee will propose at the league meetings next week that when the ball comes loose when a quarterback is throwing, replay can be used to determine if it is a fumble or an incomplete pass. replay.

Lance Armstrong and the French anti-doping agency said Armstrong was approached for a hair sample in an unannounced antidoping test Tuesday in southern France, where he is training. Armstrong said it was the 24th antidoping test he had faced since he announced his return in September, and the first time he had been asked to provide a sample of hair. Testing of hair samples is allowed under French law, but is not recognized by the World Anti-Doping Agency or cycling’s governing body, U.C.I.

Evgeni Plushenko is planning a comeback to defend his Olympic title at the Vancouver Games. Plushenko, a three-time world champion, dominated skating from 2003-6. He is back training with his longtime coach, Alexei Mishin, and has mastered two quadruple jumps, according to his agent. Plushenko, 26, has not competed since winning the Turin Games in 2006. evgeni.

Mafaaz earned an automatic berth into the Kentucky Derby by winning the $115,000 Kentucky Derby Challenge Stakes at Kempton Park in England on Wednesday. Mafaaz, a chestnut colt, defeated 13 rivals to gain one of the 20 spots for the Derby on May 2. Mafaaz, making his third career start and first in 2009, was ridden by Richard Hills and trained in England by John Gosden, who had two Breeders’ Cup triumphs and also spent 11 years at Santa Anita. mafaaz.

Vancouver was awarded a Major League Soccer team, which will begin play in 2011 and join Toronto as the league’s second Canadian team. The N.B.A. star Steve Nash is part of the Vancouver ownership group. mls.

Lance Mackey, who is from Fairbanks, Alaska, won the Iditarod sled-dog race for the third consecutive year when he completed the 1,100-mile trek across the Alaska wilderness, about six hours ahead of the second- and third-place finishers. Mackey slapped hands with fans along Nome’s Front Street and was mobbed by family members after crossing under the city’s famed burled arch at 11:38 a.m. Immediately after winning, he gave treats to his dogs. dogs.

Jack McClinton made seven 3-pointers and scored 25 points in the first round of the N.I.T. as visiting Miami beat Providence, 78-66. Baylor defeated visiting Georgetown, 74-72. In the C.B.I. tournament, St. John’s lost to host Richmond, 75-69. nit.
Japan beat Cuba 5-0 in the World Baseball Classic, ending one of the most remarkable streaks in modern sports.

MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. -- Kevin Youkilis is the latest American player who will no longer wear the United States uniform this year because of an injury. Youkilis, the first baseman for the Boston Red Sox, has a mildly sprained left ankle and mild Achillies' tendinitis in his left foot.

Celebrity perfumes occupy a decidedly downmarket place in perfume. According to Karen Grant of the industry tracking company NPD, 46 percent of the premium perfumes (those over $75) sold in 2008 were designer brands. Celebrity perfumes were 1 percent. In other words, if you had money and, presumably, taste, you didn't buy them. As art - creativity, quality, legitimacy - their reputations are abysmal.
A slide show of images from the music festival in Austin, Tex.

Federal prison officials are easing restrictions on an American-born soldier for the Taliban, John Walker Lindh, moves that his lawyer said would allow Mr. Lindh to tell his story for the first time. A spokesman for the Department of Justice, Dean Boyd, said the restrictions, which were imposed in 2002, would expire Friday. Jim Brosnahan, a lawyer for Mr. Lindh, said Mr. Lindh would be able to contact and meet with people other than his lawyers and relatives. Mr. Lindh, 28, is serving a 20-year sentence for aiding the former Taliban government in Afghanistan. Mr. Lindh, of Fairfax, Calif., was captured in Afghanistan in 2001 and is scheduled to be released from a prison in Terre Haute, Ind., in 2019.

The Senate voted 92 to 5 to confirm a former mayor of Dallas, Ron Kirk, as the Obama administration’s senior official in charge of trade policy. As United States trade representative, Mr. Kirk is expected to oversee a shift in the nation’s trade priorities. While the Bush administration concentrated on expanding free-trade agreements, Mr. Kirk made clear in his confirmation hearing that a priority would be ensuring that the nation’s trading partners abide by existing agreements.

A man accused of being an operative for Al Qaeda and who was held for nearly six years before being charged as a terrorist must remain behind bars as the criminal case against him continues, a federal judge ruled. The judge, Robert Carr, refused to release the man, Ali Saleh Kahlah al-Marri, on bond, despite the defense’s offer of collateral worth more than $1 million and its proposal to keep him guarded in a safe house. Mr. Marri is scheduled to be arraigned Monday in Illinois on federal charges of providing material support to terror and conspiracy. He has been in a Navy brig near Charleston since 2003.

A jury recommended the death penalty for a man convicted of murdering five federal firefighters who were overrun by one of several wildfires he ignited in Southern California in 2006. Jurors took less than a day to decide that the man, Raymond L. Oyler, left, deserved to die. Mr. Oyler, 38, was convicted of five counts of first-degree murder, 20 counts of arson and 17 counts of using an incendiary device. At sentencing, set for April 3, the judge could give Mr. Oyler life in prison without the possibility of parole.

A judge dismissed criminal charges against a Phoenix gun shop owner accused of supplying firearms to Mexican drug cartels. Judge Robert L. Gottsfield of Maricopa County Superior Court ruled that the prosecution’s evidence against the shop owner, George Iknadosian, was not sufficient to support conviction and that all of the gun purchases had been legal, even if weapons ended up with the cartels. Mr. Iknadosian, 47, was accused of selling more than 700 weapons to straw buyers, knowing that the firearms were bought on behalf of drug cartels. He had been charged with fraud, money-laundering and other offenses.

An obituary on Saturday about the artist Ernest Trova misstated the given name of his wife, who died last year. She was Carla Clingman Rand Trova, not Carol. The obituary also misspelled the surname of a singer whose concerts Mr. Trova attended all over the United States. He is Julio Iglesias, not Yglesias.

An obituary on March 5 about the playwright Horton Foote misstated the Broadway performance history of the actress Kim Stanley. She appeared in “The House of Bernarda Alba,” by Federico García Lorca, at the ANTA Theater in 1951. The 1952 production of Mr. Foote’s play “The Chase,” at the Playhouse Theater, did not introduce her to Broadway.

An article on Wednesday about Jazz at Lincoln Center’s 2009-10 season misstated the dates of concerts by the singer Kurt Elling with the accordionist Richard Galliano next year. They will be May 14-15, not March 14- 15.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on March 10 about the Laurence Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys, misidentified the award won by Elena Roger for her role as Édith Piaf in “Piaf.” She was named best actress in a musical, not simply best actress. (Margaret Tyzack was named best actress for her role as Mrs. St. Maugham in “The Chalk Garden.”).

A chart on Monday with the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament bracket, sizing up the field according to various statistical measures, erroneously included a team. Oregon State, which indeed has a relatively poor free-throw percentage, did not make the tournament.
The thing the two franchises from opposite sides of the Hudson River have in common is pain.

A report in the City Room column on March 11 about a push to keep lever voting machines in New York State misstated their origins. The lever machine was invented in the United States in 1897, not in Britain in 1888. The report also misidentified the year and place where the machines were first used in an election. They were first used in 1898 in Buffalo and Rochester, not in 1892 in New York City.
The government sued the Union Pacific Railroad in an effort to force the company to pay $37.7 million in fines related to drug smuggling aboard the company’s trains.

A report in the National Briefings column on March 4 about possible layoffs of public employees in Puerto Rico misstated the percentage of the island’s budget that comes from federal financing. It is 21 percent, not two-thirds.

An article on March 11 about an academic fraud case against Dr. Scott S. Reuben, an anesthesiologist in Springfield, Mass., paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by a spokeswoman for Baystate Medical Center, where he formerly practiced. The spokeswoman, Jane Albert, said in an interview that an investigating committee concluded that Dr. Reuben fabricated data underlying much of his research, and she added that he had cooperated with the investigation. She did not comment on whether he himself admitted fabricating data.

An article on March 11 about homeless families living in California motels, using information from Greg Hayworth, a member of one such family, referred incorrectly to Mr. Hayworth’s educational background. Mr. Hayworth neither graduated from Syracuse University nor ever enrolled there.

The American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California filed a lawsuit on Wednesday in state Superior Court contending that an Orange County high school allowed a hostile environment to develop against gay and female students there, citing the brief cancellation of a school production of the musical “Rent” as one piece of evidence. The lawsuit, which argues that state and federal equal protection laws were violated, was filed on behalf of a female student at Corona del Mar High School who was said to be a target of rape and death threats by male students. It contends that sexist and homophobic comments are common at the school and that school officials have done little in response. The school drama teacher, Ron Martin, said last month that the school’s principal, Fal Asrani, had canceled the “Rent” production; Ms. Asrani said that was not true, and later she approved the production. A spokeswoman for the Newport-Mesa Unified School District said that she had no immediate comment, but that one would be forthcoming.

The summer music season continues to offer options for hippies of all ages. The concert promoter Live Nation announced that it would produce a show to celebrate the 90th birthday of Pete Seeger, right, on May 3 at Madison Square Garden. Live Nation said the show would be a benefit for Mr. Seeger’s Hudson River Sloop Clearwater organization, which promotes conservation of the Hudson River, and would feature more than 40 artists, including Bruce Springsteen, Joan Baez, Dave Matthews, Ani DiFranco, Eddie Vedder and Emmylou Harris. Also, Billboard reported that Phish had added 12 dates to its summer tour, the first the band has played since 2004. The new dates include performances in Darien Center, N.Y., on Aug. 13 and Saratoga Springs, N.Y., on Aug. 16. The tour is scheduled to begin on June 4 in Wantagh, N.Y.

Los Angeles prosecutors have charged the rapper Kanye West with misdemeanor battery, grand theft and vandalism in connection with the destruction of a photographer’s camera, The Associated Press reported. Mr. West, left, was arrested at Los Angeles International Airport in September after the confrontation. His road manager, Dan Crawley, faces six misdemeanor charges: two counts apiece of battery, vandalism and grand theft. Mr. West’s lawyer, Blair Berk, declined to comment.

The dearth of blush-inducing signage around Times Square will soon be rectified when the Sarah Ruhl play “In the Next Room (or the vibrator play)” comes to Broadway in the fall. Lincoln Center Theater announced that it would present Ms. Ruhl’s play, about a group of women in a New York spa town in the late 1800s, at a Shubert theater to be announced. Les Waters, who directed the play at the Berkeley Repertory Theater in California, will also direct the Broadway production. Previews are to begin on Oct. 22, with the opening scheduled for Nov. 19. Lincoln Center Theater said that it would also present “Broke-ology,” a new play by Nathan Louis Jackson, at Lincoln Center’s Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. Previews are to begin on Sept. 10, with an opening planned for Oct. 5. No casting was announced for either play. ... Ms. Posey will be featured in “This,” a new comedy by Melissa James Gibson about a widow and her circle of friends, as part of Playwrights Horizons’ 2009-10 season.

U2’s new album, “No Line on the Horizon” (Interscope), fell to No. 3 in its second week out with 132,000 sales, a drop of 73 percent from its opening week. J. Holiday’s new “Round 2” (Capitol) sold 55,000 to reach No. 4, and Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) was No. 5 with 52,000 sales in its 18th week out. Chris Cornell, the former lead singer of Soundgarden and Audioslave, opened at No. 10 with 26,000 sales of his third solo album, “Scream” (Interscope), produced by Timbaland.

BLOOM--Murray Teigh, former President and founding member of the American Society of Journalists and Authors, died February 10th. He was the author of over 700 magazine articles and six books, one play and a novel. He was husband to Sydelle Bloom and is survived by his daughters, Ellen and Amy, and his four grandchildren.

Russia said Wednesday that it was banning the hunting of harp seals up to 1 year of age. The announcement, by the Natural Resources Ministry, came less than a month after Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, according to the state news media, told his cabinet that the hunting of baby seals was a ''bloody industry.''

IT takes planning, strength and guts to venture through a sheer terrain of snow and ice so treacherous that, if you find yourself suddenly sliding down the side of a mountain or into a crevasse, a metal weaponlike tool that may have as many as three sharp points could save your life. Every spring in the United States, as mountaineers of various skill levels eye certain snowy peaks -- Mount Washington in New Hampshire, Mount Rainier in Washington, the San Juan Mountains in Colorado -- mountaineering axes are often added to lists of essential gear. With temperatures higher, and avalanche hazards lessened despite plenty of remaining ice and hard snow, this is the time of year when many find those peaks most appealing. The axes usually remain uneventfully tethered to the wrist and are used like canes; the T-shaped top of the ax acts as a handle. But when a mountaineer slips, the shaft of this foreboding tool can be grasped so that the serrated knife-like point of the ax can be plunged into a frozen surface -- a gravity fighting technique known as ''self arrest.''

The summer music season continues to offer options for hippies of all ages. The concert promoter Live Nation announced that it would produce a show to celebrate the 90th birthday of Pete Seeger, right, on May 3 at Madison Square Garden. Live Nation said the show would be a benefit for Mr. Seeger's Hudson River Sloop Clearwater organization, which promotes conservation of the Hudson River, and would feature more than 40 artists, including Bruce Springsteen, Joan Baez, Dave Matthews, Ani DiFranco, Eddie Vedder and Emmylou Harris. Also, Billboard reported that Phish had added 12 dates to its summer tour, the first the band has played since 2004. The new dates include performances in Darien Center, N.Y., on Aug. 13 and Saratoga Springs, N.Y., on Aug. 16. The tour is scheduled to begin on June 4 in Wantagh, N.Y.

IN late February 1860, Abraham Lincoln -- about to give the most important speech of his career to that point, at Cooper Union in New York -- took a stroll down Broadway. He was fascinated by the shops, the slums, the horse-drawn trolleys, the pedestrian throngs, and he couldn't help but notice the many museums that lined the bustling street, foremost among them P. T. Barnum's world-famous American Museum, with its menagerie of animals and oddities and carnival-like attractions. Lincoln dared not set foot inside. ''Museums were really sideshows back then,'' said Harold Holzer, author of more than 20 books on Lincoln and co-chairman of the Lincoln Bicentennial Commission. When Lincoln ''came back to New York as president-elect in 1861, I think Mary and the boys probably did go'' to Barnum's museum but Lincoln himself would not have, Mr. Holzer said, adding, ''He probably thought it was a little undignified.''

North Carolina's bid for an N.C.A.A. championship is likely to begin without point guard Ty Lawson, the Atlantic Coast Conference player of the year. Lawson, who averaged 15.9 points and 6.5 assists a game this season while directing the Tar Heels' fast-paced offense, jammed his toe in practice March 6. Although he played two days later, helping North Carolina beat Duke to win the A.C.C. regular-season title, swelling forced him to sit out two games in the conference tournament last week.

YOU could never call them wallflowers, but quite a few visitors to the Armory Show art fair in Manhattan earlier this month evidently intended to meld with the works on display. Consider Knight Landesman (bottom right), the publisher of Artforum magazine, whose electric-blue suit was nearly a match for his chair. Or Aidan Salakhova, a dealer from Moscow (right), whose polka-dot tent dress made a soothing counterpoint to the ghostly wire ''furnishings'' inside her makeshift clinic/gallery. More-audacious types made like human billboards, flaunting artworks on their backs. Among them was Paula Kohatsu (below center), who wore a hand-painted tattoolike design, enhancing its splashy effect with a mohawk-crested hat. As a pair of mock astronauts sheathed in crinkly silver jumpsuits (bottom left) pointed out in unison, ''We are the art.''

Kelly Clarkson, below, is back on top. Her critically praised new album, ''All I Ever Wanted'' (RCA), opened at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, with 255,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. ''Love vs. Money'' (Def Jam) by The-Dream, with guest appearances by Mariah Carey, Kanye West and Lil Jon, took second place with 151,000 sales in its first week at stores. U2's new album, ''No Line on the Horizon'' (Interscope), fell to No. 3 in its second week out with 132,000 sales, a drop of 73 percent from its opening week. J. Holiday's new ''Round 2'' (Capitol) sold 55,000 to reach No. 4, and Taylor Swift's ''Fearless'' (Big Machine) was No. 5 with 52,000 sales in its 18th week out. Chris Cornell, the former lead singer of Soundgarden and Audioslave, opened at No. 10 with 26,000 sales of his third solo album, ''Scream'' (Interscope), produced by Timbaland.

Natasha Richardson, a Tony Award-winning actress whose career melded glamorous celebrity with the bloodline of theater royalty, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She had suffered head injuries in a skiing accident Monday north of Montreal, and was flown to New York on Tuesday. She was 45 and lived in Manhattan and in Millbrook, N.Y. Alan Nierob, a spokesman for her husband, the actor Liam Neeson, announced Ms. Richardson's death Wednesday night.

NICHOLLS--Richard Hall, 70, of Stamford, CT, died March 14th after a courageous ten-year battle with cancer. He continues to be an inspiration to his devoted family and friends for his integrity, wisdom and keen sense of humor. Rich was a nationally recognized tax lawyer in the tax-exempt bond field. He was a former head of the tax department at Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon and was of counsel to Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe. Rich was called "the tax lawyer's tax lawyer" in The Bond Lawyer and was a valued mentor and friend to the many successful attorneys he worked with during his 40-year career. His colleagues described him as insightful and creative, with an encyclopedic memory and an ability to "say more with fewer words than anyone else they knew." He did extensive pro bono work for the American Bar Association and the National Association of Bond Lawyers and in 2000, was awarded the Bernard P. Friel Award for distinguished service in public finance. Rich graduated from The Hill School, Amherst College and Stanford Law School and received a master's degree in tax from NYU. He was an avid sailor, skier and swimmer and a former Captain of the Amherst swimming team. He was a longtime member of the Stamford Yacht Club and loved racing competitively on his boat, Rhiannon. Above all, Rich was a man who knew how to enjoy life and cherish his family. He was a truly exceptional and loving father, brother and grandfather, as well as husband to his late wife, Anne. He will be dearly missed by all of his family and friends, including his devoted children, Jamie Nicholls Biondi and Christopher Nicholls, their spouses, Fran and Yvonne, his six much loved grandchildren, and his first wife and mother of his children, Judy Cormier. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Rich's honor to The Myeloma Institute for Research and Therapy (attention: Betty Tucker), University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, 4301 West Markham St., Slot 816, Little Rock, AR 72205. A private gathering of friends to remember and honor Rich will be held in late April.

YUNIS--Alexander, born Brooklyn, NY, April 12, 1909 passed away on March 18, 2009, three weeks before his 100th birthday. He was an exceptional son, brother, husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He took care of all of his family and was loved and respected by all. There was no task too difficult for him to undertake and he will be missed by all who knew him. He is predeceased by his beloved wife of 47 years, Martha Yunis; survived by his son Joel and wife Cooki Yunis, his daughter Linda and son-in-law Paul Mittelman and by his son Marc and his wife Miriam Yunis; grandchildren Bari Schorr and her husband David, Steven Yunis and his wife Ilana, Scott Mittelman and his wife Leah, Aaron Yunis and his wife Lynne, Benjamin Yunis and Joshua Yunis; great- grandchildren Anna Yunis, Jack Yunis, Maxwell Schorr and Serena Lilly Yunis, and his sister Janet Raclyn. He was as proud of his family's accomplishments as his family was of his. Al graduated Fordham Law School in 1935 and practiced law as a successful trial lawyer for 52 years, interrupted only by his service in the United States Army from 1943 1945, and had a long and productive life. He always stood up for what he believed in and feared no one, was always ready to help a friend or family member in need, and never failed to do the right thing. Graveside Service at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Queens, NY, Thursday, March 19th at 10:30 am. Shiva will be observed Thursday through Wednesday mornings at the home of his son Marc at 30 Deer Path Road, Roslyn, NY and at the home of his son Joel at 975 Park Avenue, New York, NY.

The dearth of blush-inducing signage around Times Square will soon be rectified when the Sarah Ruhl play ''In the Next Room (or the vibrator play)'' comes to Broadway in the fall. Lincoln Center Theater announced that it would present Ms. Ruhl's play, about a group of women in a New York spa town in the late 1800s, at a Shubert theater to be announced. Les Waters, who directed the play at the Berkeley Repertory Theater in California, will also direct the Broadway production. Previews are to begin on Oct. 22, with the opening scheduled for Nov. 19. Lincoln Center Theater said that it would also present ''Broke-ology,'' a new play by Nathan Louis Jackson, at Lincoln Center's Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. Previews are to begin on Sept. 10, with an opening planned for Oct. 5. No casting was announced for either play. ... Parker Posey will take a break from her schedule of what seems like 50 movies a year to appear in a new stage work at Playwrights Horizons, the theater company announced. Ms. Posey will be featured in ''This,'' a new comedy by Melissa James Gibson about a widow and her circle of friends, as part of Playwrights Horizons' 2009-10 season.

10 P.M. (Sundance) HEAVY METAL IN BAGHDAD The Sundance Channel observes the sixth anniversary of the Iraq war with three documentaries. The triple bill begins with Eddy Moretti and Suroosh Alvi's report on Acrassicauda, a heavy metal band -- including Firas Al-Lateef, above -- as it struggles to stay together -- and stay alive -- in post-invasion Iraq. In ''Hometown Baghdad,'' at 11:30, Barrett Hawes, Kate Hillis and Ziad Turkey weave together the experiences of three Baghdad college students who videotaped their daily routines. And in ''No End in Sight,'' at 1:15 a.m., Charles Ferguson, a former Brookings Institution scholar, interviews government officials, journalists, soldiers and Iraqi civilians to examine how the Bush administration formulated policies and strategies in American-occupied Iraq. 8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY In the last episode before a hiatus, Daniel (Eric Mabius) and Wilhelmina (Vanessa Williams) try to turn around Mode magazine's fortunes by devoting an issue to sex. Meanwhile Marc (Michael Urie) and Amanda (Becki Newton) give Betty (America Ferrera, above center, with Mr. Urie and Ms. Newton) a makeover designed to rev up her sex life with Matt (Daniel Eric Gold).

GAVIGAN Rev. Msgr. Peter J.,of Our Lady of Victory Parish in The Bronx entered into eternal rest on Tuesday, March 17, 2009 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. Aged 73. Army Veteran Msgr. Gavigan was born on April 24, 1935 in Brooklyn, NY to Peter and Anna (O'Brien) Gavigan. He graduated from Incarnation Elementary School, Manhattan Prep and Cathedral College in NYC. NEAL BENEZRA is not a showman. But as museum directors nationwide face plummeting endowments and potentially crippling budget cuts, Mr. Benezra's even-keeled approach and penchant for collaboration in his stewardship of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art may be a blueprint for how to endure the financial uncertainty. ''We benefited from the fact that we went through a tough time seven years ago,'' said Mr. Benezra, 55, who grew up in the Bay Area.

GERMANYBRF Two suspects in a heist at Germany's largest department store have been released because they are twins whose fingerprints and DNA are indistinguishable, a court said Wednesday. The authorities have said that in the heist, in the early hours of Jan. 25, at least three burglars stole jewelry and watches valued in the millions of dollars from the store, Kaufhaus des Westens, in Berlin. A glove found at the scene led investigators to conclude that at least one of the twins, who have been identified only as Abbas and Hassan O., 27, participated in the burglary. The authorities cannot tell which one, however, and said each twin could deny involvement and accuse his brother. The police are still searching for at least one accomplice, the authorities said. None of the valuables have been recovered.

brfAZERBAIJAN Azerbaijan voted Wednesday to approve a constitutional amendment removing a two-term limit on the presidency. With more than half of polling stations reporting, votes were running in favor by a ratio of more than 9 to 1, election officials said. Opposition groups had called for a boycott of the vote, arguing that it would allow President Ilham Aliyev, 47, whose family has dominated the politics of the former Soviet republic for nearly four decades, to be president for life. Mr. Aliyev took over from his father, Heydar, a former Soviet official and K.G.B. officer, in 2003 and easily won a second five-year term in October.

The Federal Reserve's decision to buy $1 trillion of government debt and mortgage-backed securities jolted Wall Street on Wednesday. Within moments of the announcement, stocks and Treasury prices soared while the value of the dollar tumbled. With financial companies leading the markets higher, the Dow Jones industrial average rose to its highest levels in about a month and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 2.1 percent to end just shy of 800 points. Investors applauded the move and said the Fed's decision to essentially print money could help to lower borrowing costs and allow more people to refinance mortgages.

The French have always had a thing for Austin, including recognizing the city as the capital of the Republic of Texas in the 1839 Treaty of Amity, Navigation and Commerce and assigning a bit of a dandy — Monsieur Jean Pierre Isidore Alphonse Dubois, a secretary in the French Legation in Washington – to serve as a liaison. He built a fine house about half a mile east of town that stands at the oldest framed structure in the city. The house and its grounds are now surrounded by a stone wall and have been repurposed as a park that overlooks downtown.

“You’d have to say that the Hold Steadies have been really embraced by Austin. They’re great, of course, but they have a fun thing, a bar band thing, that makes it all the better.” – Brady Dyer, Austin resident.

A jury has ordered the South Korean pop star and actor Rain and his managers to pay more than $8 million in damages to a Hawaiian concert promoter for a canceled concert in Honolulu in 2007, The Associated Press reported. Rain, whose real name is Jung Ji-hoon, was scheduled to perform at Aloha Stadium on June 15, 2007, but canceled the show a few days before the performance date. At the trial, lawyers for the promoter argued that Rain never intended to perform, and that his crew never shipped their equipment or applied for visas; Rain testified that his concert stage was not correctly set up, and that he was not involved in the decision to cancel the show. Promoters in Los Angeles have filed a similar suit, after a planned Rain concert at the Staples Center was canceled hours before show time.
Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete stories.)

Standing at the corner of Sixth Street and Trinity in Austin on Thursday night at 9 p.m, you could hear the following sounds: guitars – groaning ones, keening ones, strummy ones; all manner of bass, from in-the-groove country to finger pop pyrotechnics; keyboards of all wattage; thunderous drums coming from all directions; an accordion; what sounded like a triangle and a dreadful attempt at white soul harmony.

Well. On Thursday night – sorry, technically Friday morning — I had one of those fabled SXSW experiences where wildly disparate musical experiences are jammed up against one another, both with their own pleasures. First there was the Rock the Rabbit party, sponsored by Playboy and complete with tail-wearing (and –baring) bunnies, free-flowing booze, an out-of-the-way location and a rumored-about “surprise” guest, Jane’s Addiction. The reunited group took the stage around 1:30 a.m. and did a tight, lively, and, for Austin this week, long set. Dave Navarro was shirtless and vamping for the cameras; Perry Farrell wore a tank and a grin and prowled the stage like an eager comeback model, which he sort of is; the crowd, many of whom were fans from 20 years ago, sang along, a relative rarity in a festival full of new bands.

The Master Chorale of Washington, a 42-year-old group that performed at the opening of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in 1971, will shut down in May, The Washington Post reported. In a statement, Virginia Austin Schubert, the chairwoman of the chorus’s board, said that the group, which has recently been unable to cover its operating costs through ticket sales and donations, had lost a significant part of its investments in the economic downturn. The chorus is scheduled to perform Orff’s “Carmina Burana” at its final concert on May 17.
Here are some outtakes from the hundreds of shows that went off in Austin on Thursday:

The Philadelphia Orchestra took a step toward filling its leadership vacuum on Thursday when its board chose an investment company executive as chairman. The executive, Richard B. Worley, who is managing director of Permit Capital Group, LLC, will formally take over in September but will begin working with the interim chairman, Joseph Jacovini, now the orchestra said. Mr. Worley has been a member of the board since 2006, and he served a previous stint from 1997 to 2003. The move is likely to give impetus to the search for an executive director and a music director. Charles Dutoit is providing temporary artistic leadership and the orchestra has an acting executive director.

What could have been a bitter dispute between Bruce Springsteen and Conan O’Brien over the custody of the drummer Max Weinberg has been resolved amicably. Mr. Weinberg is currently performing on Mr. Springsteen’s tour, which runs through August, but is scheduled to join Mr. O’Brien when the comedian becomes host of the “Tonight” show in June. In a release, Mr. Springsteen’s publicists said that for tour dates at which Mr. Weinberg cannot appear, he will be replaced by his son Jay. In a statement, Mr. Springsteen said: “I want to express my appreciation to Conan O’Brien, and everyone on his team, for making it possible for Max to continue to do double duty for both us and for him. We promise to return him in one piece.”
President Obama proved to be the ultimate in late-night guest bookings Thursday night as the “Tonight” show matched its highest rating in the last 11 years.

A sense of newness pervades everything at South by Southwest, keeping attendees in a semi-paranoid state of rushing to catch the next buzz band and the next about-to-be-a-buzz-band, then bragging about it on whatever is the newest method of communication technology (hello, Twitter).

For the last several years, Playboy’s parties have been considered among the hardest to get into here, because of some combination of celebrity (Elijah Wood turned up once), well-known acts like Motley Crue and offbeat locations. On Thursday, in an old Safeway across the highway from most of the SXSW action, fans that were more scantily-dressed than the norm here came to see a reunited Jane’s Addiction do a “surprise” (that is to say, heavily rumored but unconfirmed) set. For the first time in many years, all the original members — including the bassist Eric Avery and the drummer Stephen Perkins — were accounted for, and seemed much happier than they had been in their heyday nearly two decades ago.

To be able to attend musical performances as part of your job is, for the most part, a privilege beyond price. For big, high-profile events featuring world-class performers, the point is too obvious to need discussion, though many humbler occasions prove at least as edifying.

Sitting on the lawn at the French Legation Museum, with a sweet breeze and kids and dogs and families, thinking: What a lovely coincidence that one of the Tallest Man on Earth’s best songs, “The Gardener,” has a lot of flower imagery — lilies and roses and daisies. A perfect fit for this parklike setting, and the studious attention of fans of Other Music, the New York record store that helped organize this showcase. Everybody’s lolling in the grass, listening raptly as Kristian Matsson, who is from Sweden but sounds Dylanish and looks like a more rockabilly James Franco, sings about wanting to be the king of Spain. In this perfect environment, anything seems possible.

In this era of outrage over c-suite perquisites and high-flying bonuses, it's a little easy to get wrapped up in the outrage.

I have a friend who was in Washington this week, and he stopped into Wednesday's Congressional inquisition - oops, I mean hearing - into the A.I.G. bonuses. He stayed about 15 minutes and left when he couldn't take it anymore. He didn't know which was worse, he told me afterward: the way the A.I.G. financial products traders had conned the company into handing them bonuses - or the Congressional hearing complaining about the bonuses. "What a waste of taxpayers' money," he said. He was referring to the hearing, not the bonuses.

Even though some Milan boutiques were offering hush-hush discounts on fall merchandise as early as last December (a full month prior to the city's officially sanctioned sales period), the Camera della Moda, Italy's governing fashion body, issued a statement yesterday declaring that price breaks on spring merchandise would not - dio mio! -- commence earlier than the traditional July start date. Though we admire its efforts at maintaining the sanctity of the city's shopping rituals, our money is with Paola Bottelli, the tack-sharp investigative reporter for the prestigious financial paper Il Sole 24 Ore, who sniffed out that several Italian luxury brands were in cahoots to establish early discounting. According to her sources, many luxury brands plan to start hacking prices on April 25, just in time to nab the style-conscious mobs descending on the city for the annual furniture fair. What's next, a press release denying that Donatella dyes her hair?

Not long ago, charm bracelets were the exclusive province of Hollywood wives, but these days they're also appearing on the arms of L.A.'s most powerful men. Odd as it seems, a quirky charm bracelet is quickly joining fast cars, yachts and Malibu beach homes as the latest Alpha-Male accoutrement. Ironically the bracelet is the perfect symbol for the alpha male since the main charm is a gold gorilla. Designed by Entourage's Jamie-Lynn Sigler and her friend, Holly Freeman, the solid gold link bracelet - with room for a dozen charms - became all the rage on the set of her popular HBO show, before making its inevitable appearance at the city's trendiest boutiques. Sigler's jewelry company, CJ Free, also offers a menagerie of 14 karat gold charms to accompany the bracelet, including a ladybug and an elephant. But not surprisingly, most of her macho customers tend to favor the gold gorilla. CJ Free also makes charm bracelets for women, as well as a slightly more butch version made of leather and gold (starting at $500). But it's the classic all gold charm version (starting at $780) that's selling off the racks. What's next? Studly solitaires?

The graphics pioneer Peter Saville often refers to himself in the third person, invoking the Peter Saville brand. For example, he is putting the final touches on a new showroom in Shoreditch for the Danish textile company Kvadrat, in collaboration with the architect David Adjaye. "David has pretty much created a space that is a tribute to Kvadrat and Peter Saville," he says. Saville has been working with Kvadrat for nearly five years, principally as a consultant and creative director, but this project, even by his own standards, is perhaps his most Saville-esque with the company to date.

We've enabled a new feature called Apture on select New York Times blogs: Dot Earth, Economix and Diner's Journal. Apture allows readers to dig deeper into a subject without ever leaving the page. In a blog post like this, when you see a hyperlink with a small icon next to it, click on that link. You'll instantly see related videos, maps, documents, photos, New York Times topic pages and other content, all while staying on the same page.

We've been busier than JFK airport sniffing out what's new, now and not-to-be-missed in the world this spring. There's no better way to begin than with a cover shot in Chicago: avant garde fashion shot against modern architecture in a city of newfound vitality. From there it's on to the teensy weensy Alpine nation of Liechtenstein, where the proud - but peculiar - citizenry don't let size stop it from achieving big things. And then to Bali for a look at how an iconic tourist destination stays true to itself. Along the way we check in with artists in Toronto, jazz afficionados in Kansas City and foodies on Corsica. And because it's not quite so cripplingly expensive now (everyone's following the strong dollar these days!), we go on a shopping spree in Florence, Italy; pick up some contemporary art in Mexico City; and book a trip to Brisbane to size up Australia's latest cultural hub. We're even feeling adventurous enough to offer up a highly opinionated guide to Dubai. Don't be fooled, the emirate is still party central in the Middle East - every bit as glam and glitzy but with fewer banker blowhards. We can roll with that.

The big policy news this week has been the Fed's decision to buy $1 trillion of long-term bonds, going beyond the normal policy of buying only short-term debt. Good move -- but it's probably worth pointing out that yes, this does expose the Fed, and indirectly the taxpayer, to some risks. And in so doing, it blurs the line between fiscal and monetary policy.

So, just what is a Moc? Glad you asked. According to Chattanooga (which, by the way, is the preferred name for the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, or U.T.C., but please do not call it U.T.-Chatt or Tenn-Chatt), the original nickname was the Moccasins, and the mascot in the 1920s was a snake. An American Indian soon came to represent the Moccasins, and a moccasin shoe was used as a logo in the 1980s.

RODRIGUEZ--Alberto Rafael, founding partner and chief creative officer of the preeminent Hispanic advertising agency REVOLUCION, died suddenly of a heart attack on Sunday morning in Manhattan. He was 40 years old. Born on August 14, 1968, in Miami, Fla., Alberto was the son of Hilda Gasca and the late Alberto Rodriguez. He had one sister, Barbara Macina of Clifton, New Jersey, and was devotedly married to Tre Miller-Rodriguez. For nearly 20 years, Alberto delighted consumers and clients with his award-winning campaigns. At Hispanic Marketing Services in Miami, his meteoric rise on the Coca-Cola and Seagrams campaigns caught the attention of The Vidal Partnership, which recruited him to New York in 1992. In 2000, Alberto and his colleague Federico Mejer founded REVOLUCION, which is 100% Hispanic owned and operated. Ad Age ranked the agency among the Top 20 Hispanic Independent Agencies in 2007. He is survived by his wife, mother, sister and step-father, Hector Gasca of Miami, Fla. Flowers can be sent to the funeral home (address below) and donations in his name can be made to the American Heart Association (americanheart.org). Friends may attend a viewing on Friday from 2pm - 5pm and 7pm - 9pm at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street (greenwichvillagefuneralhome.com). A funeral service will be held Saturday at the First Presbyterian Church on Fifth Avenue, 12 West 12th Street, at 3pm. A celebration of his life will follow immediately afterward - and forever.

Raab President, Hunter College Hunter High School '73

CUTLER--Philip May 10, 1924, Athens, GA March 17, 2009, New York, NY. Philip's innumerable friends and his family note with sadness the death of the gentlest, sweetest man any of us have ever known. World traveler of infinite curiosity and impeccable taste, Philip throughout his career, first at Macy's, then at Lord & Taylor, and in the years he was an independent furniture consultant, was influential in helping manufacturers in the Philippines and China to develop and export products to the American market. While at Lord & Taylor he also organized pioneering exhibitions of 20th century vintage furniture and objects and he was among the first to bring these works to the attention of collectors and museums. Beyond his professional credentials, his humanity, wit, grace, and charm made him beloved by everyone he met all over the world. His personal warmth was such that he had many friendships that endured over fifty years. An extraordinary son, brother, uncle, and godfather, Philip was someone who always put the well being of others ahead of his own. With his dearest friend Santiago Cortes, Philip took great joy in exploring the world, traveling to India, China, Peru, Egypt, Cuba, Jordan, Vietnam, and Thailand. Throughout this his love of New York City, his home for sixty years, was a constant in his life. For the last eleven years, he derived enormous pleasure from the beautiful view from his terrace overlooking Central Park. Philip's endearing modesty restrains us from praising him as much as we might want to. Our loss is deep, but the gift of having had him in our lives will never diminish. A memorial service is being planned. Contributions in Philip's memory can be made to New Yorkers for Parks, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017 or to the charity of your choice. Suzy, Michael, Jake, Lucie, Elizabeth, Ralph, Jane, Paola, and Claudio.

MANGINI--George, died on March 11, 2009 after a brief battle with cancer. He was 88 years old. George was the beloved son of Rose and Andrew Mangini. 12 nieces and nephews survive him. A serious art collector and consummate New Yorker, he was born on August 3, 1920, the third of five children. He attended both parochial and public schools in New York, and after serving in the Pacific theater during World War II, he returned to New York, and in 1948 received a B.A. from New York University. He then lived in Rome for a short time and later in Paris where he studied at the Sorbonne. He returned to New York in the early 1950s and lived in the same apartment for the next 60 years. He worked for Lord & Taylor in the antiques department and as a silver buyer for Tiffany & Co. Later, he started the Gallery Shop at the Brooklyn Museum, and then the Crafts of All Nations shops at The United Nations. From 1992, George was a volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum in the European Sculpture and & Decorative Arts library. George was an extraordinary character and will be greatly missed by his family and friends. A private Mass will be held in celebration of his life on Friday, March 20. His family would like to suggest memorial contributions to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, Development Office, 1000 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY 10028-0198, or to The Catholic Worker, 36 East First Street, New York, NY 10003.

It is not a good idea to be too close to Maryland Coach Gary Williams when the Terrapins make a mistake. He will whirl toward the bench and explode to anyone within earshot. It happens often, and Williams can have a face as red as his team's jersey. It is not something as routine as a missed shot that sets him off. It is usually a defensive mistake or a sloppy pass. The assistants seem to brace for it; some even talk back to him. Williams will even stand there and rant to himself, pleading for an answer to how something like this could happen.
JON KESSLER Kessler's Circus

MARKS--Clement E.,M.D., died at his home in Chester, Connecticut at age 72, from pancreatic cancer. Dr. Marks was Clinical Professor of Medicine at the New York University Medical School and attending physician at the New York University Langone Medical Center. He was revered by generations of medical students and medical house staff as an iconic teacher of clinical medicine. Dr. Mark's special expertise was in pulmonary medicine and geriatrics. He was a devoted and compassionate physician to his patients, yet maintained eclectic interests as an avid traveler, gourmet, art collector and amateur architect. Clement Edward Marks, Jr. was born October 6, 1936 in Plymouth, Pennsylvania, to Eleanor and Clement E. Marks. He was graduated from Dartmouth College in 1958 and earned his medical degree from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. He served as intern, resident and chief resident at Bellevue Hospital Medical Center. During 1963-1965 he was Captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps. Following residency he was Fellow in Pulmonary Medicine at NYU and remained there throughout his career. He is survived by his former wife Celine Sullivan, numerous cousins, colleagues and friends. Services will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the LymeAcademy College of Fine Arts, Old Lyme, CT 06371, or the James Beard Foundation, 167 W. 12th St. New York, NY 10011. Services Robinson, Wright & Weymer Funeral Home, Centerbrook, CT.

Whitey Lockman, the New York Giants outfielder-first baseman who set the stage for Bobby Thomson's pennant-winning home run against the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1951 and who played in two World Series at the Polo Grounds, died Tuesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 82. His death was confirmed by Gary Hughes, a Chicago Cubs executive, according to Yahoo Sports, which said the cause was pulmonary illness. Lockman was a former Cubs manager and a longtime member of their organization. The San Francisco Giants and the Cubs observed a moment of silence for Lockman before their exhibition game in Mesa, Ariz., on Wednesday.

An 83-year-old man, who admitted that as a Nazi concentration camp guard he took part in a two-day killing spree in which 42,000 people were killed, was deported to Austria from his home in Wisconsin, immigration officials said. The man, Josias Kumpf, admitted that he participated in a murderous November 1943 Nazi operation that went by the code name Aktion Erntefest -- Operation Harvest Festival -- in which roughly 42,000 Jewish men, women and children were killed at three Nazi camps in eastern Poland in two days. Mr. Kumpf acknowledged that his role was as a guard and an assassin at the Trawniki Labor Camp, where 8,000 men, women and children were shot dead on Nov. 3, 1943, Justice Department officials said. He was taken earlier this week from his home in Racine, Wis., by federal immigration agents. Mr. Kumpf immigrated to the United States from Austria in 1956, and became a citizen in 1964.

OKLAHOMA 82, MORGAN ST. 54 Oklahoma had a scare against 15th-seeded Morgan State with 7 minutes 41 seconds to play when the all-American Blake Griffin got tangled with Morgan State's Ameer Ali. Ali flipped Griffin over his back and Griffin landed on his shoulders. Griffin immediately got up; Ali was ejected. Griffin finished with 28 points as the Sooners (28-5) won in Kansas City, Mo. Griffin made 11 of 12 shots for the Sooners, who shot 61 percent of the field. Morgan State finished its season 23-12. RAY GLIER

Despite a record number of arrests last year and other recent successes, New York City's Department of Investigation has been strapped by budget cuts and is unable to handle as many complaints as it used to, the agency's commissioner told a City Council committee on Thursday. The agency, which is finishing another round of cuts and is facing an even smaller budget for the coming fiscal year, is taking twice as long to do background checks on managers and other supervisors hired by the city, according to the commissioner, Rose Gill Hearn.

He was a true colleague and friend, and we will miss him dearly. Continental Grain Company

RICHARDSON--Natasha. The board of trustees and staff of amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research, mourn the sudden, tragic loss of our good friend and amfAR trustee Natasha Richardson. An ardent advocate of AIDS research, Ms. Richardson was an eloquent and persuasive spokesperson who generously contributed her time and resources to amfAR over a period of more than 15 years. She brought to our cause an exquisite combination of warmth, intelligence, drive, poise, and glamour. While her initial motivation for supporting AIDS causes was prompted by the death of her father from AIDS, it was clear that her abiding commitment was the product of her own deep-seated compassion for all people. Among many accomplishments, in 1999 she spearheaded Unforgettable: Fashion of the Oscars, an auction of Oscar dresses that raised more than $1.5 million. In November 2000, she was honored with amfAR's Award of Courage. In September 2006, Ms. Richardson joined amfAR's board of trustees, and most recently she was a featured speaker at the Foundation's annual New York Gala fundraiser on February 12, 2009. On that occasion, she spoke passionately about recent progress in AIDS research and voiced her optimism that a cure for AIDS will be found. Her radiant enthusiasm will be sorely missed by all at amfAR and by the HIV/AIDS community worldwide. Our hearts go out to Liam, the children, and the whole family. Kenneth Cole, Chairman of the Board, Mathilde Krim, Ph.D., Founding Chairman, Kevin Robert Frost, CEO.

An article last Friday about a West Hollywood artist, Scott Griesbach, who drilled a hot spring at his second home in Twentynine Palms, Calif., referred incorrectly to the reason Mr. Griesbach is more suited to discussing art than natural resource extraction. As an artist, he would be considered a right-brained type, not a left-brained type.

The House overwhelmingly approved on Thursday a near total tax on bonuses paid this year to employees of the American International Group and other firms that have accepted large amounts of federal bailout funds, rattling Wall Street as lawmakers rushed to respond to populist anger. Despite questions about the legality of the retroactive 90 percent levy, Democrats and some Republicans said the tax on bonuses for traders, executives and bankers earning more than $250,000 was the quickest way to show angry Americans that Congress intended to recoup the extra dollars. Even backers of the measure noted it was an extraordinary step.

DALRYMPLE--Dennis M.,died Thursday, March 5, in New York City. He was 67. He is survived by his wife, Jamie Raab, and their children, son Ian Dalrymple and daughter Lola Dalrymple. The cause of death was a cerebral hemorrhage. In a forty year career in book publishing as a literary contracts expert, he consulted with hundreds of authors, publishers and literary agents. He worked with such companies as Avon Books, Dell Publishing and Harper and Row (now HarperCollins), and then joined Warner Books as Director of Contracts where he stayed for 17 years. There, he met his wife, Jamie Raab, who is currently Publisher of Grand Central Books (formerly Warner Books). He was born in Waterloo, Iowa to Dwight Marion Dalrymple and Willa (Bette) Rasche, and grew up in Sarasota, Florida, before moving to New York City. Dennis loved New York City with the passion of a transplant, living first in Greenwich Village and in recent years on the Upper West Side. Mr. Dalrymple was a longtime anti-war activist who never met a war he wasn't prepared to protest. He was a founding member of the Youth International Party, its members known as Yippies, formed in 1967 by leftists and cultural icons Jerry Rubin, Abbie Hoffman and Paul Krassner to radicalize hippie youth to protest the Vietnam War. He also nominated Pigasus the Pig for President at the 1968 convention. Mr. Dalrymple was an avid news junkie, an expert cook, a loyal friend, and, most of all, a devoted husband and father. Mr. Dalrymple is also survived by his sister, Sandra Scanlan; his stepmother, Marion Dalrymple; his four half sisters Jennifer Heit, Julie Rexford, Jere Gilbert and Jane Murphy. A memorial services will be held on Thursday, March 19th at 4 pm at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South in New York City.

URQUIJO--Rocio Novales, mother to Mercedes and Inigo Zobel, grandmother and beloved friend, died Thursday at her home in New York where she had lived for the past 29 years. Rocio Urquijo Novales was born in Madrid on April 21, 1935 to Rosario Novales and Francisco Urquijo. As an artist, Rocio Urquijo has been recognized as an exceptional and gifted artist of imagination and ingenuity, especially in her color sense. She will be deeply missed by everyone.

The last time Pittsburgh guard Levance Fields played on the court here, in late December 2007, he fractured the fifth metatarsal bone in his left foot. And now that Fields has returned to the scene, he must confront questions about another injury, this time to his groin. The foot fracture caused Fields to miss a significant portion of the 2007-8 season. The groin injury, which he sustained against Marquette on March 4 and which appeared to hamper him three days later against Connecticut, kept him out of nine straight days of practice.

Sure, it’s preposterous: a group including Bun E. Carlos from Cheap Trick on drums, James Iha from Smashing Pumpkins on guitar, Adam Schlesinger from Fountains of Wayne on bass and Taylor Hanson from the onetime teenypop idols Hanson on vocals. That group is Tinted Windows, a multi-generational alliance devoted to power pop as barefaced 1970’s nostalgia. The smiling, hard-hitting Mr. Carlos is the band’s link to the halcyon era, with Mr. Hanson–in red pants, white shades and loosened necktie at a Friday afternoon set–dressed as a latter-day version of Cheap Trick’s singer, Robin Zander and singing with a breathy yelp that can edge into a rasp.

Years of rock-showcase experience have shown me that Japan likes to export jokey concept bands that quickly wear thin. So had I not looked at a wrong date in the SXSW schedule, I never would have ended up seeing BO PEEP, a three-woman hard-rock band from Tokyo. Lucky me. There was no joke about BO PEEP’s brutally efficient riffing, whether the band was bashing out brusque one-chord stomps or dissonant metal lines or blaring punk. The vocals were usually unintelligible — I’m pretty sure they were in English — with a touch of Yoko Ono quaver. But no matter. BO PEEP could strongarm itself a place alongside any American or English stoner rock band, and should.

Friday turned into my night of hymns and incantations. At the Central Presbyterian Church, the Low Anthem, from Providence, R.I., harmonized on slow, sustained songs — often waltzes — using instruments like harmonium, clarinet, some kind of small euphonium and a set of metaldiscs played with a bow for eerie high tones, perfect accompaniment for lines like “Oh, my God, the water’s all around.” Most of the music was stately and mournful, with lyrics contemplating faith, loss, destruction and self-destruction in visionary imagery: “They say the sky’s the limit/The sky’s about to fall.” Every so often, making the quiet songs sound even quieter, the Low Anthem played something electric, bluesy and distorted, but equally serene in its desolation.
King Khan and the Shrines: Unabashed sleaze = rock’s origin?

“Don’t Shoot I’m a Man” was the opening song at Devo’s show on Friday night – a new number and, of course, a jokey one, given the group’s We-Are-Robots style (and dance moves). Taking the stage in their trademark gray jumpsuits, they played in front of an enormous video screen with images that were at once sharply designed and satirical – like a scrolling riff on the iPod commercial dancers, who slowly morphed into apes, a double-edged pun (‘devo’ stands for devolution). Is Devo making fun of the music industry? Yes, of course. But they’re having fun doing it, sort of. “After hatching this about 30 years ago as an art school joke, it’s now an all too hideous reality,” Gerald Casale, one of the groups founders, said at a press conference earlier in the day, Billboard.com reported. “So we’re just here to entertain everybody who’s as devolved as we are now.”

My Sunday column is about education reform and focuses on Michelle Rhee, the remarkable chancellor in Washington D.C. Some of the criticisms are reasonable -- she has led with her chin in ways that added to antagonism and distrust among teachers -- but at the end of the day the children in Washington seem likely to benefit significantly, after decades of neglect. If she can turn around the schools there, and test scores suggest she's beginning to, then that will be a historic accomplishment. More broadly, she has been willing to face some of the toughest issues, including the need to replace ineffective teachers, in a way that I admire.

WISCONSIN 61, FLORIDA STATE 59 Trevon Hughes's spinning lay-in with two seconds left in overtime lifted 12th-seeded Wisconsin to an upset of fifth-seeded Florida State in Boise, Idaho. With the Badgers trailing, 59-58, Hughes, a junior from Queens, drove the lane against Toney Douglas. Hughes drew a foul on a spin move and banked the ball off the glass and through the basket. After Hughes made the ensuing free throw, Florida State's long inbounds pass was batted away.

Stocks dropped on Friday as investors worried about the consequences of efforts on Capitol Hill to claw back bonuses from firms that received government bailouts. Financial shares pulled down the broader markets, giving back many of their gains from earlier in the week. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 122.42 points, or 1.65 percent, to 7,278.38, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 15.5 points, or 1.98 percent, to 768.54. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index declined 26.21 points, or 1.77 percent, to 1,457.27.

Borrowing a page from Syracuse and Connecticut, Ohio State, the No. 8 seed in the Midwest Region, and Siena, the No. 9 seed, needed two overtimes to settle their first-round N.C.A.A. tournament game here Friday night. Siena outlasted Ohio State by the end of the second overtime, thanks to the junior guard Ronald Moore, who not only tied the score at the end of the first overtime with a 3-pointer but also won the game with another one that he sank with 3.9 seconds remaining. Siena will play Louisville on Sunday in a second-round game.

RODRIGUEZ--Alberto Rafael, founding partner and chief creative officer of the preeminent Hispanic advertising agency REVOLUCION, died suddenly of a heart attack on Sunday morning in Manhattan. He was 40 years old. Born on August 14, 1968, in Miami, Fla., Alberto was the son of Hilda Gasca and the late Alberto Rodriguez. He had one sister, Barbara Macina of Clifton, New Jersey, and was devotedly married to Tre Miller-Rodriguez. For nearly 20 years, Alberto delighted consumers and clients with his award-winning campaigns. At Hispanic Marketing Services in Miami, his meteoric rise on the Coca-Cola and Seagrams campaigns caught the attention of The Vidal Partnership, which recruited him to New York in 1992. In 2000, Alberto and his colleague Federico Mejer founded REVOLUCION, which is 100% Hispanic owned and operated. Ad Age ranked the agency among the Top 20 Hispanic Independent Agencies in 2007. He is survived by his wife, mother, sister and step-father, Hector Gasca of Miami, Fla. Flowers can be sent to the funeral home (address below) and donations in his name can be made to the American Heart Association (americanheart.org). Friends may attend a viewing on Friday from 2pm - 5pm and 7pm - 9pm at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street (greenwichvillagefuneralhome.com). A funeral service will be held Saturday at the First Presbyterian Church on Fifth Avenue, 12 West 12th Street, at 3pm. A celebration of his life will follow immediately afterward - and forever.

Sir Nicholas Henderson, an urbane, gregarious and often flamboyant diplomat who labored to win the Reagan administration's backing for Britain's military campaign to recover the Falkland Islands and was considered by many of his peers to be one of Britain's most distinguished postwar diplomats, died Monday in London, family members said. He was 89. An Oxford-educated diplomat, he was settling into a new life in retirement in 1979 after holding ambassadorships in Poland, France and Germany, when Britain's incoming prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, named him ambassador to Washington.

There are few players in the country who incite opponents the way Oklahoma's Blake Griffin does. He throws his 251 pounds into the lane with spin moves and post-ups and can clear space with the subtle force of a lean-in. Griffin, a 6-foot-10 forward, serves up physical play and it is sometimes served right back to him, maybe with a measure of scorn attached. This season he has sustained a concussion, received stitches, been flipped, taken a knee to the groin and received assorted blows to the head.

10 P.M. (Sundance) POISON FRIENDS (2006) In Emmanuel Bourdieu's psychological thriller set in French literary academia, Thibault Vinçon, above, plays André, an erudite, charismatic graduate scholar who serves as a mentor to two younger, impressionable students (Alexandre Steiger and Malik Zidi). But falling under André's spell is risky: he's also a manipulative control freak who enjoys playing with people's lives. ''As a group portrait of apprentice intellectuals the film has an almost documentary accuracy,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It also has a degree of energy, an appetite for strong feelings and big ideas, notably missing in American movies about the young and overeducated, which tend to specialize in mumbled ironies and tiny epiphanies.'' 8 P.M. (National Geographic) ICY KILLERS: SECRETS OF ALASKA'S SALMON SHARK Once a year on the northernmost coast of the Gulf of Alaska thousands of ravenous salmon sharks gather to attack millions of Pacific salmon desperate to reach their spawning grounds in Prince William Sound. But how is the salmon shark able to survive icy waters, unlike the 400 or so other known shark species?

President Obama quickly apologized for his quip on ''The Tonight Show'' on NBC on Thursday comparing his modest bowling skills to those of athletes who have disabilities. Chatting with the host, Jay Leno, the president said he had been practicing at the White House bowling alley and rolled a 129. ''It was like the Special Olympics or something,'' Mr. Obama said.

FINK--Edith (Boloker), 90, loving and much loved wife, mother, grandmother and friend, died peacefully Saturday, March 7, in Atlanta, GA. after a short illness. She was born October 27, 1918 in Brooklyn, NY, one of two children of Isaac and Mae Boloker. She attended the New York City schools, and graduated from James Madison High School and Hunter College. Predeceased by her husband, Harold Fink, and eldest son, Dr. Edward B. Fink, Edith at various points in her life served as a bookkeeper, full-time mother and valuable back-up at Majestic Car Wash, her family's business. She leaves a daughter, Elizabeth Leaderman, and a son-in-law, Dr. Scott Leaderman, both of Atlanta, a son, David Fink, and a daughter-in-law, Phyllis Hyman, both of West Hartford, CT. She also leaves six grandchildren, Jason, Laura, Jennifer, Ian, Ben and Jessie, and two great-grandchildren, Savannah and Kelly. A member of Hadassah and ORT, she was an avid reader, a movie lover, a Frank Sinatra admirer and a well-informed observer of current affairs. She was a splendid cook, a talented seamstress and a committed volunteer. Above all, she was a devoted wife, loving mother and grandmother, and an uncommonly thoughtful, committed friend who maintained relationships for decades. She loved ice cream and lilacs, but mostly she loved her husband and family, always thinking of them first and herself last. Burial was March 9 at Star of David Cemetery in North Lauderdale, FL. Memorial donations may be made to The Jewish Tower, 3160 Howell Mill Road, Atlanta, GA. 30327.

Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.
