BERNSTEIN--Milton, 91, beloved husband of Ray (deceased) of Monroe, NJ, formerly of Boynton Beach, FL and Jericho, NY, passed away on March 20, 2009. He is survived by his adoring children, Dr. Jay Bernstein (Sandy), Dr. Larry Bernstein (Diane), Sandy Lenger (Dr. Steven) and loving grandchildren, Emily, Amy, Jane, Marisa, Benjamin (Efrat), Samuel, Paul and Carly. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend. Funeral services will be held Sunday, March 22, 2009 at 10am at the East Brunswick (NJ) Jewish Center.

What could have been a Texan spectacular for the last night of South By Southwest was a near-debacle instead. It was a double bill at the Auditorium Shores riverside amphitheater with Erykah Badu and the Cannabinoids, her digitally oriented producers from Dallas, and Explosions in the Sky, Austin’s majestic instrumental rock band.

There were so many rumors about when Kanye West’s “secret” show would start that by the time he actually took the stage at 9 p.m. at the Fader Fort on Saturday, people were literally running to catch him, cameras held aloft. He rewarded their adoration with a long set, though he was often more an emcee than a performer, introducing guests and collaborators like Erykah Badu, Common, Fonzworth Bentley, the spoken word artist Malik Yusef, and the rappers 88 Keys, Kid Cudi and Consequence. Technically the event was a showcase for Mr. West’s label, G.O.O.D. Records, and he spent more time talking up his performers than himself, boasting that they would soon be arena-sized; when they were on stage, he watched from the wings.

Pity Ida Marie and Yelle. They were the final two performers at the Perez Hilton showcase on Saturday night (read: early Sunday morning), and they had the misfortune to go on after Kanye West showed up to do a spontaneous set, just a few hours after getting off stage at the Fader Fort a few blocks away. Both spaces were awash in branding: the Fader Fort included a pop-up Levi’s store as well as booths for Ray-Bans and online T-shirt companies, and the Perez party had a “Dell playground” (a swing set and slide set up indoors on Astroturf, a convenient place to pass out), plus free drinks. Backstage the artists were handed Dell computers to pose with. No one seemed to mind.

My first drink - if you don't count my childhood best friend mixing together a little of everything from her parent's liquor cabinet and daring me to drink it - was a strawberry daiquiri. I was 16 years old and at a bar called Amberjacks in New Orleans. The bar was a local favorite of friends I'd met doing summer stock in Maine. Of course, these friends were older and I was mooning over one of them, a guy who was doing dinner theatre in Metairie and who lived with a ferret. In retrospect, it's no wonder I felt the need to drink. I pined uselessly after Gary while a strange Russian woman named Laneshka kept lurching into him and putting her hand on his knee. I thought I was terribly sophisticated, as 16-year-old girls drinking fruity, frothy drinks often do.

For women who love a perfect pair of heels, the French shoe designer Christian Louboutin is a gatekeeper to desire. Thankfully, he makes shoes - ultra-high stilettos, pumps covered in spikes, marzipan-colored lace-ups - that cater to almost any fancy. When it comes to his craft, Louboutin is unyielding. ''When I design my summer collection, I must work in a hot place,'' he says. ''And I must be in a cold place when I design for winter.'' This year he chose Brazil for the summer; his estate in the French countryside has no heat and is therefore ideal for wintertime. A consummate globe-trotter, Louboutin always packs light: ''I only do carry-on.'' But what about fanatics who can't bear to part with their Louboutins when they travel? ''My advice to them would be to ship the pairs before. That way, they can bring as many as they'd like.''

False starters in sprints face immediate exclusion from the race under a new proposal by the world governing body of track and field. Currently, one false start is allowed per race; another false start means the automatic exclusion of the guilty sprinter regardless of who caused the first false start. The new rule would mean an immediate expulsion for any offender.

The baseball players association filed a grievance against the major league clubs after the Los Angeles Dodgers said charitable donations would be required in future player contracts. “They’re making a lot of money, these players,” Frank McCourt, the Dodgers’ owner, said Thursday. The Major League Baseball Players Association filed the grievance Friday, saying the requirement violated baseball’s collective bargaining agreement. Unless the grievance is settled, the matter will be decided by the arbitrator Shyam Das. charity.

To the Editor: Your article “Riding the Rails” revived recollections of a wonderful nine-week Amtrak trip circumnavigating (well, not quite) your wonderfully diverse country back in 1999.

To the Editor: I hope that Amtrak’s weaknesses take their sweet time catching up with those of the airlines, because my husband and I prefer to ride trains, even though their already-higher costs keep rising and the erratic amenities are gradually eroding. We love watching the rivers and mountains pass by, towns light up, stations come and go; we love talking in the dark from our respective bunks as the train rattles and sways as it takes us to our destination. There is time to read, to write, and to think about where we’ve been, where we’re headed. Amtrak used to offer “slumber coaches,” tiny individual compartments only slightly more expensive than regular coach fare. Reviving those would make us monumentally happy. There is a Zen saying: Do not hasten, my friend — you may arrive. Carol Pearce-Worthington.

To the Editor: Regarding your article on scenic trains, you might also mention one of the lesser known but fabulously scenic train trips of the world: the ride from Belgrade, Serbia, to Bar, Montenegro, on the Adriatic coast. During a 9-to-10-hour trip, this train goes through more than 250 tunnels and hugs countless mountainsides. The route was constructed by Tito in the 1970s and had no true economic purpose. But it does provide an unforgettable rail experience. Steve Kutay.

To the Editor: Andy Isaacson’s “Riding the Rails” (March 8) brought back many wonderful memories. In late winter of 1996, three young daughters and I began a cross-country “home school” excursion. I’m sure I am not the first charcutourist to come to Corsica with an extra suitcase for sausage. Sausage made from wild boar. Spicy salami-style sausage. Sausage made from pork livers soaked in red wine, stuffed into casings and hung above the fireplace to smoke. So when I met my first local, a food-obsessed 20-something named Olympe Ricco, I immediately asked her where I could find the island’s best. She shot me a look of utter incredulity: “But the sausage is fini for the season.”.

It is a chilly Thursday evening in Toronto, and the habitués of the city’s Parkdale neighborhood are, as usual, spoiled for choice. A former manufacturing district west of downtown, Parkdale is the city’s prime destination for the young, the bohemian, the studiously shaggy — the epicenter of an art and indie-music boom that has prompted locals to nickname their town Torontopia.
The View From Here.

WHO’S THERE The city is brimming with creative types lured up from Melbourne and Sydney by low taxes and plentiful jobs. Advertising agencies and design firms continue to move in, creating a stable but lively base for artists, writers and musicians, particularly in the areas of New Farm and Fortitude Valley.

A surge in new galleries and museums in Mexico City is making the capital — and Latin American art in general — the culturati’s latest fixation. After nearly a decade without a permanent space of its own, the city’s leading contemporary art gallery, Kurimanzutto (Gobernador Rafael Rebollar 94), finally christened its new home in November. The renovated lumberyard building shows Mexican and international artists including Miguel Calderón and Rirkrit Tiravanija. In the Roma neighborhood, the popular graffiti- and street-art gallery Centro Cultural Border (Zacatecas 43) moved into a larger space and added a lively cafe and bookshop. And a few doors down from the restaurant Contramar (Durango 200), an art-scene hangout, the curator Fernando Mesta shows local talent like Guillermo Santamarina (right) at his new space, Gaga (Durango 204). On the institutional front, the big arrival is the Museo Universitario Arte Contemporáneo (Insurgentes Sur 3000), which made a splashy opening with a notorious installation by Miguel Ventura that used Nazi imagery and live lab rats. The Centro Cultural Universitario Tlatelolco (Ricardo Flores Magón 1), a former government ministry, shows a stirring exhibit about Mexico’s 1968 student rebellion; it also houses the Colección Blaisten, which has a remarkable private collection of Mexican painting from the revolution to the 1980s. And there’s more to come: next year, the billionaire magnate Carlos Slim Helú’s Museo Soumaya will move into its new home, a dazzling white sea-sponge-shaped structure by Fernando Romero. [?][?][?] DANIEL HERNANDEZ.

It feels almost wrong to call Bioparc Valencia a zoo, even though the $75 million menagerie, which completes its first building phase in the Spanish city this spring, is home to some 4,000 animals. It’s more like an ecologically minded theme park. There are no cages on the almost 25 acres, and species mingle in recreated ecosystems as they would in the wild. Impalas run with giraffes and rhinos chase zebras at the African Savanna exhibit. Lions observe this delectable scene (but dine elsewhere) from atop granite cliffs. Visitors take it all in on paths separated from the animals by rivers or rocks or, as in the tropical jungle, from inside tunnels disguised as fallen trees. And these are only the visible innovations. Because many of the 250 species are endangered or threatened, the park is creating reserve populations that could be returned to the wild. “It is a last resort in the case of extinction,” says Bioparc’s general director, Koen Brouwer. “We prefer to use the animals as ambassadors to make people aware of the dangers and prevent the worst.” Apartado de Correos 15005; bioparcvalencia.es/ingles.html. [?][?][?] DALE FUCHS.

Style and practicality don’t usually mix when it comes to women’s shoes. But Phootlery defies the odds. Discreet elastic loops secure the interchangeable straps, which run from gemstone-encrusted to gladiatoresque, and make that weekend beach bag a lot lighter. From $140; go to phootlery.com. The Amara spa in the Park Hyatt is a kind of international pupu platter of pampering — there are Andalusian fountains, Beverly Hills-esque garden suites, hallways scented with tropical blossoms and many Moroccan-lantern-lit nooks in which to escape. The treatments, which use Carita products and Middle Eastern oils, include an Indian head massage and a Dead Sea salt bath, and there’s an outdoor rain shower to release your inner emir. 011-971-4-602-1234.
Books.

FROM LAP DOGS TO SNOW GLOBES to Fabergé eggs, miniatures have always delighted humanity, and — if my vacations are any indication — countries are no exception. In my travels, I’ve often gone hundreds of miles out of my way to visit improbably tiny sovereign states, not knowing myself what it was that drew me to them, and usually regretting the detour. Andorra, that enigmatic republic in the Pyrenees, revealed itself to be a cluster of duty-free shops and dusty, neglected-looking hills; Monaco felt like a glorified suburb of Nice; and Vatican City, despite the pomp, seemed like little more than one of Rome’s less charming neighborhoods. As with any obsession, however, disappointment only sharpened my desire. The impossible country of my imagination existed somewhere, I was sure of it: the fact that I hadn’t been there yet was the best proof of its magical obscurity. What’s more, I had a hunch as to this mysterious nation’s location, and even as to what it might be called. I was reasonably sure its name was Liechtenstein.

SINCE 1871, when it rose spectacularly after the Great Fire, Chicago has been famous for pioneering architecture — from the steel-frame skyscraper to the flat geometry of the Prairie School to Mies van der Rohe’s clean Minimalism. When it comes to cutting-edge fashion, though, the city rarely registered. Lost between the glamorous coasts, it’s been a no-style zone. Until now.
PARK HYATT DUBAI.
Cleverly capturing the world’s attention with a series of megaprojects, Dubai became the world’s first branded city. But what of the projects themselves?.

I’m sure I am not the first charcutourist to come to Corsica with an extra suitcase for sausage. Sausage made from wild boar. Spicy salami-style sausage. Sausage made from pork livers soaked in red wine, stuffed into casings and hung above the fireplace to smoke. So when I met my first local, a food-obsessed 20-something named Olympe Ricco, I immediately asked her where I could find the island’s best. She shot me a look of utter incredulity: “But the sausage is fini for the season.”.

I have a neighbor named Richard. He’s a prime example of what I call a Baby Boomer Bummer. Richard was a globe-trotter in the late ’60s and ’70s, before exotic travel became popular with the masses. When I pass him in the hall with my suitcase, he always asks where I’m going — then interrupts to wax euphoric about how much better my destination was back in his day. Evidently, food and sex were not only free, but better and unlimited.

For women who love a perfect pair of heels, the French shoe designer Christian Louboutin is a gatekeeper to desire. Thankfully, he makes shoes — ultra-high stilettos, pumps covered in spikes, marzipan-colored lace-ups — that cater to almost any fancy. When it comes to his craft, Louboutin is unyielding. “When I design my summer collection, I must work in a hot place,” he says. “And I must be in a cold place when I design for winter.” This year he chose Brazil for the summer; his estate in the French countryside has no heat and is therefore ideal for wintertime. A consummate globe-trotter, Louboutin always packs light: “I only do carry-on.” But what about fanatics who can’t bear to part with their Louboutins when they travel? “My advice to them would be to ship the pairs before. That way, they can bring as many as they’d like.” [?][?][?] ALEX HAWGOOD.

It wasn’t just foreclosures that ravaged the Cleveland neighborhoods described by Alex Kotlowitz (March 8). The automatic-eviction policies of banks are also to blame. The extent of the tragedy of abandonment and neighborhood decline could have been avoided if banks allowed eligible tenants and home­owners to pay rent and live in the foreclosed properties until they were sold to new owners.

An article on March 1 about the art collectors Jose Mugrabi and his sons, Alberto and David, referred imprecisely to a sculpture of theirs that was at the Guggenheim. It was exhibited by the museum as a “promised gift,” but when the Mugrabis chose not to donate it, the museum returned it to them. It was not bought back by the Mugrabis.

I was struck by Sara Corbett’s use of the words “real” and “reality” (March 8). While it is fair to describe the avatar Filthy Fluno and his ilk as “a series of scripted animations,” it is not quite correct to say “none of it is real.” Notably, virtual currency (the money Filthy earns selling in the virtual world) is real. Virtual experiences, commerce and relationships are real. Struck with these new mixed realities, many in the field have replaced the terms “real life” and “real world” with “physical life” and “physical world,” because virtual spaces, whether they are fictional or imagined, are not imaginary. These are live, populated spaces — we could be there now.

I have to disagree with the rosy picture Mark Levine painted of Zipcar (March 8). It has not been my experience that you can go online at any time and find a choice of cars waiting for you around the corner. At least not in my city. Since about last Memorial Day, if you try to make a reservation on a weekend, your likelihood of finding anything at all available (forgetting about luxury models, for which the rate structure is less advantageous) for immediate use is actually quite slim.

HOW much does it cost to own a car? Wheels readers debated that issue after I posted an article about how the recession has helped to decrease driving. I have since found that the cost of car ownership is probably a whole lot more than you think. If your estimates are based on what you paid for your vehicle, plus the cost of gas, oil and repairs, you're forgetting about insurance, depreciation, parking fees, tolls and registration, among other things. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, American ''consumer units'' (similar to a household) spent an average of $8,758 on all forms of transportation in 2007 (up 2.9 percent from 2006). We're a car-owning country, so only $537.81 of our average spending went to public transit, including taxis and air travel. The latter expenses would appear to skew the statistics because the lowest-income fifth of the population spent an average of $171.30 annually on transit and the richest fifth $1,406.45.

WORTH & WORTH'S Jakob hat, a dusty-hued Western with a tall crown, a floppy brim and a well-worn patina that takes a week to produce, is no Easter bonnet. It isn't precious. It doesn't say ''spring.'' Yet it has a rugged elegance that will always have appeal. Its namesake, the musician Jakob Dylan, fell for it the minute he saw it. The playwright David Mamet put it on his wish list. (''He told me if anyone came into the shop asking what he wants,'' recalled Orlando Palacios, the Worth & Worth owner and designer, ''I should tell them this hat.'') And Robert Geller, whom GQ has named best new men's wear designer in America, incorporated a black version into his fall collection. But it is now, just as spring's cool, rainy days begin, that the hat, which is unisex and made to order, is especially desirable. ''The more weathered it gets,'' Mr. Palacios said, ''the better it looks.'' Jakob hat, $425 at Worth & Worth, 45 West 57th Street; (212) 265-2887.

ROZEK--Professor Edward J. October 13, 1918-February 19, 2009. Edward Rozek passed away at his home of natural causes on February 19, 2009. A professor of comparative governments at the University of Colorado, he was born and raised in Poland. After the country was overrun by Hitler and Stalin, he escaped via Hungary, Yugoslavia, and Italy to France. There he joined the First Polish Armored Brigade which took part in the defense of Paris. After France fell, he made his way to England. He became commander of a platoon of tanks in the 10th Reconnaissance Regiment of the First Polish Armoured Division, which fought from Normandy to northern Germany. He was wounded three times. The last time he was blinded by an anti-tank land mine and spent 10 months in English and Scottish hospitals. He received four Purple Hearts, three Crosses of Valor, four British war medals, and Polonia Restituta Officer Class and Komandoria. He ended his military career with the rank of Major. In 1948, the British Government gave him, as a former officer, a one-way ticket to anywhere in the world. He chose to take the Queen Mary to America. He arrived with no family, only $50 and a suitcase full of books. After working on a dairy farm and then a gas station to earn college tuition, he was admitted to Harvard where he earned three degrees: A.B. (magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa), A.M. and Ph.D. In 1956, he became a professor of comparative governments at the University of Colorado. He directed the Central and East European Studies Program for 25 years and was deputy editor of the Journal of Central and East European Affairs. He founded and for 34 years directed the Institute for the Study of Economic and Political Freedom. He also founded and directed from 1972 to 1999 the Center for Science and Technology, which organized numerous conferences in which several Nobel Prize winners and other distinguished scholars from American and European universities participated. He lectured at many universities and public institutions in the United States, Europe, South Korea, the Republic of China, and South Africa. Professor Rozek wrote several books. The best-known is Allied Wartime Diplomacy, for which he received the National Book Foundation Award. The American philosopher Sidney Hook dedicated his book, Academic Freedom and Academic Anarchy, as follows: "To Edward J. Rozek---Embattled fighter for free men, free society and the free university against fascism, communism and totalitarian liberalism." CU students elected him Professor of the Year and Distinguished Faculty Member. After teaching for 43 years at the University of Colorado, Professor Rozek retired in 1999. From 2000 to 2003, he held the Endowed Garnsey-Rozek Professorship in Economics and Political Freedom at the University of Northern Colorado. During the 1980 Presidential campaign, Professor Rozek was a member of Ronald Reagan's Advisory Council on Defense and Foreign Policy. He was an honorary member of the legendary Solidarity of Poland and received Knighthood in the Venerable Order of St. John, which was founded around 1100 AD. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth; his sons, Christopher and Jonathan, and four grandchildren, Alexander, Philip, Thomas and Christina. Services were held at Sacred Heart of Mary Church in Boulder, CO on February 24. Memorial contributions can be made to the Orphanage for the Blind and the Deaf and sent to Wells Fargo Bank, PO Box 227, Boulder, CO 80306-9980.

NICHOLLS--Richard Hall, 70, of Stamford, CT, died March 14th after a courageous ten-year battle with cancer. He continues to be an inspiration to his devoted family and friends for his integrity, wisdom and keen sense of humor. Rich was a nationally recognized tax lawyer in the tax-exempt bond field. He was a former head of the tax department at Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon and was of counsel to Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe. Rich was called "the tax lawyer's tax lawyer" in The Bond Lawyer and was a valued mentor and friend to the many successful attorneys he worked with during his 40-year career. His colleagues described him as insightful and creative, with an encyclopedic memory and an ability to "say more with fewer words than anyone else they knew." He did extensive pro bono work for the American Bar Association and the National Association of Bond Lawyers and in 2000, was awarded the Bernard P. Friel Award for distinguished service in public finance. Rich graduated from The Hill School, Amherst College and Stanford Law School and received a master's degree in tax from NYU. He was an avid sailor, skier and swimmer and a former Captain of the Amherst swimming team. He was a longtime member of the Stamford Yacht Club and loved racing competitively on his boat, Rhiannon. Above all, Rich was a man who knew how to enjoy life and cherish his family. He was a truly exceptional and loving father, brother and grandfather, as well as husband to his late wife, Anne. He will be dearly missed by all of his family and friends, including his devoted children, Jamie Nicholls Biondi and Christopher Nicholls, their spouses, Fran and Yvonne, his six much loved grandchildren, and his first wife and mother of his children, Judy Cormier. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Rich's honor to The Myeloma Institute for Research and Therapy (attention: Betty Tucker), University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences, 4301 West Markham St., Slot 816, Little Rock, AR 72205. A private gathering of friends to remember and honor Rich will be held in late April.

THE NEWSMartin Brodeur, the goaltender for the New Jersey Devils since 1993, notched the 552nd regular-season victory of his National Hockey League career on Tuesday, breaking the league record. BEHIND THE NEWS After deflecting a shot by Troy Brouwer of the Chicago Blackhawks with three seconds remaining to preserve a 3-2 lead and claim the record, Brodeur cut down one of the nets he defended during the game as a souvenir. The goalie he eclipsed, Patrick Roy, retired in 2003 after 12 seasons with the Montreal Canadiens and 8 with the Colorado Avalanche; Roy still holds the league record for combined regular-season and playoff victories, with 702.

If it feels like there's a bit more elbow room on the train into work these days, you're not imagining it. Job losses from the recession appear to be rippling through the public transport system. New Jersey Transit says ridership dipped in January and February for the first time after five years of record growth. The growth trend began to shift in the last three months of last year, when ridership was still growing but at the slowest rate since 2004, according to Dan Stessel, the director of media relations for New Jersey Transit, who cautioned that the data was very preliminary.

OUTPOSTS March Madness is our greatest sideshow, mood-lifter and time-suck all in one. It's sports at its most thrilling, more so than the slow choreography of the World Series, the bloated spectacle of the Super Bowl or the go-through-the-motions slog of professional basketball playoffs. And forget about college football, which may have its championship system determined by Congress. There, a ''national title'' is conferred on a team that gets the highest ratings in a bowl sponsored by a company now in receivership. Give me the clean, no-excuse trials of the young hoopsters. Hilltoppers and Huskies, Owls and Orangemen, Sun Devils and Blue Devils (the Satan subset). One of 65 teams will emerge champion. No dispute. Lose a game, you're gone. Win six in a row, you're King of the World.
Pop/Jazz Ben Ratliff

The look in Paris on the thousands of women gathered for the recent designer shows was all about legs and their coverings: leggings, tights and seamed stockings. BEAUTY-wise, nothing pops quite like a pair of orange lips; and from soft tangerine to saucy blood orange, they were all over the spring and fall runways. ''It's a glamorous look,'' said the makeup artist Diane Kendal, who painted the models' lips a sun-kissed coral for Proenza Schouler's spring show (above left). And bold as it is, it's surprisingly wearable. Maxine Leonard, who used MAC Meltdown for Karen Walker's fall show, advises women with dark skin tones to use an orange with a hint of red or blue, while those with pale skin should stick with more pastel shades. ''Whether it's an orange-tinted gloss or something more opaque, it's a nice alternative to red,'' she said. ''And it feels modern.'' MAC So Chaud, Morange and CB96 lipsticks, $14 at MAC shops.

LIKE many musicians who play for the handful of small professional orchestras outside of New York City these days, Gabriel Schaff, a violinist, is struggling to cobble together a living. Mr. Schaff, 49, has contracts that guarantee work with four orchestras, including the Stamford Symphony Orchestra and Long Island Philharmonic. He substitutes in others, including the Westfield Symphony Orchestra in Union County. And he takes side work, like Broadway shows, in between. But side work has grown scarcer as Broadway retrenches. Substitute jobs are in shorter supply. Nearly all the orchestras Mr. Schaff regularly plays for are offering less work than in the past, because of the economic downturn. And one of those groups, the Opera Orchestra of New York, has just canceled its two remaining shows this season at Carnegie Hall, citing significant reductions in ''all areas of public support.''

For years, I missed out on March Madness. During my sophomore, junior and senior years at Penn, we dropped games in the first round. It's tough to turn on the television for games when you've let your dream slip out of your fingers. So for three years, I avoided tournament pools like the plague, licked my wounds and recovered in time to watch the Final Four. This year, I thought I'd lose the best weeks in sports for a different reason. When I won a Marshall scholarship to go to Oxford University, giving up basketball was just part of the bargain. The time difference meant games didn't typically end until 3 a.m., and worse, the British aren't exactly basketball fans. It's almost impossible to catch a game on TV. Naturally, I assumed that when March Madness rolled around, I'd find myself hunched over my laptop, streaming games from CBS.

He is survived by his adoring children, Dr. Jay Bernstein (Sandy), Dr. Larry Bernstein (Diane), Sandy Lenger (Dr. Steven) and loving grandchildren, Emily, Amy, Jane, Marisa, Benjamin (Efrat), Samuel, Paul and Carly. He was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend. Funeral services will be held Sunday, March 22, 2009 at 10am at the East Brunswick (NJ) Jewish Center.

McNEELY--Donald, ventured forth from this life on March 9 in Pebble Beach, California, a place he had been drawn to while exploring the most exclusive golf courses of the West Coast with a friend before shipping off to the Pacific Theater of WWII. He was 94 years old and his long life was filled with adventures and successes, unflagging faith and courage, and boundless acts of kindness. Up to the end, he was as sharp as the day he graduated from Yale in 1937. A student of history, keen on current events, he clipped out articles voraciously for family and friends from publications from around the world. Always eager to know more about the world, his enthusiasm for life was evident in his booming voice and ready cheerfulness. His nimble mind, unique wit and impressive vocabulary made him a captivating communicator and wordsmith. His adventures took him from the playing fields of Yale to the wartime battle of Guadalcanal while in the Navy's special intelligence department to the ranks of handpicked advisors serving on Ronald Reagan's "Grace Commission". Don was born on July 10, 1914, in St. Paul, MN and went to St. Paul Academy where sports became one of his grand delights. He won the state squash championship in 1955-57, threw the ball around with his friend, Hank Greenberg, in wartime baseball games, and played tennis until he was 90. In 1962, he became co-owner of the Minnesota Vikings and helped bring the Washington Senators to Minnesota as the Minnesota Twins. He enjoyed the company of others and that translated into club memberships around the country, many involving golf and tennis, like the Cypress Point Club in Pebble Beach, the White Bear Lake Yacht Club, the Yale Club and River Club of New York City; the Minneapolis Club; the Los Angeles Country Club; and the Old Capital Club in Monterey, CA. Sportsmanship influenced how he lived his life. Fair and honorable (his son Kevin said he never made a joke at someone else's expense), he supported causes important to him and paid tribute to those who helped him along the way. He memorialized his beloved aunt and uncle with the Lee and Rose Warner Coliseum at the Minnesota State Fair and the Palestra sports center at St. John's University in Collegeville, MN (where he also funded the McNeely Spectrum, the campus field house), and helped establish the Rose Warner Writing Center and the soon-to-be Rose Warner Science Lab at the College of St. Scholastica in Duluth, MN. He was dedicated to environmental education which resulted over forty years ago in the creation of The Lee and Rose Warner Nature Center, which partners with the Science Museum of Minnesota. He raised five children with his wife and great love, Marjorie, and founded in her name the Marjorie McNeely Conservatoryat Como Park, the Marjorie McNeely Gallery at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, and the Marjorie McNeely Fund for the Blind or Illiterate in Monterey County, CA. A savvy entrepreneur and a innovative thinker, he joined his father's business- The St. Paul Terminal Warehouse Company-after the war and turned it into a national company called Space Center, Inc. He was co-founder of Control Data Corporation and his past directorships include Buckbee-Mears; Conwed Corporation; North Star Research & Development Institute; North Star Steel; Northwest Airlines; Wells Fargo (Norwest Bank); and Red Owl Stores. To give young men and women the skills to succeed in business, he established the Donald McNeely Center for Entrepreneurship at St. John's University in Collegeville, MN. From his cherished home on Manitou Island in White Bear Lake, MN, Don reached out into the community and beyond to help guide religious, civic, arts, and educational organizations like the Catholic Charities, Como Friends, Guthrie Theater, The McNeely Foundation, YMCA, and Yale University where he founded scholarships. Standing at six feet, five inches tall, he was referred to by family and their friends affectionately as "Big D" and left a sizable wake behind him. Donning a bow tie and bachelor button in his lapel, he displayed his own dapper style. He was a generous man, not only with his resources and his time, but also with his heart. Wary of inherited wealth he had optimum respect for those who generated their own good fortune and success. He encouraged his children in their passions believing that he himself "did not work a day in his life" as he remained active in business until his passing day. His daughter Nora wrote of her father last year that his rich and meaningful life had exuded character that was "deep, genuine, complicated, and beautiful". Those who knew him found him to be a true gentlemen and an original and are fortunate souls indeed. His wife Marjorie (nee Reeds) died in 1998. His children, Nora McNeely (Michael) Hurley, Robin Brooks Tost, Greg McNeely, Kevin (Rosemary) McNeely, and Peter (Incy) Brooks, survive him; as do his grandchildren Jamie Tost, Jen (Pete) Masterson, Peter (Jen) Brooks Jr., Holly (Eric) Robinson, and Hannah Rose McNeely and great-grandchildren Piper and Pen Brooks and Miles Masterson; brother Harry G. McNeely, Jr. and eleven nieces and nephews. A memorial Mass and reception to celebrate his life will be held in the spring. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Marjorie McNeely Conservatory at Como Park, 1225 Estabrook Drive, St. Paul, MN 55103.

HANNA--Paul J. Paul J. Hanna was born in Canonsburg, PA and lived in Summit, NJ for many years until he moved to the Ocean Reef Club in Key Largo, FL and Hound Ears Club in Blowing Rock, NC. He passed away peacefully on February 26, 2009. As a farm boy growing up in western Pennsylvania during the Great Depression, he mowed the lawn at the church cemetery for 25 cents an hour and worked to put himself through night school. He graduated with honors from the University of Pittsburgh (where he was a member of the Beta Gamma Sigma Honor Society) and later graduated from the Credit and Financial Management School at Dartmouth College. He grew up to fight for the country he loved, experience a highly successful business career, help others and his community, and be a loyal and loving husband, father and grandfather. He enlisted as a Private in the Army in 1941, and rose to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel in the 101st Airborne Division. He received the Bronze Star, Belgian Croix de Guirre, Dutch Order of William, Presidential Citation with Cluster, and the World War II Victory Medal. After the war, he spent 32 years at Manufacturers Hanover Corporation in New York. He was in charge of its banking in the eastern half of the United States. Later in his career at the Holding Company, he developed its financial-related businesses in consumer finance, leasing and mortgage banking, as well as its footprint in upstate New York. He was a member of the Association of Reserve City Bankers. Paul also served as a director of United Jersey Banks and several of its subsidiaries. Always looking for new challenges, Paul retired early as Executive Vice President of Manufacturers Hanover to become Vice Chairman of GEICO Corporation in Washington, DC and Chairman of its financial services company in Denver. While at GEICO, he negotiated the purchase of 25% interest in AVEMCO, a general aviation insurance company, and served on its board for 15 years. Later, he negotiated the purchase of Manufacturers Hanover Mortgage Company for Fireman's Fund Insurance Company and served on its board (which was called Source One Mortgage Services Company in Southfield, Michigan) for several years. Over the years, Paul served on the boards of 45 companies in banking, insurance and financial-related businesses. Paul cared deeply for others and the communities in which he lived. He served on the board of Rider University for many years and as its Chairman for three years. He received an Honorary Degree of Doctor of Laws from Rider in 1989. As the basis of this award, Rider noted that Paul was "a man who has devoted his entire life to the common good - in service to his country, to business, and to education". He founded and served as President of the Hanna Foundation which has provided philanthropic support for many deserving causes during Paul's lifetime and going forward. Also, he served as President of the board of the Ocean Reef Medical Center and he helped to build its Foundation of which he had also served as President. Paul was governor of the Ocean Reef Yacht Club and a member of the Angler's Club in Key Largo Florida. In addition, he served on the boards of the Greater Miami YMCA and Lees McRae College. Paul's hobby and passion was golf. He enjoyed taking his sons on golfing ventures around the nation and world including numerous outings in Scotland, England, Ireland and Australia. He always remembered walking off the 18th green with his sons at St. Andrews' Old Course late in his life. Paul was a member and served as President of Baltusrol Golf Club. He also belonged to Burning Tree Golf Club, Columbia Country Club, Card Sound Golf Club and Hound Ears Club Paul loved and was devoted to his family. His first wife, Grace Hanna, died in 1989 after 43 years of marriage. His second wife, Joan Chapin Hanna, died in 1999. He is survived by his two sons and their wives: Paul II (Sandra) and Lee (Mindy), and five grandchildren. He is also survived by a stepson and stepdaughter (Steve Chapin and Lori Simm), their spouses (Nancy and Daryl), and four step-grandchildren. Paul has been placed to rest in a private service at the New Jersey Veterans Memorial Cemetery of Wrightstown, NJ. There will be a memorial service to celebrate his life at the Ocean Reef Chapel on April 4, 2009 at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Foscoe Christian Church, 8834 Highway 105 South, Boone, NC 28607 or the Ocean Reef Medical Center Foundation, 50 Barracuda Lane, Key Largo, FL 33037

LIKE many musicians who play for the handful of small professional orchestras outside of New York City these days, Gabriel Schaff, a violinist, is struggling to cobble together a living. Mr. Schaff, 49, has contracts that guarantee work with four orchestras, including the Stamford Symphony Orchestra and Long Island Philharmonic. He substitutes in others, including the Westfield Symphony Orchestra in New Jersey. And he takes side work, like Broadway shows, in between. But side work has grown scarcer as Broadway retrenches. Substitute jobs are in shorter supply. Nearly all the orchestras Mr. Schaff regularly plays for are offering less work than in the past, because of the economic downturn. And one of those groups, the Opera Orchestra of New York, has just canceled its two remaining shows this season at Carnegie Hall, citing significant reductions in ''all areas of public support.''

FITZSIMMONS--William H.,of Southampton and Palm Beach, died at his Southampton home on March 14, 2009 at age 86, after a long, brave battle with cancer. Adored husband of Jean Remmel Little; father of William McCauley, Edward, and Thomas; step-father of Alexandra Remmel Swoope and Lawrence Remmel. Profoundly wise, exceptionally handsome, kind and heroic, he will be missed enormously by his many friends and family. Born in Springfield, Illinois, Bill graduated from Northwestern University and Harvard Business School. He proudly served in WWII as a Navy pilot, LT.j.g., air sea rescue in the Pacific arena. An advertising career fallowed in NYC. In 1970 he moved to Bridgehampton, establishing his own real estate firm. He also was adjunct professor at Long Island University. A memorial service will be held May 16, 2009 at 4pm at St. John's Church, Southampton. If desired, remembrances may be made to Southampton hospital, William FitzSimmons Fund, 240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968 or to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Head and Neck Services, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10065, Attention: Richard K. Naum.

HOVDESVEN--Arne Lesher of Wilmington, NC and New York City, formerly of Briarcliff Manor, NY died peacefully at The Osborn, Rye, NY March 12 at the age of 80 after a long battle with Alzheimer's. Beloved husband of Helen O'Brien; devoted father of Steven and Eric Hovdesven and Susan Hovdesven-Miller (Matt); loving stepfather of O'Brien, Michael (Melissa) and Colleen Murray; cherished grandfather of Samantha and Sydney Miller; brother, Bayard (Marilyn) and former daughter-in-law Ana Hovdesven. Born in Hagerstown, MD on May 17, 1928, Mr. Hovdesven graduated from North Texas State, BA, 1947. Called to active duty 1950-53, he served in the U.S. Army 555th Field Artillery Battalion and was awarded the Bronze Star for meritorious service in Korean combat. He graduated University of Michigan Law School, J.D., 1956 and was a member of the Editorial Board of the Michigan Law Review. Mr. Hovdesven was a senior partner of Shearman & Sterling, LLP. He practiced corporate finance, specializing in public and private offerings of corporate securities. He had extensive experience in handling matters before the Corporate Finance Staff of the SEC. He advised Consolidated Rail Corporation in connection with its privatization in 1987, which at that time was the largest transaction of its kind in the United States. He served as Chairman of the Securities Committee and of the Business Law Section of the NYS Bar Association and was a member of the Committee on Corporate Laws of the ABA. He retired in 1995 after a 40 year career, having been Of-Counsel and a Senior U.S. Securities Law Advisor. A man of quiet charm, gentle manner, integrity, loyalty and brilliance, he will be greatly missed. Memorial Service: Monday, April 20, 10:30am St. Bartholomew's Chapel, Park Ave at 51st St., New York. Reception to follow. A memorial service is planned in Wilmington, NC for May. Memorial Contributions may be made to: Arne Hovdesven Alzheimer's Research Fund, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine, 100 North Charles Street, Suite 410, Baltimore, MD 21201, Payable to: Johns Hopkins University.

CUTLER--Philip May 10, 1924, Athens, GA March 17, 2009, New York, NY. Philip's innumerable friends and his family note with sadness the death of the gentlest, sweetest man any of us have ever known. World traveler of infinite curiosity and impeccable taste, Philip throughout his career, first at Macy's, then at Lord & Taylor, and in the years he was an independent furniture consultant, was influential in helping manufacturers in the Philippines and China to develop and export products to the American market. While at Lord & Taylor he also organized pioneering exhibitions of 20th century vintage furniture and objects and he was among the first to bring these works to the attention of collectors and museums. Beyond his professional credentials, his humanity, wit, grace, and charm made him beloved by everyone he met all over the world. His personal warmth was such that he had many friendships that endured over fifty years. An extraordinary son, brother, uncle, and godfather, Philip was someone who always put the well being of others ahead of his own. With his dearest friend Santiago Cortes, Philip took great joy in exploring the world, traveling to India, China, Peru, Egypt, Cuba, Jordan, Vietnam, and Thailand. Throughout this his love of New York City, his home for sixty years, was a constant in his life. For the last eleven years, he derived enormous pleasure from the beautiful view from his terrace overlooking Central Park. Philip's endearing modesty restrains us from praising him as much as we might want to. Our loss is deep, but the gift of having had him in our lives will never diminish. A memorial service is being planned. Contributions in Philip's memory can be made to New Yorkers for Parks, 355 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10017 or to the charity of your choice. Suzy, Michael, Jake, Lucie, Elizabeth, Ralph, Jane, Paola, and Claudio.

AS prevalent as pants at the fall fashion shows, thigh-high boots are the item to own next season. Or, for some, this minute. In Paris, fashion editors fortunate enough to get their legs into a pair -- none are in stores now -- trotted them out like prized show ponies. Some of the savvier women had procured them last fall. Others, like Emmanuelle Alt of French Vogue (near left), pinched them right off the runway. (In Ms. Alt's case, they were Isabel Marant.) Still others cobbled together makeshift versions. It has been reported that Lauren Santo Domingo of Vogue took an old pair of Brian Atwood boots to Leather Spa in Midtown Manhattan and had 14 inches of suede tacked on.

Hunched over my computer, immersed in my point-of-sales software, I heard the tell-tale sounds from below. There were strange noises and the pitter-patter of aimless circling, which I knew so well from my son Daniel, 13, who has autism. I quickly found my target in the crowded store, a mother with her arms desperately encircling a squirming 12-year-old. ''Julian, I told you that first we have to get a present for Dad!'' she pleaded as Julian relentlessly sought to check out the picture books for small children.

WALKER--Daniel (Dan), March 6th, 2009 of pneumonia; actor, director, drama teacher, the Brearley, 1975- 1994. Co-founder Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theatre. Beloved, adored husband of Dina, and father of Daisy and Sheafe Walker.

HIRSCH--Robert L.,M.D., of Rye, NY, died at age 85 on March 20, 2009, after a long illness. Former medical director of the Greater New York Blood Program, he is remembered with love by his wife, Lillian, his three children, Linda, Phyllis (Herb Lison), and Michael (Lisa); and grandchildren Jonathan and Sarah Lison. Memorial services at a later date. Contributions may be made to the Fresh Air Fund, www.freshair.org.

OKLAHOMA 73, MICHIGAN 63 Oklahoma's Blake Griffin, the Big 12 player of the year, was unstoppable, and Michigan's only hope was to get some whistles from the referees to slow him down. But there was no help from the officials, and the second-seeded Sooners beat 10th-seeded Michigan in Kansas City, Mo., to advance to the Round of 16. Griffin scored 33 points and collected 17 rebounds for the Sooners (29-5), who have regrouped after a late-season slump of four losses in six games cost them a No. 1 seed.

VOSKOVEC--Christine, nee McKeown, beloved wife of the late George Voskovec, died peacefully at her home on Long Island, on March 12, 2009. She was a long time resident of New York City and Los Angeles. She is survived by daughters Victoria Voskovec Cebek and Georgeanne Voskovec Gotfried and grandchildren. Brothers William and Robert and nieces and nephews. She will be sadly missed by family and friends.

HILL CLIMBING IN CABO DE GATA-NÍJAR NATURAL PARK, SPAIN, JAN. 12, 2009 Leo Feuchtenberger, 20, from Hamburg, Germany. ''For a living I do 'nothing' at the moment except feeling nature and enjoying life. I am traveling by bicycle, since I finished school in August. I saved some money for my trip by teaching math, physics and working as a baby sitter. My trip started in Hamburg and I cycled through the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Spain, Gibraltar and Morocco. Next is Italy, Slovenia, the Czech Republic and then back to Germany. Here you see me cycling up a hill in the heat of southern Spain in the natural park, just before Almería. I was probably thinking: 'Yeah, having a car like that photographer over there could be nice, to get my luggage up this hill.' But I also remember that I was in a good mood, because my day started with going downhill at around 67 kilometers per hour after I slept on the peak in my tent.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

An article last Sunday about the new Broadway revival of ''West Side Story'' included a quotation from Peter Marks, a critic for The Washington Post, who wrote in January, ''It's love at first sight for us.'' He was referring to one of the stars, Josefina Scaglione, who plays Maria; he was not referring to the current version of the musical.

JIM GOLDBERG The photographer Jim Goldberg has a talent for documenting transience. He captured the shifting experiences of wealth and poverty in the late 1970s and early '80s for a groundbreaking multimedia series called ''Rich and Poor''; his 1995 project ''Raised by Wolves'' (far right) photographed teenage runaways in Los Angeles and his hometown, San Francisco. For this issue, he shot the tourist playground of Bali -- ''a very different place of contradictions,'' he says. (''How Green Is My Bali'' is on Page 78.) A recipient of the Henri Cartier-Bresson Award, Goldberg was recently commissioned to document migration and refugee trafficking throughout Europe; ''Current,'' from 2006, is at center. And if he is known for his experimental use of text alongside images, he cites ''trust and intimacy'' with his subjects as the crux of his work: ''Their safety net gets thinner and thinner by the day.''

KLINE--Roger. For 13 years, Continental Grain Company and the Fribourg family have had the honor of having Roger Kline as Advisor to its Board of Directors. We have benefited from his wisdom and advice, his forward thinking, and his professionalism. Throughout, he accomplished all this with a real human touch. He was a true colleague and friend, and we will miss him dearly. Continental Grain Company

Though Comedy Central may be most closely identified with caustic topical comedians like Jon Stewart and Stephen Colbert, as well as foul-mouthed (if hilarious) animated series like “South Park,” the cable channel has signed a development deal with the ventriloquist Jeff Dunham who starred in the most-watched show in its history, Variety reported. The debut of “Jeff Dunham’s Very Special Christmas Special” drew 6.6 million viewers in November, and a DVD release sold more than 400,000 copies; Mr. Dunham’s live tour, featuring puppets like Melvin the Superhero Guy and Achmed the Dead Terrorist, grossed $19.2 million last year. Mr. Dunham’s deal with Comedy Central includes a six-episode series planned for 2010, as well as a standup special and a new DVD.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Monday morning.

Canceled shows never die; they’re just rebroadcast on DirecTV. Variety reported that the satellite broadcaster DirecTV had acquired the rights to broadcast three short-lived network series – some so short-lived that their first seasons weren’t shown in their entirety – on its 101 Network. The three series are “Smith,” a 2006 CBS crime drama about a gang of professional criminals, whose cast included Simon Baker, Virginia Madsen and Ray Liotta; “The Nine,” a 2006 ABC drama about a group of strangers linked as hostages in a bank robbery; and “Eyes,” a 2005 ABC series about a high-tech detective agency. In January, DirecTV began rebroadcasting “Wonderland,” a well-reviewed if abbreviated ABC series from 2000; its new batch of resurrected shows will begin showing in April.

The 92nd Street Y has announced its 2009-2010 concert season, the 10th that has been programmed by Hanna Arie-Gaifman. Among the highlights will be a series of appearances by the Hungarian-born pianist Andras Schiff in which he will focus on the compositions of Haydn. Mr. Schiff will perform concerts on Feb. 25 and 27, 2010, and offer a lecture recital on Feb. 28, 2010; he will also appear with the Hungarian author Peter Esterhazy on March 1, 2010. There will also be a series of concerts focused on the music of Hungary. Other events include Christian Tetzlaff’s presentation of Bach’s Partitas and Sonatas for solo violin on Oct. 25; the biennial Guitar Marathon on Jan. 31, 2010; performances by the pianists Zoltan Kocsis (on Oct. 17) and Marc-André Hamelin (on Dec. 12). More information can be found online at www.92Y.org/concerts.

Among the many showcases, parties and corporate events at SXSW, there are always a few gigs with a DIY streak, like buskers performing atop newspaper boxes or late-night punk shows on the Lamar Street pedestrian bridge. On Thursday night, the Brooklyn promoter Todd P. threw an acoustic barbecue in a dusty parking lot downtown; about 20 bands turned up to do 10-minute sets each, in a format that was decidedly more sing-a-long than rock’n’roll. Here are scenes from that night and interviews with Todd and a nattily-dressed fan, Bruno Wizard, the frontman of the seminal British punk band the Homosexuals.

The Public Theater has postponed the first preview and opening night of its production of Craig Lucas‘s play “The Singing Forest.” In a news release, the Public said that the play, about an Austrian-born Holocaust survivor turned psychoanalyst and her coterie of patients, was delayed “due to the need for additional technical rehearsals.” The first preview has been rescheduled to April 10 from April 7, and opening night is set for April 28 instead of April 27. The cast includes Olympia Dukakis, Jonathan Groff and Randy Harrison, and the play is directed by Mark Wing-Davey.

The actor and comedian Robin Williams is recuperating from heart surgery he underwent March 13, after a health scare that forced the postponement of his “Weapons of Self-Destruction” tour. In a news release, Mr. Williams’s publicists said that he had undergone a three-and-a-half hour procedure on Friday at the Cleveland Clinic to replace his aortic valve, repair his mitral valve and correct his irregular heartbeat. Earlier this month, Mr. Williams was performing in Florida when he announced he was postponing four shows because of shortness of breath; his heart problems were later diagnosed at the University of Miami Hospital. In a statement, Dr. A. Marc Gillinov, a staff cardiothoracic surgeon at the Cleveland Clinic, said that Mr. Williams would have normal heart function in a few weeks. Mr. Williams is expected to resume his “Weapons of Self-Destruction” tour, which included dates on Broadway, in the fall.

The Metropolitan Opera announced that Margaret Jane Wray would sing the role of Santuzza in Mascagni’s “Cavalleria Rusticana” on Monday night. She is replacing Waltraud Meier, who is ill, the Met said in a release. Ms. Wray has previously sung the roles of Sieglinde in “Die Walküre” and Ortrud in “Lohengrin,” among others, at the Met. Ms. Meier is scheduled to return to “Cavalleria Rusticana” on Thursday.

I don’t think I’m alone in feeling that this season of “Big Love,” which ended Sunday, was the show’s best so far both in macro thematics and micro details (for instance, the satanic Hollis Green’s partner in brutality turns out to be a cross-dressing woman, and not just any babe with a penchant for putting on a tuxedo, but Roman Grant’s plus-sized, deranged little sister.)

David Letterman shocked his audience – and just about everyone he knows – by announcing on his show Monday night that he had quietly gone to a courthouse in Teton, Mont., Thursday afternoon and married his long-time girlfriend Regina Lasko. Mr. Letterman dropped the word after his monologue, and just after he congratulated the actor Bruce Willis for getting married last week.

Sometimes an early-week crossword has an explanation clue that ties it all together. I fill in the grid in more or less random order, and I happened to find 62 Across early on: "They can be found in 20- and 55-Across and 10- and 26-Down." What's your strategy when you discover a "they can be found" clue? I used to view it as the key and tackle that section first, knowing it would make the rest of the puzzle easier. Now, I purposefully ignore such corners until the other theme answers have been filled in, giving myself a chance to suss out the common thread myself. It's a bonus puzzle you can choose to accept or not.

Job security is an issue for all of us - even Britney Spears got the memo. Love her, hate her, say what you want about her (to crib a line from her latest single, "If You Seek Amy"), as her "Circus" tour criss-crosses the country, few can argue that the artist-formerly-known-for-all-the-wrong-reasons has got back down to business. Among the most revealing aspects of her latest reinvention are her barely-there stage get-ups - and I'm not talking about her lack of pants. It is certainly Spears's most ambitious relationship with the runway to date, due in no small measure to her close collaboration with Dean and Dan Caten of the label Dsquared, the identical twins who have dressed the likes of a touring Madonna and are known for a strict allegiance to all things pop. Here, brother Dan opens up on dressing Britney's big top. She performs tonight at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y.

The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine has hoisted into place two poignant -- and quite beautiful -- reminders of the suffering and penance that always precede rebirth in the Christian liturgical calendar.On Monday, members of the cathedral's Textile Conservation Laboratory raised two of the 12 Barberini tapestries in St. John's collection, "The Crucifixion" and "Agony in the Garden," into the arches of the north and south transept for display during the Easter season. It is the first time either of these tableaux have been on public view since the devastating fire in 2001 that heavily damaged the north transept and two other Barberini tapestries.

Warren Buffett still lives in the same Omaha home he bought for $31,500 in 1958. But other billionaires prefer a lifestyle more representative of their wealth, Forbes Magazine reports. Originally released in 1993, Dave Hickey's "The Invisible Dragon: Four Essays on Beauty" posed a radical idea to the art world: lose a bit of the self-congratulatory political posturing, pretty please, and get back to the business of sensuous beauty. Hickey did this, in part, by using his razor-sharp prose to extol the virtues of images that are not for the faint of heart. (See the notorious Mapplethorpe photograph of a man and a fist - and use your imagination.) The art world responded as it typically does when it's told to drop the attitude. It reveled in being offended -while simultaneously making the slim tome (the original's only 64 pages) the de facto cocktail talk of gallery openings and dinner parties.

The clay pot, a classic Vietnamese dish, is as fragrant as can be, and there's very little to it. Sugar is barely browned in a bit of oil. Seasonings -- shallots, garlic and ginger -- are cooked directly in the sugar-oil mixture, then chunks of pork are added. Vary the taste only by changing the main ingredient or increasing (or decreasing) the abundant amounts of black pepper, chili, garlic, ginger and fish sauce.

Evgeni Malkin is having a superb season for the Penguins, and fans in The Igloo have taken to chanting "M.V.P." for him. Does this qualify him to be excused from anything more than a fine -- $2,500 is the maximum the league can fine a nonsuspended player -- for this blatant head shot to Kings winger Wayne Simmonds on Friday night? After all, as Shelly Anderson writes in The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, Malkin was allowed to promise Colin Campbell, the N.H.L.'s alleged disciplinarian, he would not do it again.

Teenage birth rates are climbing. For huge numbers of people in India the imminent introduction of the world's cheapest car - the Nano - is a boon to families all over the developing world that currently speed around town on overloaded two-wheelers, often with an infant perched precariously on someone's lap.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg held the first public event of his re-election campaign on Sunday in familiar, friendly grounds: the Christian Cultural Center in Canarsie, Brooklyn, one of the city's largest and most influential churches. Its pastor, A. R. Bernard, has been a longtime supporter of Mr. Bloomberg's, first joining his transition team in 2001 and then endorsing him in 2005, when the mayor first ran for re-election.Standing before a cluster of cameras at the entrance to the church's parking lot with dozens of community leaders and congregants, Pastor Bernard once again backed Mayor Bloomberg, who is vying for a third four-year term after successfully pushing for a law that allows local elected officials to serve for 12 years instead of eight.

12 Hours of Sebring: The Audi R15 diesel-fueled racecar made its debut this weekend at Sebring, in Florida, and gave Audi a familiar result -- another win. Driven at different times by Allan McNish, Tom Kristensen and Rinaldo Capello, the No. 2 Audi R15 battled the No. 8 Peugeot 908 HDi FAP, which also runs on diesel fuel, from start to finish. The Peugeot, driven by Franck Montagny, Sebastien Bourdais and Stephane Sarrazin, managed to pull in front of the No. 2 Audi for a brief moment, but the French team otherwise remained a few seconds behind the Audi throughout the endurance race. A tire puncture with three hours left to go seemed to signal the end of the Peugeot challenge. But a late-race charge brought the team back into contention, though their efforts fell just short. It was the fifth win at Sebring for Kristensen; he has also won the 24 Hours of Le Mans eight times. Audi has won the LMP1 class the last 10 years (and has been the overall winner nine out of the last 10 races) at Sebring.

He told me he's found that puzzles are a great way to interest non-mathematicians in math, and he wishes more math courses involved this sort of problem-solving.

Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, currently on a 50th anniversary tour that was scheduled to end in May, has added performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, June 9 to 14. The company will present two programs on alternate dates: “Best of” will feature selections from the troupe’s repertory, including a new production of the artistic director Judith Jamison’s “Hymn,” a tribute to Ailey that includes several company dances along with narrative recollections from current and former dancers in a text conceived, written and narrated by Anna Deavere Smith. The second program, “Classic Ailey,” includes his 1958 ballet “Blues Suite” and a one-act version of “Anniversary Highlights,” made up of excerpts from many of Ailey’s dances. Schedule and ticket information is at bam.org.

The Screen Actors Guild and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers remain in a tense deadlock over a new contract for the actors, but another group, the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, has approved its new agreement. The 35,000 members of 15 Hollywood locals, made up of film and television production workers, have ratified a three-year contract that will go into effect on Aug. 1. The contract includes some small pay increases but also cuts in health and pension benefits, The Associated Press reported. Though some union members mounted an opposition, accusing union leaders of selling them short, the majority argued that the contract was the best they could expect in a dismal economy; the 15 locals, which represent carpenters, electricians, prop makers and other skilled technicians, unanimously endorsed the contract.

Egypt is expected to make an official request to the United States this week for the return of a Pharoanic coffin smuggled out of the country 125 years ago, The Associated Press reported. The wooden coffin, right, is more than 3,000 years old and belonged to Pharaoh Ames of the 21st Dynasty, which ruled from 1081 B.C. to 931 B.C., said Zahi Hawass, the secretary general of the Supreme Council of Antiquities of Egypt. The ornately decorated coffin was seized by customs officials in Miami last month, when an American, who bought it from a dealer in Spain, was unable to provide sufficient paperwork to prove ownership. The council has sent documents to authorities in Miami proving that the coffin was taken out of Egypt illegally in 1884.

Students from the University of California, Berkeley, won four awards and the University of California, Los Angeles, grabbed three at the Academy of Television Arts & Sciences Foundation’s 30th College Television Awards, held at the Culver Studios in Los Angeles on Saturday night. Tom Bergeron of “Dancing With the Stars” was the host, and the presenters included Masi Oka (“Heroes”) and Jim Parsons (“The Big Bang Theory”). The awards recognize excellence in undergraduate and graduate student video, digital and film production in a variety of categories including animation, children’s, documentary and drama. The foundation received a record 712 submissions from 214 schools in 42 states, almost double the number of entries a year ago.

The drummer Jimmy Chamberlain has left Smashing Pumpkins, according to a brief note on the band’s Web site, smashingpumpkins.com. Mr. Chamberlain was an original member of the group, started by the guitarist and singer-songwriter Billy Corgan in 1988. Mr. Corgan “will continue to write and record as Smashing Pumpkins with plans to head into the studio this spring,” the message read. Mr. Chamberlain was the only original member of the band — which broke up in 2000 and reformed in 2006 — to play on the recent 20th anniversary tour. ... Guns N’ Roses has a new guitarist (again). The band has announced that Dj Ashba, a guitarist and songwriter whose credits include being a co-writer and co-producer on Mötley Crüe’s latest album, “Saints of Los Angeles,” has replaced Robin Finck.

Computer Worm Called Conficker The Conficker worm is scheduled to activate on April 1, and the unanswered question is: Will it prove to be the world's biggest April Fool's joke or is it the information age equivalent of Herman Kahn's visionary 1962 treatise about nuclear war, ''Thinking About the Unthinkable''?

CHARLTON-Alice (Simon), of Newton, MA, died on March 14, 2009 at the age of 90. She lived most of her life in New York City, graduated from Hunter College, Phi Beta Kappa, received her Master's degree from Columbia University Teachers College, and taught art and photography at NYC high schools for decades. Her husband, Alex, who was a physician, died in 1995. She leaves three daughters, Elinore, of Arlington, MA, Valerie and her husband, Devron Char, of San Francisco, CA, and Vickie, of Belmont, MA; a grandson, Danton Char, and his wife, Susan Lee Char, of San Francisco, CA; and a great-granddaughter, Reeve Alexandra Char. She is also survived by a sister, Klari Tufel, of Seattle, WA; in-laws; and numerous nieces and nephews.

Privilege may have its rewards, but it also has its price. Several members of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball selection committee were paying it on the first weekend of the tournament. Members of the committee fan out to the first- and second-round sites every year as tournament representatives. The members whose teams are among the 64 selected for the field are sent to a different site than their university's team to ensure neutrality.

The United States must look for a way out of the war in Afghanistan, President Obama said, signaling that the military buildup there is meant to open the door to seeing the eventual withdrawal of American and NATO troops from the country. ''There's got to be an exit strategy,'' Mr. Obama said in a wide-ranging interview that was aired on CBS's ''60 Minutes'' on Sunday. ''There's got to be a sense that this is not perpetual drift.''

Some 17.5 million young people ages 13 to 17, like Kabrina Moton of Cincinnati, above, own cellphones. Most get connected along with their parents: of 230 million users in the United States, 114 million belong to a family plan. Verizon and Sprint have the largest group of young people, each with about 4.5 million users. Their phones, like the enV and the Rumor, offer a music player, video capabilities, a camera and, for fast text messaging, a full qwerty keyboard. SHELLY FREIERMAN

The players union has discovered that at least 22 teams require players to make donations, something it says violates the Basic Agreement. Manny Ramírez signed a two-year, $45 million contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers this month, then donated $1 million to the Dodgers Dream Foundation. The union filed a grievance after Frank McCourt, the Dodgers' owner, said ''every future Dodger'' would make a donation. ''These clauses are individually negotiated between clubs and players,'' said Rob Manfred, baseball's executive vice president for labor relations and human resources. ''The idea that they would file a grievance to contest them is surprising.'' Greg Bouris, a spokesman for the union, said it would not comment until after the World Baseball Classic. If the sides do not agree on a way to settle the grievance, it will be resolved by an arbitrator.

In Darfur, Fear of More Trouble The expulsion of organizations that provide clean water, medical treatment, food and shelter for millions of Sudanese in Darfur has thrown the world's largest aid operation into disarray, putting the lives of millions of displaced people at risk.

HOVDESVEN--Arne Lesher of Wilmington, NC and New York City, formerly of Briarcliff Manor, NY died peacefully at The Osborn, Rye, NY March 12 at the age of 80 after a long battle with Alzheimer's. Beloved husband of Helen O'Brien; devoted father of Steven and Eric Hovdesven and Susan Hovdesven-Miller (Matt); loving stepfather of O'Brien, Michael (Melissa) and Colleen Murray; cherished grandfather of Samantha and Sydney Miller; brother, Bayard (Marilyn) and former daughter-in-law Ana Hovdesven. Born in Hagerstown, MD on May 17, 1928, Mr. Hovdesven graduated from North Texas State, BA, 1947. Called to active duty 1950-53, he served in the U.S. Army 555th Field Artillery Battalion and was awarded the Bronze Star for meritorious service in Korean combat. He graduated University of Michigan Law School, J.D., 1956 and was a member of the Editorial Board of the Michigan Law Review. Mr. Hovdesven was a senior partner of Shearman & Sterling, LLP. He practiced corporate finance, specializing in public and private offerings of corporate securities. He had extensive experience in handling matters before the Corporate Finance Staff of the SEC. He advised Consolidated Rail Corporation in connection with its privatization in 1987, which at that time was the largest transaction of its kind in the United States. He served as Chairman of the Securities Committee and of the Business Law Section of the NYS Bar Association and was a member of the Committee on Corporate Laws of the ABA. He retired in 1995 after a 40 year career, having been Of-Counsel and a Senior U.S. Securities Law Advisor. A man of quiet charm, gentle manner, integrity, loyalty and brilliance, he will be greatly missed. Memorial Service: Monday, April 20, 10:30am St. Bartholomew's Chapel, Park Ave at 51st St., New York. Reception to follow. A memorial service is planned in Wilmington, NC for May. Memorial Contributions may be made to: Arne Hovdesven Alzheimer's Research Fund, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Fund for Johns Hopkins Medicine, 100 North Charles Street, Suite 410, Baltimore, MD 21201, Payable to: Johns Hopkins University.

Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim runs a program predicated on consistency. Everything from the practice plan to the limited plays on offense to Boeheim's cantankerous demeanor rarely change. Consistency has bred obvious success and predictability. Every few years, Syracuse will appear in the N.C.A.A. tournament and its trademark 2-3 zone will take on a mystical quality, forcing another team's star player to evaporate.

KLINE--Roger C. The partners of McKinsey & Co. mark with sadness the passing of our beloved colleague, Roger Kline, who died in his sleep March 18, while in London on business. Roger joined the firm in 1976 and was part of the team that built our banking and securities practice, which he led from 1996 to 2004. He was elected a director in 1986 and led our New York Office in 1995-96. Roger co-founded McKinsey's investment office, was a member of the firm's board, chaired the finance committee, and was a member of the office of the managing partner. More importantly, he was a friend and mentor to a generation of colleagues, teaching many of us how to solve the most challenging problems and how to convey answers to clients with both absolute candor and empathy. He earned the trust of business and government leaders around the world, who relied on his counsel, as did a wide circle of friends who prized his wit, erudition and unflagging kindness. Roger leaves a rich legacy at McKinsey, where he played the "loyal opposition" challenging complacency and destroying faulty logic. In 2007, Roger established the McKinsey Center for Advanced Problem Solving to ensure that our teams will always have the most sophisticated tools to solve our clients' problems. Roger was President of Friends of the Atlantic Partnership, which promotes dialogue between European and U.S. opinion leaders, and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. His philanthropic activities centered on issues of adoption, as Chairman of Whole Child International, and through the Evan B. Donaldson Adoption Institute. We will miss Roger's extraordinary intellect and his dedication to the firm and its clients. We join Roger's widow Susan, his son Matthew, his brother Gil, and the rest of his family in mourning the loss of a remarkable man.
DANCEBRAZIL Skirball Center
What we’re reading (and watching) on Tuesday morning.

The J. Paul Getty Museum has announced that it has established a partnership with the Museo Archeologico Nazionale in Florence to exhibit works from that museum. The first work to be shown at the Getty under this arrangement will be “The Chimaera of Arezzo,” an Etruscan bronze sculpture dating to the early 4th century B.C. depicting the mythological beast made from parts of a lion, a serpent and a fire-breathing goat. The exhibition will also include antiquities from the Getty’s collection as well as works on loan from museums in Rome, Naples, Basel, New York, Boston, and Atlanta; it is scheduled to run from July 16 through Feb. 8, 2010. The Getty said it hoped to collaborate with the Museo Archeologico’s sister institutions throughout Italy in the months ahead.

Finally, a job where abiding passions for rock music and science fiction are considered assets: the Experience Music Project and Science Fiction Museum and Hall of Fame announced that it had selected Christina Orr-Cahall as its new director. Ms. Orr-Cahall is currently the chief executive and director of the Norton Museum of Art in West Palm Beach, Fla., and previously served as president of the Corcoran Gallery and College of Art in Washington as well as the chief curator of art at the Oakland Museum of California. She succeeds Josi Irene Callan, the interim director of the Experience Music Project and Science Fiction Museum and Hall of Fame, and is expected to begin by July 1.

Since his last book did not single-handedly solve the world’s environmental problems, Al Gore will return to the subject of global warming in a new book to be released by Rodale Inc., the publisher said in a news release. The book, “Our Choice,” will return to the milieu of Mr. Gore’s 2006 bestseller, “An Inconvenient Truth: The Planetary Emergency of Global Warming and What We Can Do About It.” In a statement, Mr. Gore said the book would offer plans to address the climate crisis while creating jobs and promoting economic growth, developed through meetings that Mr. Gore has held with scientists, engineers and policy experts. Rodale said the book would be published on Nov. 3 and would be printed on 100 percent recycled paper. It said that all proceeds from the book would be donated to the Alliance for Climate Protection, a nonprofit group.

The Weinstein Company is in the early stages of turning a biography of Judy Garland into a play, a musical, or a film, with the actress Anne Hathaway to play Garland, the company announced on Monday night. The project was first reported by The Associated Press.

The Academy Award-winner F. Murray Abraham will lead an 11-member ensemble cast for the Atlantic Theater Company’s world premiere of “Offices,” a set of three one-act comedies by Ethan Coen, the Oscar-winning filmmaker.

The coming production of “My Trip Down the Pink Carpet,” a solo show written and performed by Leslie Jordan, has been postponed because of Mr. Jordan’s role in a coming series pilot for Lifetime Television, “Alligator Point.”

Updated | 5:26 p.m. The Three Billys of Broadway are no more — or, to be precise, they’ve grown by one. The producers of the musical “Billy Elliot” — who have largely based their publicity campaign on the three young actors who rotate in the title role of the boy ballerina — announced Tuesday afternoon that they had added a fourth actor, Tommy Batchelor, to the lineup of Billys. Mr. Batchelor, 13, of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., began dancing when he was 4, and has been an understudy for the three Billys: David Alvarez, Trent Kowalik and Kiril Kulish. A spokeswoman for the Tony Awards eligibility committee said that its ruling allows the original Three Billys to be considered for a nomination — not Mr. Batchelor — and that this decision would not be revisited.

In Venice, a city of odd spaces, Gianni Colombo's walk-in art installation "Spazio Elastico" (1967-68) at the Palazzo Grassi contemporary art museum, is one of the oddest. Who: The Replacements, the 1980s band from Minneapolis.Standout Album: "Pleased to Meet Me" (1987)Educational Value: The 'Mats, as fans-in-the-know call them, were one of the most influential bands of the '80s, whom critics adored but who never really made it big. You can hear traces of the group's caterwauling guitars and the raw warble of its lead singer, Paul Westerberg, in current acts like the Killers and Arcade Fire. The group released eight studio albums before breaking up in 1991, leaving behind a whole lot of smashed guitars and a deep catalog of punk-pop prototypes like "Unsatisfied" and "Can't Hardly Wait" - which recently showed up on the playlist of New York's awesome new WRXP-FM (101.9) and is also covered by Justin Townes Earle on his latest CD, "Midnight at the Movies." In their only instance of being behind the curve, the band was skeptical of music videos (or was that ahead of the curve?), but the few that exist offer several teachable style moments. Witness below, in the video for "The Ledge," the tube socks and thin-soled metallic jazz flats; the ratty, flyaway hair with nary a beard in sight; the adorable ennui. It's like watching some of the interns in my office.
