Reader, be warned: the "XXL" on the cover of the new Tom of Finland book (Taschen) alludes not just to the tome's oversize dimensions, but to its, ahem, larger-than-life content. Until his death in 1991, Tom of Finland, who was born Touko Laaksonen, produced thousands of homoerotic images depicting men before, during and after fetishistic sexual activity. His work has always had a cult gay following - the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe was a major promoter - as well as considerable impact within the fashion community. Vivienne Westwood famously used his drawing of two naked cowboys on a T-shirt, and designers like John Bartlett and Jean-Paul Gaultier have also mined his aesthetic.

Last Sunday night, on "60 Minutes," the reporter Steve Kroft reacted with astonishment when President Obama laughed heartily as he acknowledged public dudgeon at government bailouts of bad banks and ailing auto manufacturers. "Are you punch-drunk?" Kroft asked. President Obama shook his head; it was just "a little gallows humor," he said - meaning, apparently, that when the president takes a step back from the crises he's confronted in his two months in office, he can see a certain humor in their gravity and variety. On Monday, talking heads on the news and the Web scolded the president for his levity. "President Obama chuckled through '60 Minutes' last night," MSNBC's Contessa Brewer observed (a typical finger-wag). "But the economy is no laughing matter."

But today's outbreak is the tried and true alarum -- McCarthyism! -- as in The New McCarthyism. It's apparently like a contagion today.

Smack in the middle of hard and highly secretive negotiations between Gov. David A. Paterson and the Legislature comes yet another dollop of bad budget news. Book of the month. Beer of the month. Bacon of the month. For 2009, the Lower East Side gallery Invisible Exports has established Artist of the Month. The gallery has invited an impressive roster of curators including Gianni Jetzer, the director of the Swiss Institute, and Matthew Higgs, the White Columns director, to select one artist to create a limited-edition work each month. January's calendar boy was Willam Powhida, whose "Post-Boom Odds" places bets on the chances of any of today's art stars mattering 10 years from now. The "body trash artist" Dash Snow gets a 50-to-1 chance of surviving (we're talking strictly his career here), while the goth and gloom artist Banks Violette has a brighter outlook at 5 to 1. For April, the critic Ana Finel Honigman selected the Turkish-born photographer Pinar Yolacan, who created "Boro" (above). You can collect all 12 for $2,400 (which includes shipping and handling).

Even as the push for new energy options intensifies, it's clear that the fossil-fuel era is likely to last quite a few more decades. So it's important to assess both environmental problems and victories attending the extraction of such resources. Twenty years after the Exxon Valdez ran on the rocks in southern Alaska, the amount of oil spilled from ships has dropped sharply even as the amount of oil moved by sea has risen. (The data at the preceding link are maintained by the International Tanker Owners Pollution Federation; there's lots more background on spills posted by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and Environmental Protection Agency.) The improvement is little comfort to communities that are still confronting decades-old stains and the ecological impact from past petroleum disasters.

And this time the reaction was widely positive, giving the embattled Mr. Geithner a critically needed lift.

Goldman Sachs and China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China have been in discussions for the New York bank to reduce its stake in the world's largest financial institution, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing unnamed sources. (DealBook's Andrew Ross Sorkin also reported the talks.)
Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said on Monday that the economic crisis showed that the American financial system had failed a major test and was in need of an overhaul.
Barclays is in talks with Goldman Sachs about a sale of the British bank's iShares unit, Reuters reported, adding one more name to a growing list of possible bidders.

Entrepreneurs working on electric cars, solar cells or other technologies that some critics dismiss as uneconomical or impractical can take heart. A little history may put their challenges into perspective.
Swiss drug company Nycomed could be in the market sell itself for as much as 10 billion euros ($13.57 billion), according to The Wall Street Journal.

Sometimes I think we all watched too many episodes of "The Waltons." Remember? At bedtime, the lights blink out, one by one, in the old farmhouse. Goodnight, John-Boy. Goodnight, Jim-Bob. Goodnight to Mama and Daddy and, of special relevance to readers here, goodnight to Grandma and Grandpa.
All is not lost for Wall Streeters deprived of their megasalaries and lavish lifestyles after the financial tsunami that has wiped out so many jobs.

The Internal Revenue Service is challenging some of the tax deals structured by AIG Financial Products, the unit of the giant insurer that has caused political outrage over $165 million in employee bonuses, The Wall Street Journal reported.
The chief financial officer of Stanford Financial Group, James Davis, is cooperating in fraud investigations of the group, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing Mr. Davis's lawyer.

The chief executive of Dell said on Tuesday that talk of I.B.M. possibly buying Sun Microsystems was providing an "enormous opportunity" to his company in the corporate server market, Reuters reported.
Richard D. Parsons, the former Time Warner chairman and chief executive, will step down from the board before its next annual general meeting, Reuters reported, citing a regulatory filing on Monday.

When markets were rising, many Canadians fretted about leveraged buyouts that put several of the country's largest corporations under foreign control. The markets' collapse, however, created the environment for the creation of a new, large Canadian energy firm, The New York Times's Ian Austen reported.

Details of the government's plans to clean up the nation's banks ignited a blazing stock market rally on Monday, lifting Wall Street to its best one-day performance in five months and tempting some investors to imagine what they would not have dared just a few weeks ago - that the worst may finally be over.
The trustee handling the liquidation of Bernard L. Madoff's brokerage business told a federal judge on Monday that he had found $75 million in new assets in Gibraltar.

The new government stress tests looming for the nation's largest banks are already making Dick Kovacevich's temples throb, Breakingviews says. The Wells Fargo chairman recently called the one-off health checks, which are intended to see if banks need more capital to weather a worsening economy, "asinine."
Time Warner said it would pay $241.5 million for a 31 percent stake in Central European Media Enterprises, the broadcast company founded by the cosmetics heir Ronald S. Lauder.

People I don't know are following me on Twitter. How are they finding me?
Spansion, a flash memory chip maker operating in bankruptcy, said Monday it is in talks with multiple companies about a possible sale of some or all of its assets, The Associated Press reported.
Today's idea: Sports fandom feeds a primitive human need to belong to a whole larger than the self. "Marx was wrong: The opiate of the masses isn't religion, but spectator sports."

In a report issued on Tuesday, the McKinsey Global Institute, the economics research arm of McKinsey & Company, warned that unless robust efficiency measures are undertaken, global markets face the "risk of a second oil-price shock" once the economy recovers and demand for liquid fuels surges.

DirecTV renewed its deal as the N.F.L.’s exclusive satellite carrier and will continue to offer the Sunday Ticket package of out-of-market afternoon games from 2011 to 2014. The deal will cost DirecTV $1 billion a year, a leap from $700 million.

Lil E. Tee, who upset the heavily favored Arazi to win the 1992 Kentucky Derby, has died. He was 20. The horse was euthanized at Old Frankfort Stud in Lexington, Ky., on March 18. The farm said the horse fell ill last month after an operation to repair an obstructed bowel. Lil E. Tee needed lifesaving stomach surgery as a yearling, dimming his racing prospects. Owned by W. Cal Partee and trained by Lynn Whiting, Lil E. Tee, with Pat Day riding, captured the Derby at 17-1 odds. He was retired as a 4-year-old, having won seven of 13 career starts.

A judge dismissed the golfer John Daly’s libel lawsuit against a Florida newspaper and granted The Florida Times-Union’s request for summary judgment. Duval County Circuit Judge Hugh Carithers ruled that the former columnist Mike Freeman’s statements were either true or constitutionally protected opinion. Daly had sued in 2005, saying a column by Freeman written during the Players Championship that year defamed him. Freeman is a former reporter for The New York Times.

The committee hoping to bring the 2016 Olympics to Chicago has an early commitment from President Obama to be in Copenhagen for its final presentation and the International Olympic Committee vote. Pat Ryan, chairman of the Chicago 2016 bid, said Obama planned to attend the meeting in October. Heads of state have been present at meetings more frequently in recent years. When London overcame the favorite Paris to land the 2012 Games, a strong, in-person push by British Prime Minister Tony Blair was viewed as one of the reasons.
For the second time in as many tries, the Japanese are atop the international baseball world, with Ichiro Suzuki giving them a 10th-inning win over rival South Korea.

Because of an editing error, an Op-Ed article on Sunday, about the parole of Sara Jane Olson, misstated a detail of the biography of a leader of the Symbionese Liberation Army, Donald DeFreeze. He joined a gang in Buffalo, not New York City.

The Moment is showcasing a set of collaborative illustrations from the artists Anton and Linus Kern, Dan McCarthy and Jack Pierson. The series, a product of a salon hosted in upstate New York by Anton, is featured in the new issue of the journal (all lowercase, naturally), on select newsstands now.

The State Senate overwhelmingly approved a bill to allow same-sex marriage, setting the stage for the House to take up the matter this week. The Senate, which is dominated by Democrats, voted 26 to 4 in favor of the measure, which would allow gay couples to marry starting in September. Vermont was the first state to permit civil unions for gay couples, in 2000, and it would be the third, after Massachusetts and Connecticut, to approve same-sex marriage. The House Judiciary Committee will start hearing testimony on it Tuesday. Gov. Jim Douglas, a Republican, opposes the bill but has not said whether he will veto it.

The Mount Redoubt volcano erupted five times overnight Sunday and Monday, sending an ash plume more than nine miles into the air in the volcano’s first emissions in nearly 20 years. Residents in Anchorage, the state’s largest city, were spared from falling ash, though fine gray dust fell on communities north of there. Ash from Alaska’s volcanoes is like a rock fragment with jagged edges and has been used as an industrial abrasive. It can injure skin, eyes and breathing passages, and can also cause damage engines in planes, cars and other vehicles. Mount Redoubt, which has an altitude of 10,200 feet, is about 100 miles southwest of Anchorage.

A former State Department employee has been sentenced to a year of probation for looking at more than 150 confidential passport files. The employee, Dwayne Cross of Upper Marlboro, Md., admitted that he looked at the applications of celebrities, politicians, athletes, members of the news media, friends and family members out of idle curiosity. Federal law says that the applications, which include passport photos and other personal information, can be accessed only for official government duties. Mr. Cross, one of three former State Department employees to plead guilty in the case, was also sentenced to 100 hours of community service.

A federal jury convicted Chicago’s former streets and sanitation commissioner of using bogus documents and other fraudulent acts in a scheme to load the city payroll with political campaign workers. The former official, Al Sanchez, 61, was found guilty of four charges of mail fraud and was acquitted on three others. Prosecutors said Mr. Sanchez engaged in fraud to camouflage the fact that city jobs were given only to political workers, including those belonging to his Hispanic Democratic Organization. Mr. Sanchez ran the streets and sanitation department from 1999 to 2005.
The recession seems to have a sweet tooth. And if history is any guide, economic distress has usually increased traffic at the candy counter.

Officials say more than 3,000 patients at a Veterans Affairs hospital in Miami had colonoscopies with equipment that was not properly sterilized. They have been told they should be tested for H.I.V. and other diseases. The V.A. insists the risk of infection is minimal and only involved tubing on equipment, not any device that actually touched a patient. But it is the second recent announcement of errors during colonoscopies at V.A. facilities. Last month, more than 6,000 patients at a clinic in Tennessee were told they may have been exposed to infectious body fluids during colonoscopies.

A blizzard shut down major highways in Wyoming and South Dakota, and meteorologists said one mountainous area might get as much as 40 inches of snow. Mount Rushmore National Memorial closed because of the icy, blinding weather in the Black Hills of South Dakota. Temperature plummeted as the storm moved eastward and wind gusted to more than 60 miles an hour. The storm came in the midst of calving season for cattle ranchers, with the cold and wind posing a threat to many calves’ survival.
ING Group has asked 1,200 workers, including its 200 “top employees,” to return last year’s bonuses.
Time Warner Said It Would Pay $241.5. Million For a 31 Percent Stake In Central European Media Enterprises, the Broadcast Company Founded By the Cosmetics Heir Ronald S. Lauder.
Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group said it would close dozens of branches and cut 1,000 jobs as part of continuing efforts to streamline operations.

A strike by Petrobras workers cut output at refineries in Brazil and also temporarily halted crude production of 60,000 barrels a day and 1.4 million cubic meters of natural gas, union officials said.
Mr. Hughes was a fisheries biologist and the son of the poets Sylvia Plath and Ted Hughes.
Mr. Bo was an exuberant New Orleans pianist and singer who wrote for and worked with artists like Irma Thomas, Etta James and Art Neville of the Neville Brothers.
Mr. Flagello was a bass with a rich voice and wide range who sang 528 performances at the Metropolitan Opera as part of an international career.
The Dubai developer building an $8.6 billion complex on the Las Vegas Strip with the casino company MGM Mirage is suing MGM Mirage because it is worried about the project’s viability.

Duke’s Gerald Henderson would seem to have a brighter N.B.A. future ahead of him than his father, who won three championship rings (two in Boston and one in Detroit). He may eventually earn a place on the mythical all-sons team ahead of his collegiate peers with more famous surnames like Jordan, Pippen and Sampson.

The Dubai developer helping build the $8.6 billion CityCenter complex on the Las Vegas Strip said Monday it is suing struggling partner MGM Mirage amid concerns about the project's viability, The Associated Press reported.
The only surviving gunman of the Mumbai terrorist attacks told a court in India on Monday that he would agree to a government-provided lawyer.
Four soldiers and five militants were killed Monday, the army said, the highest toll in the past year for such a firefight.
Wednesday, March 24, 1909
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Stars of the last six decades were on hand for the inaugural Knicks Legends Awards, but the Knicks of this decade faltered down the stretch and lost to the Orlando Magic.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about the departure of the drummer from the band Smashing Pumpkins misspelled his surname. He is Jimmy Chamberlin, not Chamberlain. The report also referred incorrectly to the original band members who took part in a recent 20th-anniversary tour. Billy Corgan, the guitarist and singer-songwriter, was on the tour; Mr. Chamberlin was not the only original member.
Ben Gordon scored 7 of his 21 points in the final three and a half minutes and the Chicago Bulls hung on for a 101-99 victory over the Washington Wizards.
The Mexico attorney general’s office is offering up to $2 million for information leading to the arrest of any of 24 top traffickers on the list.
The Senate has done virtually nothing to address the glacial pace of confirmations that often leads presidents to expand the White House staff and the number of appointees who serve without approval.

To the Editor:.
A measure to enlarge the opportunities for Americans to participate in productive national and community service is a sound investment in the nation’s future.
The suffering that illegal immigrants endure is a civil-rights crisis that cannot be left to fester while we wait for the big immigration bill that may or may not arrive under this president.
If Citizens United prevails in its Supreme Court case, it would allow corporate money to flood into partisan politics in ways it has not in decades.
A 33-foot-high ceiling at a chemical storage building in southwestern China collapsed Monday, killing at least 11 workers, according to the state-run news agency.
FRONT PAGE.

A theater review on March 16 about “Blithe Spirit,” at the Shubert Theater, misidentified the nationality of the director, Michael Blakemore. While he has worked extensively in Britain, he is Australian, not British.
With a 4-2 victory, the Flyers handed Devils goalie Martin Brodeur only his third loss in 12 games since returning from biceps surgery.

A music review last Tuesday about the violinist and violist Julian Rachlin, at the Frick Collection, misspelled the title of a Fritz Kreisler piece he played as an encore. It is “Liebesleid,” not “Liebeslied.”.
Women’s Professional Soccer will try to re-establish a top-tier league from the ashes of the Women’s United Soccer Association, which folded after the 2003 season.

Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about efforts by the Italian government to have the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek museum in Copenhagen return what Italy says are looted antiquities referred incorrectly to an Italian prosecutor who is deciding whether to press charges against the museum and misstated the prosecutor’s given name. The prosecutor, Paola Giorgio Ferri (not Paolo) is a woman.
In the absence of good-faith measurement of the banking system, taxpayer-financed purchases of bad assets could court huge unnecessary risks.
The police in Northern Ireland said they had charged a 17-year-old with the murder of a police officer two weeks ago in a town 25 miles from Belfast.
The Macedonian presidential election on Sunday was free of violence and met most democratic standards, international monitors said Monday.
The Picasso paintings, now owned by the Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, were purportedly sold under duress in Nazi Germany.
Nobody seems to like talking much in “Inked Baby,” a listless new play by Christina Anderson.
This work comes closer than Shakespeare in making 21st-century audiences feel what it must have been like to be a foot soldier in the early 15th century.

An article on Friday about the first phase of a federal program intended to help revive lending to consumers and businesses misstated the share of financing that will be supplied by the Treasury Department. It will provide the first 10 percent of the money lent in the program — not the first 20 percent. (The rest of the money for the program, known as TALF, will come from the Federal Reserve.).
At least 19 people were killed by a suicide bomber at the wake for the brother of an official of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan party.
Despite being slammed by the global economic downturn, the main worry for the Malaysian government is its dysfunctional political system.

A picture caption with the Talking Business column on Saturday, about public indignation over bonuses at the American International Group, misidentified the building behind a group of protesters in Manhattan on Thursday. It is the Deutsche Bank headquarters at 60 Wall Street — not the A.I.G. headquarters. (A.I.G. has offices nearby at 160 Water Street.).

An article in some editions on Friday about a warning by the city’s commissioner of investigation that budget cuts at the Department of Investigation would hamper its anticorruption work misstated the size of the agency’s current budget and its size under planned reductions. The current budget is $21.2 million, not billion, and the proposed is $19.3 million, not billion.
DirecTV will continue to be the league’s exclusive satellite carrier and will offer the Sunday Ticket package of out-of-market afternoon games from 2011 to 2014.

An article on March 11 about an academic fraud case against Dr. Scott S. Reuben, an anesthesiologist in Springfield, Mass., paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by a spokeswoman for Baystate Medical Center, where he formerly practiced. And a correction in this space on Thursday failed to correct the headline and another comment by the spokeswoman that was paraphrased incorrectly.

An article and a headline on March 15 about a meeting of finance ministers from the Group of 20 nations outside London described the makeup of the group incorrectly. The organization, also called the G-20, consists of the 19 leading industrial and developing nations and the European Union; it is not composed of 20 industrial nations.
Sixth-seeded Purdue, which had lost to North Carolina in two of the past three N.C.A.A. tournaments, defeated the third-seeded Tar Heals, 85-70, in the second round.
With seating charts, special stools and a little wanderlust, breaks in college basketball action have become highly scripted affairs.
For his Round-of-16 date with Villanova, Duke’s Gerald Henderson will head to the city where his father’s legendary steal helped save the most important series of the Bird era.
Ms. Saqafi, the wife of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was known as the “mother of the Islamic Revolution.”
After a devastating hurricane last year, the fear of the next big storm infects a whole town.
If Goldman succeeds in returning our money, it could put pressure on other banks to give their money back, too, lest they appear weak.
China’s central bank says a currency system controlled by the International Monetary Fund would be more stable and economically viable.
The six-count indictment charges State Senator Hiram Monserrate with three counts of second-degree assault and three counts of third-degree assault.
While we bear responsibility for our problems, the caricature of Mexico being propagated in the United States only increases the despair on both sides of the Rio Grande.
A former professor who wrote a controversial essay about the Sept. 11 attacks said he was not in favor of terrorism and denied that he plagiarized parts of another essay.
Lottery numbers for March 23, 2009.
Facing a budget shortfall and hundreds of layoffs, officials at the city’s Administration for Children’s Services vowed to keep caseloads under control.
Fifteen years after the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect, the pact, in some cases, has produced results that were exactly opposite of what was promised.
Epiphanny Prince scored 18 of her 27 points in the second half to boost Rutgers to a surprisingly lopsided victory over Auburn, which had won its first 20 games and was ranked in the top 10.
The Oakland police announced that they had made a tentative DNA match connecting the gunman in a deadly shootout with police officers with an unsolved sexual assault.
Senator Charles E. Schumer expressed his views at an event sponsored by the group Empire State Pride Agenda, saying New York should “take a lead on this issue.”
Courtney Paris, a star center at the University of Oklahoma, promised that she would pay back her scholarship if the Sooners do not win the championship.
The Supreme Court will consider how far school officials can go to enforce zero-tolerance drug policies.
Overcrowded classrooms, new admissions procedures and more families rethinking private schools have made competition for zoned schools tight.
Xavier Nady beat out Nick Swisher — who was earlier bumped from first base when the team signed Mark Teixeira — to become the primary right fielder this season.
Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said 15 of the top 20 bonus recipients in A.I.G.’s financial products division had returned their bonuses.
When you put more boots on the ground in Afghanistan, you not only augment your army’s firing power, you give it the capacity to experiment.
President Obama named a longtime real estate industry executive, David H. Stevens, to head the Federal Housing Administration.
Officials said competing agendas and a leadership void threatened hopes of holding on to the Governor’s Mansion, a United States Senate seat and other posts.
Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner staged a comeback after his first presentation of the bank recovery plan fizzled six weeks ago.

Curt Schilling retired from baseball Monday, ending a career in which he was one of the game’s most dominant pitchers and grittiest competitors.

Officials say that by the summer, they hope to have a final design of the parapets that will surround the memorial pools.
More than a hundred thousand members of Unite Here, the union representing hotel, restaurant, apparel and laundry workers, have broken away and merged into a separate union.
Batting a .276 with no homers, no runs batted in and no stolen bases, Derek Jeter never became an impact player during the U.S.’s stint in the World Baseball Classic.
As unemployment has risen and 401(k)’s have shrunk, American adults have been consuming more candy.
The discovery of the remains of 16 women, most thought to be prostitutes, in Albuquerque has raised questions about the city’s darker side and the failure of the police to find them earlier.
N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said owners could vote in May on plans to lengthen the regular season to 17 or 18 games, though the longer season is unlikely to begin before 2011.
As the police hunted for clues, friends of the journalist, George Weber, 47, of ABC News Radio, gathered to remember a “great guy.”
Environmental groups trying to protect wilderness areas are battling other environmental groups working to create renewable energy sources like solar or wind plants.
Rather than wait for a rescue from the State Legislature, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will vote Wednesday to increase subway and bus fares and bridge and tunnel tolls.
Sasha Cohen, who took home a silver medal in the 2006 Turin Games, suggested that she might try for gold next year at the Vancouver Olympics.
Joseph Gorak fell in love with dance at age 3. Now, at 19, he has landed in the American Ballet Theater’s corps de ballet.
As employment opportunities for students and recent graduates shrink, colleges with work-study programs are attracting new interest.
The new government stress tests looming for the nation’s largest banks are already making the temples of the Wells Fargo chairman’s temples throb.
A federal judge postponed the sentencing of a man convicted of running a medical marijuana dispensary and asked the Department of Justice to clarify its position on such cases.
Much of the citizenry would like to storm the citadel, any citadel, be it A.I.G. headquarters, the M.T.A., Bernard Madoff’s penthouse or City Hall.
Whatever the reason for John Maine’s recently shortened stride, his spring training performance has been the most troubling among the starters.
It will be the first Thanksgiving game for the Giants since 1992, when they lost to the Dallas Cowboys, 30-3, and only their third Thanksgiving Day game since 1938.
A field of genetically identical amoebas in Texas raises the possibility that cells might organize on much larger scales than once thought.
Mr. Komives, a sharpshooting guard who played for 10 years in the N.B.A., was perhaps best remembered for the trade that sent him to the Detroit Pistons for the future Hall of Famer Dave DeBusschere.
A judge ruled that the Food and Drug Administration had bowed to political pressure from the Bush administration.
Despite a shakeout and large withdrawals, the hedge funds left standing will post a respectable profit this year, a Deutsche Bank survey found.
In Chicago, a city that adores its architectural legacy, a state appellate court found that the city’s landmark ordinance was “vague, ambitious and overly broad.”

The Public Theater has postponed the first preview and opening night of its production of Craig Lucas’s play “The Singing Forest.” In a news release the Public said that the play, about an Austrian-born Holocaust survivor turned psychoanalyst and her coterie of patients, had been delayed because of “the need for additional technical rehearsals.” The first preview has been rescheduled to April 10 from April 7, and opening night is set for April 28 instead of April 27. The cast includes Olympia Dukakis, Jonathan Groff and Randy Harrison, and the play is directed by Mark Wing-Davey.
To reverse a downturn caused by fewer travelers and less spending, hotel spas are offering quicker, less expensive services and discounts to local clientele.
Leon Botstein’s program with the American Symphony Orchestra featured bland, derivative works by the relatively unknown composer, William Grant Still, on Sunday.
Media buyers seem to agree that the Major League Baseball Network could become a successful player in the television sports marketplace.
The Guinean musician Sidiki Conde and his ensemble, Tokounou, combined traditional music and dance with jazz and urban rhythms at Symphony Space on Friday.
The singer Judith Owen has a comic side, but over all her story is one of perseverance.
The news photograph of Barack Obama that was appropriated by the artist Shepard Fairey for his “Hope” poster is now on sale at a Chelsea gallery.
Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, whose new show comes to Madison Square Garden on Thursday, has its problems, but experts say the show could benefit from the recession.
Jim Jones, best known for grim street-corner raps and jubilant celebrations of the hip-hop good life, is using a new play to promote his album.
Public fury, ignited when the Detroit automakers flew to Washington, has besieged the business aviation industry. But the industry is fighting back.
Bobby Reynolds considers himself just a working stiff who gets to see many parts of the world, thanks to his job as a professional tennis player.
Ali Saleh Kahlah al-Marri made his first appearance in an Illinois courtroom, where he will be tried later this year on charges of providing aid to terrorists.
The concert, “A Celebration of the Spiritual and Gospel Music,” jointly presented by Carnegie Hall and the Apollo in Harlem, was hardly ordinary.
In the animal kingdom, a male’s grand display of weaponry can discourage lesser rivals.
At the same time, the court-appointed trustee, Irving H. Picard of the law firm Baker Hostetler, was meeting stiff opposition from prosecutors in New York.
Russia’s latest budget seeks to spur economic growth in domestic sectors that do not depend heavily on high oil prices.
“Yessified!,” Sally Silvers’s first big group work since 2005, is entirely puzzling.
The Atlantic Ballet Theater of Canada’s “Don Juan,” with a cast of just 10, had its New York premiere on Sunday.

A work by John Adams, right, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, will make its New York premiere as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival, Lincoln Center announced. The piece, an opera-oratorio called “A Flowering Tree,” will be directed by Peter Sellars and feature a cast of Indonesian dancers and American singers; it is scheduled to be performed at the Rose Theater on Aug. 13, 14 and 16. The Mark Morris Dance Group will perform new works called “Empire Garden” and “Visitation,” which Mr. Morris created in collaboration with Yo-Yo Ma and Emanuel Ax, at the Rose Aug. 19 through 22. The opening-night concert, at which Louis Langrée will conduct the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra with featured performances by the pianist Leif Ove Andsnes and the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote, is scheduled for July 28. The festival runs through Aug. 22. More information can be found online at LincolnCenter.org.

The actor and comedian Robin Williams, below, is recovering from heart surgery he underwent on March 13 after a health scare that forced the postponement of his “Weapons of Self-Destruction” tour. In a news release Mr. Williams’s publicists said that he had undergone a three-and-a-half-hour procedure at the Cleveland Clinic to replace his aortic valve, repair his mitral valve and correct his irregular heartbeat. Earlier this month Mr. Williams was performing in Florida when he announced that he was postponing four shows because of shortness of breath. His heart problems were later diagnosed at the University of Miami Hospital. In a statement Dr. A. Marc Gillinov, a staff cardiothoracic surgeon at the Cleveland Clinic, said that Mr. Williams would have normal heart function in a few weeks. Mr. Williams is expected to resume his “Weapons of Self-Destruction” tour, with dates on Broadway, in the fall.

In Wells Tower’s sad-funny-disturbing stories, the world is a precarious place, where the innocent have bad dreams, and even the not-so-innocent worry about “the things the world will do to them” and their loved ones.
Now that shoppers have sworn off credit cards, we’re risking an epidemic of a hitherto neglected affliction: saver’s remorse.

The 92nd Street Y has announced its 2009-10 concert season, the 10th that has been programmed by Hanna Arie-Gaifman. Among the highlights will be a series of appearances by the Hungarian-born pianist Andras Schiff, who will focus on the compositions of Haydn. Mr. Schiff will perform concerts on Feb. 25 and 27, 2010, and offer a lecture recital on Feb. 28; he will also appear with the Hungarian author Peter Esterhazy on March 1. In addition, there will be a series of concerts focused on the music of Hungary. Other events include the biennial Guitar Marathon on Jan. 31, 2010; Christian Tetzlaff’s presentation of Bach’s Partitas and Sonatas for solo violin on Oct. 25; and performances by the pianists Zoltan Kocsis (on Oct. 17) and Marc-André Hamelin (on Dec. 12). More information can be found online at www.92Y.org/concerts.

Warner Brothers has introduced a new DVD-on-demand offering for fans of niche vintage films. At WarnerArchive.com, the studio is now selling about 150 of the more obscure and offbeat movies from its library, and they can be ordered directly for $19.95 each. “Many of these films I do not believe would have had a home at retail, due to their narrow appeal,” said George Feltenstein, Warner’s senior vice president for theatrical catalog marketing. They include, for instance, “The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing” (1973), starring Burt Reynolds. Others are Joan Crawford vehicles (“When Ladies Meet,” 1941), westerns (“Wichita,” 1955) and silent films (“The Kiss,” 1929, starring Greta Garbo). Television shows are to be added soon.
Canceled shows never die; they’re just rebroadcast on DirecTV.
More than 16 million viewers tuned in to “60 Minutes” on Sunday for that newsmagazine’s interview with President Obama, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

Walgreen said its same-store sales increased 1.3 percent because prescription sales rose.
The jewelry retailer says it expects its earnings to be disappointing this year, but vows not to cut prices to bolster sales.

Israel’s Likud Party opened talks with the Labor Party, in a continued effort to form a broad government.

Infants in middle-income countries are getting vaccines weeks later than recommended.

Jane Lubchenco is an outspoken marine ecologist who pushes colleagues to engage the public.
Does vitamin E do anything to help prevent cancer, Alzheimer’s disease or heart disease?
As the E.P.A. prepares to regulate heat-trapping gases, it is embarking on an ambitious regulatory challenge.
The government said the Dalai Lama’s presence would have drawn world attention to the tensions between the Dalai Lama and China, one of South Africa’s most important trading partners.
The company lost its top credit rating because of higher risks at the conglomerate’s struggling G.E. Capital lending unit.
The 174-year-old Ann Arbor News will shut down and become primarily Web-based. Three other publications will publish print versions three days a week.
An artist-turned-medical-student is using CT scanners to peer into the meat and guts of cultural icons like the Big Mac, Barbie and the iPhone.
Could fish oil capsules contain the harmful pollutant found in some species of fish?
The United States has thrown its support behind the Danish prime minister as the new secretary general of NATO, but must now try to get Turkey to agree, senior officials said.
Youthful freshness was the hallmark of the accomplished performance of Brahms’s First Symphony that Ryan McAdams led on Sunday at Carnegie Hall.
Details of negotiations on a highly restrictive plea bargain for Binyam Mohamed, a Guantánamo detainee, were revealed in a legal document released by a British court.
The drug used for reducing wrinkles is also being used to relax muscles stiffened by a stroke.
The shells of a well-studied intertidal snail around Mount Desert Island in Maine have increased significantly in size over the last century.
Neither the death of Barbaro nor the on-track euthanization of the filly Eight Belles prompted meaningful and uniform safety and medication rules.
Did the United States lose a World Baseball Classic semifinal game on Sunday? Or have we lost the game itself.
The Nano, a fuel-efficient, compact car costing $2,500, is being greeted warily by automakers and car enthusiasts.
A new study on the region around the Chernobyl nuclear accident in Ukraine suggests that invertebrates are highly sensitive to radiation.
Why haven’t the icy particles and dust that make up the rings of Saturn coalesced into a moon?
The private plane that crashed outside of Butte, Mont., on Sunday carried members of three close-knit families.
Online tool can predict your risk of developing adult-onset diabetes.
The official, Kamal Midhat, was the deputy leader in Lebanon of Fatah, the mainstream Palestinian faction led by Mahmoud Abbas.
Difficult cases raise questions about who is fit to become a doctor.
Lance Armstrong crashed during the first stage of a five-day race and broke his right collarbone, adding an obstacle to his preparation for the Tour de France in July.
Putting himself at greater risk of being arrested, President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan made his first trip abroad since the International Criminal Court issued a warrant against him.
All of the remaining teams resonate as recognizable college basketball brands.
An anti-Cinderella crowd is cheering the second round of the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament, which came and went with shockingly few shocking upsets.
Existing-home sales rose as buyers scooped up foreclosure properties, but the median sales price fell 15.5 percent.
Nicholas Hughes, the son of Sylvia Plath and the British Poet Laureate Ted Hughes, killed himself at his home in Alaska.
The Treasury presented its plan to draw private investors into partnership with a new federal entity to buy up risky assets.
Two telecommunications rivals will cut costs by jointly building sites or consolidating existing antenna towers in Britain, Germany, Ireland and Spain, but they do not plan to cut jobs.
Suncor Energy has agreed to acquire Petro-Canada in an all-stock deal worth about $15 billion.
A senior Taliban leader responsible for numerous roadside bombings and suicide attacks against NATO forces has been killed, officials said.
A Federal Express cargo plane burst into flames as it landed outside of Tokyo, and the police confirmed that the pilot and co-pilot had been killed.
Scientists have now shown how bats land, hanging upside down from their heels.
Figuring out whether a child has head lice may require more than just taking a look.
Exercising after a heart attack can be helpful to one’s recovery, but the benefits can vanish in weeks if the exercise is stopped, a new study has found.

Because of an editing error, an article last Tuesday about efforts by the Italian government to have the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek museum in Copenhagen return what Italy says are looted antiquities referred incorrectly to an Italian prosecutor who is deciding whether to press charges against the museum and misstated the prosecutor's given name. The prosecutor, Paola Giorgio Ferri (not Paolo) is a woman.

To the Editor: ''What does it take to make a medical expert?'' asks Dr. Richard A. Friedman (''Accepting the Risks in Creating Confident Doctors,'' Mind, March 17). Surprisingly, his answer is not knowledge. While ''expert'' opinions vary widely, there are right and wrong answers in health science. Many doctors' expert opinions (including those of attending physicians) are simply wrong.

A music review last Tuesday about the violinist and violist Julian Rachlin, at the Frick Collection, misspelled the title of a Fritz Kreisler piece he played as an encore. It is ''Liebesleid,'' not ''Liebeslied.''
To the Editor: Re ''Appalachia's Agony'' (editorial, March 16):

The civil war within Unite Here, the union representing hotel, restaurant, apparel and laundry workers, has reached the secession stage. A splinter group claiming to represent 150,000 of Unite Here's 400,000 members announced Monday that its delegates had voted to break away and merge into the Service Employees International Union.

KLINE--Roger C. The partners of McKinsey & Co. mark with sadness the passing of our beloved colleague, Roger Kline, who died in his sleep March 18, while in London on business. Roger joined the firm in 1976 and was part of the team that built our banking and securities practice, which he led from 1996 to 2004. He was elected a director in 1986 and led our New York Office in 1995-96. Roger co-founded McKinsey's investment office, was a member of the firm's board, chaired the finance committee, and was a member of the office of the managing partner. More importantly, he was a friend and mentor to a generation of colleagues, teaching many of us how to solve the most challenging problems and how to convey answers to clients with both absolute candor and empathy. He earned the trust of business and government leaders around the world, who relied on his counsel, as did a wide circle of friends who prized his wit, erudition and unflagging kindness. Roger leaves a rich legacy at McKinsey, where he played the "loyal opposition" challenging complacency and destroying faulty logic. In 2007, Roger established the McKinsey Center for Advanced Problem Solving to ensure that our teams will always have the most sophisticated tools to solve our clients' problems. Roger was President of Friends of the Atlantic Partnership, which promotes dialogue between European and U.S. opinion leaders, and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. His philanthropic activities centered on issues of adoption, as Chairman of Whole Child International, and through the Evan B. Donaldson Adoption Institute. We will miss Roger's extraordinary intellect and his dedication to the firm and its clients. We join Roger's widow Susan, his son Matthew, his brother Gil, and the rest of his family in mourning the loss of a remarkable man.

A picture caption with the Talking Business column on Saturday, about public indignation over bonuses at the American International Group, misidentified the building behind a group of protesters in Manhattan on Thursday. It is the Deutsche Bank headquarters at 60 Wall Street -- not the A.I.G. headquarters. (A.I.G. has offices nearby at 160 Water Street.)

After producing superlatives like the world's biggest statue of a jackrabbit and the nation's most unpopular modern-day president, Texas can now boast what may be its most bizarre and undoubtedly its slimiest topper yet: the world's largest known colony of clonal amoebas. Scientists found the vast and sticky empire stretching 40 feet across, consisting of billions of genetically identical single-celled individuals, oozing along in the muck of a cow pasture outside Houston.

Mexico's former president, Carlos Salinas, used to promise that free trade and foreign investment would jump-start this country's development, empowering a richer and more prosperous Mexico ''to export goods, not people.'' Fifteen years after the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect, only the first part of that promise has been realized.
Dot Earth From Andrew C. Revkin's blog, nytimes.com/dotearth.

The State Senate overwhelmingly approved a bill to allow same-sex marriage, setting the stage for the House to take up the matter this week. The Senate, which is dominated by Democrats, voted 26 to 4 in favor of the measure, which would allow gay couples to marry starting in September. Vermont was the first state to permit civil unions for gay couples, in 2000, and it would be the third, after Massachusetts and Connecticut, to approve same-sex marriage. The House Judiciary Committee will start hearing testimony on it Tuesday. Gov. Jim Douglas, a Republican, opposes the bill but has not said whether he will veto it.

Insulin was named before it was discovered. In 1909, a French researcher coined the name after concluding that the isles of Langerhans in the pancreas must secrete some essential, yet unknown, metabolic substance. A group of Canadian researchers, including Frederick G. Banting and John J. R. Macleod, isolated the material more than a decade later, meticulously extracting it from cells of a dog's pancreas.

Sasha Cohen, the ethereal figure skater with an Olympic silver medal and the grace of a prima ballerina, has not competed in three years. Asked if she missed it, she sighed. ''I remember the smell of the arena, the brightness of the lights and, oh, that nervousness you feel in your stomach,'' she said in a recent interview. ''Then you disappear into your own world. You go into that mode, like: 'I can do this. I am strong.' It's hard to explain. There's nothing like it.''

FLAGELLO--Ezio. The Metropolitan Opera is saddened by the death of bass Ezio Flagello, who had a distinguished career with our company, singing 50 roles and 528 performances between 1957 and 1984. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

DELALLA--Angelina, on March 22. Wake at Morisco Funeral Home Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9, Astoria, 718-728-2888. Funeral Mass Thursday, 11am at Mt. Carmel Church, Astoria, Interment Pinelawn Cemetery. In lieu of flowers family will accept donations in her name to charity.

Our Kentucky Derby contender list has a new No. 1: Mafaaz, the winner of the inaugural Kentucky Derby Challenge Stakes last week in Sunbury-on-Thames, England. He is talented and has an experienced trainer in John Gosden. But most significant, Mafaaz is drug free, and if he wins the Kentucky Derby, he may shame the American thoroughbred industry into doing right by its athletes and banning the practice of giving medications to horses on the days they race. Neither the suffering and eventual death of Barbaro, the 2006 Derby winner, nor the on-track euthanization of the filly Eight Belles after finishing second in last year's Derby has prompted racetracks and horsemen in the United States to adopt meaningful and uniform safety and medication rules.

The loose ball bounced into Kia Vaughn's hands, but her soft shot from no more than 2 feet somehow kicked off the rim. Vaughn frowned. Another sizable and hard-earned Rutgers lead looked as if it were evaporating in the span of a few futile minutes. But the Scarlet Knights had already covered this. Two months earlier, they had blown a big lead to Tennessee -- at home, no less -- and they thought they knew how to prevent another collapse.

The American military marked another milestone the other day in the initiative perhaps most responsible for taming the violence in Iraq: All but 10,000 of the 94,000 Sunni militiamen -- many of them former insurgents who agreed, for cash, to stop killing American soldiers -- had been turned over to the control of the Iraqi military. Significantly, the militiamen themselves were not celebrating.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about the departure of the drummer from the band Smashing Pumpkins misspelled his surname. He is Jimmy Chamberlin, not Chamberlain. The report also referred incorrectly to the original band members who took part in a recent 20th-anniversary tour. Billy Corgan, the guitarist and singer-songwriter, was on the tour; Mr. Chamberlin was not the only original member.

Copyright lawyers have been arguing over Shepard Fairey's appropriation of a news photograph of Barack Obama for his ''Hope'' campaign poster and whether it constitutes ''fair use.'' But no one has disputed that it is a work of art. But what about the photograph on which the poster is based? Taken by Mannie Garcia while on assignment for The Associated Press in 2006, the picture is now on sale at a Chelsea gallery in a limited edition of 200. The prints are going for $1,200 apiece, and at least one has been purchased by a fine-arts museum.

ING Group has asked 1,200 workers, including its 200 ''top employees,'' to return last year's bonuses. The bank also deferred 2009 variable cash compensation for all workers until a new policy is established next year, it said in a message to employees and obtained by Bloomberg News. ''Given the continuing public scrutiny of variable pay practices in our industry, ING is moving to align its variable compensation practices with the new reality,'' it said. ING received a 10 billion euro ($13.5 billion) bailout from its government in October.

A year ago, Sweden's most prestigious medical school found itself in an international uproar after it unknowingly admitted a student who was a Nazi sympathizer and a convicted murderer, then scrambled to find a way to expel him. It is hard to imagine how the case could get any more bizarre. But it has.

The fundamental difference between Xavier Nady and Nick Swisher is selectivity at the plate. Swisher was first in the majors last season in pitches seen per plate appearance. Nady was 113th. Patience was the hallmark of the Yankees' offense during their most recent glory years. Hitters waited for the right pitch and ground through opposing staffs. Swisher embodies that approach.

GOLDSCHMIDT--Leonard, 84, of South Orange on Sunday, March 22nd, 2009, at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. Predeceased by his beloved wife of 54 years, Rita Betty Goldschmidt in 2005. Devoted father of Dr. Marc Goldschmidt, Dr. Harlene Goldschmidt, and Pamela Goldschmidt, loving brother of Sally Abrahams and adored grandfather of Mackenzie Wilson. Memorial contributions may be made to Jewish charity of choice.

In a snub of the International Criminal Court, President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan traveled on Monday to Eritrea, barely three weeks after the court issued a warrant for his arrest on war crimes charges for atrocities committed in Darfur. It was Mr. Bashir's first trip abroad since the court issued its warrant, and it seemed to come as something of a surprise to people in the region. The trip had not been announced in Sudan, and foreign news agencies said that even those close to the Sudanese government had not been apprised of Mr. Bashir's plans.

Last week, The New York Times ran an article about Connecticut's rare ability to avoid fouls while getting plenty of fouls called on the other team. The differential during the regular season was 8.5 fouls a game, which allowed UConn to shoot nearly 15 more free throws, on average, than its opponent. Seven of the past eight national champions had differentials of 2.6 fouls a game or higher -- which sounds like a small number but really isn't. Only 11 teams in the N.C.A.A. tournament this year had such a big advantage in fouls. Twenty had negative numbers, including Louisville.

FOR SALE: TAINTED ASSETS If all goes as planned, private investors will team up with a new federal entity to buy up to $1 trillion in tainted assets that are congesting credit markets. A BETTER PRESENTATION The announcement of the plan to deal with tainted assets by Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, was much smoother than his previous efforts. [A1.]

The trustee handling the liquidation of Bernard L. Madoff's brokerage business told a federal judge on Monday that he had found $75 million in new assets in Gibraltar. He also said he was monitoring claims against the Madoffs' chateau in France, and had received clearance from a British court to work with counterparts in London on liquidating the Madoff business there. But at the same time, the court-appointed trustee, Irving H. Picard of the law firm Baker Hostetler, was meeting stiff opposition from prosecutors in New York.
To the Editor: Re ''Iran, Jews and Pragmatism'' (column, March 16):

More than 16 million viewers tuned in to ''60 Minutes'' on Sunday for that newsmagazine's interview with President Obama, according to Nielsen's estimates. The show was delayed nearly an hour from its usual 7 p.m. time slot because of an overrun of CBS's college basketball coverage, which averaged more than 15 million viewers during the first part of prime time. CBS led the night over all, broadcasting ''The Amazing Race'' around 9 (11.6 million) and ''Cold Case'' at 10 (10.8 million). ABC was a close runner-up, largely because of ''Desperate Housewives'' (14.7 million). NBC ranked third for the night, as its new series ''Kings'' (4.6 million) continued to struggle at 8. Fox was fourth with its animated comedy lineup.

Duke's Gerald Henderson would seem to have a brighter N.B.A. future ahead of him than his father, who won three championship rings (two in Boston and one in Detroit). He may eventually earn a place on the mythical all-sons team ahead of his collegiate peers with more famous surnames like Jordan, Pippen and Sampson. There won't soon be a better son of a ball-playing father than Kobe Bryant, son of Joe, a former Philadelphia 76er known as Jellybean. Some of the other leading sons, past and present, include:

At 27, the conductor Ryan McAdams is not that much older than the players in the New York Youth Symphony, who are mostly of high school and college age. And youthful freshness was the hallmark of the accomplished performance of Brahms's First Symphony that Mr. McAdams led with this impressive ensemble on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Beyond the technical confidence, it was the unjaded enthusiasm of the playing that made the Brahms so rewarding. It is impossible for the performance of a staple to slip into routine when the orchestra is made up of gifted young musicians, many playing the piece for the first time.

A slew of political scandals gripping Malaysia and a transfer of power fraught with uncertainty have shaken the elite here, with exquisitely poor timing. As a major trading nation, Malaysia has been slammed by the global downturn. Its exports have collapsed by nearly one-third, and current projections show that its economy will shrink by as much as 5 percent this year.

HERSH--Jerome J.,89, of Peekskill, died on March 22, 2009. Practiced law in Peekskill for over 60 years. Former City Court Judge, a Judicial Hearing Officer for the Ninth District. Survived by wife, Joanne Pines Hersh, children: John (Doriann), Richard, M.D. and Anne, three grandchildren. Funeral Services Private. Donations to The Field Library; 4 Nelson Ave. Suite 2; Peekskill, NY 10566.

Nobody seems to like talking much in ''Inked Baby,'' a listless new play by Christina Anderson that opened on Monday night at Playwrights Horizons. Husband and wife can't seem to communicate, or even agree on whether to see a therapist to improve communication. Sisters eye each other warily, their amity impeded by the fact that one slept with the other's husband. (For surrogate-mothering reasons, but still.) The sassy girlfriend is a party, but then she begins exhibiting symptoms of a mysterious disease, which puts a damper on her enthusiasm for girl talk. One of the livelier exchanges in this odd and frustrating play is an intimate colloquy between a man and a pretzel stick.

Nicholas Hughes, the son of the poets Sylvia Plath and Ted Hughes, killed himself on March 16 at his home in Alaska, four decades after his mother and father's lover took their own lives. He was 47. His sister, Frieda Hughes, announced his death, by hanging, over the weekend. Friends and family said he had long struggled with depression.
International UNEMPLOYED SUNNI MILITIAMEN

CONWAY--Joseph P. The partners, associates and staff of Cahill Gordon & Reindel LLP are profoundly saddened by the passing of Joseph P. Conway, our accomplished retired partner and friend of 43 years. Joe was a leading finance practitioner who helped the Firm define and distinguish its prominent corporate and securities practice. We are proud to have been his partners, friends and colleagues. Our deepest sympathies to his wife, Mary Louise and their son John Conway and daughters Elizabeth West, Anne Gamble and Ellen Macleish.

A theater review on March 16 about ''Blithe Spirit,'' at the Shubert Theater, misidentified the nationality of the director, Michael Blakemore. While he has worked extensively in Britain, he is Australian, not British.

After her stroke, Francine V. Corso, a software engineer who worked on NASA's lunar lander, was housebound from 1992 to 2001. Her left arm was twisted up near her neck, making it difficult to pull on a blouse, and her fingers curled so rigidly that her nails buried themselves in her palm. When she finally learned to rise from her wheelchair, her contorted left leg had the so-called horse gait of many brain-injury victims -- she stepped toe-downward, and then fought to keep her foot from rolling over.

This letter was written to William C. Rhoden in response to his Sports of The Times column about the need for drug reform in thoroughbred racing. I am a devout fan of horse racing, an active bettor, a columnist and author of several horse racing books. I dearly love to watch the sleek, stunningly beautiful thoroughbreds as they perform countless feats of speed and endurance.

THE business jet industry, as we all know, has been hit hard by a teetering economy and public hostility against anything perceived as wretched corporate excess. Sales are down. Orders are being withdrawn. Corporate flight departments are being closed or told to keep a low profile. Layoffs are mounting.

Mexican authorities published a list of their most wanted drug traffickers on Monday. The attorney general's office is offering up to $2 million for information leading to the arrest of any of 24 top traffickers on the list and up to $1 million for any of 13 lieutenants -- more than double previous rewards. The list was the government's first public breakdown of major traffickers, who are listed by cartel and include aliases like the Taliban, the Monkey and Marblehead.

An article on March 11 about an academic fraud case against Dr. Scott S. Reuben, an anesthesiologist in Springfield, Mass., paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by a spokeswoman for Baystate Medical Center, where he formerly practiced. And a correction in this space on Thursday failed to correct the headline and another comment by the spokeswoman that was paraphrased incorrectly. The spokeswoman, Jane Albert, said in an interview that an investigating committee concluded that Dr. Reuben fabricated data underlying much of his research, and she added that he had cooperated with the investigation. She did not say that he himself admitted fabricating data. (This error in the article was repeated in the headline.) In addition, Ms. Albert said in the interview that the hospital found that Dr. Reuben fabricated data in some or all of 21 journal articles; she did not say that he did not conduct the clinical trials described in those articles.

Q.Why haven't the icy particles and dust that make up the rings of Saturn coalesced into a moon? A.NASA scientists suggest that some of the moons of Saturn are giving rise to rings, rather than vice versa.

With major elections approaching over the next year and a half, leading New York Democrats are expressing deep concerns that the party has been thrown into turmoil by competing personal agendas, ideological rifts and a leadership void. Democratic politicians and strategists warn that the strife threatens to undercut not only any chance of remaining competitive in the race for City Hall this year, but hopes of holding on to the Governor's Mansion and a United States Senate seat in 2010.

Early this month, Courtney Paris, an all-American center at the University of Oklahoma, made a promise that was rare and provocative: if the Sooners did not win the national basketball championship, she would repay the cost of her scholarship. Her pledge became a primary story line of the women's N.C.A.A. tournament and elicited strong reactions in support and in criticism of Paris, a senior. The vow has raised questions about personal responsibility in sports, the emphasis placed on winning and an athlete's obligations in fulfilling a scholarship contract.

A senior Taliban leader responsible for numerous roadside bombings and suicide attacks against NATO forces has been killed along with nine other insurgent fighters, NATO said Monday. Maulawi Hassan, described as a well-known Taliban commander in southern Afghanistan, was killed Saturday in an attack on his compound near Kajaki, in Helmand Province, according to a NATO statement.

Nature is reputed to be red in tooth and claw, but many arms races across the animal kingdom are characterized by restraint rather than carnage. Competition among males is often expressed in the form of elaborate weapons made of bone, horn or chitin. The weapons often start off small and then, under the pressure of competition, may evolve to attain gigantic proportions. The Irish elk, now extinct, had antlers with a span of 12 feet. The drawback of this magnificent adornment, though, was that the poor beast had to carry more than 80 pounds of bone on its head.

Glenn Marlin Sundby, an acrobatic stuntman who helped propel gymnastics to national prominence as a magazine publisher and a founder of the sport's national governing body, died Wednesday in Vista, Calif. He was 87. His death was announced by USA Gymnastics, the successor to the United States Gymnastics Federation, which Mr. Sundby helped form.

In another indication that China is growing increasingly concerned about holding huge dollar reserves, the head of its central bank has called for the eventual creation of a new international currency reserve to replace the dollar. In a paper released Monday, Zhou Xiaochuan, governor of the People's Bank of China, said a new currency reserve system controlled by the International Monetary Fund could prove more stable and economically viable.

The nation is close to a major civic breakthrough. By a 321-to-105 vote last week, the House approved an ambitious bipartisan measure to enlarge the opportunities for Americans of all ages and income levels to participate in productive national and community service. A similar plan is now before the Senate. A favorable vote this week would help speed a worthy initiative to President Obama's desk.

SANDLER--Julian. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the death of Julian Sandler, longtime Advisory Board member of The Rabbinical School. Julian brought his love of Judaism and his keen insights to our school, helping us attract and support the strongest possible candidates for the rabbinate. We extend our condolences to his beloved wife, Nina; sons Ian (Mackenzie) and Joel (Michelle); and extended family. May his memory be for a blessing. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

As sports leagues in North America retrench during the recession, the soccer business in the United States, although cautious in the current climate, is taking a different course. Last week, the expansion Seattle Sounders F.C. of Major League Soccer played its inaugural game, sandwiched between the announcement of new teams in Vancouver, British Columbia; and Portland, Ore., that will begin play in 2011, increasing the league to 18 teams. On Sunday, the new seven-team women's league, Women's Professional Soccer, will try to re-establish a top-tier league from the ashes of the Women's United Soccer Association, which folded after the 2003 season.

KABAKOW--Gussie, Manager Pension Fund, Bakery Drivers Union, volunteer NY Eye and Ear, Beth Israel Hospice, American Women's ORT, WE Care/Village E. Towers and Workmen's Circle died March 21, age 95. Diminutive in stature, giant in spirit, she generously shared her intelligence, warmth, and love. Dear mother of Masha (Sy Rudman), and Sunny (Paul Fischer). Beloved husband Ben, daughter Sara (Wallace Mandell) and son Don preceded her in death. She leaves loving friends, nieces, nephews, eight grandchildren and eight great-grand- children. Contributions to ORT, www.ortamerica.org or place of your choice. Gathering March 24, 1pm, Wellwood Cemetery, 631-249-2300.

''Haggadah (or the Passover Show),'' Witness Relocation's new production at La MaMa E.T.C., stands as a noisy rebuke to that too-familiar creature: the interminable family Seder. A whirl of speedy activity, with projections, music, dancing and short skits, ''Haggadah,'' directed and choreographed by the troupe's leader, Dan Safer, is theater for the short-attention-span, when-do-we-eat? crowd. Conceived collaboratively -- the program calls the eight performers co-creators and co-choreographers -- the show is more a series of riffs than a retelling of the Passover story, in which Moses leads the Jews out of captivity in Egypt. There's a hit-or-miss quality to those riffs, which run from silly (Moses, encouraged to have a jelly bean, opens a can and a paper snake pops out) to sober (a Holocaust-like story about a hut full of dead bodies).

A federal judge in Manhattan said on Monday that he was deeply troubled by the secrecy of a settlement concerning two Picasso paintings purportedly sold under duress in Nazi Germany. In the settlement announced last month, the Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum said they would continue to own the Picassos, and would pay a confidential sum to the heirs of the paintings' original owner, Paul von Mendelssohn-Bartholdy, and his wife, to resolve the case.

THE FACTS Fish oil supplements are increasingly popular with people who don't like seafood but are attracted by claims of cardiac benefits. But could they also expose you to the harmful pollutants found in some species of fish?

CHILDS--Mary Cole, of New York and Washington, DC, died March 20. Daughter of Dr. Rufus Cole and Annie Hegeler Cole of Mt. Kisco, NY, she is survived by her son, David Childs, and her daughter, Ellyn Allison, and their spouses, four grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Former director of the Children's Book Council, New York, she was deeply committed throughout her long life to promoting children's literacy.

After breaking his right collarbone Monday during a race in Spain, Lance Armstrong now faces his first serious obstacle since his return to professional cycling: whether he can recover fast enough to compete in two of the sport's most prestigious events. Armstrong, who took three and a half years off before coming back this season, had planned to race in his first Giro d'Italia, which begins May 9, before competing in the Tour de France in July. Armstrong, 37, has about seven weeks to heal before the Giro.

Joseph Gorak, 19, has just joined the American Ballet Theater's corps de ballet as an apprentice after dancing with its junior company for two and a half years. He fell in love with ballet at age 3, after seeing the ''Nutcracker'' in his hometown, Fort Wayne, Ind. Early shows: I was very theatrical as a kid. I made up my own choreography and put on performances for myself and my parents and my brother. And our cats and dogs.

In a little-noticed act of political faintheartedness, the Obama administration has pulled back from nominating Thomas Saenz, a highly regarded civil-rights lawyer and counsel to the mayor of Los Angeles, to run the Justice Department's civil rights division. Mr. Saenz, the former top litigator in Los Angeles for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, or Maldef, was privately offered the job in January. The floating of his name led to fierce outbursts from anti-immigrant groups and blogs, which detest him for being so good at what he does.

KLINE--Roger. The Board and Staff of the Evan B. Donaldson Adoption Institute mourn the sudden loss of our friend and supporter Roger Kline. We will miss his wise counsel and leadership on behalf of adoptive families. We send our heartfelt condolences to his son, Matt, and brother, Gil. Susan Notkin, Board President Adam Pertman, Exec. Director

The actor and comedian Robin Williams, below, is recovering from heart surgery he underwent on March 13 after a health scare that forced the postponement of his ''Weapons of Self-Destruction'' tour. In a news release Mr. Williams's publicists said that he had undergone a three-and-a-half-hour procedure at the Cleveland Clinic to replace his aortic valve, repair his mitral valve and correct his irregular heartbeat. Earlier this month Mr. Williams was performing in Florida when he announced that he was postponing four shows because of shortness of breath. His heart problems were later diagnosed at the University of Miami Hospital. In a statement Dr. A. Marc Gillinov, a staff cardiothoracic surgeon at the Cleveland Clinic, said that Mr. Williams would have normal heart function in a few weeks. Mr. Williams is expected to resume his ''Weapons of Self-Destruction'' tour, with dates on Broadway, in the fall.

Figuring out whether a child has head lice may require more than just taking a look. German scientists examined 304 children at five primary schools that reported persistent head lice infestations. First, a researcher examined their scalps, parting the hair at five places where eggs or lice are often found. Then a different investigator, unaware of the results of the first test, examined the same children, this time wetting the hair with conditioner and running a fine-tooth comb from the scalp to the end of the hair. The results appear in the March issue of The Archives of Dermatology.

Details of negotiations on a highly restrictive plea bargain for a Guantánamo detainee were revealed in a legal document released by a British court on Monday. The measures proposed by the United States included a prison term of at least three years more than the seven he had already been detained, a gag order, an end to his efforts to obtain documents that might bolster his claims that he was tortured while in C.I.A. custody, and an agreement not to file lawsuits against the United States government or any of its officials.

Canceled shows never die; they're just rebroadcast on DirecTV. Variety reported that the satellite broadcaster DirecTV had acquired the rights to broadcast three short-lived network series, so short-lived that their first seasons weren't shown in their entirety. The three series are to be broadcast on DirecTV's 101 Network. They are ''Smith,'' a 2006 CBS crime drama about a gang of professional criminals, whose cast includedSimon Baker, Virginia Madsen andRay Liotta; ''The Nine,'' a 2006 ABC drama about a group of strangers linked as hostages in a bank robbery; and ''Eyes,'' a 2005 ABC series about a high-tech detective agency. In January DirecTV began rebroadcasting ''Wonderland,'' a well-reviewed if abbreviated ABC series from 2000; its new batch of resurrected shows will begin showing in April.

Hedge funds are down, but not out. That, anyway, is the conclusion of a closely watched industry survey to be published on Tuesday, which paints a sobering portrait of what was once one of the highest-flying businesses on Wall Street.

If you're going to suffer an eternity in hell for your unrepentant libertine ways, you might as well enjoy them, right? Alas, the Don Juan of Igor Dobrovolskiy's production, Kostyantyn Voynov, is rather oppressed by his unrelenting sexual drive. Beset by kinky nightmares, his hair in a fabulously chronic state of disarray, our boy is barely keeping it together. The Atlantic Ballet Theater of Canada's ''Don Juan,'' with a cast of just 10, had its New York premiere on Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts. (Nothing like a sexual predator to enliven a matinee crowd.)

A former professor who has accused the University of Colorado of firing him because of a controversial essay he wrote about the Sept. 11 attacks took the stand Monday in his lawsuit against the university and offered a defense of those remarks. Carrying a stack of books to the witness box, his long hair pulled back in a ponytail, the former professor, Ward L. Churchill, told a packed courtroom about the essay, in which he described office workers killed in the World Trade Center attacks as ''little Eichmanns.''

The Obama administration's new plan to liberate the nation's banks from a toxic stew of bad home loans and mortgage-related securities is bigger and more generous to private investors than expected, but it also puts taxpayers at great risk. Taken together, the three programs unveiled on Monday by the Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, could buy up to $2 trillion in real estate assets that have been weighing down banks, paralyzing credit markets and delaying the economic recovery.

An article and a headline on March 15 about a meeting of finance ministers from the Group of 20 nations outside London described the makeup of the group incorrectly. The organization, also called the G-20, consists of the 19 leading industrial and developing nations and the European Union; it is not composed of 20 industrial nations.

The six of them attended college together. They pursued graduate degrees at the same university, then all settled into medical professions and started families around the same time. And on Sunday they were all sitting on the same private plane, with their seven young children, headed to a much-anticipated ski vacation at an exclusive resort in Big Sky, Mont.

The 92nd Street Y has announced its 2009-10 concert season, the 10th that has been programmed by Hanna Arie-Gaifman. Among the highlights will be a series of appearances by the Hungarian-born pianist Andras Schiff, who will focus on the compositions of Haydn. Mr. Schiff will perform concerts on Feb. 25 and 27, 2010, and offer a lecture recital on Feb. 28; he will also appear with the Hungarian author Peter Esterhazy on March 1. In addition, there will be a series of concerts focused on the music of Hungary. Other events include the biennial Guitar Marathon on Jan. 31, 2010; Christian Tetzlaff's presentation of Bach's Partitas and Sonatas for solo violin on Oct. 25; and performances by the pianists Zoltan Kocsis (on Oct. 17) and Marc-André Hamelin (on Dec. 12). More information can be found online at www.92Y.org/concerts.

Because of an editing error, an Op-Ed article on Sunday, about the parole of Sara Jane Olson, misstated a detail of the biography of a leader of the Symbionese Liberation Army, Donald DeFreeze. He joined a gang in Buffalo, not New York City.

The Supreme Court hears arguments on Tuesday in a case that gives it a chance to stop political groups and corporations from gouging a major hole in federal campaign finance law. The case revolves around ''Hillary: The Movie,'' an anti-Hillary Rodham Clinton film made before the 2008 election. A lower federal court ruled that the film falls under federal law restricting the airing of attack ads. The Supreme Court should affirm that ruling. ''Hillary: The Movie'' was produced by Citizens United, a conservative nonprofit corporation. The film is full of express arguments that Mrs. Clinton would not be a suitable president or commander in chief.

To the Editor: As one who forgets someone's name so fast that I wonder if I ever heard it, ''In One Ear and Out The Other'' (Basics, March 17) hit home. Natalie Angier quotes the Harvard psychology professor Daniel L. Schacter as saying, ''We humans are pretty good at gist recall but have difficulty with being exact.''

Carol Mrowka considers her East Village neighborhood here attractive, comfortable -- and ordinary. So when the city deemed the area an official landmark, Ms. Mrowka found it absurd and went to court. ''Sure, it's a nice neighborhood,'' said Ms. Mrowka, a real estate agent who moved 12 years ago to the neighborhood, north and west of the Loop, with its cottages and small, flat buildings that were home to immigrants in the late 1800s. ''The basic style of the buildings is pretty, but this is not a landmark.''

A FedEx Express cargo plane burst into flames as it landed Monday morning at Narita International Airport outside Tokyo, and the company confirmed that the pilot and co-pilot had been killed. Video of the crash showed a massive fireball erupting from the plane as its belly touched down, just after its nose had banged hard on the runway. The plane then veered to its left, flipped over and skidded off the runway in flames. Fire engines rushed to the scene and sprayed the plane with foam.
The Red River is rising in Fargo, N.D., and is expected to crest about 22 feet above flood stage. On Monday, workers installed a portable interlocking container system to hold back the water.

Giants fans should plan to eat their turkey early this Thanksgiving because their team will play Thanksgiving night in Denver. It will be the first Thanksgiving game for the Giants since 1992, when they lost to the Dallas Cowboys, 30-3, and only their third Thanksgiving Day game since 1938. It will be the first time the Broncos have hosted a Thanksgiving game since 1963. The Giants are 1-3 in Denver, last playing there Sept. 10, 2001.

Detectives spent Monday in and around the Brooklyn apartment of a freelance radio reporter, searching for clues as to who killed him over the weekend and whether it was someone he knew, the police said. The reporter, George Weber, 47, was found dead in the apartment, at 561 Henry Street in Carroll Gardens, on Sunday morning. An autopsy was performed on Monday, and the police said that Mr. Weber had been stabbed in his head, his neck, the front and rear of his torso, his arms and his hands, which appeared to have defensive wounds.
