His feet had been bound with duct tape, said Paul J. Browne, a police spokesman.

DirecTV renewed its deal as the N.F.L.'s exclusive satellite carrier and will continue to offer the Sunday Ticket package of out-of-market afternoon games from 2011 to 2014. The deal will cost DirecTV $1 billion a year, a leap from $700 million. The new agreement will offer features that fans without DirecTV have long wanted. Fans living in areas where they cannot get DirecTV will be able to buy it on broadband directly from the satellite carrier, no later than 2012. Also, Sunday Ticket's Red Zone Channel will be made available, for a fee, also no later than 2012, to Dish; telephone companies like Verizon and AT&T; wireless; and Internet providers. The four-year-old Red Zone channel provides highlights and live look-ins to games when teams are inside their opponents' 20-yard line.

The four-day N.C.A.A. tournament binge, one of the best stretches in American sports each year, has ended. Now that the dust has settled after two rounds, the residue looks chalky (to borrow a horse racing term). Each of the 16 remaining teams resonates a recognizable brand name in college basketball. None could be considered a surprise to have advanced.

Israel's conservative Likud Party opened coalition talks with the center-left Labor Party on Monday, as the prime minister-designate and Likud leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, continued efforts to form a broad government and to avoid leading a narrow right-wing coalition. But the Labor leader, Ehud Barak, the current defense minister, is facing strong opposition within his party to the idea of sitting in a government led by Mr. Netanyahu. Some Labor opponents have warned of a split; the party is expected to vote on whether to join the new government at a special convention on Tuesday.

A work by John Adams, right, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, will make its New York premiere as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival, Lincoln Center announced. The piece, an opera-oratorio called ''A Flowering Tree,'' will be directed by Peter Sellars and feature a cast of Indonesian dancers and American singers; it is scheduled to be performed at the Rose Theater on Aug. 13, 14 and 16. The Mark Morris Dance Group will perform new works called ''Empire Garden'' and ''Visitation,'' which Mr. Morris created in collaboration withYo-Yo Ma andEmanuel Ax, at the Rose Aug. 19 through 22. The opening-night concert, at whichLouis Langrée will conduct the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra with featured performances by the pianist Leif Ove Andsnes and the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote, is scheduled for July 28. The festival runs through Aug. 22. More information can be found online at LincolnCenter.org.

When markets were rising, many Canadians fretted about leveraged buyouts that put several of the country's largest corporations under foreign control. The markets' collapse, however, created the environment for the creation of a new, large Canadian energy firm. On Monday, Suncor Energy confirmed that it would acquire Petro-Canada, forming a company with a combined market capitalization of about 43 billion Canadian dollars.

and who doesn't these days? -- you might try getting angry over the scarcity of pitchforks in this city. Horse whips, too. There is a pent-up demand for them yearning to be satisfied. Rage is all the rage now. Outrage is the in rage.

Howard Komives, a sharpshooting guard who played for 10 seasons in the National Basketball Association but who was perhaps best remembered for the trade that sent him to the Detroit Pistons from the Knicks for the future Hall of Famer Dave DeBusschere, died Sunday in Toledo, Ohio. He was 67. Komives's son, Shane, said his father died after surgery for head trauma that apparently resulted from a fall at his home. Komives had had difficulty walking because of knee and ankle problems and was found unconscious by his wife, Marcia, his son said.

HADLEY--Ann, wife of William, died on February 23. Former British citizen who spent most of life in the U.S. She kept her accent, sense of humor and generous spirit. She volunteered for a dozen years in New York Hospital (Children's Department) and mentored ESL students of Park West H.S. She gave a lot of herself and asked for little in return. Her cousins and friends in Ireland, England and U.S. will miss her.

LaPOOK--Elsa (Eisenbud), died peacefully on March 23 at age 86 surrounded by family after a joyous and fulfilled life. Beloved wife, best friend, and partner of 66 years to Dr. Sidney LaPook, magnificent mother to Judith, Nancy (Diamond), Jonathan and Corinne, and adored mother-in-law to Bob Diamond, Kate Lear and Wayne Pasternack. She was the devoted and much loved Babba of Michael, Rebecca, Laura, Sam, Daniel, Jesse and Noah. Daughter of Kalman and Leonora Eisenbud, sister of Leon and Merrill. Elsa grew up roller skating on the Upper West Side and returned to the City with her husband after raising their family in West Hempstead and Great Neck. Elsa was a 1945 graduate of Hunter College where she was a member of Alpha Epsilon Phi. During the War she served on the Home Front, spotting planes and volunteering for the USO. She never stopped giving: to her family, friends and to the community. She was a writer, poet, journalist and community leader. Elsa served as President of the Cornwell Avenue PTA and the Council of PTAs for West Hempstead School District 27, and was President of the Sisterhood of the Malverne Jewish Center, which she helped found. She wrote and directed school and temple musical productions. She loved dance, music, theatre and traveling the world. A passionate tennis and ping pong player, she was amazed at the wonders of nature and had a lifelong zest for learning. She never peeled an orange without thinking "at this moment this orange has never seen the light of day." Her positive energy, optimism and integrity inspired us all. Her nest was never empty. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center, Columbia University Medical Center, 1150 St. Nicholas Avenue, New York, New York 10032 Attention: Steve Bennett. Memorial Service Thursday, March 26, 10am, Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83 Street.

I ALWAYS laugh when people think being an athlete is glamorous. If they only knew. For some highly ranked players on the Association of Tennis Professionals World Tour, it can be really lucrative and come with all of the perks that you can imagine, including flying in private jets or first class.

Images of the Lofoten Islands, whose towering mountains, rustic villages and craggy seascapes make for one of Norway's most scenic regions. The remote archipelago, located off the country's northern coast just above the Arctic Circle, has been home to fishermen since at least the 12th century. Visitors can rent rustic cabins called rorbuer, left, which were originally built for fishermen. nytimes.com/travel

HARRISON--Jeanne, died on March 21, 2009 at home in New York City. Ms. Harrison pioneered her way into show business at an early age delivering over seven thousand classic radio shows such as "Boston Blackie", "Cisco Kid" and "Philo Vance". Jeanne then moved on to television and was the first woman to direct and produce a network television program "Yesterday's Newsreel" for NBC during her time with the Ziv Company. Moving to advertising in the mid-60s, Ms. Harrison was Senior Vice President and Executive Producer for J. Walter Thompson and SVP/Creative Director for American Cynamid and American Home Products. She then established her own production company, directing for a host of clients from Anacin and Bloomingdales to Union Carbide, Robitussin and hundreds more. Her work has received such major awards as the Clio, the Monitor and the Peabody. She was a member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, The Director's Guild, and she was one of the first women admitted to the Friars' Club. She leaves two daughters, Liza Leeds and Lydia Leeds. Funeral Service today March 24, at 1:15pm, Riverside Memorial, 180 West 76th St.

HOWARD--Sylvan, passed away in Cleveland, OH on March 22, 2009. Devoted mother of Mark of Cleveland, OH; cherished grandmother of Michael, Halle and Amanda; dear sister of Benny Steck, Irene Pector, Leonard Steck and the following deceased Eddie and Joe Steck. Services will be held Tuesday March 24, 2009 at 1pm at Wellwood Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY. Services by Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer 718-263-7602.

-- For much of the last 90 years, Kettering University honed its reputation as the West Point of the automobile industry, offering valuable work experience for its students at car companies and parts suppliers, and then virtually assuring them lucrative jobs upon graduation.

Derek Jeter was the face and, very often, the voice of the United States team in the World Baseball Classic. When the event was promoted in December during the winter meetings in Las Vegas, Jeter was the only player there. Tournament organizers figured Jeter's star power was enough advertising. Several marquee players bypassed the tournament for reasons big and small, but Jeter participated in his second straight Classic. He understood that he is one of the most popular American players, and believed that it was crucial for him to represent the red, white and blue.
PATTEN--Moultrie. Actor and Jazz musician died March 18. Services in care of Ross Hollywood Chapel of Portland, Oregon.

To the Editor: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention calls for antibiotics and condoms to halt the rise in sexually transmitted diseases among teenagers (Vital Statistics, March 17). I have another suggestion.

A 33-foot-high ceiling at a chemical storage building in southwestern China collapsed Monday, killing at least 11 workers, according to Xinhua, the state-run news agency. Tang Zongwei, governor of the Fuling District, where the building, the Jianfeng Chemical Plant, is located, said the accident occurred in an area under construction.

Two of the world's largest cellphone operators, the Spanish company Telefónica and the British giant Vodafone, said Monday that they would share infrastructure in several European markets in an effort to cut costs and protect profit margins. The companies said in a statement that they had agreed to share networks in Britain, Germany, Ireland and Spain, and were in ''detailed discussions'' about doing so in the Czech Republic. In practice, the agreement means the companies will jointly build sites or consolidate existing antenna towers and infrastructure for second- and third-generation networks, reducing the total number of cellphone towers in operation and cutting the amount they pay to rent equipment.

8 P.M. (CW) REAPER It turns out that the Devil (Ray Wise, above center, with Armie Hammer, left, and Bret Harrison) has another son, Morgan (Mr. Hammer), and wants Sam (Mr. Harrison) to teach him the ropes of the soul-capturing business. (Morgan may seem perfect -- tall, charming and rich -- but his work ethic is lacking.) Meanwhile, Sock (Tyler Labine) uses his boss, Ted (Donovan Stinson), in the latest workplace plot, and Ben (Rick Gonzalez) thinks that his human form horrifies his demon girlfriend, Nina (Jenny Wade). 7 P.M. (Showtime) A MIGHTY HEART (2007) Angelina Jolie, left, stars as Mariane Pearl in this drama, directed by Michael Winterbottom, about the kidnapping of the Wall Street Journal reporter Daniel Pearl (Dan Futterman) in Pakistan in 2002. In her review in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis wrote, '' 'A Mighty Heart' is effectively fashioned, as jolting as it is polished, as well as a surprising, insistently political work of commercial art.''

Leon Botstein's programs with the American Symphony Orchestra are built around a single question, asked either explicitly (in Mr. Botstein's program notes) or implicitly: why aren't these composers (or works) better known? At the orchestra's Sunday afternoon concert at Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Botstein asked that question explicitly about William Grant Still (1895-1978). Still is not really as obscure as Mr. Botstein makes him out to be. Though he was by no means the first African-American composer to make his way in classical music (Scott Joplin was writing operas when Still was a child), most reference works name him as the first to have a symphony performed by a major American orchestra, and the first to have an opera staged by a major American company.

The last time anyone saw Michelle Valdez, she was working the streets of the War Zone, a neighborhood of housing projects, heroin and sex shops near the University of New Mexico. It was 2004, and like a growing number of young prostitutes here, Ms. Valdez, a 22-year-old mother of two, had vanished one day. Save for the close-knit group of women she hustled with, and the parents who had lost her to the streets, Ms. Valdez's disappearance went virtually unnoticed.

An article in some editions on Friday about a warning by the city's commissioner of investigation that budget cuts at the Department of Investigation would hamper its anticorruption work misstated the size of the agency's current budget and its size under planned reductions. The current budget is $21.2 million, not billion, and the proposed is $19.3 million, not billion.

FLEISCHMANN--David J.,world peace advocate, educator, editor, artist and avid traveler, died March 20, 2009, at age 68. A 31-year editing career encompassed publications such as Forbes, Newsweek and Reader's Digest Travel Guide USA. In the 1960s coordinated education program of Citizen Exchange Corps, an East-West Exchange arranging visits between US and USSR private citizens. Chaired Social Studies Department and taught history at high school for gifted underachievers in 1970s. Alumnus of New York University and Bronx High School of Science. Survived by wife Elena; nieces Sharon, Julie and Melanie; nephew Mark; cousins Relly Liebowitz and Edward Vernoff. Memorial service Wednesday, 2pm March 25th, at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donation preferences and memorial website: www.davidfleischmann.com

MARKS--Lowell R. Born August 2, 1938, in Brooklyn, New York and died March 21, 2009 in Los Angeles. Lowell is survived by his beloved spouse, Javier Abadia, his partner for the last 12 years. He is also survived by his former wife and dear friend, Carolyn Shadduck, two daughters, Melissa Cavanaugh and Amy McKenzie, sons-in-law Jeff and Dennis, and four grandchildren Kristi, Sarah, Ryan, and Megan, as well as his brother Malvin, sister-in-law Joan, nieces Janet Marks and Kathleen Reich, and nephews Andy Marks and David Reich.

Hotel spas have long been a haven of calm for business travelers seeking to get the kinks out of their backs after a long flight or to unwind before a big meeting. But as the economic downturn hurts the hotel business, the spas are dealing with their own stresses. According to PKF Consulting, spa revenue rose 5 percent from 2006 to 2007, largely because of higher charges for treatments. But since last fall, hotel spas have been dealing with both reduced occupancy and guests who have sharply curbed their discretionary spending.

Basketball coaches diagram plays and demand that they be run with precision. More than ever, that includes the action when the game stops. The timeout may be the most orchestrated part of a college basketball game, the element that the coach can truly control -- and does. Coaches are pushing their timeout huddles farther onto the court and unveiling a growing array of formations.

Like a slide show at a family reunion, the faces and the memories flickered by, each image a reminder of what the Knicks once were, and what they have long been missing. Dick McGuire strode across the Madison Square Garden floor, followed by Richie Guerin, Willis Reed, Walt Frazier, Bernard King and Patrick Ewing. They stood alongside Susan Braun, the daughter of Carl Braun, the franchise's first star.

The recession could give new life to co-operative education, programs that combine college classes with jobs in related fields that have been around for more than a century. Cautious employers ''increasingly see that hiring a co-op graduate is a good strategy, since they know they are getting someone with experience,'' said Paul Stonely, president of the National Commission for Cooperative Education, a trade organization based in Boston.

VALLADARES--Jorge J.,of Scarsdale, New York passed away on March 21, 2009, after suffering a heart attack at home. Born on February 3, 1940 in Havana, Cuba, Mr. Valladares was exiled with his family to the United States where he became a U.S. citizen and then graduated from the University of Oklahoma in 1969. He built a successful career as the founder and manager of several international oil distribution and trading companies. He is survived by his beloved wife of forty years, Dr. Rosario Hiriart Valladares, his three brothers, two sisters and their children. He is also survived by his wife's sister and brother and their children. Services are being handled by the Caballero Rivero Woodlawn Funeral Home at 8200 Bird Road, Miami, Florida 33155. Services will be held at St. Timothy's Catholic Church in Miami on Thursday, March, 26th. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial donations be made to the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center at the University of Miami, Florida.

After years of coasting on high commodity prices, the Russian government is now acknowledging it will need to get by on a much diminished revenue stream for the foreseeable future. At the same time, economic policy officials here are striking an upbeat note, saying declining oil income is likely to spur growth in other areas of the economy.

At the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine on Monday, two Easter tapestries made in the mid-1600s, ''The Crucifixion'' and ''Agony in the Garden,'' above, were hung for the first time since a 2001 fire in the cathedral. An article and more photographs are at nytimes.com/cityroom.

A senior Palestinian official was killed Monday along with two colleagues and a driver when a roadside bomb detonated next to their convoy as they left a Palestinian refugee camp in southern Lebanon, security officials said. The Palestinian official, Kamal Midhat, was the deputy leader in Lebanon of Fatah, the mainstream faction led by Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president. Three bodyguards were wounded in the blast.

Georgian authorities on Monday arrested nine members of an opposition party on weapons charges, as tensions mounted ahead of April protests that will call for President Mikheil Saakashvili to step down. Shota Utiashvili, a spokesman for Georgia's Interior Ministry, said 10 people had been arrested. He showed surveillance video of five men buying automatic weapons and discussing future arms purchases, saying the suspects were ''different people from different groups.''

Doctors and researchers regularly rely on CT scanners to create images of body parts like brains, chests and knees. But an artist-turned-medical-student in Manhattan is using one such machine to peer into the meat and guts of cultural icons like the Big Mac, the Barbie and the iPhone, creating whimsical and occasionally creepy images. Satre Stuelke, 44, said his aim was to penetrate the metal, plastic or organic interiors of pop objects and foods, asking people to ''think about how things are constructed.''

The Guinean musician Sidiki Conde is paralyzed from the waist down. But that doesn't stop Mr. Conde, who performed on Friday night at Symphony Space with his ensemble, Tokounou, from dancing. His legs tucked up neatly at his sides, knees almost into armpits, he bounces on his hands across the stage, stands on them as he turns upside down and shakes his pelvis side to side with a beaming enthusiasm that is a reproach to more curmudgeonly souls. ''You must enjoy life,'' Mr. Conde said frequently throughout the evening, which began as he beat out intricate rhythms on the krin, a loglike slit drum played with sticks. ''This is all you have. Be happy. Thank you for listening to this song.''

National Football League owners could vote in May on plans to lengthen the regular season to 17 or 18 games. The longer regular season, however, is unlikely to begin any earlier than 2011, Commissioner Roger Goodell said Monday at the N.F.L.'s annual meeting. Adding at least one regular-season game while reducing the preseason schedule is a critical component of what Goodell called ''increasing value'' -- the league's attempt to find new revenue while remaining attractive to fans in the challenging economic climate. There is almost no chance that the regular season will remain at 16 games.

DirecTV renewed its deal as the N.F.L.'s exclusive satellite carrier Monday and will continue to offer the Sunday Ticket package of out-of-market afternoon games from 2011 to 2014. The deal will cost DirecTv $1 billion a year, a leap from the $700 million it pays annually. The new agreement will offer features that fans without DirecTV have long wanted: access to the games shown exclusively on Sunday Ticket since 1994.

A strike by Petrobras workers cut output at refineries in Brazil and also temporarily halted crude production of 60,000 barrels a day and 1.4 million cubic meters of natural gas, union officials said. The walkout over profit-sharing and safety issues may force the company to cut output from about 40 percent of the Campos Basin, Brazil's main producing region, as well as fields in Brazil's northeast and Amazon regions, said Marluzio Ferreira, spokesman for the national oil workers federation. Work was also disrupted at 11 refineries, he said. The union says Petrobras has refused requests to improve safety measures, and that 165 employees have been killed since 2002. The union also says the company has sought to cut revenue and profit sharing. Petrobras, which is adding workers, is aiming to reduce costs as oil prices fall and it embarks on a $174.4 billion five-year investment plan. Petrobras said in a statement on its Web site that all its units were operating normally during the strike.

Warner Brothers has introduced a new DVD-on-demand offering for fans of niche vintage films. At WarnerArchive.com, the studio is now selling about 150 of the more obscure and offbeat movies from its library, and they can be ordered directly for $19.95 each. ''Many of these films I do not believe would have had a home at retail, due to their narrow appeal,'' said George Feltenstein, Warner's senior vice president for theatrical catalog marketing. They include, for instance, ''The Man Who Loved Cat Dancing'' (1973), starring Burt Reynolds. Others are Joan Crawford vehicles (''When Ladies Meet,'' 1941), westerns (''Wichita,'' 1955) and silent films (''The Kiss,'' 1929, starring Greta Garbo). Television shows are to be added soon.

This time President Obama directed some of the stagecraft. This time Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner fleshed out the substance of their long-anticipated program to remove banks' toxic assets and revive the financial system. And this time the reaction was widely positive, giving the embattled Mr. Geithner a critically needed boost. Mr. Geithner had a lot on the line in Monday's announcement, despite Mr. Obama's repeated insistence that his job was safe. The Treasury secretary's highly publicized unveiling six weeks ago of his plan's ''framework'' had been panned for lacking details, hobbling Mr. Geithner as he was trying to build credibility with the financial markets and clout in Washington.

BUCHTHAL--Fred, 92, passed away March 20, 2009. Born December 21, 1916 in Berlin, Germany. He was a resident of Teaneck, NJ. Fred came to America from Nazi-occupied Germany in 1936 and joined the US Army to fight Hitler. He served with the 5th Tank Division during the WWII. He was a life master bridge player and an avid chess player. Fred was a long-standing member of the National Council of Jewish Women's Swim In to aid MS patients and Meals on Wheels. Fred has left this Earth a better place. He relentlessly supported the underdog, and often provided help for the unfortunate individuals who didn't have the same human rights and opportunities. He helped to publish Spartacus, when the author was blacklisted and he supported Paul Robeson's efforts with the Progressive Party in 1948. Husband to the late Esther (Goldman). Father to Ronald and (wife) Susan, Stanley and (wife) Maja, and Larry. Grandfather to David and (wife) Mary, Caryn and (husband) John, Lucas, Marina, and Anna. Brother to Claes, 96 and Chaim Tal, 90.

An article on Friday about the first phase of a federal program intended to help revive lending to consumers and businesses misstated the share of financing that will be supplied by the Treasury Department. It will provide the first 10 percent of the money lent in the program -- not the first 20 percent. (The rest of the money for the program, known as TALF, will come from the Federal Reserve.)

The Public Theater has postponed the first preview and opening night of its production of Craig Lucas's play ''The Singing Forest.'' In a news release the Public said that the play, about an Austrian-born Holocaust survivor turned psychoanalyst and her coterie of patients, had been delayed because of ''the need for additional technical rehearsals.'' The first preview has been rescheduled to April 10 from April 7, and opening night is set for April 28 instead of April 27. The cast includes Olympia Dukakis, Jonathan Groff and Randy Harrison, and the play is directed by Mark Wing-Davey.

Though Comedy Central may be most closely identified with caustic topical comedians like Jon Stewart andStephen Colbert, as well as foul-mouthed (if hilarious) animated series like ''South Park,'' the cable channel has signed a development deal with the ventriloquist Jeff Dunham, above, who starred in the most-watched show in its history, Variety reported. The debut of ''Jeff Dunham's Very Special Christmas Special'' drew 6.6 million viewers in November, and a DVD release sold more than 400,000 copies. Mr. Dunham's live tour, featuring puppets like Melvin the Superhero Guy and Achmed the Dead Terrorist, grossed $19.2 million last year. Mr. Dunham's deal with Comedy Central includes a six-episode series planned for 2010, as well as a stand-up special and a new DVD.
GENDLER--Paul. 12/23/25 -3/24/05. Dad - not a day goes by when I don't need your advice or want to share something with you. I miss you so. Ellen

Sales of previously owned homes in the United States showed unexpected strength in February, offering a glimmer that the tumbling housing market may be searching for a bottom even as economists brace for another wave of foreclosures driven by rising job losses. The National Association of Realtors reported on Monday that sales of existing homes rose 5.1 percent in February after a 5 percent decline in January. Home sales in the Northeast, South, West and Midwest all gained ground for February as buyers scooped up foreclosure properties.

Last week, two major studies from the United States and Europe found that P.S.A. testing -- the annual blood test used to screen men for prostate cancer -- saves few if any lives, while exposing patients to aggressive and unnecessary treatments that can leave them impotent and incontinent. The news was unsettling and confusing to many middle-age men, particularly those who already have diagnoses of prostate cancer as a result of P.S.A. testing. Doctors say some men are reconsidering surgery or radiation treatment they have planned. Others, convinced that their lives were saved by P.S.A. screening, wonder how anyone could question the value of early detection of prostate cancer.

Ten years ago Judith Owen seemed on the verge of becoming the next in a singer-songwriter lineage that runs from Joni Mitchell through Annie Lennox. Ms. Owen, who is 42 and of Welsh ancestry, had just completed her major-label debut for Java Records, a Capitol subsidiary run by Glen Ballard, the songwriting producer of Alanis Morissette's 1995 blockbuster, ''Jagged Little Pill.'' The machinery was in gear for a major promotional campaign. Then the roof collapsed. In a change of management, Capitol severed its ties with Java and left Ms. Owen's album, then titled ''Creatures of Habit,'' in limbo. Instead of flying into a rage, Ms. Owen, who has waged a lifelong struggle with depression, blamed herself.

CONWAY--Joseph P.,of East Orleans, Massachusetts, on March 22, 2009. Beloved husband of Mary Louise. Loving father of son John Conway and daughters Elizabeth West, Anne Gamble and Ellen Macleish. Grandfather of Abigail, William and Thomas Conway, Angus and Camilla West, John, Alex and Lucy Gamble, Ramsey, Cameron and Sionna Macleish. Mr. Conway was a law partner at Cahill, Gordon & Reindel and played an integral role in the expansion in the 1980s of Cahill's corporate and securities practice. He graduated from Manhattan College and Columbia Law School and served as an officer in the United States Navy with tours of duty on the aircraft carrier USS Yorktown. Relatives and friends may call on Thursday morning from 10:30 to 11:30 at the Cody-White Funeral Home, 107 Broad Street, Milford, Connecticut and are then invited to attend a Mass of Christian Burial at Holy Infant Church, 450 Racebrook Road, Orange, Connecticut at 12:00. Contributions in his name may be made to the Robert J. Christen History Lecture Fund at Manhattan College.

Six years after the idea was hatched, India's much-hyped Tata Nano was introduced on Monday. The supercheap compact car with a base model selling for about $2,230 is aimed at the developing world's millions of motorcycle owners with four-wheel dreams. It arrives as Tata Motors struggles with production problems and a huge debt load.

not that there is much -- seems to come with an asterisk. The market is popping, but, as some bears ask, is it just a setup for another bigger fall? So here's something else to ponder: Goldman Sachs is planning to give back its TARP money soon. Very soon, actually -- ideally within the next month, according to people involved in the process. That's a much quicker timetable than the end-of-year goal previously set out by Lloyd C. Blankfein, Goldman Sachs's chief executive. As taxpayers, we should be thrilled that Goldman is going to quickly pay back the $10 billion it was given last October, right?

Most of the Mets took Monday off, but not pitcher John Maine, a critical component of their starting rotation. The pitching coach, Dan Warthen, asked Maine to work a bullpen session and Maine agreed. ''I haven't pitched stellar by any means,'' Maine said. ''Everything was out of whack.''

Facing a $62 million budget shortfall and the impending layoffs of 557 employees, the commissioner of the city's Administration for Children's Services vowed on Monday not to let caseloads rise above an average of 12 per caseworker, saying that would be unacceptably high. ''If that should happen, and we can't keep the caseload at 12, we will indeed have to seek additional staff,'' the commissioner, John B. Mattingly, said at a preliminary budget hearing of the City Council's welfare committee. He said he had received a ''very clear commitment'' from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the Office of Management and Budget ''that we will keep ahead of the caseload demands,'' adding, ''That has not changed.''
All is well in candy land. JAMIE HALLMAN, owner of a candy store in San Francisco. on an increase in sales during the economic downturn. [A22]

SERVODIDIO--Monsignor John T. Pastor and Director of Catholic Charities, passed away on March 22, 2009, after serving for 55 years as a Roman Catholic Priest. Viewing will take place at St. Joseph's Church, 171 St. Mary's Avenue, Staten Island, on Tuesday, March 24, 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm, and Wednesday, March 25, in the afternoon from 2 to 7pm, followed by a Mass of Christian burial at 7:30pm. The funeral mass, celebrated by Cardinal Egan, will be held at St Joseph's Church on Thursday at 10:30am followed by interment at Holy Mount Cemetery, located on California Road, Eastchester, NY. A memorial mass will be held at the Church of the Assumption, 100 Pleasant Avenue, Tuckahoe, on Saturday, March 28, at 9:30am. Donations in his name should be made to St. Joseph Church and School, 171 St. Mary's Avenue, Staten Island, New York 10305.

Even now, well before hurricane season, Jean Hubert tries to tamp down the panic that wells up in his chest whenever dark clouds mass overhead. His unease multiplies if even stray raindrops splatter through his corrugated roof. Its seemingly robust support boards snapped like matchsticks in the cascading floodwaters last year, puncturing random holes in the flimsy tin.
To the Editor: Re ''Stadium Is Citi Field, but the Subway Stop Has Other Ideas'' (news article, March 12):

ROBERT C. BYRD, the Democratic senator from West Virginia, chastised the Obama administration last month for using White House policy czars to undermine the president's own cabinet. ''At the worst,'' he wrote to President Obama, ''White House staff have taken direction and control of programmatic areas that are the statutory responsibility of Senate-confirmed officials.'' Mr. Byrd is right to question the proliferation of policy czars -- after all, President Obama inherited a half-dozen czar positions from previous administrations and has already added more of his own, including czars for health, urban affairs and ''green jobs.'' But czars are rarely the fearsome giants of interference that concern Mr. Byrd. Most have more stalemates than successes, hardly ever receive the presidential attention they were promised and often quit in frustration.

President Obama's long-awaited plan to revive the banks could work if certain assumptions about the future are right. But there is not much, beyond faith, to believe those assumptions will pan out -- and even if there were, it is hard to see how the plan is the best way to go. In the near term, the plan would provide financing to buy $500 billion of banks' bad assets -- and possibly up to $1 trillion over time. Most of the financing would be in the form of low-cost government loans and loan guarantees for private investors who buy the troubled assets.
TANCER--Michael. Five years have passed, but our loving thoughts of you are with us always. Your Family

Five minutes into each performance of ''Zing Zang Zoom,'' the new magical menagerie from the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, an 8,500-pound elephant named Asia seems to vanish abruptly in a grand illusion. Is it possible this disappearing act presages the future of the circus itself? The down economy has taken its toll on working-class families, the traditional core audience of Ringling, a show-business perennial that offended circus purists by abandoning its classic three rings three years ago. And competitors, both nouveau and non, have proliferated, from Cirque du Soleil to New York's Big Apple Circus.

''That was so New York,'' said an audience member as Sally Silvers's new ''Yessified!'' ended on Sunday night at Performance Space 122, where Ms. Silvers has been performing for an impressive 29 years. And it's true: Ms. Silvers is a certain kind of intrepid New York artist, an unrepentant experimentalist who has had a long and lauded career without ever becoming a known name outside the contemporary-dance world. ''Yessified!,'' Ms. Silvers's first big group work since 2005, is entirely puzzling. And entirely delightful, partly for that reason. As the nine dancers (including Ms. Silvers) endlessly enter and exit, forming and re-forming groups that perform strange, truncated gestures and bendy, bouncy little steps, it's interesting to contemplate why some artists are able to leave you feeling fine -- even exhilarated -- by the realization that you have absolutely no idea what's going on.

IT is rare that media buyers form a consensus on anything, but in the case of the neophyte Major League Baseball Network, which had its premiere in January, they seem to agree that they like its chances of becoming a successful player in the television sports marketplace. Executives at the network, two-thirds owned by Major League Baseball and one-third owned by a group of cable and satellite operators, said that it was on target to meet its first-quarter ad revenue projections, with major advertisers like Sprint, I.B.M., Kraft, Domino's Pizza, Geico, Progressive, Sony PlayStation, 2K Sports and Viagra, among others, already on the air. And none of them are among the 18 official M.L.B. sponsors, who, at some point this year, also are expected to jump in with varying amounts of advertising-dollar support.

Southern California Coach Tim Floyd seemed drained, as if someone had pumped all the blood out of him. For the third time in three years, the 6-foot-9 forward Taj Gibson had fouled out of the game that eliminated the Trojans from the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament. And this might have been the worst one of all.

About three decades ago at a scientific conference on aging, just about every presenter was taking vitamin E, a nutrient with antioxidant properties that, it was thought, would slow the cellular ravages of age. In subsequent years, many reports from observational and case studies suggested that vitamin E in daily doses far greater than recommended could help to stave off heart disease and stroke, various common cancers, dementia and Alzheimer's disease, cataracts and macular degeneration, respiratory tract infections and a host of other serious and sometimes fatal health problems.

As David Myers scans the rocky slopes of this desert canyon, looking vainly past clumps of brittlebush for bighorn sheep, he imagines an enemy advancing across the crags. That specter is of an army of mirrors, generators and transmission towers transforming Mojave Desert vistas like this one. While Whitewater Canyon is privately owned and protected, others that Mr. Myers, as head of the Wildlands Conservancy, has fought to preserve are not.

SMITH--Barbara Roberts, 84, born in New York City died at her residence in Syracuse, NY, Sunday, March 22, 2009. Mrs. Smith was predeceased by her husbands Mort Roberts and Irving Smith. Survived by her sons, Philip and Edward Roberts.
To the Editor: Re ''Blacks Suffer Heart Failure More Than Whites, Study Finds'' (news article, March 19):
Sweating a Test At Wells Fargo

SHORE--Marcel, of New York City and Lake Worth, Florida died at the age of 88 on March 21st. Beloved husband, father and grandfather, Marcel was born on September 15th, 1920 in Romania, and was raised in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. After service in World War II, Marcel married Ann Kaufman, his loving wife of 64 years. He worked in various manufacturing firms and also taught citizenship to immigrants. In the 1970s, he entered the real estate market in Manhattan. His success enabled him to pursue his passion for world travel, and he and Ann made dozens of trips over the years. Other survivors include two sons, Alan of Bellingham, Washington and Daniel of Santa Cruz, California, daughters-in-law Kirsten and Miriam and two grandchildren, Karina and Jonathan.

HAUBEN--Andrea. The Officers, Board of Governors, and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of Andrea Hauben, daughter of our members, Vicki and Ron, and extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Neda S. Birbrower, Pres. Ronald M. Stuart, Sec.

GRIGORIOU-THEOCARAKIS--Catherine, 49, passed away on March 17 in Athens, Greece after a long battle with cancer. A New York based poet, Catherine is survived by her husband Nicholas Theocarakis, her mother Evangelia and her brother Stelios Grigoriou. She will be dearly missed by her family and friends. Funeral services will be held in Greece.
To the Editor: Re ''Has a 'Katrina Moment' Arrived?,'' by Frank Rich, and ''Toxic R Us,'' by Maureen Dowd (columns, March 22):

WILSON--Linda B. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of Linda Babcock Wilson, wife of Kendrick R. Wilson III, longtime member of our Board of Trustees and Co-Chair of the Development Committee. An artist and painter, Linda was active in their community of Bedford where she had been on the board of the Bedford Historical Society and the Historic District Review Commission. Anchors in the conservation community of the Paradise Valley in Montana where Ken and Linda spent time on their ranch along Eightmile Creek, they were recognized in 2003 as Conservationists of the Year by the Montana Land Reliance. The Wilsons made their ranch a model of protecting open space, range and riparian areas. We extend our deepest condolences to their children Jane D. Hall, Olivia W. Thompson and Kendrick R. Wilson IV, to Linda's sister Jody Wilmerding, brothers John and Frederick, and to all their family. Dean R. O'Hare Aldo Papone Co-Chairs, Board of Trustees Thomas P. Sculco, M.D. Chief Medical Officer Louis A. Shapiro President and CEO Hospital for Special Surgery
TRAINING A LENS On Broadway

It was inconsequential to the outcome of the game, but Jamelle Horne's ''missed'' dunk in Arizona's 84-71 victory over Utah on Friday night in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament was interesting for a couple of reasons, not all having to do with physics. It's not every day that you see a dunk go through the rim but not all the way through the basket. The officials alertly did not count it as a field goal, and the ball remained live.

South Africa has barred the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader and a Nobel Peace Prize winner, from attending a peace conference here this week that is supposed to promote the 2010 World Cup and the potential of sport to unite people across races and nations. The government said Monday that the Dalai Lama's presence at the conference would have distracted the world's attention from South Africa's hosting of the World Cup and drawn it instead into the fraught relations between the Dalai Lama and China, one of the country's most important trading partners. Thabo Masebe, a government spokesman, said the Tibetan leader's presence ''would not be in South Africa's best interests.''

GONSHER--Bernard, 83, died March 21, 2009. Adored husband of Nora (predeceased), daddy of Barbara, Wendy and Debra. Honey of Kenny and Cory. Great-grandfather of Naizha, Levi, Marco, Dean. My pa's the finest friend I ever knew, I only wish that you could know him too.

FEURMAN--Charles. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Charles Feurman, beloved father of Fran Szczesny. Fran, past president of Manhattan Women's Philanthropy and a leader on several commissions, is devoted to social and humanitarian causes that strengthen the New York Jewish community. We extend our condolences to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

To the Editor: Re ''No Single Path for Cancer Care in the Elderly'' (Personal Health, March 17): As a longtime oncologist and hospice physician, I believe there is another way through the thicket of decisions that confront older patients with cancer -- the ''goals of care'' conversation.

Ali Saleh Kahlah al-Marri, accused by the government of being a sleeper agent for Al Qaeda and held as an enemy combatant for almost six years, made his first appearance Monday afternoon in the courtroom where he will be tried on charges of providing aid to terrorists. He entered a plea of not guilty. The trial, made necessary when the Obama administration switched the case from the military to the civilian legal system in February, should be completed by the end of the year, said Judge Michael M. Mihm of Federal District Court. Judge Mihm questioned Mr. Marri at the 30-minute hearing to ensure that he understood the charges and scheduled further hearings with Mr. Marri's lawyers and those for the government.

Raymond Schneider politely elbowed his way through crowds of customers as he made for the bulk candy bins at Dylan's Candy Bar across from Bloomingdale's in Manhattan. Since he was laid off in December, Mr. Schneider, a 33-year-old interior designer, says he has become a ''gummy junkie,'' stocking up on sweets every time he shops for groceries. ''Sugar is comforting,'' he said as he scooped Red Licorice Scottie Dogs into a plastic bag. ''There's nothing more stressful than growing financial insecurity everywhere.''

WOLFF--Louis. The members and staff of Kleinberg, Kaplan, Wolff & Cohen, P.C. offer our sincerest condolences to the family of our partner and friend, Norris Wolff, on the passing of his father, Louis Wolff. Our thoughts are with Norris, his wife Judy, his mother Molly, his children Jonathan and Erica, his sister Sharon Mann and her family, his brother Ira Wolff and his family, and all of Louis's family and friends.

Daily newspapers will become a thing of the past for readers in four Michigan markets, with issues being printed only three days a week in Flint, Saginaw and Bay City, and twice weekly in Ann Arbor. Advance Publications said it would close the 174-year-old Ann Arbor News in late July, and replace it with two new corporate entities: a primarily Web-based news operation, AnnArbor.com; and a printing company that will publish two days a week. All 272 employees at The News, which has weekday circulation of 45,000, will be laid off and invited to apply for jobs at the two new companies. Their staff size has not been determined, but ''there will be by far fewer positions,'' said Laurel Champion, publisher of The Ann Arbor News.

A New Jersey congressman asked the Treasury Department on Monday step in to end the Nets' $400-million deal with Barclays Bank, which would put the British company's name on the team's proposed Brooklyn arena, because it indirectly received federal bailout funds. In a letter to Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner, Rep. Bill Pascrell Jr., a Democrat, said that ''it is appropriate for the U.S. to request that Barclays cancel this naming-rights agreement'' because A.I.G. paid the bank $8.5 billion out of the $170 billion the insurance giant has received in taxpayer assistance to prevent its collapse.

Each name, slightly more than one-and-a-half inches tall, will carry the most intimate memories. All 2,982 names together, arrayed atop parapets stretching more than 1,500 feet around two great pools, will convey the vastness of the loss. With such a range of scale and so many emotions attached, it is no wonder that one of the simplest architectural details of the new World Trade Center -- the parapets around the memorial pools -- has taken so long to design.

The Oakland police announced late Monday that they had made a tentative DNA match connecting the gunman in a deadly shootout with police officers on Saturday with an unsolved sexual assault last month. The match needs to be confirmed with additional testing, officials said, but the announcement seemed to be offered as a possible motive from the police for why the gunman, Lovelle Mixon, a 26-year-old parolee, might have chosen to shoot at the officers, rather than surrender.

HAMBURGER--Robert, 94, died peacefully on March 21. His memory is cherished by Mary Jo, his wife of 68 years; his sons Robert Jr. and Peter; his daughters-in-law Ilene and Joy; his grandchildren Zoe, Max, and David; his step-granddaughter Kiara Berglund; and by Morena Garcia, a dear family friend. Along with the close circle of his family and personal friends, his memory will be treasured by the many people who were thankful to have known him and to have experienced his generosity of spirit, his humor, his good sense, his elegance, and his love of life. All of us will miss him greatly--he leaves a great void in our hearts--but we will always be grateful that he was blessed with a long and healthy life, and that we were privileged to share a portion of it with him. Contributions in his memory can be sent to Hospice of Palm Beach, Jupiter Medical Center, or The Diabetes Association.

''Apollo Theater, make some noise in this room,'' Byron Cage commanded midway through his performance in ''A Celebration of the Spiritual and Gospel Music'' on Sunday afternoon. Under ordinary circumstances, you suspect, Mr. Cage, a handsome, charismatic gospel singer from Atlanta, would hardly need to urge participation. But the concert, jointly presented by Carnegie Hall and the Apollo in Harlem, was hardly ordinary. Part of the soprano Jessye Norman's Honor! series, the event was meant to provide a concise overview of African-American religious music, from the slave-era spiritual to modern gospel styles. A sense of formal occasion might have kept most of a large, appreciative audience from doing what otherwise might have come naturally.

Where you might have least expected the Harlem rapper Jim Jones to be on Friday night was exactly where he was, yawning and meandering his way through a late-night play rehearsal at Roy Arias Studios & Theaters on the fourth floor of a nondescript building just off Times Square. In a pink plaid shirt and a low-hanging pair of light blue True Religion jeans, he looked a little bit like a bored schoolkid who knows the right answers but doesn't want to repeat them for the hundredth time. Still, he persisted, repeating his lines and hitting his marks, and watching while the rest of the cast smoothed out transitions as musical cues blared from an iPod connected to miniature speakers.

Violence erupted across Iraq on Monday in attacks that left at least 32 people dead and scores wounded, including a suicide bombing at a crowded wake that killed at least 19 mourners. The suicide attack took place just after sunset at a wake for the brother of an official of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan party near Jalawla, a small town in Diyala Province. Mourners had gathered when a man detonated a belt of explosives, sending a powerful blast through the crowd and wounding 39 people, security officials said.

WOLFF--Louis. The board of directors, members, and staff of the Food Allergy Initiative mourn the loss of Louis Wolff, our dear friend and father of our vice chairman and co-founder, Sharyn Mann. Louis was determined to build a healthier future for his beloved granddaughter, and for all children who suffer from life-threatening food allergies. We will remember him always for his commitment to FAI's mission and love for his family. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Molly; to Sharyn and her husband, Steve; to his grandchildren, Tamara and Joseph; and to the entire family. Louis was a remarkable man who will be deeply missed by all who knew him. Todd J. Slotkin, Chairman and President The Food Allergy Initiative

The United States has thrown its support behind the Danish prime minister as the new secretary general of NATO, but it must now try to get Turkey to agree, senior American and European officials said Monday. While most European countries had lined up behind Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen of Denmark, 56, the Obama administration has been quietly recommending the Canadian defense minister, Peter MacKay, 43, in part because of Canada's significant role in Afghanistan.

Staking their claim as the nation’s most prolific composers of punk operas — and really, are there any other competitors? — the members of the band Green Day announced that their follow-up to “American Idiot” would be a rock ‘n’ roll narrative titled “21st Century Breakdown,” to be released by Reprise Records on May 15. In a statement, the group said that the album would tell the story of a young couple as they venture “through the mess and promise of the century so far,” and would be organized in three acts, titled “Heroes and Cons,” “Charlatans and Saints” and “Horseshoes and Handgrenades.” “American Idiot,” released in 2004, sold more than 12 million copies worldwide.

Sales of Kelly Clarkson‘s new album, “All I Ever Wanted” (RCA), dropped 65 percent last week to 90,000, Nielsen SoundScan reported, but that was enough for it to hold at No. 1 on the Billboard chart for a second week. U2 reached second place with 76,000 sales of “No Line on the Horizon” (Interscope) in its third week, and the “Twilight” soundtrack (Atlantic), featuring Linkin Park, Muse and Paramore, jumped 11 spots to No. 3, helped by the DVD release of the film last week. The-Dream‘s “Love vs. Money” (Def Jam) is No. 4 with 56,000 sales, and Lady GaGa’s “Fame” (Interscope) is No. 5 with 50,000. Down the chart, the Atlanta rapper Gorilla Zoe opened at No. 8 with 31,000 sales of “Don’t Feed da Animals” (Bad Boy/Atlantic), and the literary folk-rock band the Decemberists opened at No. 14 with early sales of “The Hazards of Love” (Capitol); although not widely available until this week, the album moved 19,000 copies on iTunes and on vinyl.

SAN FRANCISCO — Satoru Iwata, chief executive of Nintendo, is clearly the most powerful person in the $46 billion global video game business. The company’s flagship hardware products, the Wii and the handheld DS, are each No. 1 in their sectors. (And the company’s flagship software franchises, like Mario and Zelda, are icons.) Nintendo has also played a crucial role in the cultural evolution of video games in recent years. By making games and systems that appeal to an audience far broader than the core young male demographic, Nintendo has become one of the leaders in bringing games into the mainstream.

Don’t let the sunshine in just yet: the Broadway revival of “Hair” has canceled its final preview performance, scheduled for Monday. The cancellation was first reported on Playbill.com, the Web site of Playbill magazine. In a statement, publicists for “Hair” said, “The March 30th preview was canceled to allow the company a day of rest in the midst of a long string of consecutive performances.” The production, which is a transfer of the Public Theater’s “Hair” revival that ran at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park last summer, is scheduled to open at the Al Hirschfeld Theater on Tuesday. Ticketholders for Monday’s preview performance can call Telecharge at (212)239-6200.

It’s paradise lost, all over again: The Off-Broadway run of “The Garden of Earthly Delights” will play its final performance on April 5 at the Minetta Lane Theater. The production, a revival of the director and choreographer Martha Clarke‘s interpretation of the Hieronymus Bosch triptych, had opened in November and was extended twice. Its current extension was scheduled to play through May 31, but its producer, Rhoda Herrick, said in a news release that it was closing earlier because of the downturn in the economy. An international tour of “Garden of Earthly Delights” is planned for the 2009-2010 season.

Updated | 4:40 p.m. Actors’ Equity Association will hold hearings on June 8 and 9 at which an arbitrator will consider the dispute regarding Jeremy Piven‘s departure from the Broadway play “Speed-the-Plow,” the play’s producers said in a news release. The hearings will follow a meeting held on Feb. 26 at which a panel composed of members of Actors’ Equity and the Broadway League, representing the producers, did not penalize Mr. Piven for his abrupt exit from “Speed-the-Plow” in December. At that hearing, Mr. Piven said he was suffering from mercury poisoning, which he attributed to eating fish twice a day for 20 years. In a statement, the producers of “Speed-the-Plow” said that the case would be heard by George Nicolau, and that they had requested “a wide range of relevant information from Mr. Piven,” including “medical records and documentation of Mr. Piven’s activities both during and after the run of the show.” In a statement, a publicist for Mr. Piven said he “is looking forward to testifying in arbitration along with his doctors so that the truth comes out about the very health serious risks caused by mercury exposure.”

The coming Broadway production of “Race,” a new play by David Mamet, has found itself a director who’s well-versed in its author’s verbal flourishes and confrontational staging: David Mamet. The show’s publicists said that Mr. Mamet would direct the new play, about which few other details have been disclosed. No cast or even a plot description has been announced, though it is scheduled to begin previews on Nov. 21 and open on Dec. 10 at a Shubert Theater to be determined. “Race” will mark the Broadway directing debut for Mr. Mamet, who has had many other plays (including “Speed-the-Plow,” “Glengarry Glen Ross” and “American Buffalo”) performed there, and whose directing credits include the films “State and Main” and “The Spanish Prisoner.”

Most comedians spend years on the stand-up circuit in hopes of landing their first television role. But as he’s often done in his career, Ricky Gervais took a slightly different approach. After he and his writing partner Stephen Merchant created the BBC sitcom “The Office” (which Mr. Gervais starred in, and which spawned an American remake on NBC) and the HBO series “Extras” (in which they were both featured), Mr. Gervais then decided it was time to spin one-liners in front of live audiences. Lured by the promises of creative freedom and free glasses of water, he starred in the HBO stand-up special “Ricky Gervais: Out of England,” which will have its DVD release on Tuesday.

The Museum of Modern Art is home to classic works by Cézanne, Van Gogh, Picasso — and, for at least one night, a music video by an indie band from Brooklyn. On Tuesday, the rock duo Department of Eagles (comprised of Fred Nicolaus and Grizzly Bear’s Daniel Rossen) unveiled the video for its song “No One Does It Like You” at MoMA, as part of PopRally, the event series hosted by the museum and P.S.1.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Wednesday morning.

Yale University filed suit Tuesday to assert its ownership of the Vincent Van Gogh painting “The Night Cafe,” and to block the claim of a man who says he is the descendant of a previous owner of the painting, The Associated Press reported. The work, painted by Van Gogh in 1888, has been in the collection of the Yale University Art Gallery since it was donated in 1961 by Stephen Carlton Clark. Mr. Clark was a Yale alumnus who served as chairman of the Museum of Modern Art‘s board and as a director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and who bought the painting in the 1930s. In 1918, the painting belonged to the Russian industrialist Ivan Morozov, whose property was nationalized during the Communist Revolution. In its suit, Yale said it was contacted last year by lawyers for Pierre Konowaloff, who says he is the great-grandson of Mr. Morozov, and is seeking the painting as well as financial compensation.
Physical limitations, intense rehabilitation and an entirely new way of life: six men and women talk about their lives after a spinal cord injury.
Tent cities have sprung up in Sacramento and Fresno, Calif., as more people lose jobs and housing in the economic downturn.
The Picasso biographer discusses several works by the artist featured in a new show at the Gagosian Gallery.
In this New Jersey resort city, plunge pools and flat-screen TVs create calm amid the casinos.

My Thursday column was inspired by my interest in how financial experts could get so many things so wrong. Part of the answer may have to do with research in neuro-economics suggesting that appetites for risk grow until catastrophe happens. (As I've written, this may be a particular problem with male traders, and that's one reason to have a diverse group around to promote risk management.) More recently, I came across the rich research from social psychology suggesting that expertise is typically overrated in any case, and that experts often don't do much better than neophytes. I find Professor Tetlock's work particularly impressive, because it is empirical and rooted in actual forecasts by a broad pool of pundits over a long period of time.
Throughout parts of North Dakota and western Minnesota, residents are bracing for the Red River and Missouri River to spill their banks.
“In the Motherhood,” a new comedy on ABC that was adapted from a series of webisodes, tries to refresh the family sitcom with a jolt of deadpan satire.
We go from yesterday's pseudo-Seuss to a more upscale poet today. The whole Emily Dickinson creation is only six lines long. The first two are in the grid, and it ends like this:
Caffeine is one of the few performance enhancers that are not banned by the World Anti-Doping Agency, and studies have proved that it does work in athletes' favor.

Tens of millions of Americans are enrolled in private employer-sponsored retirement plans -- the great majority of them in 401(k) plans, which long ago replaced traditional pension benefits. These plans are easy to participate in with payroll deduction, and most people -- once signed up -- don't spend much time thinking about the investments they've chosen.

Moody's Investors Service on Wednesday cut the debt ratings of Bank of America and sent its rating of the bank's preferred stock into junk territory, citing an increasing risk that government intervention may be needed to bolster the bank's capital position.
An ensemble from Woodstock N.Y. plays the music of an orchestra that survived the Holocaust by playing for the Nazis.

In late January, some Democrats on Capitol Hill grew concerned that President Obama was planning to use his powerful new political organization - Organizing for America - to pressure even friendly lawmakers into falling in line behind his agenda.
When the Obama administration set out to sweet talk Congressional Democrats into rallying behind the president's budget, it didn't mess around.

Losses in three of their last four games prevented the Cowboys from making the playoffs, but Dallas hopes that addition by subtraction can help propel it back atop the N.F.C. East and into the postseason. One of two teams -- Carolina being the other -- without a first-round pick, the Cowboys will be looking to add depth. Will Terrell Owens's departure force the front office to spend their first pick on a wide receiver?
Add Republican Jim Gibbons of Nevada to the list of governors who has decided to accept the federal unemployment funds available through the $787 billion stimulus package.

John Paynter is coming out of retirement to join the boutique investment bank Greenhill & Company as a senior adviser. Mr. Paynter, the former vice chairman of JPMorgan Cazenove, is well known among institutional investors in Britain and can help Greenhill expand its advisory work there.
Last October, Astronomers spotted an asteroid on a collision course with Earth. They found pieces of it in a Sudan desert, which could tell something about the early solar system.

Drug wars appear to be escalating in Mexico, with violence spilling across the border into the United States. As Mark Landler reported today, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton for the first time acknowledged that Americans' demand for drugs feeds the Mexican drug trade and all its ills.

Intel's chief executive, Paul Otellini, has confirmed what everyone in Silicon Valley suspected: Sun Microsystems -- either whole or in parts -- has been offered for sale to just about any company with a pulse.
A New York law student won a court order to temporarily freeze the assets of Peter B. Madoff, the brother of the jailed swindler Bernard L. Madoff, the student's lawyer said Wednesday.

This is why we love PBS. Because it brings us smart documentaries like "The Powder & The Glory," which recounts the long rivalry between the beauty queens Helena Rubinstein and Elizabeth Arden. (It plays at various times throughout the month of April.) Back around 1910, when these entrepreneurial ladies were first mixing up tinctures in their kitchens, makeup was reserved for prostitutes and performers. In the words of Rubinstein, "all the American women had purple faces and gray lips." Today, of course, it's a $175 billion business.
SOUTH ORANGE -- Police Sgt. Joe Levanda reported several break-ins to cars in the village this week, some during daylight hours.
Oy.
The big iPhone news today is that AT&T is making good on its promise to sell iPhones with no contract required. What has been overlooked is that it is possibly the Worst. Deal. Ever.
Justin Fox asks, Paul Krugman: Smart economist or all-knowing being?

Wrapped in a different way but still enormous, the omnibus lands bill passed the House of Representatives today and should shortly become law. State after state, group after group, have pumped out the releases describing the vast projects that are included in the bill since the House voted 285-140 to pass the legislation.

Don Garber is not worried about the English superclub Chelsea co-opting U.S. soccer fans. A.C. Milan, the Italian team that stole David Beckham's heart, poses no threat. And the Major League Soccer commissioner is perfectly happy to share fans with Inter Milan or Club America.

Sprint has announced the next 10 cities in which it will offer the high-speed 4G network. If it sounds suspiciously like the earlier announcement by Clearwire, there is a good reason. It's the same network.
The Sunday Styles cover last weekend about four screenwriters who call themselves "the Fempire" continues to generate a lot of discussion in movieland.

From supreme to sustainable - how far we've traveled in the two years since Tom Ford gave the keynote address at the IHT Supreme Luxury Conference 2007 in Moscow. Today, on the homepage of the IHT's Web site, Suzy Menkes reports from the IHT Sustainable Luxury Conference 2009 in New Delhi, with video interviews on "green-washing" and material-free living with the likes of Stella McCartney and Viktor & Rolf. One message? Mindless acquisition is looking a lot like yesterday's Birkin. As Dries Van Noten puts it, "Look to the past, but don't be nostalgic."

In "Crisp Analysis With a Big Helping of Onions," Richard Sandomir writes about Bill Raftery, the college basketball phrasemaker and fanalyst, who seems to have elevated his broadcasting game through the years.

The graveyard shift. The lobster shift. Burning the midnight oil. In the city that never sleeps, ways to describe the 24-hour life of New York City abound. But probably no book has ever examined the nature of nighttime work in the city -- and of the often forgotten, faceless people who do it -- in as great depth and descriptive power as "Nightshift NYC," a scholarly but readable book recently published by the University of California Press.

In the Russian K.H.L. semifinals (best of seven), Ak Bars Kazan faced Game 5 of their series with Dinamo Moscow without Frederik Norrena, their No. 1 goalie. Norrena was placed on the injured list prior to the game due to a broken finger, so it was down to 21-year-old Stanislav Galimov to guard the Ak Bars nets:

The rising tide of unemployment that has been sweeping across the country has officially reached the New York suburbs. For the first time in this recession, New Jersey's unemployment rate has surpassed the national rate, the state's Department of Labor and Workforce Development reported Wednesday. New Jersey's jobless rate jumped to 8.2 percent in February, from 7.3 percent in January. The national rate was 8.1 percent in February.There now are more unemployed people in New Jersey -- about 370,000 -- than at any other time since the state began keeping records in 1976, the department's data show. The number of employed residents with jobs -- 4.14 million -- was the fewest since mid-2004.
In an unusual move, the ratings agency Standard & Poor's has weighed in on the proxy contest between the activist investor William A. Ackman and the discount retailer Target.

(Our mutual friends Peter Menzel and Faith d'Aluisio have a wonderful book called "Man Eating Bugs" which covers that subject pretty well. And here's a YouTube video with even more on the subject.)

Spring has (almost) sprung, and designer collaborations are blooming. A.P.C. has collaborated with Liberty Fabrics on an ongoing range -- including this floral shoulder bag perfect for walks in the park -- while Charlotte Ronson brings her girly glamour to JC Penney with her new I Heart Ronson line. (We love this tiered skirt that resembles a rosebud.) And in an unlikely pairing, the French textile designers Paule Marrot Editions have teamed with Nike Sportswear for a pair of slim-fitting sneakers for femme tomboys - the perfect accessory to show off your trunks in a Kate Moss for Topshop liberty print dress.

On Tuesday, the editors of the Room for Debate blog asked four economists if they thought the plan offered by Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner to buy toxic assets would shore up the nation's banking system.

Over the objections of federal prosecutors, control of Bernard L. Madoff's stake in his Mayfair operation in London has been given to the trustee who is already handling the liquidation of his New York brokerage business, Diana B. Henriques of The New York Times reports.
The lineup for this year's PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature was announced today at an event held in the beautiful courtyard of the Instituto Cervantes in New York.
The media -- especially as embodied by Jim Cramer -- has been accused of starting, perpetuating or inflating bubbles. A new study looks at the dotcom bubble of the late 1990s and declares otherwise.
The ABC sitcom, which began life as an online series, has its premiere on March 26.

The Treasury Department said Wednesday that it would send proposals to Congress this week that would allow it to seize troubled nonbank financial companies, one day after Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner called for expanded powers in order to avoid possible future bailouts.

TAMPA, Fla. -- With the big club off Wednesday, Andy Pettitte threw a Class A game at the minor-league complex down the street from Steinbrenner Field. If Pettitte ever pitches there again, he might want to ask his former teammate, Tampa Mmanager Luis Sojo, to pick more reliable fielders.

It's not Macworld or the Electronic Entertainment Expo, but the annual Game Developers Conference in San Francisco attracts a singular audience devoted to the fine arts of fighting, car racing, golf-swinging and puzzle-playing -- all virtual, of course.

Listeners to the Don and Roma morning show on WLS, the powerhouse Chicago talk-radio station, were treated to a guest host with a familiar voice this morning: Rod R. Blagojevich, who was impeached and removed from office as governor of Illinois in January.

Those who have been privately arguing that a shorter Oscar season might punch up the appeal of the Academy Awards just got sucker-punched by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. The group's decision to schedule the 82nd Oscar broadcast on March 7 of next year adds two weeks to the awards season, which already seemed a tad long by the time the ceremony was held on Feb. 22 of this year.

Those of you who remain curious about the truffle dinner at Patricia Wells's kitchen last week -- or those who'd like to see some good pictures of the dinner -- might visit Dorie Greenspan's site to see her latest post.

Is there truly a good reason that the issue of goal celebrations is being debated in parts of the hockey world? That is, beside the fact that Don Cherry cared enough to make it a main point on Coaches' Room Coaches' Corner in recent weeks (video) and some in the media felt compelled to follow -- which may not qualify as a good reason.

When Syracuse won the national title in 2003, fans made up satirical T-Shirts proclaiming the Orange as the Big 12 champions. That's because Syracuse ran through the gamut of top Big 12 teams - Oklahoma State, Oklahoma, Texas and Kansas - to win the program's first national title.

President Obama traveled to the Capitol Wednesday afternoon to rally Democrats to adopt a budget opening the door to his health care, energy and education plans, arguing that his proposals were crucial to restoring the nation's economic health. Carl Hulse and David Herszenhorn have more here.

This week, Simeon Bankoff, the executive director of the Historic Districts Council, will be answering selected readers' questions about community-based preservation efforts of New York City's neighborhoods, from community organizing to seeking landmark designation and rezoning.

The small-plates trend is fine for restaurants. What happens when you want to serve multiple mini-courses at home? The French designer Jean-Marc Gady has a solution. His Gourmet tray is joined at the lip - a combination of three or seven basic dishes fused into a new format and function.

"NCIS" and "The Mentalist" led the ratings for CBS on an abbreviated Tuesday night of prime time television, cut short by President Obama's press conference during the 8 p.m. hour. According to Nielsen's estimates, each CBS show delivered 17.5 million viewers at 9 and 10 p.m., respectively, tied with each other for the night's largest audience.

"In the Motherhood," which has its debut on ABC on Thursday, was created by a marketing company as a Web video series. After drawing millions of views online in the last two years, it was transformed into a traditional network situation comedy, making it the first Web show to be remade for network television. But what made the Web series unique - an interactive style of storytelling - was quashed by the legal engine of Hollywood.

A host of reports from Madagascar indicate that environmental turmoil, including raids on parks for rosewood, is rising in the wake of political upheaval in that remarkable island nation, which is home to hundreds of extraordinary animal and plant species.
Michele Bachmann, a Republican Congresswoman from east-central Minnesota, has some fighting words for President Obama's energy plans.
The maximum fine for leaving your vehicle unattended and idling in New York City is only $5 -- even if the car eventually kills people because it loses control or is stolen.

Talk about savory breakfast! The flavoring combination used in today's Minimalist column need not be limited to noodles and broth. My breakfast was quinoa with exactly the same "sauce": soy, sesame oil, ketchup, vinegar and sriracha. Definitely breakfast of champions.

If an athletic director is pondering whether to hire Mike Dunlap as basketball coach, the first call should be to the Denver Nuggets Coach George Karl. As I wrote for an article in Wednesday's paper, Dunlap is an unusual case because he will be leaving Arizona when its N.C.A.A. tournament run ends. Dunlap was brought in as associate head coach in Tucson and was offered the interim job when Lute Olson retired because of health reasons. Dunlap, who won two Division II national titles at Metro State in Denver, turned down the Arizona job on principle because he felt he was good enough to be the head coach. Karl wouldn't disagree.
On The Local's virtual refrigerator today, fish painted in watercolors, by Victoria, an 8th grader in Claudia Sohr's class at Millburn Middle School.
This nutty, tangy salad is built around high-protein royal quinoa, found originally in South America.

The pleasures of meal at Vinegar Hill House, which I covered in the Dining Briefs, extend to dessert: the chocolate Guinness Stout cake ($7), with sour cream frosting, is not to be missed.

I live in New York City and am about to enter into a lease agreement. My landlord wants me to pay for heat and hot water. Isn't the landlord legally obligated to provide heat and hot water to residential tenants?

Last year my mother entered a nursing home. We decided to remove her name from the ownership of our co-op for estate reasons. Our accountant now says that she should file a gift tax return, since my brother and I now have her shares. The accountant thinks we need to find out the cost of the shares when the co-op was purchased in 1958 and use that number as the value of the gift. Is our C.P.A. correct?

Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner pressed his case on Wednesday for expanding the government's ability to take over and restructure ailing institutions that threaten the broader financial system, Anahad O'Connor of The New York Times reports.

The refreshing, light nature of this Vietnamese salad, traditionally made with rau ram, a minty herb, makes it a great complement to a dish with more powerful flavor -- this pork clay pot, for instance.

In yet another sign that the line between real news and fake news is getting thinner, one of CNN's main anchors during the 1980s and 1990s, Bobbie Battista, has taken a step through the looking glass and can now be seen anchoring reports online for ONN, The Onion News Network.

A recent report from The Archives of Internal Medicine found that regular eaters of red meat had a modestly higher risk of dying during a 10-year study period than those who ate very little meat. And beyond personal health, many people are finding other reasons to eat less meat. Several reports now say meat consumption contributes to global warming, and regular reports about animal cruelty and the meat industry have caused many people to lose their appetite for meat. At the same time, meat tastes good, and many people don't want to become full vegetarians.

It took three years of stop-and-start negotiations, but a Chinese real estate company is finally signing a lease for space in a 102-story skyscraper under construction at ground zero, becoming the first commercial tenant for the rebuilt World Trade Center.
Three Chevrolet designers brought four new Camaros to Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday, parking the sporty cars -- in silver, black and red -- outside the Times Building.
Richard X. Bove, the banking analyst from Rochdale Research, thinks that Paul Krugman and the markets need a bit of a reality check when it comes to banks and the quality of their assets.
