The size of Fake Estate, a 100-square-foot gallery in Chelsea run by Julia Trotta, is not the right fit for many artists. But for the French multimedia artist Davide Balula, whose "American Wall Nut" is currently on view at the space until April 4, it's plenty of room. The piece, composed from a selection of wooden planks that have been removed from the space's floorboard and inlaid into the wall of the gallery, is perhaps a tribute to Fake Estate's past life as a utility closet. Where the floor's planks have been taken away, white drywall, emulating the surface of the gallery's four walls, fills in the empty space.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Earlier tonight, President Obama held his second prime time press conference. He spent the first half defending the economy, and the second half defending the decision to interrupt "American Idol."

Overtime losses on Tuesday night have set up elimination games for a few teams in the Canadian Hockey League playoffs, none more dramatically so than for the Guelph Storm, who lost, 7-6, in double overtime to the Saginaw Spirit. The Storm had three two-goal leads in the game but T.J. Brodie's power-play goal at 5 mintues40 seconds of the second overtime could send Saginaw into the second round of the playoffs for the first time in its seven-year history.

In the summer of 2005, when Captain Chafik Gharby lost power in both engines of the small commercial plane he was flying from Italy to Tunisia, he was initially hailed as a hero for bringing the plane down on the sea off Sicily, which allowed 23 of the 39 people on board to swim to safety.
Paris | The three-year-old Musée du Quai Branly is dedicated to the display of the indigenous art of the Americas, Africa, Asia and Oceania, and it has defined that mission broadly - very broadly.

Variety points out that the Motion Picture Association of America is playing it pretty quiet about Hollywood's 2008 box-office and ticket sales figures. In past years, these numbers were either unveiled with great fanfare at the annual ShoWest conference in Las Vegas or in the days leading up to it. But this year, with ShoWest set to kick off Monday, the numbers are nowhere to be seen and all indications are they will be downplayed at the Vegas gathering. And it's not because the numbers are bad. Hollywood has been doing quite well of late, thanks very much. The problem, Variety says, is that Hollywood, for political reasons, doesn't want to seem to be bragging about its good fortune while the economy is in such dire straits.

We editors have an almost clinical compulsion for identifying that one single word, no matter how obscure, that perfectly expresses a complex idea. With this in mind, I created GIPE, an acronym formed from "good idea, poorly executed," and now one of the most useful terms in my lexicon.

A U.S. corporate directors' group on Tuesday recommended a slate of new governance principles for company boards, including better communication with investors on executive pay and improved oversight of business risks, Reuters reported.

Spice Group, a suitor for Satyam Computer Services , may withdraw from the race to buy the fraud-hit Indian outsourcing firm because of a lack of transparency in the bidding process, its chairman said on Wednesday, according to Reuters.
Stocks ended lower Tuesday, giving back some of the gains they posted a day earlier in the biggest one-day rally in five months.

NYSE Euronext, which operates stock exchanges in Amsterdam, Brussels, Lisbon and Paris, said it would cut fees on its European markets by about 20 percent as it fights increasing competition in the region.

I am annoyed by the time and effort it takes to change screen resolution in Windows XP when I use program that require specific resolutions. Is there a simple way to toggle between different settings?

Today's idea: Brevity has a noble lineage, from the aphorisms of the ancient Greeks to "The Elements of Style" by Strunk and White. So why bemoan the rise of Twitter? Language | People are giving the micro-blogging service Twitter a hard time "for attention-span erosion that will hasten our descent into duh, stupidness," writes Ryan Bigge at The Smart Set. For example, Samantha Bee of "The Daily Show" mocked Twitter's 140-character limit with "Grunter" -- since "not all my followers have time to read my entire tweet."
A.C. Milan will play Inter Milan in Foxborough, Mass., on July 26 as part of a four-club, six-city tournament that also includes Chelsea and Club América.
A sixth dog in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog race has died. Race officials said a dog on Alan Peck’s team died during a flight to Nome from Shaktoolik.

The Astana rider Levi Leipheimer won the second stage of the Vuelta a Castilla y León race Tuesday, beating his teammate Alberto Contador by 16 seconds. Leipheimer won the 17-mile time trial around the town of Palencia, Spain, in 33 minutes 17.78 seconds. Leipheimer, who won the Tour of California this season, leads Contador in the overall standings by 16 seconds.

Detroit Pistons guard Allen Iverson must pay $260,000 for standing idly by and watching his bodyguard beat up another man in a 2005 bar fight, a federal appeals court ruled. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit rejected Iverson’s attempt to throw out the verdict decided by a jury in 2007.

Oksana Domnina and Maxim Shabalin of Russia did matadors everywhere proud with a sharp and aggressive pasodoble, winning the compulsory dance to take the early lead at the world figure skating championships in Los Angeles. Tanith Belbin and Ben Agosto, in their first competition since Agosto injured his back, were second. The United States champions Meryl Davis and Charlie White are fourth. The original dance is Thursday, the free dance on Friday.

The women’s basketball coach at the United States Coast Guard Academy who committed suicide earlier this month had been put on paid leave three days before his death amid an investigation by federal prosecutors, a university official has said.
The Yankees and the city have reached a tentative agreement on the sale of Yankee Stadium memorabilia that guarantees the city $10 million.
President Obama was the center of attention on March 24. But behind the scenes, a lot had to be done before he took the stage.
Metro, a German retailer, is expected to announce that it is buying a controlling stake in 24-7 Entertainment, which provides technology for online music downloads.

Today is the swan song for our week-long showcase of collaborative illustrations from the artists Anton and Linus Kern, Dan McCarthy and Jack Pierson. The series, a product of a salon hosted in upstate New York by Anton, is featured in the new issue of the journal (all lowercase, naturally), on select newsstands now.

Montreal coach Bob Gainey’s decision to combine Alex Tanguay, Alex Kovalev and Saku Koivu on the top line paid off for the Canadiens, who snapped a five-game losing streak with a 6-3 win over the Atlanta Thrashers.

NYSE Euronext, which operates stock exchanges in Amsterdam, Brussels, Lisbon and Paris, said it would cut fees on its European markets by about 20 percent.
Japan’s exports plunged by a record in February as deepening recessions in the United States and Europe sapped demand for the country’s cars and electronics.
A Queens man said that he narrowly escaped becoming the second person in two weeks to be struck by an arrow when someone shot into his house.

Brazil will lend $700 million for Argentina’s biggest airline, the state-owned Aerolineas Argentinas, to buy 20 planes from the Brazilian aircraft-maker Embraer. The Embraer 190 models, which seat up to 114 people, will be delivered over five years, said Ivan Ramalho, executive secretary of the ministry. Embraer said in February it would reduce 20 percent of its work force.

Spark Capital, a venture capital firm based in Boston, is trying to turn the economy's tumult into an opportunity to find fresh ideas. On Wednesday, the company is unveiling Start@Spark, a seed investment arm for early-stage Web companies that will grant as much as $250,000 to a handful of budding entrepreneurs.

An obituary on Tuesday about Nicholas Hughes, a fisheries biologist whose mother, the poet Sylvia Plath, committed suicide in 1963 when he was a year old, misstated the timing of her 1953 suicide attempt. It took place after she returned home to Massachusetts from a summer job at Mademoiselle in New York, not while she was working there.
The Mets welcomed their final three World Baseball Classic participants back to camp with lively banter and playful teasing.
The United States Federal Aviation Authority has grounded the helicopter model involved in a fatal crash off the Newfoundland coast until modifications are made.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the artist Erik Parker misstated the closing date of an exhibition of his work at Paul Kasmin Gallery in Chelsea. The show ends on Saturday, not April 28.

An article on March 16 about readings of a new play by Caryl Churchill, “Seven Jewish Children: A Play for Gaza,” at two theaters in Washington and the New York Theater Workshop, misstated the history of the New York theater’s plans for another play about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, “My Name Is Rachel Corrie.” In 2006 the theater postponed transferring a production of the play from London; it was not canceled, although it ultimately ran at another theater in New York.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a court-appointed trustee’s discovery in Gibraltar of additional assets of the former investment manager Bernard L. Madoff misstated the month that Mr. Madoff pleaded guilty to running a vast Ponzi scheme. It was on March 12, not in February.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Saturday about a raid on the offices of a Manhattan community organization linked to City Councilman Miguel Martinez, whose sister is on the group’s board of directors, referred incorrectly to Mr. Martinez. He is not in fact an employee of the Department of Education; his sister, Maria, is.

An article on Tuesday about a court appearance by Ali Saleh Kahlah al-Marri, accused of being a sleeper agent for Al Qaeda, gave incorrect given names for two spectators. A 22-year-old woman who attended the hearing because she had studied the case in law school is Erin McCarthy, not Karen. And her mother, who accompanied her, is Elaine McCarthy, not Erin.

Investigators are trying to determine if a firefighter charged with the latest suspicious fires in an arson-plagued Philadelphia suburb could be responsible for any other unsolved blazes. The firefighter, Robert Tracey Jr., 37, of Coatesville, was charged with lighting two small trash fires a few blocks apart in Coatesville on Friday. The fires caused no injuries or significant damage. Mr. Tracey was a longtime volunteer at the city’s West End Fire Company, eventually attaining the unpaid position of assistant fire chief. He left that post last month to become a paid firefighter with the Coatesville Fire Department. He was jailed in lieu of $2 million bail. Coatesville has had 22 arson fires this year and nearly 50 since February 2008.
Danilo Gallinari will most likely undergo back surgery in the coming weeks, ending his rookie season, which was more frustrating than rewarding.

Former Sheriff Mike Burgess of Custer County was sentenced to 79 years in prison for using his power over female drug court defendants to force them to have sex with him. In January, a jury in Major County, where the case was moved because of pretrial publicity, found Mr. Burgess guilty on 13 felony counts, including five counts of second-degree rape. Prosecutors alleged that Mr. Burgess sexually abused inmates and drug court defendants; he had been a member of a team controlling a drug court. Several female offenders testified that they feared they would be sent to prison if they did not provide sexual favors to him.
This intimate restaurant tucked away on the Brooklyn waterfront is as attractive as it is elusive.

A federal judge denied Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger’s request to remove a court-appointed receiver who wants the cash-strapped state to spend $8 billion on new health care facilities at state prisons. The administration said it would appeal. The judge, Thelton E. Henderson of Federal District Court, rejected, among other things, the state’s claim that the receiver, J. Clark Kelso, was violating federal law by seeking the construction money. Judge Henderson gave the receiver control of the prison medical system in 2006 after finding conditions in the state’s 33 adult prisons so bad that an average of an inmate a week was dying of neglect or malpractice. That has not changed, he said in the latest ruling.
There’s some accomplished, appealing cooking at Atria, though it’s not clear that many people have noticed.

NASA’s online contest to name a new room at the International Space Station went awry. The comedian Stephen Colbert won. The name Colbert beat out NASA’s four suggested options in the space agency’s effort to have the public help name the addition. NASA’s mistake was allowing write-ins. Mr. Colbert urged viewers of his Comedy Central show, “The Colbert Report,” to write in his name. And they complied, with 230,539 votes. That beat Serenity, one of the NASA choices, by more than 40,000 votes. Nearly 1.2 million votes were cast by the time the contest ended Friday. NASA reserves the right to choose an appropriate name, and an agency spokesman said NASA would decide in April.

President Obama said he was nominating Johnnie Carson, one of the government’s most senior Africa hands and career Foreign Service officers, to succeed Jendayi Frazer as assistant secretary of state for African affairs. Mr. Carson had stints in two nations that have endured the greatest political turmoil over the past two years, serving as ambassador to Kenya from 1999 to 2003 and Zimbabwe from 1995 to 1997. He was also ambassador to Uganda from 1991 to 1994. Most recently, Mr. Carson was the national intelligence officer for Africa on the National Intelligence Council. Before he joined the council, he spent 37 years in the Foreign Service, with posts in Botswana, Mozambique and Nigeria, among others.

The Senate, by voice vote, has confirmed Gary Locke, a former governor of Washington, as commerce secretary. Mr. Locke, 59, was the nation’s first Chinese-American governor. In the commerce job, he has promised to focus on job creation and to closely oversee the 2010 census. Mr. Locke was President Obama’s third choice to run the Commerce Department; his first two withdrew. The Commerce Department has broad responsibilities, including the census, many aspects of international trade, oceans policy and weather forecasts. It is also overseeing the transition to digital television.

Because of an editing error, a listing on Jan. 7 in the Off the Menu column misstated the name of a pizza restaurant scheduled to open on March 29 in Greenwich Village. It is Kesté Pizza e Vino, not Esté Pizza e Vino. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on March 20.

A judge has ruled that a Colorado Springs church building belongs to the Episcopal Diocese of Colorado and not a breakaway parish. Ownership has been in dispute since March 2007, when some members and leaders of Grace Church and St. Stephen’s left the national body over theological differences. The breakaway group aligned itself with the conservative Convocation of Anglicans in Virginia but continued to worship in the building.

A former Army paratrooper, Sgt. William Kreutzer, has been sentenced to life in prison after admitting he killed a fellow soldier and wounded 18 others in a shooting at Fort Bragg in 1995. Sergeant Kreutzer, 39, had pleaded guilty to one charge of premeditated murder and 18 other charges in order to avoid a possible death sentence. The military judge also reduced his rank to private, ordered him to forfeit all future pay and be dishonorably discharged.
The Obama administration must decide whether Nawaz Sharif is likely to be a reliable ally or an obstructionist force.

Because of an editing error, a listing last Wednesday in the Off the Menu column for Anthos Upstairs, which opened on March 19, misstated its telephone number and address. As if the economy were not causing enough consternation at the White House, the first presidential fund-raiser of the year, which will be held Wednesday in Washington, has yet to sell out. An e-mail solicitation went out late Monday, trying to drum up interest among Democrats -- or Obama admirers of any stripe. ''I wanted to let you know that tickets for this Wednesday's concert with the president are about to sell out!'' said the message, signed by Gov. CORWIN--Phillip, poet, United Nations official, and teacher - died Monday from pancreatic cancer. He was 72 years old. The Weinstein Company is in the early stages of turning a biography of Judy Garland, above right, into a play, a musical or a film, with the actress Anne Hathaway, above left, to play Garland, the company announced on Monday night. The project was first reported by The Associated Press. The Weinstein Company acquired the film and stage rights last year to Gerald Clarke's ''Get Happy: The Life of Judy Garland,'' published in 2000 by Random House. Emily Feingold, a Weinstein Company spokeswoman, said on Tuesday that the Garland project was ''in a very, very early phase'' and that executives had just begun reaching out to writers and directors to help them decide whether to develop the work as a stage musical, a play with music, a film or in more than one version.

OFFENBACH--Marilyn, beloved wife of the late Gene; devoted mother of Marla (John) Hurban and Dana (Robert E. Williams) Offenbach; loving grandmother of Joshua and Helaina. Services Thursday, 11:00am at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Inc. 162 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

HUBERTH--Harry G.,Jr., of Pinehurst, NC, passed away March 22, 2009 after a brief illness. A funeral service will be held at 1:30pm Thursday March 26, at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Southern Pines, NC. Harry is survived by his devoted wife, Susan, of 30 years; son Harry Huberth and wife Sandy; daughter Laurie Holden and husband Michael; daughter Annie Huberth, two stepdaughters Katherine Burdge and Christine Ambrose, and five grandchildren. Harry was a highly decorated WWII veteran. As Commanding Officer B Company, 141st Infantry Regiment, 36th Infantry Division, he was awarded the Silver Star, 2 Bronze Stars, 2 Purple Hearts and the Croix de Guerre among others. Harry was a member of the Lost Battalion which was rescued by the Japanese American volunteers of the 442nd Regimental Combat team, and involved in the liberation of the concentration camp survivors at Hurlach. Harry retired in 1989 as Chairman of Huberth and Peters, Inc., a New York real estate firm. In addition to serving on numerous real estate industry boards, Harry was Chairman of the Fifth Avenue Association, and served on the boards of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary and the Manhattan Savings Bank/Republic Bank for Savings, later H.S.B.C. Harry was an accomplished horseman both in the hunt field and show ring and was awarded a Lifetime Achievement Award at the Washington Capital Challenge Horse Show. Harry was a graduate of Colgate University where he was recognized as an All-Time Letter Winner on the men's soccer team. Harry was actively involved in various churches, recently as the Treasurer of Trinity Church in Upperville, VA, a member of the vestry of Emmanuel Church in Delaplane, VA, and as a member of Emmanuel Episcopal Church. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to any of the following organizations: The Sand Hills Area Land Trust, the Penick Village Foundation or the Schnauzer Rescue of the Carolinas. Online condolences may be made at www.bolesfuneralhome.com Boles Funeral Home and Crematory of Southern Pines is serving the family.

AMBLE--Bjorn Ommundsen, of Mt. Sinai, NY, devoted husband to Marie for 44 years, died on March 18. Born in Norway on December 24, 1923, Bjorn emigrated in 1951. An avid tennis player, skier, reader of the New York Times and gardener, Bjorn's first love was his family to whom he was selflessly and tirelessly devoted. His daily refrain of "I'm a lucky man" was sincere and summed up his outlook which was only in his final days robbed from him by dementia. In addition to his wife, he is survived by daughters, Karen Amble and Erika Craven, son-in-law Jason Craven and grandchildren Max and Siri Craven.

ARAD--Odeda. It is with a heavy heart that we share the news that Odeda passed away peacefully in the arms of her children Ori Dubow and Tamar Powers, in the early morning of Saturday, March 21st. She is also survived by her son-in-law Michael Powers, her adored grandsons Joseph and Daniel and legions of beloved and cherished friends. A teacher for 50 years and an artist for all of her life, Odeda engaged the intellect and creative spirit in everyone she encountered, becoming lifelong friends with people met through often random encounters. She was extraordinary in her generosity and in comforting friends and strangers alike, sharing her loving heart with gusto. A celebration of her life will take place on Friday, March 27th at 1:30pm at 351 E. 61st St., New York, NY 10065.

The European Commission said that ''very significant subjects'' still need to be resolved before it can complete a tariff reduction agreement with South Korea. Already facing a catastrophic reduction in sales because of the global economic downturn, the European automotive industry reacted with alarm to the announcement at a news conference in Seoul early Tuesday of a proposed agreement to ease trade restrictions. But the European Commission's spokesman on trade, Lutz Güllner, moved quickly to tamp down suggestions that the bloc was on the verge of signing an agreement. Among the issues left to be resolved, Mr. Güllner said, was a timetable for eliminating the Europe's 10 percent tariff on imported cars. If a deal is completed, it will be a rare move toward free trade at a time when politicians across the globe are under pressure to resort to protectionism. A free trade agreement between the United States and South Korea, reached in 2007, has not been ratified in part because some American Congressional leaders fear the agreement would be detrimental to the nation's automakers. A successful deal with the European Union could put pressure on American leaders to approve the agreement. STEPHEN CASTLE

New York Representative for Nicoverken Ship Repair Group for 30 years. Taught at the Marine Maritime Academy in the mid fifties. Retired lieutenant commander in the Naval Reserve in the early 1980s. BUCHTHAL--Fred, 92, passed away March 20, 2009. Born December 21, 1916 in Berlin, Germany. He was a resident of Teaneck, NJ. Fred came to America from Nazi-occupied Germany in 1936 and joined the US Army to fight Hitler. He served with the 5th Tank Division during the WWII. He was a life master bridge player and an avid chess player. Fred was a long-standing member of the National Council of Jewish Women's Swim In to aid MS patients and Meals on Wheels. Fred has left this Earth a better place. He relentlessly supported the underdog, and often provided help for the unfortunate individuals who didn't have the same human rights and opportunities. He helped to publish Spartacus, when the author was blacklisted and he supported Paul Robeson's efforts with the Progressive Party in 1948. Husband to the late Esther (Goldman). Father to Ronald and (wife) Susan, Stanley and (wife) Maja, and Larry. Grandfather to David and (wife) Mary, Caryn and (husband) John, Lucas, Marina, and Anna. Brother to Claes, 96 and Chaim Tal, 90.

Maggie is young but not young-looking. Somewhere in the backwoods of the American South, she works in a slaughterhouse and meatpacking plant to support herself and her 14-year-old daughter. The daughter is dating a Salvadoran boy whose career goal is to join a gang. To keep going, Maggie smokes a pipe of crystal meth now and then. And when she falls into bed with a handsome drifter, things get worse. The dramatis personae of Colin McKenna's meaningful two-act drama ''The Secret Agenda of Trees'' might feel at home on one of those talk shows in which the host encourages guests to scream bleep-worthy accusations. Mr. McKenna looks at these people more sympathetically, but in the tepid production at the Wild Project, directed by Michael Kimmel, their pain is hard to buy.

DeMARCO--Angelo M. Beloved husband of Josephine. Devoted father of Angela, Karen, Joseph and Christine; cherished brother of Connie; adored grandfather and loving uncle. Passed away March 20. LaPOOK--Elsa (Eisenbud), died peacefully on March 23 at age 86 surrounded by family after a joyous and fulfilled life. Beloved wife, best friend, and partner of 66 years to Dr. Sidney LaPook, magnificent mother to Judith, Nancy (Diamond), Jonathan and Corinne, and adored mother-in-law to Bob Diamond, Kate Lear and Wayne Pasternack. She was the devoted and much loved Babba of Michael, Rebecca, Laura, Sam, Daniel, Jesse and Noah. Daughter of Kalman and Leonora Eisenbud, sister of Leon and Merrill. Elsa grew up roller skating on the Upper West Side and returned to the City with her husband after raising their family in West Hempstead and Great Neck. Elsa was a 1945 graduate of Hunter College where she was a member of Alpha Epsilon Phi. During the War she served on the Home Front, spotting planes and volunteering for the USO. She never stopped giving: to her family, friends and to the community. She was a writer, poet, journalist and community leader. Elsa served as President of the Cornwell Avenue PTA and the Council of PTAs for West Hempstead School District 27, and was President of the Sisterhood of the Malverne Jewish Center, which she helped found. She wrote and directed school and temple musical productions. She loved dance, music, theatre and traveling the world. A passionate tennis and ping pong player, she was amazed at the wonders of nature and had a lifelong zest for learning. She never peeled an orange without thinking "at this moment this orange has never seen the light of day." Her positive energy, optimism and integrity inspired us all. Her nest was never empty. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center, Columbia University Medical Center, 1150 St. Nicholas Avenue, New York, New York 10032 Attention: Steve Bennett. Memorial Service Thursday, March 26, 10am, Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83 Street.

8 P.M. (HBO2) THEY KILLED SISTER DOROTHY Daniel Junge's documentary examines the case of Dorothy Stang, above, a 73-year-old nun, born in Ohio, who became a Brazilian citizen. She campaigned for three decades for peasants' rights and sustainable development in the Amazon basin before she was killed in 2005, shot six times on a jungle road. The film draws on archival footage, photographs, letters and interviews with people involved in the subsequent trial, including two men who confessed to the murder. 8 P.M. YEARS ago, I made spicy pork sausages from scratch. I borrowed the food grinder and sausage stuffer attachments for my KitchenAid mixer from my dad. I ordered salted sheep intestines online and soaked them while I stuffed cold cubes of pork and fat through the grinder. After seasoning the meat, I extruded it into the casings, gleefully watching the floppy strands blow up like those long narrow balloons usually twisted into puppies.

A Los Angeles County court has issued a restraining order against a man who tried to break into the set of the ABC reality series “Dancing with the Stars” in an attempt to meet one of its contestants, The Associated Press reported. The man, Robert O’Ryan, was arrested Tuesday after an incident Monday in which he jumped a fence at CBS Studios, where “Dancing with the Stars” is produced. Mr. O’Ryan was said to be seeking out Shawn Johnson, 17, the Olympic gymnast featured on the current season of the show. A search of Mr. O’Ryan’s car yielded two loaded guns as well as duct tape and love letters written to Ms. Johnson, the police said. He is being held on $35,000 bail, on suspicion of carrying a loaded firearm in public; an April 14 hearing has been set to consider an extension of the restraining order.

The PEN American Center has announced the lineup for its annual World PEN Voices Festival of International Literature, which will run from April 27 through May 3 in New York. Among the events, which will bring together 160 writers from 40 countries, is the Evolution/Revolution reading series on April 29, which will feature Edwidge Danticat, Salman Rushdie and Muriel Barbery, among other authors, reading in their original languages; an April 30 panel hosted by The New York Review of Books called “The Economic Crisis and How to Deal with It,” with Paul Krugman, George Soros and Nouriel Roubini and others; and the PEN Cabaret, a performance on May 2 featuring Lou Reed, Laurie Anderson, Sean Wilsey and other writers and performers. A full schedule can be found online at www.pen.org/worldvoices.

In a sign of the times, even Mozart is now being updated for the “American Idol” age. A coming production of his opera “Così fan tutte,” about a pair of officers and their fickle sister fiancées, and the romantic machinations of the sisters’ maid and an elderly philosopher, will ask audience members to vote at intermission for which characters should be married in the opera’s final scene. The production, called “Così fan Tutte: Defining Women,” will be performed by the Underworld Productions Opera Ensemble at Symphony Space on April 29 and 30, and it invites theatergoers to vote by sending text messages from their cell phones. Cast members will then perform the democratically chosen ending. In a news release, the opera company notes that its production has been relocated from 18th-century Italy to modern-day Massachusetts, “where nuptials between any combination of three men and three women would be legal.”

Thirteen paintings that may be the work of Hitler will be sold at an auction in Britain scheduled for April, Reuters reported. The artworks, which include a possible self-portrait, would have been made when he was a struggling artist in Vienna, vying unsuccessfully to gain entrance to its Academy of Arts before he fought in World War I. The auction house Mullock’s, which is conducting the sale, said that the paintings were by Hitler and were likely to fetch between about $580 and $1,448 dollars each. A previous sale of paintings possibly made by Hitler, held in Cornwall in 2007, provoked questions about the authenticity of the works. A historical document expert from Mullock’s said the subjects of his paintings tended to be similar, featuring flowers and romantic landscapes with cottages.

Doctors placed a five-inch metal plate and 12 screws into Lance Armstrong’s broken right collarbone Wednesday. The healing may take 8 to 12 weeks, but Armstrong could be back on a bike in a few days, though Elenz ordered him to ease back into training.

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the unintended consequences of the North American Free Trade Agreement referred incorrectly to the workers shown at Intel’s design center in Guadalajara. They consist mostly of skilled technicians and engineers who have benefited under Nafta, including wage increases and more job opportunities. They are not among the information technology workers in Mexico who hold low-wage assembly jobs and have seen few benefits from the trade agreement. (An accompanying picture showed farmers near Etzatlán, Mexico, who are representative of those who have not benefited much under Nafta.).

When Syracuse won the national title in 2003, fans made T-shirts proclaiming the Orange as the Big 12 champions. That was because Syracuse ran through the gantlet of top Big 12 teams -- Oklahoma State, Oklahoma, Texas and Kansas -- on the way. Perhaps the biggest reason the Orange won that title was because the former assistant Troy Weaver landed Carmelo Anthony, who has become college basketball's one-and-done prototype. The next biggest reason was the Orange's 2-3 zone defense, which left Big 12 teams looking as if they were staring at the equation from ''Good Will Hunting.''

Most people who own an iPhone, a Prius or a Nintendo Wii have never heard of Porite, but this small company outside Tokyo makes a crucial part of their toys' vital organs. Despite the ubiquity of the tiny copper bearings Porite churns out by the millions each day, orders all but dried up in September. Now shipments are down about 40 percent from last year, as consumers in the United States and elsewhere rein in spending on sophisticated electronics.

A Turkish officer was arrested Wednesday in connection with suspected extrajudicial killings in the country's predominantly Kurdish southeast in the 1990s. A court in Diyarbakir, the largest city in the southeast, issued the arrest warrant for the officer, Col. Cemal Temizoz, pending a trial. Colonel Temizoz served near the town of Cizre, about 40 miles from the Iraqi border in Turkey's southeast, from 1993 to 1996, when hundreds of Kurdish civilians and activists were said to have been killed by security forces with links to the military. In excavations around Cizre, officials have so far found pieces of clothing and at least 20 bones, which will be subject to DNA examination.

This week, The Times introduces a blog by Ben Schott that will explore the vocabulary of current events -- some serious, others frivolous, some neologized, others newly newsworthy. Each day, Schott's Vocab will track the words and phrases that encapsulate the times in which we live or shed light on a story of note.

EVEN if you lack outdoor space, you can grow something -- basil or rosemary, for instance, in a sunny window. It may not seem like much, ''but if you have somebody over and you're chopping something real quick, you can say, Hand me a piece of that basil,'' said Felder Rushing, a noted garden writer and speaker. ''That's all it takes to get that feeling of connection to the land.'' To save money, use recycled materials, like old plastic pots (usually given away free by nurseries) or planters made from rubber tires.

RICHMAN--Arthur, former Mets and Yankees executive passed away March 25, 2009 at the age of 83. He was predeceased by his brother Milton, a Hall of Fame award-winning columnist and sports editor for United Press International for four decades. Mr. Richman is survived by his wife of 29 years, Martha. Services Thursday, 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

SOLVIN--Alvin Jay, M.D.,died March 24th, 2009 at home. Beloved husband of Ellen, loving father of Stacy Solvin and Randy Solvin Lumi (Christopher), adored grandfather of Ben. A dedicated cardiothoracic surgeon who was larger than life, he will be missed by his loving family, grateful patients, and devoted friends. Services Thursday, March 26th, 12:30pm, Boulevard Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, New York.

DEAL-MAKING isn't dead. But it could use a shot in the arm. Despite several high-priced takeovers, including Pfizer's $65 billion purchase of Wyeth in January and Merck's $46 billion acquisition of Schering-Plough, the volume of mergers and acquisitions in the first quarter is lower than it has been in more than a decade.
MIDWEST

FOR the last several months, Americans have looked to Washington to lead them. But where's the leadership on Wall Street? There is an enormous opportunity for a C.E.O. to come forward with a plan to reform the financial system and pledge a change from business as usual. Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase's chief executive, has been the most outspoken of his peers during the crisis -- and has done an admirable job addressing the issues -- but he has been more focused on helping instill confidence in the economy and the health of his own firm. John Mack, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, has shown glimpses of public leadership, at one point apologizing for the crisis by saying, ''We are sorry for it.''
WEST

Wall Street and Washington have always made for strange bedfellows. Congress pushed and prodded with rules and regulations, and Wall Street pushed back. But lawmakers also gave tax breaks and eased some rules, allowing the money crowd more room to run. Behind the scenes, financiers sought support on Capitol Hill -- usually with a campaign contribution in hand.

ARAD--Odeda. It is with a heavy heart that we share the news that Odeda passed away peacefully in the arms of her children Ori Dubow and Tamar Powers, in the early morning of Saturday, March 21st. She is also survived by her son-in-law Michael Powers, her adored grandsons Joseph and Daniel and legions of beloved and cherished friends. A teacher for 50 years and an artist for all of her life, Odeda engaged the intellect and creative spirit in everyone she encountered, becoming lifelong friends with people met through often random encounters. She was extraordinary in her generosity and in comforting friends and strangers alike, sharing her loving heart with gusto. A celebration of her life will take place on Friday, March 27th at 1:30pm at 351 E. 61st St., New York, NY 10065.
FALCO--Louis. 3/26/93. Your loving Being & your contributions to dance & theater continue to inspire us. Your friends & family

SHUGAR--Lois Rapaport, died on Wednesday, March 25, 2009 in New York City. She is survived by her beloved children Amy Raffaella Shugar and Jonathan Harry Shugar. She was a devoted sister and sister in-law of Martin, Richard and Brooke Kamin Rapaport. Her cousins Herbert Marton, Myron Rapaport, Robert Rapaport, Michael Rapaport, Peter Rapaport, David Rapaport, Vicki Schnell, Paul Schnell, Linda Golding, Nancy Schnell and Eric Schnell and their families deeply mourn her passing. She was much loved by aunts and uncle Stella Rapaport Fuld, Selma Rapaport Pressman, Ina Schnell, and Marianne and Seymour Schnell. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, March 26, 2009 at 11:00am at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

This week, The Times introduces a blog by Ben Schott that will explore the vocabulary of current events -- some serious, others frivolous, some neologized, others newly newsworthy. Each day, Schott's Vocab will track the words and phrases that encapsulate the times in which we live or shed light on a story of note.

WILSON--Linda (Babcock), loving wife of Kendrick R. Wilson III and beloved mother of Jane D. Hall, Olivia W. Thompson, and Kendrick R. Wilson IV, died peacefully in her home in Hobe Sound, FL on Saturday, March 21. Mrs. Wilson was a longtime resident of Bedford, NY and Livingston, MT. She is an alumna from Oldfields School and attended Denver University and Parsons School of Design. She is survived by her first grandchild, Timothy K. Hall, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Babcock, and siblings, John B. Babcock Jr., Joanne B. Wilmerding, and Frederick H. Babcock. Mrs. Wilson was a talented artist, a philanthropist, and an admired member of the Bedford Garden Club. She will be remembered for her creative spirit and warm heart. She was an avid sportswoman, with a passion for preserving the natural beauty of the Northern Rockies, particularly Montana. More than anything, Mrs. Wilson loved her family, and she will be forever missed. A service will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, NY on April 3 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in her honor to The Brain Tumor Center and mailed to MSKCC, 1275 York Avenue, Room C713, New York, NY 10065, c/o Ms. Desert Horse-Grant

NOT long ago, investors lined up to write checks to hedge funds, with visions of huge returns. But after last year's lousy investment performance and record levels of hedge fund closures, many are now realizing that hedge funds aren't an asset class, but a legal construct -- and the legal agreements can be absurdly one-sided. With the balance of supply and demand tilted in investors' favor for the first time in years, even some star managers are now on the back foot. It's time for investors to push for their rights.

KREMER--Abraham J.,90, passed away on March 24, 2009 in Englewood, New Jersey. He was the beloved husband of Reba Goodman, father of Martin, Daniel, and Jonathan Kremer, brother of Joan Ringler, Leah Weitzman, and Simi Rosen, grandfather of eight, and uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Abraham was one of the founders of two advertising agencies Rosston, Kremer & Slawter and Warren/Kremer Advertising as well as a founder of the Frisch School and Yavneh Academy in Paramus. A passionate philanthropist, Abe was responsible for raising millions of dollars for charities including the UJA and P.E.F. Israel Endowment Funds, which he also served as president. A renowned collector of Judaica including a preeminent collection of the five megillot, in over 50 languages. He was president of the Jewish Book Council, and a Past Chairman of the United Jewish Appeal of Bergen County. Abe was also of critical assistance to the Jewish Theological Seminary. Funeral services will be held on Thursday March 26, 10:00am at the Frisch School, 120 W. Century Rd., Paramus, New Jersey.

We send deepest sympathies to all the Conway family.

Egyptian officials welcomed President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan to Cairo on Wednesday, apparently undeterred by the arrest warrant that has been issued against him for war crimes and crimes against humanity by an international court. The Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, and senior government ministers received Mr. Bashir, left, at the airport in Cairo, then held a meeting to discuss the arrest warrant and conflict in Darfur, among other matters. It was the second international visit by Mr. Bashir this week, following a trip to Eritrea on Monday. Mr. Bashir has also pledged to attend an Arab League summit meeting in Qatar next week. He has been defiant since the arrest warrant was issued on March 4 by the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

HARDLY a day goes by without another drawn-out Congressional hearing concerning all things Wall Street. Congress has dragged down dozens of economists, regulators and so-called masters of the universe from their respective ivory towers, faceless government buildings and glass-laden high-rises to face the wrath of the American people. While the hearings have yielded important insights on the global financial crisis, they have also illustrated how little some members of Congress know about the very system they are supposed to be overseeing. Those who have watched the hearings from their desks at work or their couches at home have seen it all in the past few months: grandstanding, off-topic questions, the butchering of names, bad jokes, backhanded compliments, folksy insights and political rancor.

RUTHERFURD--Alice Polk, of New York City and Fishers Island, NY died peacefully on March 25 at the age of 91. She was the beloved wife of Winthrop Rutherfurd who predeceased her in February 1988. Campbell at 1076 Madison Avenue on Sunday, March 29 from 4:00-7:00pm. WALL STREET is bracing for a regulatory tsunami to make its way up from Washington. Lawmakers are considering sweeping changes to the Depression-era securities laws and regulatory agencies that failed to prevent the economic downturn. As these new proposals gain momentum, Representative Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat who is chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, will have a central role in influencing the size and scope of these new regulations.

One of the nicer touches of Leon Botstein’s American Symphony Orchestra concerts at Avery Fisher Hall is that in addition to the Lincoln Center program book, listeners are given a large-format booklet of notes, essays and vocal texts. Among the essays, invariably, is a rumination by Mr. Botstein, who in addition to conducting this orchestra and the Jerusalem Symphony, is president of Bard College and is comfortable writing academic prose.

In this third and final installment of our Q&A with Ricky Gervais, the “Office” and “Extras” star, he talks about his upcoming movie projects, including “This Side of the Truth,” which he directed with Matthew Robinson and which will mark his film-directing debut — and why he nonetheless believes that the medium of television has beaten film. (In part 1 of this interview, Mr. Gervais discussed his comic philosophy and the double-edged sword of celebrity. In part 2, he spoke about his artistic influences, his explorations of stand-up comedy and Nelson Mandela.)

Updated | 12:01 p.m. Officials from the African nation of Malawi said that they would consider a petition by Madonna to adopt an orphaned girl from that country, Reuters reported. The 14-month-old girl, named Mercy James, comes from the same orphanage as Madonna’s son, David Banda, 3, whom she met in 2006 and whose adoption was completed last year. That adoption proved briefly controversial when Madonna was accused of circumventing Malawian laws that prevent foreigners from adopting children. Madonna is expected to arrive in Malawi over the weekend and appear in court on Monday for adoption proceedings. She has a daughter, Lourdes, 12, from her relationship with the trainer and actor Carlos Leon, and a son, Rocco, 8, from her marriage with the filmmaker Guy Ritchie. Her divorce from Mr. Ritchie became final in January.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Friday morning.

It has been written; now the authors behind the Academy Award-winning film “Slumdog Millionaire” are moving onto new writing assignments. In a news release, Minotaur Books, an imprint of the St. Martin’s Publishing Group, said it had acquired the United States rights for a new work by Vikas Swarup, whose novel “Q&A” provided the basis for the movie. Mr. Swarup’s new book is a novel called “Six Suspects,” about the investigation into the murder of a playboy son of an Indian official, and is scheduled for publication this summer. Also, The Hollywood Reporter said that Simon Beaufoy, whose script for “Slumdog Millionaire” won the Oscar for best adapted screenplay, had been hired by DreamWorks Animation to write a script for a new film called “Truckers.” No other details about the project were given.

Darryl McCauley, the half-brother and former business manager of the comedian and actor Dane Cook, has been held on $1 million bail after pleading not guilty to charges he embezzled millions of dollars from Mr. Cook, The Associated Press reported. Since the 1990s, Mr. McCauley had been managing the finances of Mr. Cook, whose films include “Dan in Real Life” and “My Best Friend’s Girl.” In December, Mr. McCauley was accused of taking more than $10 million from his client, including an incident that month when he allegedly tried to cash a forged check for $3 million. On Thursday in a Massachusetts court he pleaded not guilty to eight counts of larceny over $250, and charges of forgery and larceny by continuous scheme. A pretrial conference has been set for April 16.

McCarren Park Pool, the crumbling, Depression-era public swimming pool on the border between Williamsburg and Greenpoint in Brooklyn, is set to become a swimming spot again, but the concerts that put it on the rock map over the last three summers are set to move to the Williamsburg waterfront. Stephanie Thayer, executive director of the Open Space Alliance for North Brooklyn, a nonprofit group that coordinated last year’s concerts, said that a strip along the East River between North Eighth and North Ninth Streets that was designated a New York State park a few years ago will have concerts this summer, with room for 6,000 fans. The news was confirmed by the office of State Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol, who represents Greenpoint and Williamsburg. “This is the continuation of McCarren Park Pool,” Ms. Thayer said. “It’s different, but it has its own exquisite beauty, with the waterfront and the skyline of Manhattan.” She added that she plans to work with many of the promoters who put on events at the pool, but that if enough sponsorship money comes through, she hopes to also put on classical and opera concerts as well. Ms. Thayer, who in addition to her role with the Open Space Alliance is an administrator with the City Parks Department, said that renovations on McCarren Pool were set to begin on schedule this summer.

The rapper T.I. was sentenced Friday to one year and one day in prison on federal weapons violations, The Associated Press reported. In March, the hip-hop star, whose given name is Clifford Harris, pleaded guilty to three charges of illegal weapons possession, after he was arrested in 2007 following a sting operation as he received three machine guns and two silencers that had been bought for him. Mr. Harris had faced up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine for each count and initially pleaded not guilty to the charges. Since changing his plea, he has performed more than 1,000 hours of community service and appeared on a reality series, “T.I.’s Road to Redemption,” on which he warned teens about the dangers of guns and violence. He will have between 30 and 60 days to report to prison.

A man arrested Tuesday for trying to break into the set of “Dancing With the Stars” pleaded not guilty on Thursday to charges that he tried to stalk Shawn Johnson, a contestant on the show, The Associated Press reported. The man, Robert O’Ryan, was arrested after an incident Monday in which he jumped a fence at CBS Studios, where “Dancing with the Stars” is produced. A search of Mr. O’Ryan’s car found two loaded guns as well as duct tape and love letters written to Ms. Johnson, the Olympic athlete, the police said. At an arraignment in Los Angeles County Superior Court, Mr. O’Ryan was charged with one felony count of stalking and two misdemeanor counts of carrying a loaded gun in a vehicle, and his bail was raised to $220,00 from $35,000. A trial was scheduled for April 27.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- Johan Santana breezed through the Washington Nationals tonight, needing only 75 (!) pitches to get through the first seven innings of the Mets' 3-1 victory. He struck out six, walked none and allowed one run -- on an Alberto Gonzalez R.B.I. triple in the second -- and once and for all eased any of the Mets' concerns heading into his opening day start in Cincinnati.

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- Slowly but surely, the Mets' roster is taking shape. The team's decision to release Ron Villone tonight assures them of beginning the season without a second left-hander in the bullpen. And the Mets' choice to reassign Nelson Figueroa and Carlos Muniz means that Brian Stokes and Darren O'Day are all but guaranteed the final two bullpen spots behind J.J. Putz, Francisco Rodriguez, Sean Green, Bobby Parnell and Pedro Feliciano. The only possible options remaining are Fernando Nieve, who hasn't pitched much, and Elmer Dessens, who would be a long man on a team that doesn't really want/need one.

As Apple announced in January, the company will incorporate a new $1.29 pricing structure for selected hit singles and some classic tracks on iTunes. The price increase - to $1.29 from 99 cents - will go into effect April 7, sources said.

When I was 17, I worked at the counter of brick oven pizza place in the New Jersey town where I grew up. I lasted about three months, until I got a better job making sandwiches at a shop around the corner. The constant access to slices, the abuse customers inflicted over the phone when they were angry about their late deliveries and, worst of all, the fact that all my clothes smelled like melted mozzarella -- it was enough to put me off pizza for several years.

For one hour on Saturday evening, 8:30 to 9:30 p.m., exterior lights will shut off at a score of New York City landmarks, including the Empire State Building, the New York Public Library, the United Nations headquarters, City Hall and the Brooklyn Bridge. But New Yorkers need not worry -- we hope -- about a recurrence of the citywide blackouts of 1965, 1977 and 2003.

As regular readers - and followers of The Moment on Twitter - know, last week I was on a whirlwind road trip through Croatia and Slovenia. Bokeh is a cool effect in which the background of a photo is blurred to draw the viewer's attention to a particular area. The effect is typically achieved by using a D.S.L.R. camera set at a wide aperture to create a narrow depth of field. A more creative way to play around with bokeh is by attaching a Lensbaby to your D.S.L.R. Lensbaby is a "selective focus" S.L.R. lens that lets you focus on a subject (the "sweet spot") and blur everything at the edges.

I'm moving into an apartment that was occupied by the previous tenant since before the building went co-op, and thus the washer-dryer was exempt from a co-op prohibition against washer-dryers. The seller of the unit believes that the apartment is grandfathered and exempt from this rule in perpetuity. I don't want to ask a lot of questions and draw attention to the situation, but I want to know my status before I put money into a new washer-dryer.
What is a statue of limitation for deed fraud?

Ingmar Bergman may be dead, but his spirit lives on in my native Sweden. After a couple of decades of my compatriots trying to be upbeat, morose has become chic again (and, in my opinion, it's what we do best). In particular, a group of young women are promoting a sexy new gothic vibe that seems inspired by horror movies, long dark winter nights and plenty of vodka. Skål!

The Baghdad government recently began allowing cars into the Zahara market, and it seemed that everyone was unhappy about it. For the first time in years, the shop owners and sidewalk vendors had to accustom themselves to the sight of cars up and down the street, including a canary yellow Peugeot that was illegally parked next to a photo studio about 1 o'clock Thursday afternoon.

Leslie Kaufman of The Times' environment reporting unit is wondering what happens when family members have different visions of how much, or even whether, to green their lives. What happens when one spouse wants a hybrid and the other an S.U.V.? Any squabbles over what kinds of bags come back from the supermarket, or tossing food scraps into the trash instead of composting? There's been some academic work assessing whether men and women have different environmental attitudes. But how does that play out on the ground, or in the kitchen?

You don't need to speak German to appreciate this video clip from a '70s German sports TV show. We're not sure what we love more: the dancing fashion show presenting the proposed new outfits for the Bundesliga (the German national soccer league) or the serious voice-over accompanying the Brazilian samba beats, providing a detailed description of each outfit's color combination ("for our esteemed black and white audience"). Either way, it's wunderbar.

The much-discussed collapse of feature film production in Los Angeles - widely attributed to financial incentives offered just about everywhere else around the country - has been matched by a less-noticed phenomenon: Far fewer shooting days are being logged by student filmmakers here.

Updated, 6:01 p.m. | An M.T.A. construction truck struck an overhead road sign on the Queens-bound plaza of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge at 1:10 p.m. on Friday, causing the steel sign structure to come crashing down on all six lanes and injuring two people who were on the truck, according to M.T.A. Bridges and Tunnels. The accident, which did not injure other passengers, the agency said, forced the immediate closure of the bridge. Cars were being rerouted to the Throgs Neck or Robert F. Kennedy Bridges just before the onslaught of Friday afternoon traffic.

A native son of South Orange, New York Times reporter Andrew Jacobs has directed a sometimes-heartwarming, sometimes-inspirational documentary that deals with a topic that is rarely heartwarming or inspirational: the Holocaust.
Heather Armstrong is pregnant again; she is due to give birth to a daughter, her second, early this summer.

Parisian chic has finally landed in London with the opening yesterday of the glistening Lanvin flagship on Mount Street. Rather than throwing a large party, Lanvin celebrated with three intimate, hourlong salon-style presentations hosted by the label's affable designer, Alber Elbaz. The first two were women-only, with gentlemen (and celebrities) being allowed to join the 7 p.m. session. Elbaz talked the 50 guests at each presentation through highlights of the spring/summer 2009 collection, including dresses that look like separates but actually zip up the side and -- the hit of the evening -- a black T-shirt dress with a hidden belt that women were scrambling to try on after the show. It was very haute couture and super-intimate, but Elbaz's wit - he even quipped about his new protein diet - kept the atmosphere relaxed.Among the guests from the fashion-art-music axis were Yasmin Le Bon, Bryan Ferry, Dinos Chapman, Zandra Rhodes, Juergen Teller, Sadie Coles, Marc Newson, Stephen Jones and Samantha Cameron (the wife of the leader of England's opposition party). After the presentation there was an exclusive dinner party at the home of Ivor Braka, the super-connected London art dealer, before Elbaz jetted off to Paris to pack for his holiday. We miss you already, Alber - come back soon!
Rents are falling in New York City. Some tenants are trading up. Others are paying less for similar space.

Canon Dr. Evangylee Baldwin. He had been absent from her life until she was almost 30. Here are her recollections, slightly condensed, about having to eulogize him.

Americans have a history of believing in oracles that tell them to dig. Where I grew up, not far from the American Society of Dowsers in Danville, Vt., even skeptical farmers consulted dowsers to help them decide where wells should go. Before he discovered Mormonism, Joseph Smith was a "money digger" who trusted that a stone in a hat, properly viewed, could lead him to buried treasure; when the stone pointed the way to a hill in New York that contained the Book of Mormon, he hit the mother lode. California, of course, was settled in part by men who felt called to go gold-digging. And in this century, with perhaps less riding on their hunches than Smith or the forty-niners, a growing clique of hobbyists who started in Oregon nine years ago have combined G.P.S. satellite technology and social networking in a curious pastime called geocaching.

Rohatyn, the financier and former ambassador to France who helped save New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s, offers this view on the importance of infrastructure investment and how the financial system can be repaired. The text is adapted from a speech he gave this week at the Economic Club of Chicago. Once upon a time, there was a little towhead named Chesley who simply loved clothes. Please, she begged her mother: Buy me go-go boots and a vinyl miniskirt. To which her mother replied, "No!" But she would buy her little darling a sewing machine and any fabric in the world. And so began Chesley McLaren's burning ambition: to become a world-class fashion designer.

With the opening of DreamWorks Animation's "Monsters vs. Aliens" this weekend, Hollywood kicks off a period in which major and expensive 3D films will roll out over the next couple of years. The studios are hoping that recent advances in the technology will make the format more acceptable to audiences and perhaps give ticket-buyers a reason to get off their sofas and head to the multiplex. The problem, though, is that there are not as many 3D-equipped cinemas as the studios had hoped. In short, a lot is riding on this. Variety has a report. The film will open on 7,000 screens, only 2,000 of which will be 3D. The Hollywood Reporter weighs in, too.
As this week progressed, the likelihood of Congress imposing a 90-percent tax on huge bonuses for executives at companies receiving federal bailouts slipped farther and farther from reality.
The N.C.A.A. Division I men's tournament gets underway today and there are some exciting matchups to watch all weekend. All the regional games will be televised.

With their stock prices hitting new lows, many companies are more vulnerable than ever to hostile approaches by rivals looking to scoop up valuable businesses at bargain prices. For those not interested in selling out in a down market -- even at a 100 percent premium to their current stock price -- beating back a predator or even an activist investor can be tough without the proper defenses in place.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey awarded a $338.8 million contract on Thursday to DCM Erectors, which will furnish, fabricate and erect the 22,000 tons of steel needed to construct the World Trade Center Transportation Hub from bedrock to street level. This does not include the distinctive birdlike canopy over the main hall.The effective steel price in the new contract is $9,000 a ton, the authority said, which is several hundred dollars less than the price per ton for the steel used in a recently built underground concourse.
The debate over the potential for green jobs creation in this country continues.

Crème brûlée, that silken buttercup-yellow custard topped with crunchy dark brown teeth-sticking caramel, has a mystique to it: that miraculous topping, and how it is achieved. Because chefs use small propane torches for this, many home cooks assume that these devices are needed to make that wonderful caramel. Using a stone-cold broiler, though, blackens the topping without exposing the custard to any more heat than necessary.

More than 27 million people reportedly have taken the RealAge health quiz, which asks questions about lifestyle and family history to determine how young or old your habits make you. Readers looking for more coverage of Formula One can now find a great deal more of it on nytimes.com. With the province reeling from steep manufacturing employment declines, the Ontario government introduced a $24 billion stimulus budget on Thursday that includes $593 million in green-economy spending, as well as $2.6 billion for transit projects, mostly in the Greater Toronto region.

A coalition of community organizations and advocates released a list of 64 policy proposals this week to combat the growing income inequality in New York City. The report, called the Blue Print for Economic Growth [pdf], is intended to balance what the groups describe as economic growth for growth's sake in recent decades. Those policies, the groups say, are an outmoded legacy of the 1970s, when the biggest challenge facing the city was to stem the loss of jobs."Now we can't rely on trickle down from Wall Street jobs, we need to build an economy that is fueled by a stronger middle class," said Paul Sonn, a legal director of the National Employment Law Project, one of the groups in coalition.

The controversial and long-delayed Cape Wind project - which could become the first offshore wind farm in the United States - is inching forward.

Taylor Phinney of the United States won the individual pursuit and Morgan Kneisky of France captured the scratch title at the track world championships in Pruszkow, Poland. Phinney outpaced Jack Bobridge of Australia with a time of 4 minutes 17.631 seconds to win his first world title. Bobridge finished almost three seconds back. Phinney, 18, the son of the 1984 Olympic medalists Connie Carpenter-Phinney and Davis Phinney, set an American record of 4:15.16 in qualifying earlier in the day, breaking the record he set at the World Cup last month in Copenhagen.

The owner Tom Hicks said he is looking for investors to purchase minority interests in two of his professional sports teams — baseball’s Texas Rangers and hockey’s Dallas Stars. At the Rangers’ spring training site, Hicks said he was willing to let limited partners purchase up to 49 percent of each club, leaving him with a controlling interest. Hicks said he owned 95 percent of both teams. One potential buyer is Nolan Ryan, who was hired as the Rangers’ president in February 2008.

The Giants said Thursday that they had sold more than 70,000 personal seat licenses at the 82,500-seat stadium they are building with the Jets. The remaining unsold P.S.L.’s are in the high-priced club areas, where they cost $7,500 to $20,000 each.

Serena Williams was voted the WTA Tour player of the year for the second time. Williams also received the award for 2002. She won the United States Open in September and ended last year ranked No. 1. Dinara Safina was selected most improved player in 2008, and Zheng Jie was chosen comeback player of the year..

After a year of embarrassing protests leading up to the Beijing Games, Olympic leaders called for an end to international torch relays starting next year in Vancouver. The torch relay turned into a convenient platform for protesters to denounce China’s human rights record. Some of the biggest protests were in London, Paris and San Francisco. In San Francisco, officials were forced to reroute the parade path to avoid confrontations. The I.O.C. announced the change at its three-day meetings in Denver, but said it did not require an adjustment of the contracts for host cities.

BOSTON -- The best thing that Duke can say about its N.C.A.A. tournament appearance this year is that at least the Blue Devils weren't mocked after losing. That's what happened last season when West Virginia guard Joe Mazzulla slapped the floor to parody a Duke tradition and Joe Alexander asked who among Duke's players were McDonald's all-Americans.

It was a topsy turvy world in Melbourne on Friday during the first day of practice of the new season as many of the weaker teams from last year turned the fastest laps, while the champions struggled along at the back of the field.

You might have heard of Terracycle -- Tom Szaky's worm poop story is now part of eco-folklore! Now, the first free-standing store dedicated to Terracycle's all-natural, all-organic, all-recycled products has opened in Red Hook, Brooklyn. Appropriately called Waste Nought, the store sells everything from kid-size backpacks made from recycled Capri Sun juice pouches and flowerpots made from e-waste (think old computers and fax machines) to all-purpose house cleaner and bird feeders packaged in discarded soda bottles. Waste Nought is also trying to encourage neighborhood "up-cycling" by producing local products from local waste (for example: collecting candle remnants from local restaurants, re-casting them, then selling them back to restaurants).

The Philip Morris Company did not like to talk about what went on inside its lab in Cologne, Germany, where researchers secretly conducted experiments exploring the effects of cigarette smoking. So when the Justice Department tried to get its hands on that research in 1996 to prove that tobacco industry executives had lied about the dangers of smoking, the company moved to fend off the effort with the help of a highly regarded young lawyer named Kirsten Rutnik.

DALRYMPLE--Dennis M.,died Thursday, March 5, in New York City. He was 67. He is survived by his wife, Jamie Raab, and their children, son Ian Dalrymple and daughter Lola Dalrymple. The cause of death was a cerebral hemorrhage. In a forty year career in book publishing as a literary contracts expert, he consulted with hundreds of authors, publishers and literary agents. He worked with such companies as Avon Books, Dell Publishing and Harper and Row (now HarperCollins), and then joined Warner Books as Director of Contracts where he stayed for 17 years. There, he met his wife, Jamie Raab, who is currently Publisher of Grand Central Books (formerly Warner Books). He was born in Waterloo, Iowa to Dwight Marion Dalrymple and Willa (Bette) Rasche, and grew up in Sarasota, Florida, before moving to New York City. Dennis loved New York City with the passion of a transplant, living first in Greenwich Village and in recent years on the Upper West Side. Mr. Dalrymple was a longtime anti-war activist who never met a war he wasn't prepared to protest. He was a founding member of the Youth International Party, its members known as Yippies, formed in 1967 by leftists and cultural icons Jerry Rubin, Abbie Hoffman and Paul Krassner to radicalize hippie youth to protest the Vietnam War. He also nominated Pigasus the Pig for President at the 1968 convention. Mr. Dalrymple was an avid news junkie, an expert cook, a loyal friend, and, most of all, a devoted husband and father. Mr. Dalrymple is also survived by his sister, Sandra Scanlan; his stepmother, Marion Dalrymple; his four half sisters Jennifer Heit, Julie Rexford, Jere Gilbert and Jane Murphy. A memorial services will be held on Thursday, March 19th at 4 pm at Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South in New York City.

AMBROSE--C. Clarke, died March 22 after a short illness. Clarke was the beloved husband of Joan, adored father of Steve and his wife Suzanne, and proud grandfather of Caroline. A graduate of Cornell School of Chemical Engineering and Harvard Business School he had a distinguished career as an Investment Banker at Harriman Ripley, Drexel Firestone, and E.F. Hutton. He served as Trustee of the Brick Presbyterian Church, and the Stanley Isaacs Center in New York City and the Florence Griswold Museum in Lyme Connecticut. The last ten years of his life were enlivened by his interest in Havanese dogs and dog shows. He had the good fortune to have a number of Champions who were very successful. He will be missed. Funeral service at The Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 91st Street, Tuesday March 31st at 2pm. Interment at Riverside Cemetery, Norwalk Connecticut, 4pm. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations be made to Havanese Rescue Inc c/o Harold Donner Treasurer 11246 Ramrod Road, Woodridge, VA 22192.

WOLFF--Louis, 96, beloved husband of Molly, devoted father of Norris, Sharyn, and Ira, and proud grandfather of Tamara, Erica, Abigail, Jonathan, Joseph, Aaron and Ilan, died peacefully in his home on Sunday, March 22, surrounded by his children and grandchildren. He was an extraordinary man, who starting working at age 10, and put himself through high school and college at night. No job was too small or too demeaning if it enabled him to keep working and learning. When he wanted to get a job on Wall Street he went into the tallest building he could find, took the elevator to the top floor and started walking down, knocking on every door on every floor until he found a company that would hire him. He eventually went to Bear Stearns, starting as a runner, and ending as the head of its research department until he joined the Army in 1941. When the war was over stock market doldrums forced him to seek a career away from the Wall Street that he loved, and eventually, with his brother-in-law and a friend, he founded Greenwald Industries, which became the dominant manufacturer of coin meters for laundromats, and revolutionized that industry. Financial success enabled him to do what he enjoyed the most-helping his extended family and friends, not just with a check, but with jobs, business opportunities, education and any way he could find to put them in a position to lead fruitful lives. It didn't matter if it was his family or his wife's, first cousins, second cousins, or relatives by marriage, Lou's generosity knew no bounds. For him, family was everything. His greatest pleasure was to be with as many members of his family as possible at Passover Seders and other celebrations and all who attended basked in his joy and radiant smile and felt privileged to share these moments with him. He had a special place in his heart for his beloved Molly, his wife for 66 years as she did for him. Even when he was ill his face would light up whenever she walked into the room, and family and friends who came to visit almost always found them sitting together, still holding hands and touching each other with the same affection and love they shared for almost seven decades. Lou was a role model to all who knew him. He craved success only so that he could provide for his family and help others. He was never envious of the success of others, and never said an unkind word about anyone, being gracious and complimentary to everyone he met. He filled a special, and irreplaceable, niche in the hearts of his family and friends and will be missed but not forgotten. We will remember his every act of integrity, compassion, courage and sacrifice that enriched, encouraged or empowered others and we will try to emulate his example. Contributions may be made in Mr. Wolff's honor to American Friends of Matan, 75 Seckle Pear Road, Levittown, PA 19056. His Family
DAN GRAHAM Marian Goodman

The South Region features the most impressive collection of big men in the tournament. Oklahoma's 6-foot-10 Blake Griffin and North Carolina's 6-9 Tyler Hansbrough are national player of the year candidates. Gonzaga's 6-11 Josh Heytvelt, once a sure-fire N.B.A. prospect who has struggled with foot injuries the past few seasons, led the Bulldogs in scoring and rebounding. Even Syracuse, without one defining skyscraper, makes up for it with two rugged 6-9 players, Rick Jackson and Arinze Onuaku. On Thursday, the day before top-seeded North Carolina played No. 4 Gonzaga and No. 2 Oklahoma played Syracuse, coaches and players expressed concern about the imposing opponents.

KREMER--Abraham J.,90, passed away on March 24, 2009 in Englewood, New Jersey. He was the beloved husband of Reba Goodman, father of Martin, Daniel, and Jonathan Kremer, brother of Joan Ringler, Leah Weitzman, and Simi Rosen, grandfather of eight, and uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Abraham was one of the founders of two advertising agencies Rosston, Kremer & Slawter and Warren/Kremer Advertising as well as a founder of the Frisch School and Yavneh Academy in Paramus. A passionate philanthropist, Abe was responsible for raising millions of dollars for charities including the UJA and P.E.F. Israel Endowment Funds, which he also served as president. A renowned collector of Judaica including a preeminent collection of the five megillot, in over 50 languages. He was president of the Jewish Book Council, and a Past Chairman of the United Jewish Appeal of Bergen County. Abe was also of critical assistance to the Jewish Theological Seminary. Funeral services will be held on Thursday March 26, 10:00am at the Frisch School, 120 W. Century Rd., Paramus, New Jersey.

With the shuttle Discovery safely away from the International Space Station, a Russian Soyuz rocket blasted off Thursday from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan carrying two fresh crew members and a wealthy space tourist. Under an overcast sky, the Soyuz TMA-14 spacecraft roared to life with a burst of flame and smoke at 7:49 a.m. Eastern time and smoothly climbed away from the same launch pad used by Yuri Gagarin at the dawn of the space age.

Spy satellites have detected what looks to be a Taepodong-2 long-range missile at the Musudan-ri launching site near North Korea's northeastern coast, South Korea's leading daily newspaper, Chosun Ilbo, reported on Thursday. The paper attributed the report to an unidentified diplomatic source. North Korea told international agencies this week that it planned to put a communications satellite into orbit between April 4 and April 8, but that is widely believed to be a cover story to test the Taepodong-2. Once the rocket was installed on the pad, missile experts said, it could be launched within three or four days.

FRANKLIN--John Hope. The American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the passing of John Hope Franklin, a distinguished Fellow for forty-four years. Renowned historian and teacher, ardent defender of civil rights, and dedicated adviser to presidents, he worked throughout his life to create One America. He was a courageous yet gentle man whose seminal scholarship and quiet actions reshaped our understanding of the nation. A grandson of a slave, he continued to champion the cause of racial equality with patience, determination, and dignity well into his ninth decade. We will miss him as both a monumental American figure and as an active colleague and friend of the Academy. Emilio Bizzi, President Louis Cabot, Chair of the Academy Trust and Vice President Jerrold Meinwald, Secretary Steven Marcus, Editor Leslie Berlowitz, Chief Executive Officer

His former students and colleagues remember him with affection and respect.

BOUCHER--Alma C.,89, died March 26, 2009, in Harrison, NY. She was a longtime resident of Boynton Beach, FL, and member of the Westchester Country Club, Harrison. She is survived by her son, Kenneth Boucher of Harrison, and daughter, Barbara Wells of Greenwich, CT, and grandchildren Griffin and Ryan Boucher, and Peter, Brian and Lesley Wells. Her husband, Joseph P. Boucher, predeceased her in 1993. Mrs. Boucher was an Emeritus member of the Auxiliary Board of St. Vincent's Hospital of Harrison. She received the hospital's prestigious St. Vincent's Award for her decades of fundraising for the hospital. Mrs. Boucher founded the hospital gift shop and later, Alma's Boutique, a holiday bazaar hosted at the club, which served as the setting for fundraising activities and holiday spirit, engendered by Mrs. Boucher's endless energy. FRANKLIN--John Hope. The Trustees and staff of the National Humanities Center are deeply saddened by the passing of John Hope Franklin on March 25. A Fellow at the Center from 1980 to 1982, Franklin joined the Center's board of trustees in 1982 and served until his retirement in 1991, when he was elected Trustee Emeritus. In 2000 the Center awarded the first John Hope Franklin Senior Fellowship, which is given annually to a scholar of American history or culture. All who knew John Hope Franklin at the National Humanities Center will remember with gratitude and admiration his friendship and wisdom.

LOEW--Mildred C. (Rodman) May 28, 1913 - March 6, 2009 Mildred was educator, mother and activist. The widow of esteemed artist, Michael Loew, she touched many lives. Mildred died peacefully in NYC after a long and fulfilling life. She will be missed. Mildred was 95 years old.

CHERNIN--Herbert, died peacefully at home on March 25th at the age of 92. Devoted husband of Phyllis for 32 years. Loving father of Philip, Peter, Andrew, Peggy, Stephen and Anthony. He was the much-loved grandfather of John, David, Margaret, Matthew, Brandon, Brian, Sara, John, Ariane, Georgia and Sam. He was the beloved nephew of Eleanor. He was the patriarch of an extended family of in-laws, cousins, nieces and nephews who will miss him dearly. He was pre-deceased by his first wife Mary. Herbert was the epitome of the self-made man. After graduating from City College he went on to serve as a Lieutenant Commander in the Navy where he was awarded the Purple Heart and the Silver Star. He then formed Braunstein & Chernin, a New York City accounting firm, where he worked for the next 60 years. Herbert was an innovative and successful businessman who helped to found Seaboard World Airlines. An early fitness buff, Herb was happiest when he was outdoors and reveled in skiing with his family, swimming and long daily walks. He went for his final swim the day before he died. Memorial services Sunday, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street). In lieu of flowers, please make donations in his name to City College of NY, Shephard Hall #
