HANNAS--Lucy, died March 6th, 2009 in Essex, CT. Lucy was born in Brooklyn, NY on August 5th, 1913. She and her husband Elwood moved from Hollis, Queens to Stony Brook, L.I. in 1961. She was predeceased by her husband, Elwood, who died in 1968. For three years after Elwood's death, Lucy maintained Elwood's second generation family wood business. In Stony Brook she was a secretary at the Three Village School District. She was also a member of the Stony Brook Community Church. Lucy remained at their residence until 2002. She moved to Essex Meadows in Essex, CT. She developed many close friends while living in CT. Her children, Marilyn Hannas Flood of New Providence, NJ and Warren Hannas of Old Lyme, CT mourn their loss. She is also survived by five grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. She was a remarkable lady and will be missed by the many people whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held on April 3rd at 1pm at Essex Meadows, Essex, CT. Donations may be made to RBC Ministries at www.rbc.org or to the Essex Meadows Scholarship Foundation, 30 Bokum Rd. Essex, CT 06426. BAKER--Hobart Amory Hare, beloved husband of Helen Baker, passed away March 25 2009 in Branford Connecticut where he had lived since 1984. Born in Cynwyd Pennsylvania in 1917 to Alfred Thorton Baker and Marie Griffiths Hall, Hobey was brother to Alfred Thorton (Bobbie), Henry Baker, Polly Baker, and Lawrence Baker. After attending the St. Paul's School in Concord NH, he studied fine arts and industrial design in New York, eventually founding a furniture company with his wife which produced innovative contemporary designs for over 30 years. An accomplished classical guitarist, water colorist, and photographer, Hobey was also known as a great sportsman. He was an outstanding squash player and while residing in New York was affectionately known as HobeyCat by his playing partners. An equally gifted tennis player, he was for many years a member of the Guilford Racquet Club. A dedicated life long sailor, Hobey in 1935 joined his father and older brother Bobbie on a world ocean cruise. Departing from Hong Kong where his family had commissioned the construction of a wooden Schooner, they sailed west arriving in the United Sates after two years at sea. Hobey was the namesake of his uncle Hobart Amory Hare Baker the renowned Princeton athlete and a descendent of the first Commodore of the New York Yacht Club John Cox Stevens. Hobey and Helen were members of the Second Church of Christ Scientist in New York before retiring to Branford where they became members of the First Church of Christ Scientist in Guilford. Hobey is survived by his wife, his two daughters Shawn of Great Barrington, Ma. and Deirdre of Branford, Ct., his grandchildren Christopher Morse, Paul Schiffer, Nicholas Morse, and Jordan Schiffer, and his great-grandchildren Olivia and Ryder Morse, and Amelia Schiffer. A free spirit who embodied gentleness, purity of heart, and strength of spirit along with a sly and joyful love of humor, Hobey was deeply loved by his family and a blessing to all who had the fortune of knowing him. A gathering will be held at.......... A Memorial Service in his honor will be announced by the family.

It's been remarkable to watch how malaria has become, over the last five years, a "cool" disease. After decades in which it received little funding or attention (that's partly our fault in the media), malaria is now a major cause, with funding pouring into everything from bednets to vaccines to research into genetic tinkering with mosquitoes so that they can't infect people with malaria. The upshot is going to be huge numbers of lives saved.

On his blog Kung Fu Monkey, the screenwriter John Rogers has collected a splendid lexicon of slang used and abused in "the big writing rooms in LA." The posts [one, two, three, four] may not be new (they date to 2005), but they are certainly noteworthy for those who have not stumbled across them before. ¶ Examples include: The Gilligan Cut - "When you cut directly from a character declaring there's no way he's going to do something, to him doing it, for comedic effect"; The Rake Bit - "Something that's funny, goes on too long so it's not funny, then goes on so long that it becomes INCREDIBLY funny"; and Gilding the Matzah - "Over-writing a joke, so it's no longer funny." ¶ Rogers links to an equally valuable glossary on The Artful Writer that lists, amongst other things, David Zucker's 23 comedy phrases.

A chart in the special DealBook section on Thursday about contributions from financiers to politicians, using information from the Center for Responsive Politics, misidentified the source of political action committee contributions in two instances. Donations came from political action committees of investments and affiliates of the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Blackstone Group. The firms do not have political action committees.

ROTTENBERG--Louis A.,of Glen Head, NY and Bermuda Dunes, CA, died peacefully on March 26, 2009 in California with his loving wife of 28 years, Muriel, and his two sons, Stuart and Peter Roberts, by his side. Born March 28, 1913 in Brighton, MA, he graduated from Boston University undergraduate in 1936 and its School of Medicine in 1940. During World War II, Lou served as a captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps and spent 36 months overseas in India, Egypt, Palestine, Libya, Tunisia, Sardinia, Italy and France. After WWII he joined the professional staff of New York's Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center where he became a dedicated Professor of Medicine until his retirement in 1979. Lou, who was a diagnostic radiologist, also had a private practice. His patients included President Herbert Hoover, Eleanor Roosevelt, Cyrus Vance, John D. Rockefeller III, Robert Moses, Spencer Tracy and Katherine Hepburn, among others. Not only is Lou survived by his wife and two sons, but also by his sister, Gert Wolfe, and four grandchildren. Ida, the mother of his children and wife of more than 40 years, passed away in 1980. A memorial service will be scheduled for later this spring on Long Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in memory of Louis Rottenberg to Eisenhower Medical Center Foundation, 39000 Bob Hope Drive, Rancho Mirage, CA 92270.

Citing national security, Australia blocked a natural resources acquisition that China was seeking. Australia's treasurer, Wayne Swan, said that he had decided to halt the purchase of OZ Minerals, a mining company, by the state-owned China Minmetals Corporation, because the Prominent Hill gold and copper mine, OZ's core asset, was near an important military facility. The chief executive of OZ Minerals, Andrew Michelmore, said the company and Minmetals were discussing potential changes to the deal and would make an announcement ''as soon as possible.'' Battered by falling earnings as raw materials have plunged, OZ Minerals urgently needs a cash injection.

Overnight, this city and its university went from active participants in the N.C.A.A. tournament to half-hearted spectators. Bars were filled on Thursday night with local fans watching the Memphis Tigers, and when they lost to Missouri, the deflated spirits were palpable. Outside FedEx Forum before the South Regional semifinals, a couple of men were having a friendly argument. One said he knew how the other felt. He was a Duke fan, he said, and his team lost, too. But the other said there was no comparison. Everyone knew Duke was an inflated second seed with no chance to win the national title, he argued. Memphis was a No. 2 that many considered one of the best teams in the country. And with Connecticut distracted by illicit recruiting allegations, the thinking went, the West Region was there for the taking for Memphis.

KELLY--Dorothy Ann. Sister Dorothy Ann Kelly, provincial superior of the Ursulines of the Eastern Province of the United States and former president of the College of New Rochelle, died on March 27. She served as president of the College of New Rochelle from 1972 to 1997, following five years as academic dean from 1967 to 1972. In 1997 she was appointed Chancellor at the College of New Rochelle. In 2001 she became superior of the Community of St. Teresa in New Rochelle. In 2003, she became provincial superior of the Eastern Province Ursulines. She served on the Board of Trustees at Georgetown University, St. Aloysius School in Harlem, and Catholic University of America; Bridges to Peace (formerly Northern Ireland Peace People), the U.S. delegation to the Fourth UN World Conference on Women, and the National Museum for Women in the Arts; commissioner on Higher Education of the Middle States Association of Schools and Colleges; Board of Directors of the American Council on Education, National Conference of Christians and Jews. She was a member of the Boards of the Interreligious Council of New Rochelle, the Westchester County Association, and Sound Shore Hospital Medical Center. She was born in 1929 in New York to Sarah McCauley Kelly and Walter D. Kelly. She graduated from the College of New Rochelle in 1951. She earned a master's degree in American Church History at the Catholic University of America in 1958, and a doctorate in American Intellectual History at the University of Notre Dame in 1970. She was predeceased by her sister, Eileen K. Short. She is survived by a brother, Walter Kelly of California, three nephews and two nieces. Visiting at the Castle at the College of New Rochelle on Sunday and Monday 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass at Holy Family Chapel at the College of New Rochelle on Tuesday10:30am. Interment at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be given to the Ursuline Development Office, 1338 North Ave, New Rochelle, NY 10804.

WOLFF--Louis, 96, beloved husband of Molly, devoted father of Norris, Sharyn, and Ira, and proud grandfather of Tamara, Erica, Abigail, Jonathan, Joseph, Aaron and Ilan, died peacefully in his home on Sunday, March 22, surrounded by his children and grandchildren. He was an extraordinary man, who starting working at age 10, and put himself through high school and college at night. No job was too small or too demeaning if it enabled him to keep working and learning. When he wanted to get a job on Wall Street he went into the tallest building he could find, took the elevator to the top floor and started walking down, knocking on every door on every floor until he found a company that would hire him. He eventually went to Bear Stearns, starting as a runner, and ending as the head of its research department until he joined the Army in 1941. When the war was over stock market doldrums forced him to seek a career away from the Wall Street that he loved, and eventually, with his brother-in-law and a friend, he founded Greenwald Industries, which became the dominant manufacturer of coin meters for laundromats, and revolutionized that industry. Financial success enabled him to do what he enjoyed the most-helping his extended family and friends, not just with a check, but with jobs, business opportunities, education and any way he could find to put them in a position to lead fruitful lives. It didn't matter if it was his family or his wife's, first cousins, second cousins, or relatives by marriage, Lou's generosity knew no bounds. For him, family was everything. His greatest pleasure was to be with as many members of his family as possible at Passover Seders and other celebrations and all who attended basked in his joy and radiant smile and felt privileged to share these moments with him. He had a special place in his heart for his beloved Molly, his wife for 66 years as she did for him. Even when he was ill his face would light up whenever she walked into the room, and family and friends who came to visit almost always found them sitting together, still holding hands and touching each other with the same affection and love they shared for almost seven decades. Lou was a role model to all who knew him. He craved success only so that he could provide for his family and help others. He was never envious of the success of others, and never said an unkind word about anyone, being gracious and complimentary to everyone he met. He filled a special, and irreplaceable, niche in the hearts of his family and friends and will be missed but not forgotten. We will remember his every act of integrity, compassion, courage and sacrifice that enriched, encouraged or empowered others and we will try to emulate his example. Contributions may be made in Mr. Wolff's honor to American Friends of Matan, 75 Seckle Pear Road, Levittown, PA 19056. His Family

A child diagnosed with hand, foot and mouth disease inhales atomized medicine in a clinic specialized for the disease in Wuhan. Chinese health authorities said that the disease has sickened about 41,000 people and killed 18 children across the country so far this year. Over 90 percent of the patients are under age 5.

KELLY--Sister Dorothy Ann, OSU. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Sister Dorothy Ann, OSU, Provincial Superior of the Eastern Province of the Ursulines and 11th President of the College (1972-1997). In an association of more than sixty years, she placed her considerable talents at the service of this College community, and thousands have been touched by her wisdom, caring and goodness. She brought her bright, inquiring mind to the College first as gifted student and then as much sought after faculty member, Dean and President. She lovingly took this College to new heights. American higher education and the American Church are the beneficiaries of this multi-talented, highly competent leader, who, above all, gifted us with the witness of the woman of faith. We mourn her loss and celebrate her extraordinary life. Stephen J. Sweeny, PhD President Michael Ambler, Esq. Chair, Board of Trustees

The regional semifinal games between Pittsburgh and Xavier and Duke and Villanova took on two distinct tenors Thursday night. The Xavier-Pittsburgh game had the feel of a rugby match, except with seemingly less scoring. Duke and Villanova had a more up-tempo feel, especially with the Wildcats running away with the game in the second half. But in the Pittsburgh locker room on Friday, the Panthers assistant coaches made sure to point out that Villanova was far from a finesse team.

The soldier's body was found near the center of Gettysburg with no identification - no regimental numbers on his cap, no corps badge on his jacket, no letters, no diary. Nothing save for an ambrotype (an early type of photograph popular in the late 1850s and 1860s) of three small children clutched in his hand. Within a few days the ambrotype came into the possession of Benjamin Schriver, a tavern keeper in the small town of Graeffenburg, about 13 miles west of Gettysburg. The details of how Schriver came into possession of the ambrotype have been lost to history. But the rest of the story survives, a story in which this photograph of three small children was used for both good and wicked purposes. First, the good.

Catcher Ronny Paulino has been traded for the second time in 24 hours and the third time since December, and he is now with the Florida Marlins. The Giants sent Paulino to Florida for the minor league pitcher Hector Correa. The deal was announced Saturday after Paulino was traded Friday to the Giants from the Phillies for pitcher Jack Taschner. Paulino was traded to the Phillies from Pittsburgh on Dec. 10 for catcher Jason Jaramillo. Paulino hit .212 last season.

Well Armed won the $6 million Dubai World Cup on Saturday to claim the richest prize in horse racing. The 6-year-old Well Armed, trained by Eoin Harty and ridden by Aaron Gryder, ran away from the 14-horse field. Gloria de Campeao was a distant second, and the favorite Albertus Maximus was back in the pack and never challenged for the lead in the 1.25-mile World Cup.

The 1987 Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner Alysheba has died at the age of 25. The champion stallion was euthanized Friday night at a medical center in Lexington, Ky. The Kentucky Horse Park said he was buried Saturday at its Hall of Champions. Alysheba won the Breeders’ Cup in 1988 and was Horse of the Year.

No. 5-seeded Venus Williams also won her opening match, beating Shahar Peer, 6-3, 6-3.

Tyler Evans’s long 3-pointer at the overtime buzzer lifted undefeated Findlay to a 56-53 victory against Cal Poly Pomona in the men’s Division II national championship game in Springfield, Mass. Evans, a senior reserve guard, hit a 26-footer from the right wing for his only basket of the game as Findlay (Ohio) completed a 36-0 season. Cal Poly Pomona (25-8) was trying to become the first unranked team to win the tournament since North Alabama in 1979.

The longest game in college lacrosse history ended in the seventh overtime when Virginia Coach Dom Starsia ran out of things to say. The No. 1 Cavs outlasted No. 9 Maryland on a goal by Brian Carroll in the first minute of the seventh overtime to give them a 10-9 victory. Starsia said that it was the first time in the overtimes that a coach had not called a timeout after taking the ball in their offensive end. Starsia told the offensive coordinator Marc Van Arsdale not to bother calling a timeout right before the goal.

Gebre-egziabher Gebremariam of Ethiopia won the men’s 12-kilometer race at the World Cross-Country Championships in Amman, Jordan, and Florence Jebet Kiplagat of Kenya took the title in the women’s 8K race. Gebremariam won on the hilly course in 35 minutes 2 seconds, while Kiplagat claimed her title in 26:13. Hilda Kibet of the Netherlands finished sixth.

An article last Sunday about places where fugitives hide these days misspelled the surname of one and misstated the year he disappeared. He is James “Whitey” Bulger Jr., not Bolger, and he disappeared in 1995, not 1999.

A picture caption on March 15 with an article about efforts to seal off Tibet may have left the impression that the policemen shown running alongside a bleeding man during a protest last year in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, were cracking down on him. To the Editor: Being in the international travel business, I found “The Baffling World of Visa Restrictions” (Practical Traveler, March 8) interesting.. Though hosted by a representative in the Libyan Tourism Ministry, I was still not assured that my United States clients would be able to enter Libya legally.

To the Editor: Regarding your Journeys article “Villagers in India Open Their Homes” (March 8): One doesn’t have to make a five-hour drive to experience village life in India. On two extensive trips to India, I found myself in villages just 30 minutes outside major cities.

To the Editor: Regarding “36 Hours: Shanghai” by Aric Chen (March 15): I have had the privilege of visiting this city several times since the mid-1980s. Since Mr. Chen allocates only two and a half hours to museum viewing, I recommend spending the time in the Shanghai Museum, with its important ancient Chinese artifacts that include an exceptional collection of bronzes. In fact, the museum is in the shape of an ancient Chinese bronze ritual vessel called a ding.

Because of an editing error, an article on March 8 about the muralist Kerry James Marshall quoted Megan Wilson, a fellow muralist, out of context. Virginia Heffernan doesn’t like mixed martial arts (The Medium, March 15). That’s fine. However, to describe another combat sport, boxing, as “classy” and “literary” makes me wonder what boxers she has been watching. Boxing has always been chock-full of people who stayed a bare half-step ahead of the law — and sometimes didn’t manage even that. It is and always has been a foul, sordid business where corruption is far closer to the rule than the exception.
An exhibition at the National Academy of Design explores the individual paths that a group of artists traveled after their one collective endeavor.

Arthur Lubow, in his article on Valery Gergiev (March 15), does not mention the maestro’s affiliation and stunning artistic triumphs with the Metropolitan Opera, where he was appointed principal guest conductor by Joe Volpe in 1997. I recall his 1994 Met debut conducting “Otello.” He was habitually late to rehearsals, and at first we orchestra players were amused by this un­shaven Russian with fiery, bloodshot eyes who conducted with a chopstick or toothpick instead of a baton. Moreover, his downbeats were vague and difficult to follow. Yet from the first performance, his competence and charisma overwhelmed us, and he generated a tension and excitement that had everyone playing and singing their hearts out.

After eight years of George W. Bush and his failed “Freedom Agenda,” it is not surprising to see that he is still as stubborn and arrogant as he was as president (James Traub, March 15). S.M.U. does itself a disservice by allowing a president who pre­sided over so much misery and failure, due to his recklessness and incompetence, to establish an institute in his name on his terms at the university. While there is much to learn about how not to act as president from the Bush 43 years, maybe a high-school campus in, say, Crawford would be a better location for his institute.

Because of an editing error, an article on March 15 about the proposed George W. Bush library and policy institute at Southern Methodist University omitted a sentence about the views of Thomas Knock, an S.M.U. professor who said in the article that a presidential library was good for a university. The additional sentence should have been: “But the prospect of a George W. Bush policy institute inside the walls of S.M.U. that was in no way beholden to academic principles or standards, responsible only to itself, appalled him, and many of his colleagues as well.”.

To the Sports Editor, Re ''After Stopping the U.S., Japan Is Back in the Final,'' March 23: Now that the cream of the American major leagues lost to a Japanese team in the World Baseball Classic, would it be too much to ask that ticket, parking and food prices be lowered to a level just below that in Japan after adjusting for currency exchange rates? Orin Hollander

BAKER--Hobart Amory Hare, beloved husband of Helen Baker, passed away March 25 2009 in Branford Connecticut where he had lived since 1984. Born in Cynwyd Pennsylvania in 1917 to Alfred Thorton Baker and Marie Griffiths Hall, Hobey was brother to Alfred Thorton (Bobbie), Henry Baker, Polly Baker, and Lawrence Baker. After attending the St. Paul's School in Concord NH, he studied fine arts and industrial design in New York, eventually founding a furniture company with his wife which produced innovative contemporary designs for over 30 years. An accomplished classical guitarist, water colorist, and photographer, Hobey was also known as a great sportsman. He was an outstanding squash player and while residing in New York was affectionately known as HobeyCat by his playing partners. An equally gifted tennis player, he was for many years a member of the Guilford Racquet Club. A dedicated life long sailor, Hobey in 1935 joined his father and older brother Bobbie on a world ocean cruise. Departing from Hong Kong where his family had commissioned the construction of a wooden Schooner, they sailed west arriving in the United Sates after two years at sea. Hobey was the namesake of his uncle Hobart Amory Hare Baker the renowned Princeton athlete and a descendent of the first Commodore of the New York Yacht Club John Cox Stevens. Hobey and Helen were members of the Second Church of Christ Scientist in New York before retiring to Branford where they became members of the First Church of Christ Scientist in Guilford. Hobey is survived by his wife, his two daughters Shawn of Great Barrington, Ma. and Deirdre of Branford, Ct., his grandchildren Christopher Morse, Paul Schiffer, Nicholas Morse, and Jordan Schiffer, and his great-grandchildren Olivia and Ryder Morse, and Amelia Schiffer. SILVERMAN--Edward (born November 23, 1928), died at home on March 18, 2009. BEIR--Robert L.,passed away March 27, 2009. Born April 24, 1918. Cherished husband of Joan. Adored father of Chip (Ilze), Juliette, Lisa (Dennis). Beloved grandfather of Amanda, Matthew and Natalie. Graduate of Collegiate Taft Brown Harvard Business School. Four years WWII served as Lieutenant in the Navy as Liasion Officer in Great Britain. Head of Arthur Beir & Company and The Beir Foundation. His real passion was history, which led to teaching high school students for ten years at Calhoun School and three years at Marymount College. Former President of Harmonie Club. Member of the United Nations Chairmans' Council and former Vice President of the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute. At 85 he with great pride wrote a book called "Roosevelt and the Holocaust". He was involved in many philanthropies. His capacity for forming meaningful and deep relationships with his family, friends, historians and students will leave a void for many people. Family will be receiving friends at Campbells Funeral Chapel on Sunday, March 29 5pm-7pm. Funeral at Beir Chapel at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street. Funeral 10:30am, Monday, March 30. HANNAS--Lucy, died March 6th, 2009 in Essex, CT. Lucy was born in Brooklyn, NY on August 5th, 1913. She and her husband Elwood moved from Hollis, Queens to Stony Brook, L.I. in 1961. She was predeceased by her husband, Elwood, who died in 1968. For three years after Elwood's death, Lucy maintained Elwood's second generation family wood business. In Stony Brook she was a secretary at the Three Village School District. She was also a member of the Stony Brook Community Church. Lucy remained at their residence until 2002. She moved to Essex Meadows in Essex, CT. She developed many close friends while living in CT. Her children, Marilyn Hannas Flood of New Providence, NJ and Warren Hannas of Old Lyme, CT mourn their loss. She is also survived by five grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. She was a remarkable lady and will be missed by the many people whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held on April 3rd at 1pm at Essex Meadows, Essex, CT. Donations may be made to RBC Ministries at www.rbc.org or to the Essex Meadows Scholarship Foundation, 30 Bokum Rd. Essex, CT 06426. Robinson, Wright & Weymer Funeral Home, Centerbrook, CT is in charge of the services.

BEFORE AND AFTER The banks of the Mill River in Stamford are bare, left, after workers cut down nearly 100 cherry trees that were a gift to the city from an immigrant business owner in 1957. Stamford officials removed the trees, shown in May 2007, below, to make way for a $6 million restoration of the property, including the removal of the Mill River dam. Some residents protested the decision, but city officials have said that the trees were in poor health, and that they plan to plant more than 100 new trees in a later phase of the restoration.

KOENIG--Daniel T.,68, on March 24, 2009. Beloved husband and best friend of Marilyn for 46 years, proud father of Michael (Donna) and Alan (Cindy), adoring grandpa of Alison and Jillian, devoted brother of Bonnie. Engineer, intellect, educator and most-of-all gentleman. Forever in our hearts.

SHINAGEL--Fran, 72, died at home on March 8 following ten years of decline. After 48 years of marriage, she is survived by her dedicated husband Fred, her daughters Nina and Eva, and one grandson. Fran loved good and good looking food and spent much of her professional and personal life making both. A graduate of NYU, she worked as a food stylist, recipe tester, co-authored "How Cooking Works," taught food sciences at NYU and New School, and managed J.B. Prince and Co.'s showroom. She loved good tomatoes, a well-braised lamb shank, and was only willing to eat out if they could make something she wouldn't. In her free time, she hunted mushrooms with the New York Mycological Society. She began her professional life (and life as a New Yorker) working as an airline attendant for Pan Am in 1956. There will be no memorial service at this time.

ROTTENBERG--Louis A.,of Glen Head, NY and Bermuda Dunes, CA, died peacefully on March 26, 2009 in California with his loving wife of 28 years, Muriel, and his two sons, Stuart and Peter Roberts, by his side. Born March 28, 1913 in Brighton, MA, he graduated from Boston University undergraduate in 1936 and its School of Medicine in 1940. During World War II, Lou served as a captain in the U.S. Army Medical Corps and spent 36 months overseas in India, Egypt, Palestine, Libya, Tunisia, Sardinia, Italy and France. After WWII he joined the professional staff of New York's Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center where he became a dedicated Professor of Medicine until his retirement in 1979. Lou, who was a diagnostic radiologist, also had a private practice. His patients included President Herbert Hoover, Eleanor Roosevelt, Cyrus Vance, John D. Rockefeller III, Robert Moses, Spencer Tracy and Katherine Hepburn, among others. Not only is Lou survived by his wife and two sons, but also by his sister, Gert Wolfe, and four grandchildren. Ida, the mother of his children and wife of more than 40 years, passed away in 1980. A memorial service will be scheduled for later this spring on Long Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in memory of Louis Rottenberg to Eisenhower Medical Center Foundation, 39000 Bob Hope Drive, Rancho Mirage, CA 92270.

BOYD R. Maurice, 77, of New York City and Tobermory, Ontario died on March 24, 2009 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Dr. Boyd was a preacher, author, and lecturer of international renown, and created a radio ministry that engaged listeners throughout the tri-state area. I WAS able to test drive the Tata Nano last week in Pune, India, and came away with a few impressions of this $2,000 car. It has a 32-horsepower, 624 cc, 2-cylinder engine mounted in the rear, and despite being a fraction of the size of most economy-car engines, the all-aluminum motor provides reasonable pep. Engine noise is also far less than one may imagine. Still, acceleration is hardly neck-snapping. An informal timed run from zero to 50 miles an hour took 16.4 seconds; a Tata engineer said the company's time is about one second faster.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Anti-Fighting Moves Strike Some Players as Cosmetic,'' March 15: If 75 percent of N.H.L. players believe steps should be taken to reduce head shots, how can the general managers not take action? Certainly the players are well compensated for playing a game they love, but with research showing multiple concussions can lead to higher rates of depression, cognitive disorders and Alzheimer's disease, how can executives fail to act?

DOMESTIC DISTURBANCES It's hard to write about, even admit to, simple happiness. It feels somehow indecent. Embarrassing. Immodest. Inappropriate as a topic of conversation for intelligent people. What I'm trying to get at is, I suppose, some variation of Tolstoy's observation about happy families, which always makes for a nicely quotable sentence but is, perhaps, wrong. Perhaps happiness is interesting, because it isn't, in fact, simple or uncomplicated. Perhaps the real thing isn't just a Hallmark card sentiment. For me, I realized in that moment, happiness is inextricably bound up in striving. In straining for achievement, of whatever kind. In having a challenge and making it to the other side. It doesn't much matter what the challenge or object of achievement is. If none is obvious, one always presents itself.

The N.C.A.A. has done a remarkable job of making every game site look the same. The court in Boston looks like the one in Glendale, Ariz., even if one is set inside a basketball arena and the other inside a football stadium. The N.C.A.A. supplied its own courts and outlined them in black and blue. On one black baseline in Glendale, it reads Glendale in blue letters. On the other, it reads University of Phoenix Stadium. In Boston, the letters read Boston on one end and TD Banknorth Garden on the other. Each host team is represented by a small on-court logo. Otherwise, the courts look identical.

REID--Daniel M.,January 1, 1920 March 26, 2009, passed away peacefully with Rhoda, his wife of 66 years, by his side. He lived in Greenwich, CT, Nantucket, MA, Rancho Mirage, CA, and to the end of his life traveled the world with his beloved Rhoda, even to the most unlikely and remote places. For the past 20 years, he took great pleasure reprising his greatest trips with his children Addie (Bradford Powell), Ivy, Andrew (the late Laura Reid), Robin (Paul Mickey), and grandchildren Adam Powell and Sarah and Rachel Reid. A World War II pilot, he was a co-founder and partner of Crazy Horse Apparel Company, President and Honorary Board Member of The Federation of the Handicap (now Fedcap Rehabilitiation Services), and an avid tennis, golf and bridge player. As one who liked to seize the moment, he lived life to the full, his way. He remembered where he came from through his many acts of personal generosity. Donations in his name would have pleased him greatly if made to the Fedcap Rehabilitation Services (formerly named Federation of the Handicapped), 211 West 14th Street, New York, NY 10011, 212-727-4245, jhughes@fedcap.org

THE NEWS The Metropolitan Transportation Authority board voted to make commuting in the New York area much more costly: subway, bus and commuter rail fares and bridge and tunnel tolls would rise at least 20 percent to 30 percent, with broad cuts in service. BEHIND THE NEWS The board said a looming $1.2 billion budget deficit left it no choice. But the real aim of the proposals was to rattle state political leaders enough to break an impasse over a rescue for the M.T.A. The governor and Assembly leaders have a plan for a much smaller fare increase and no service cuts, but it would add tolls on East River bridges that are now free, an idea facing resistance in the State Senate.

Outside the Look that marks an era, there are always other currents. And in Paris recently, they were a delight to the eye: the revived Sergeant Pepper jacket; new takes on the mini-crin; full bell-shape skirts; peasant embroideries; and that Renaissance must-have, the forehead band. Anna Piaggi, top right, of Italian Vogue, the mistress of all that is colorful and joyous, strolled by. Designers in New York were dressing Barbie for her 50th birthday, but in Paris they were dressing some famous mice, above at the Musée Galliera and at the Warhol show in the Grand Palais.

GRIMES--Harold Gunther, 88, born December 3, 1920, in Bronx, NY, died March 11, 2009, in Walpole NH. Husband (for 59 years minus three months) of Mary Dundon Grimes, son of Thomas A. and Violet Zetsche Grimes, brother of the late Thomas R. Grimes, uncle of Christine Grimes Hudson and the late Michael J . Grimes, cousin of Jan Zetsche Finch and Robert L. Banks. After service as a corporal in the Army Air Force in World II, he returned to NYU graduate school, where he completed course work for a master's degree. There followed a short, unhappy period with the New York City Department of Welfare, and almost three decades with the International Rescue Committee, a non-sectarian agency for political and religious refugees, where he worked with individual refugees on resettlement and representation at hearings. He traveled widely, setting up IRC offices in such places as Uganda, India, Vietnam, Rome, Stockholm, Los Angeles, Miami, and the IRC office at the Hungarian Reception Center at Camp Shanks in New Jersey. He was a resident of Manhattan and Brooklyn, where he volunteered at theCHIPS soup kitchen. He retired to Bellows Falls, Vt. and Walpole, NH. For information call 603-445-5505

COHEN--Joel, Writer and Television Executive. Joel Cohen, an executive with ABC for several decades, died March 13th at the Pax Christi Hospice at age 90. A creative force in New York media for almost 40 years in radio, advertising and finally the ABC network, Mr. Cohen was also a master of many poetic styles: the sonnet, the epic and the limerick, leaving many witty and well-loved examples. His 1942 wartime wedding, a story of lost love found and the stunts pulled to get married on the same day he shipped out, inspired a Judy Garland film, The Clock. The movie was based on a story by Paul Gallico, to whom he had recounted his travails when they met during WWII. After the war, Mr. Cohen worked in radio and advertising before joining ABC in 1961 and rising eventually to Vice President of Special Projects. To everything he worked on, he brought intelligence, innovation and wit. His beloved wife of 55 years, Dorothy Quaintance Cohen, passed away in October 1997. Mr. Cohen is survived by his three children: Recia Loraine Wilson and her husband William of Washington, DC, Peter Dale Cohen and his wife Frances of New York City, and David Michael Cohen and his wife Ivonne of Bedford Hills, NY. There are 5 grandchildren: Peter Cohen, Thomas and Kathryn Wilson, Natasha and Sarah Cohen, and one Great-Grandchild, Vanya Cohen. Donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association - alz.org (800)272-3900, or The Pax Christi Hospice in New York 212-995-6480

WEBER--Dudley, 76, of Lynbrook, NY passed away on March 27th, 2009 in Horsham, PA. Dr. Weber is survived by his children Adam (Haley) Weber, Noah (Amy) Weber, Ruth (Benjamin) Cohen. Granddaughters Emily Weber, Sedona Pearl and Eve Giselle Cohen and his former wife Linda Weber. Dudley was the beloved son of Dr. Samuel and Dorothy Weber. Brother of the late Karen Blumencranz and cousin Dr. Arthur Herold of West Bloomfield, MI. Dr. Weber was a graduate of Hofstra University and the University of Bologna Medical School. Dr. Weber was a forensic pathologist and former Deputy Chief Medical Examiner of the City of New York. Dr. Weber was a member of the Society of Anatomic, Forensic and Neuropathology. Dr. Weber was on the faculty of New York University Medical Center and was an author of several forensic pathology textbooks. Dr. Weber was in a family practice in Lynbrook, NY for 20 years. Memorial Contributions can be made to the Abramson Center, 1425 Horsham Rd, North Wales, PA, where Dr. Weber spent the final years of his life. A graveside service will be held Sunday, 2pm at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY.

KELLY--Sister Dorothy Ann, OSU. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Sister Dorothy Ann, OSU, Provincial Superior of the Eastern Province of the Ursulines and 11th President of the College (1972-1997). In an association of more than sixty years, she placed her considerable talents at the service of this College community, and thousands have been touched by her wisdom, caring and goodness. She brought her bright, inquiring mind to the College first as gifted student and then as much sought after faculty member, Dean and President. She lovingly took this College to new heights. American higher education and the American Church are the beneficiaries of this multi-talented, highly competent leader, who, above all, gifted us with the witness of the woman of faith. We mourn her loss and celebrate her extraordinary life. Stephen J. Sweeny, PhD President Michael Ambler, Esq. Chair, Board of Trustees

The term reconciliation typically conveys a sense of rapprochement reminiscent of restored ties between the United States and China or Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis. But in Congress, reconciliation can mean the opposite, conjuring up relationships more along the lines of Yankees versus Red Sox or Microsoft versus Apple. Republicans are in a tizzy that Democrats are threatening to use the budgetary procedure known as reconciliation -- it reconciles policy with fiscal guidelines -- to overhaul the health care system, possibly enact legislation on climate change and rewrite education policy.

LOOKING FOR WILDLIFE ON A SUNSET CRUISE IN CHOBE NATIONAL PARK, BOTSWANA, DEC. 18, 2008 Megan Stewart, 28, an agricultural missionary from Melbourne, Fla. ''I'm in Botswana three months out of the year, working for the Livingstone Mission Center. But my husband had never been to Africa, so he went for the holidays. And it was the first time I had been there in their summer, so everything was different because it's so green. It was a neat experience for me as well. The animals and everything are great, but the thing that blows me away is the culture of Africa. It's definitely very real and tangible. Everything's more difficult: for example, it's very common for them to walk a couple of miles to get to their destination. But when you're walking a mile to get somewhere, which I have done in Africa many times, you feel your surroundings. There's more of a fullness of life. When you're in America and you're driving in your car, you can't even remember buildings that you pass by most of the time. In Africa, you see everything.'' As told to Seth Kugel

Since last year, I have gone through the dreaded college admissions process, and as it stands right now I still have much ahead of me. I applied to two out-of-state universities, the University of Pittsburgh and the University of Massachusetts-Amherst, as well as eight schools in the SUNY system. I applied to Pittsburgh and Amherst for several reasons. The urban setting, strong reputation, and premier Division 1 athletics of Pittsburgh were very intriguing, as well as the scenic, large town campus of UMass.

As an aspiring journalist, I sought out schools that had either a great journalism program (like Emerson College or Syracuse University’s Newhouse School) or a fantastic liberal arts program (like New York University). My hope was that I would be able to practice what I one day wish to call my craft, while immersing myself in everything else college has to offer. I would be over the moon if I was to be accepted by any of these three schools. I’m choosing not to think about financial aid packages, which will likely play the largest part in where I actually go, until I have to.

New York City Center has announced next season’s Encores! schedule. “Girl Crazy,” with music by George Gershwin and lyrics by Ira Gershwin, and book by Guy Bolton and Jack McGowan, will open the season on Nov. 19 and run through Nov. 22. “Fanny,” with music and lyrics by Harold Rome and book by S.N. Behrman and Joshua Logan, will run Feb. 4-7, 2010, becoming the 50th Encores! Madonna’s attempt to adopt a second child from Malawi is expected to be ruled on by a Malawian court on Friday, Reuters reports. The singer’s effort to adopt 4-year-old Mercy James from the southern African country could be opposed by some human rights groups, who were critical of Madonna’s adoption of her Malawian son, David Banda. The critics said government authorities had given the pop singer special treatment and skirted laws that ban nonresidents from adopting Malawian children. One of Madonna’s lawyers said, in comments outside the courtroom, that the singer was asking the court to grant her an interim adoption of about 18 months. A local newspaper quoted Madonna, 50, as saying that her Malawian friends had told her that David needed a brother or sister.

Manuel said Murphy would be the Mets' regular No. 2 hitter, which pushes Castillo to eighth. Both players were hitting in those spots Monday night against the Orioles. Manuel said that he thought Castillo's high on-base percentage (.459) would transfer to the bottom of the order and that he didn't want to limit Murphy's at-bats by hitting him low.

This is the year that both the New York Yankees and the New York Mets open new stadiums, with fewer seats than the stadiums they replace. Both also have raised prices to levels that only an unlimited expense account could appreciate.
President Obama announced his plans for G.M. and Chrysler this morning, including tough terms and tight deadlines for both companies. He also raised the possibility of bankruptcy as one way forward.

If one spouse travels all the time on business, especially around the globe, it can be stressful on a marriage. It may help if a couple can travel together -- on the company's dime. That is the situation for Ronald J. Halls, the president and chief executive of the international division at athletic retailer Foot Locker.

After becoming international wheelers and dealers just a few years ago, sovereign wealth funds have staged a retreat. Instead of hunting for bargains beyond their borders, many of these government-run investment pools seem to be staying close to home.
CBS ranked No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday aided by live college basketball coverage from the afternoon as well as the newsmagazine mainstay "60 Minutes."

Green Inc. readers are encouraged to share their own thoughts and experiences in the comments section -- or by sending e-mail to greeninc@nytimes.com.
It's time to think about the Oscars - or it is if you happen to be a film distributor with ambitions for the award season that, thankfully, won't start for the rest of us until at least September.

MILLBURN -- A Millburn youth and an 18-year-old Short Hills man were arrested for marijuana possession during a week that ended with school officials announcing that police with drug-sniffing dogs will begin random searches of Millburn High School. The arrests are among the crimes reported this week in the weekly Millburn police blotter, a round-up of crimes investigated by the Millburn Police Department. The blotter is released to the public by Capt. James Miller, patrol commander/public information officer, and is edited and condensed by The Local.

A wise hockey man once said that teams can do some amazing things when they are "staring into the abyss," when they are looking at postseason extinction. Whether it's during the regular season and the chances of making the playoffs look bleak, or facing elimination in a series, clubs frequently summon up a reserve of inner strength to stay defiantly in the picture, as if the flames of hell licking their feet moves them to greatness.
Many economists say that putting more money in the hands of the unemployed is one of the most effective forms of economic stimulus. City Room wanted to test that proposition.

Some old-time football players aren't happy with the so-called Brady Rule, the recent adjustment to league rules that prohibits a defensive player who is down from lunging at a quarterback's legs.Scott Clair of The Naples Daily News listened in Friday as Hall of Famers like Sonny Jurgensen, Jack Youngblood, Mike Ditka, Jim Hart and Billy Kilmer spoke about the rule at the Mike Ditka/Jim Hart Celebrity Golf Invitational in Naples, Fla.
A New York Times article on Friday looks at the hot word in the food supply: "traceability."
I enjoy returning from vacation. It provides me the opportunity to reassess the market in light of the changes that have occurred.

It's no secret that real estate values in Las Vegas have been among the hardest hit in the country. While that's bad news for sellers, buyers and even some renters are clearly benefiting from the lower prices.

The actress Alyssa Milano - "the star of such iconic TV shows as 'Who's the Boss?' and 'Charmed,' " as her publisher puts it - has just come out with a book called "Safe at Home: Confessions of a Baseball Fanatic." Milano is crazy about the Dodgers and has even secured a foreword from their manager, Joe Torre. (Can you blame him? She looks good in blue.)

Will Rick Wagoner be remembered as the chief executive who nearly drove General Motors off a cliff or the martyr who sacrificed himself in G.M.'s darkest hour to insure the company would receive more of the government bailout money that G.M. needed to survive?

For decades Berlin has been a model of creativity despite the lack of local business tycoons and hedge fund managers to patronize its artists. So, as New York's financial sector evaporates, Berlin provides some illuminating examples of what the arts may look like here in the near future.

Maybe the man who breathes through a hole in his throat did not move you. Perhaps you were unfazed by the removal of fatty deposits from a patient's neck and the amputation of a gangrenous foot. And it's possible that you weren't paying attention when Marie, the woman missing four fingers (and bits of three more), made her debut -- and that you didn't notice when Marie left her house to help take 311 calls.

Politics as usual in New York State: The proposal to permit groceries in New York to sell wine, as is permitted in 35 other states, died quietly in secretive budget negotiations over the weekend between state legislators and Gov. David A. Paterson, according to Danny Hakim, the Times's Albany bureau chief.

President Obama announced what amounts to a do-or-die ultimatum for the struggling automobile industry on Monday, laying out strict standards that the carmakers must meet to get more government aid and declaring that the industry must survive because it is "like no other, an emblem of the American spirit," The New York Times's Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Bill Vlasic report.

Appearing on our virtual refrigerator today: Becky, an eighth grader at Millburn Middle School, created this collage in a mixed media assignment. We like the lightbulb in the middle, reminds us of great ideas coming from young minds.

Eleven groups doing conservation work or biological research in Madagascar have issued a joint statement decrying a surge in raids on the country's national parks for valuable timber, smuggling of rare wildlife and other activities abetted by the unrest and political instability there. There is some awkward phrasing in the document, which is pasted below, but the sense of deep concern is clear. Many species in the extraordinary ecosystems of Madagscar, which evolved in isolation for tens of millions of years, are found only in small numbers there, or in zoos -- as with the fossa in this video.

"High School Musical 3" won top honors at the year's best movie at Nickelodeon's Kids' Choice Awards over the weekend. The Hollywood Reporter covered the event, too. Among the other winners were Will Smith for best movie actor and Vanessa Hudgens, from "High School Musical 3," for best movie actress. Dwayne Johnson was the emcee.
Update | 3:01 p.m. The market for initial public offerings has been slow for months now. But Jonathan J. Ledecky thinks firms like his can still help bring companies public.

Brennan Bosch of the Medicine Hat Tigers ensured there would be one first-round series in the Canadian Hockey League that goes to seven games as he scored twice in Medicine Hat's 3-0 victory at home over Swift Current last night. It is the latest in a series of big goals scored by Bosch.

Scallops among the least risky of shellfish to eat raw, and true bay scallops are perhaps best that way, popped into your mouth like little marshmallows. Cooked, it's best to treat them minimally, as we do here. The season for them is just about ending, so get them while you can.
We teach our children "Good Touch/Bad Touch." Now preteens in Milford, Conn. are learning "No Touch."
Bernard Purdie, one of the most prolific drummers in history, is best known for a rhythm called the Purdie Shuffle.

The first time I came to Dunedin Stadium, in 1994, I talked with Paul Molitor of the Blue Jays about mechanics. Molitor hit with no stride at all, just a half-turn of his left foot as he swung. He had destroyed the Phillies this way in the World Series just a few months before, and he wound up in the Hall of Fame.

On a recent afternoon, two members of the Maplewood Police force surveyed my home with skeptical eyes, looking for ways that burglars could penetrate the 93-year-old structure and its detached garage.

Rick Wagoner, G.M.'s chief executive, who was forced to step down last night by President Obama's auto task force, wasn't alone, at least not in spirit. PSA Peugeot Citroën, the No. 2 automaker in Europe behind Volkswagen, fired its chief executive, Christian Streiff, Sunday night. The company will replace him with Philippe Varin, chief executive of Corus, a British steel company that was bought out by Tata Steel in 2007.

Karen O, the banshee-like frontwoman for Yeah Yeah Yeahs, is one of the ought's most captivating performers and something of a Gen Y style icon. But she is more than that: she is an artist in her own right who scored the music to Spike Jonze's new film, "Where the Wild Things Are," studied film at the Tisch School of the Arts and recently exhibited a piece of sculpture at the Fuse Gallery in downtown Manhattan. The Moment caught up with the outrageous Ms. O to discuss her band's excellent -- and vastly different-sounding -- new album, "It's Blitz," and also to discover her personal aesthetic and why she was voted "Most Atypical" in high school.

Hong Kong | There are only a few weeks a year when the weather is perfect for outdoor eating in Hong Kong: A brief spell in the spring, before the humidity envelops the city like a wet wool blanket, and an even shorter period in the fall, before the blustery weather that passes for winter in this tropical climate really sets in.

DUBLIN -- There is a fierce devotion to the national soccer team here in the Republic of Ireland. So much of the national spirit depends on the team, and that devotion transcends the natural impulse of national pride. It's the same with the other Celtic countries in world soccer -- Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. It's about England, mostly. It's about beating the English at their own game.

President Barack Obama's NCAA basketball picks have been well-documented, thanks to ESPN, which scored an interview with him two weeks ago in which he meticulously went through his selections with the sports network's college hoops guru, Andy Katz.

Another Monday, another puzzle and prize to start the week (or at least postpone work for a moment.) Lots of readers quickly solved last week's 100-Hat Puzzle (and you can find an explanation of the solution here). But you may have a tougher time with this one.

Today is the one-year anniversary of the death of Dith Pran, the survivor of Cambodia's Killing Fields and battler of genocide who was also a photographer for The Times, based in New Jersey. He took dozens of pictures for The Times of Maplewood, Millburn and South Orange.
House and Senate Democrats intend to pass their respective budgets by the end of the week before Congress heads out on a two-week Easter break.

Campaigning across the five boroughs, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg opened a new phase of his re-election bid over the weekend, arguing that the city was "headed in the right direction" and saying that his steady hand and nonpartisan style were needed to "keep making this city better."

Concluding the most secretive budget negotiations in recent memory, Gov. David A. Paterson and leaders of the Legislature outlined a $131.8 billion agreement on Sunday that would close the state's gaping deficit with billions of dollars in new taxes, financing from the federal stimulus and a substantial slowdown in the growth of health care spending.

Nicholas Dawidoff's article about Freeman Dyson in the Times Magazine nicely captures Mr. Dyson's independent spirit as well as a couple of other appealing traits: humanism and optimism. While so many other scientists and intellectuals fret about humans ruining the planet -- and some even revel in fantasies about a world free of our pernicious presence -- Mr. Dyson has long had faith in humans' ability to deal with problems like nuclear weapons and global warming.

TUI Travel, Europe's biggest travel company, said Monday that it is paying 28.5 million euros ($37.6 million) for a 19.9 percent stake in a German airline, Air Berlin.

Fifth Third Bancorp said on Monday that it had signed a deal to sell a 51 percent stake in its payment processing unit to a private equity firm, Advent International, for $561 million.

The Blackstone Group, the world's largest publicly listed private-equity firm, rejected a request from the Securities and Exchange Commission to disclose the performance of its buyout and hedge funds in its financial reports, Bloomberg News reported, citing letters the regulator released earlier this month.
American International Group has cut or delayed payments to some of its real-estate ventures, potentially leaving the developers and their bankers in the lurch, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Switzerland's UBS is expected to announce more write-downs and job cuts in the coming days, the Swiss newspaper Sonntag reported on Sunday.
In recent years, despite many challenges to his leadership of General Motors, Rick Wagoner had managed to keep a firm grip on his job, like hands wrapped tight around a steering wheel.
CF Industries Holdings, the United States fertilizer company, has rejected a sweetened $3.8 billion hostile bid from a Canadian rival, Agrium, calling the offer "grossly inadequate."

Stocks fell sharply in Europe and Asia on Monday, amid fears that the Group of 20 meeting this week would fail to come up with a plan to restart global growth and signs of chaos in the auto industry, The New York Times's David Jolly and Bettina Wassener reported.

Citigroup is inviting bids for Nikko Cordial, Japan's third-largest brokerage, in an auction that could net the struggling United States-based financial giant more than $5 billion, The Financial Times reported, citing people close to the situation.
The regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is looking at ways the two firms might help finance small mortgage banks hobbled by a dearth of credit, The Wall Street Journal reported.

The White House on Sunday pushed out the chairman of General Motors and instructed Chrysler to form a partnership with the Italian automaker Fiat within 30 days as conditions for receiving another much-needed round of government aid.
Abu Dhabi's planned $10 billion bond sale has gotten high marks from three major credit agencies.
The French automaker PSA Peugeot Citroën fired its chief executive Sunday and replaced him with a veteran of the steel industry.

Frog Capital, the London-based venture capital firm previously known as Foursome Ventures, has revised itself with a new chieftain and plans to target new investments in information technology and digital media.

Ever since the eruption of public fury over bonuses paid at the American International Group, many have pressed the federal government to sue the embattled insurance company to recoup those hundreds of millions of dollars.

As opening day draws near, The Times will be previewing the Yankees' and Mets' coming seasons from all angles, with analysis by Tyler Kepner, Ben Shpigel, Jack Curry and many others. But with so much happening this off-season, there are a lot of opinions to go around. We reached out to some top Yankees and Mets bloggers and got their thoughts on the 2009 season.
Donald J. Trump isn't lacking for opinions. And he has plenty to share on the economy, the American International Group and Bernard L. Madoff.

With fewer than 3,000 residents, Glascock County is not big enough to have its own hospital, jail or Wal-Mart. But for more than 100 years, it had a bank - until late last Friday afternoon, when regulators arrived to shut it down, The New York Times's Shaila Dewan reported.

This week, Susan A. McLean, the executive director of Literacy Partners, answered readers' questions about the statistics and contributing factors of illiteracy, financing for programs and other resources for those seeking help in New York. Sorry, we are no longer taking questions for this feature.

Big Blue is laying off another 5,000 workers in North America, in news first reported last week by The Wall Street Journal. And I.B.M. is taking the step in the same way it handled the previous 4,600 layoffs this year: without making any public announcement.
The Huffington Post said Sunday that it would bankroll a group of investigative journalists and make the nation's economy an initial priority for coverage.

UBS, the Swiss bank under a growing federal investigation for tax fraud, has forced out the executive formerly in charge of secret offshore accounts for wealthy Americans, the bank said Sunday, according to The New York Times's Lynnley Browning.
If only financial giants could be allowed to fail in a safe way.

Amid reports that I.B.M. is putting together a bid for Sun Microsystems, The 451 Group looks at the possible implications of such an acquisition for the software, server and storage markets. The analyst firm also looks at who else might be tempted to bid for Sun, which has yet to announce a formal deal.

Monday, 7:30 p.m. The Male Unbifurcated Garment movement began in the early 1990s, when a cross-dressing Swede named Roger Lewau launched a now-defunct Web site called the Skirts Lover Nest. Over the years, the movement has strived for civil rights in displays of pride that have included a march down Fifth Avenue, where dozens showed up in minis, tutus and full-length crimson ball gowns. Now comes "Dressed to Kilt," a fashion show hosted by the M.U.G.-wearing Scotsman Sean Connery. The models will include Andie MacDowell, the actress; Marcus Schenkenberg, the supermodel; and Robert Anderson, named in the show's promotional material as a "Scottish Hunk." Proceeds will benefit the Friends of Scotland, but M.U.G. men around the world will surely take note. M2 Ultra Lounge, 530 West 28th Street, Manhattan.

When Facebook signed up its 100 millionth member last August, its employees spread out in two parks in Palo Alto, Calif., for a huge barbecue. Sometime this week, this five-year-old start-up, born in a dorm room at Harvard, expects to register its 200 millionth user, The New York Times's Brad Stone reported Sunday.
Will the Treasury Department's latest plan to save the American banking system work?

Restructuring advisers and law firms that specialize in bankruptcy are enjoying a wave of new business, as more and bigger companies seek protection from creditors. The Deal looks at which firms are riding high in its latest league tables.
Score one for the biotech liquidators.

Marks & Spencer's executive chairman, Stuart Rose, faces a new shareholder vote on his controversial dual management role after an investor filed a resolution to the firm's annual general meeting calling on him to share power, Reuters reported.

Nearly seven years after National Century Financial Enterprises collapsed in a $2.9 billion fraud, its founder, Lance K. Poulsen, was sentenced to 30 years in prison on Friday in one of the harshest white-collar punishments in history, The New York Times's Zachery Kouwe reported.

Bank of America effectively set up a branch in a Long Island office that helped Nicholas Cosmo carry out a $380 million Ponzi scheme, according to a class-action lawsuit filed in federal court, The New York Times's Leslie Wayne reported.
Earlier this month, the European Commission set dates consigning the incandescent light bulb to the dustbin of history.
Today's idea: China is like the United States in the Great Depression, the world's major creditor on the cusp of global leadership. America is debt-depleted Britain of the same era.
Ritchie Capital, a hedge fund, has objected in a court filing to a "fire sale" of the bankrupt camera maker Polaroid, saying it will result in significantly less recovery proceeds, Reuters reported.

Sitting in a gilded upper room at 10 Downing Street last week listening to Prime Minister Gordon Brown outline his ambitions for reforming the world economy had something of an out-of-this-world feeling. With Mr. Brown seated beneath a 16th-century oil painting of Queen Elizabeth I, it was tempting to imagine for a moment that Britain was again rising grandly to the challenges of the age, in the way of Good Queen Bess, The New York Times's John F. Burns and Landon Thomas Jr. reported.
Omni National Bank of Atlanta was seized by federal regulators, the 21st bank in the United States to fail this year.
Meruelo Maddux Properties, one of the largest developers and landlords in downtown Los Angeles, said it was filing for bankruptcy protection.

BHP Billiton, the world's biggest mining company, has won support from top investors to get back on the acquisition trail after last year's failed bid for rival Rio Tinto, a newspaper report said on Sunday, according to Reuters.
Nickname for "accidental" landlords: property owners forced to rent real estate they cannot sell.
Keith Fergus holed out with a wedge from 95 yards on the 17th hole, capping his dramatic rally from four shots down to win the Cap Cana Championship in the Dominican Republic.

Jason Lawrence scored a power-play goal with 14.4 seconds left, and Boston University advanced to the Frozen Four for the first time in 12 years, beating New Hampshire, 2-1, in the N.C.A.A. Northeast Regional final in Manchester, N.H. The Terriers (33-6-4), the only top-seeded team remaining in the tournament, will face Vermont in the semifinals on April 9 in Washington. Bemidji State, which beat Cornell, 4-1, on Sunday, will face Miami of Ohio in the other semifinal.

The Detroit Tigers placed the left-handed pitcher Dontrelle Willis on the 15-day disabled list Sunday with an anxiety disorder and put reliever Joel Zumaya on the list with a sore right shoulder. Willis said he had been feeling well on and off the mound, but that doctors did not like something they saw in his blood. General Manager Dave Dombrowski said he could not provide details about Willis’s medical condition or treatment because of privacy regulations. The team said the Zumaya move was retroactive to March 27.

Gregory Bauge of France beat Azizulhasni Awang of Malaysia to capture the men’s individual sprint title and pick up the final gold medal on the closing day of the track world championships in Pruszkow, Poland.
This time, no one will accuse Barack Obama of acting like Paris Hilton.

After an injury left Whitney Hand’s shooting stroke uncertain, the 22 points she scored Sunday in Oklahoma’s 70-59 victory against Pittsburgh showed a returning touch.
Ms. Levitt was a major photographer of the 20th century who caught fleeting moments of surpassing lyricism, mystery and quiet drama on the streets of her native New York.

Miami (Ohio) and Vermont are headed to the Frozen Four. Today, the picture was completed, with Boston University coming out of the Northeast Regional, and Bemidji State emerging from the Midwest Regional in the N.C.A.A. Division I men's tournament.

MANCHESTER, N.H. -- New Hampshire used some last-second magic to make it into the Northeast Regional final of the N.C.A.A. Division I men's tournament. But as the seconds ticked off the scoreboard in the final minute Sunday night at Verizon Wireless Arena, Boston University came up with the late goal to skate off the ice with a 2-1 win and move on to Washington for the Frozen Four.
The Cyclones were well-grounded on Sunday as they contemplated unpleasantness of facing Stanford’s Jayne Appel, a power in the post, and the stellar role players who surround her.

The Los Angeles Sol defeated the Washington Freedom, 2-0, on a blustery Sunday in the inaugural game of Women’s Professional Soccer.

Andy Roddick reached the fourth round at the Sony Ericsson Open on Sunday by defeating Dmitry Tursunov, 7-6 (9), 6-2.

Connecticut vs. Michigan StateSaturday, 6:07 p.m. EasternJim Calhoun and Tom Izzo have hard-nosed reputations, so bring your shoulder pads. Michigan State made high-octane Louisville look as if it were running in quicksand Sunday, holding the Cardinals to nearly half of their previous scoring output. Connecticut's defense is anchored by the 7-foot-3 Hasheem Thabeet, who could be lured out of the lane by the Spartans' versatile big man, Goran Suton. The Huskies are more talented, but the Spartans, as evidenced by Suton's backdoor feed to Chris Allen on Sunday, are playing well together.

In Monday's New York Times, Brad Stone and I reported on tests by cable and satellite companies to create a subscriber model for TV viewing on the Internet. Worried about the proliferation of free video on the Web, the distributors want to make available an online library of TV episodes, but only to customers who pay for a cable or satellite subscription.

When someone suggests that Oklahoma guard Tony Crocker has a hot hand -- which he seemed to have Friday, scoring a career-high 28 points against Syracuse -- it is only figurative. Because Crocker rarely has a hot hand. That explains why he is one of the only players in the country to wear a long-sleeved shirt under his jersey. (''There's a girl from Texas Tech, and I just saw a guy from Auburn,'' Crocker said of others.) He has always had discomfort from cold extremities, no matter the temperature.

BEIR--Robert L.,passed away March 27, 2009. Born April 24, 1918. Cherished husband of Joan. Adored father of Chip (Ilze), Juliette, Lisa (Dennis). Beloved grandfather of Amanda, Matthew and Natalie. Graduate of Collegiate Taft Brown Harvard Business School. Four years WWII served as Lieutenant in the Navy as Liasion Officer in Great Britain. Head of Arthur Beir & Company and The Beir Foundation. His real passion was history, which led to teaching high school students for ten years at Calhoun School and three years at Marymount College. Former President of Harmonie Club. Member of the United Nations Chairmans' Council and former Vice President of the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute. At 85 he with great pride wrote a book called "Roosevelt and the Holocaust". He was involved in many philanthropies. His capacity for forming meaningful and deep relationships with his family, friends, historians and students will leave a void for many people. Family will be receiving friends at Campbells Funeral Chapel on Sunday, March 29 5pm-7pm. Family will also be receiving friends on Tuesday March 31 from 5-7pm at 895 Park Ave. Funeral at Beir Chapel at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street. Funeral 10:30am, Monday, March 30. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Calhoun School, 433 West End Ave. or Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th St.

BOYD R. Maurice, 77, of New York City and Tobermory, Ontario died on March 24, 2009 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Dr. Boyd was a preacher, author, and lecturer of international renown, and created a radio ministry that engaged listeners throughout the tri-state area. His service spanned over sixty years and included positions as the Senior Minister of Metropolitan Church in London, Ontario, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, and ultimately, The City Church, New York, an independent, inter-denominational organization founded in 1993. A memorial service will be held at 11:30am on Tuesday, March 31, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue in New York City. The family respectfully requests no flowers.

Connecticut Coach Geno Auriemma, looking somewhat irritated, could not call a timeout quickly enough. His team had fallen behind in the first half Sunday by 8 points, a deficit it had not faced in its first 35 games. It was time for a talk. Auriemma did not lace into his team or scribble a new strategy. He said he reminded his players of the game plan and told them to stick to it. The Huskies then scored 12 straight points and rolled to a 77-53 victory over California in an N.C.A.A. tournament regional semifinal.

The recession appears to have had little impact on the number of applications received by many of the nation's most competitive colleges, or on an applicant's overall chances of being admitted to them. Representatives of Brown, Dartmouth, Harvard, Stanford and Yale, among other highly selective institutions, said in telephone and e-mail exchanges in recent days that applications for the class of 2013 had jumped sharply when compared with the previous year's class. As a result, the percentage of applicants who will receive good news from the eight colleges of the Ivy League (and a few other top schools that send out decision letters this week) is expected to hover at, or near, record lows.

KELLY--Sister Dorothy Ann, OSU. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Sister Dorothy Ann, OSU, Provincial Superior of the Eastern Province of the Ursulines and 11th President of the College (1972-1997). In an association of more than sixty years, she placed her considerable talents at the service of this College community, and thousands have been touched by her wisdom, caring and goodness. She brought her bright, inquiring mind to the College first as gifted student and then as much sought after faculty member, Dean and President. She lovingly took this College to new heights. American higher education and the American Church are the beneficiaries of this multi-talented, highly competent leader, who, above all, gifted us with the witness of the woman of faith. We mourn her loss and celebrate her extraordinary life. Stephen J. Sweeny, PhD President Michael Ambler, Esq. Chair, Board of Trustees

KLEIN--Martin J. The editors of the Einstein Papers Project at Caltech deeply regret the death of M. J. Klein, former senior editor of The Collected Papers of Albert Einstein, Professor Emeritus of History of Physics and Physics at Yale. The recipient of many honors, Klein was a member of the Academie Internationale d'Histoire des Sciences, the National Academy of Sciences, APS, and AAAS. Author of path-breaking investigations into the birth of modern physics, Klein was among the most influential and respected historians of science. His profound understanding and discerning judgment on intellectual matters, and his warm sense of humor, will be greatly missed by all. We transmit our deepest condolences to his entire family.

FONTINELL--Eugene, died March 16, 2009. Gene served in the Army Air Force during WWII as a pilot in the Air-Sea Rescue Service in the South Pacific; he received the Purple Heart. For more than 40 years, he taught philosophy at Iona College, the College of New Rochelle and Queens College, where he served as chairman of the philosophy department. He published two books on the philosophy of religion. Gene was the beloved brother of Marlene of FL, and Chub and his wife Carol of Manhattan; he was the adored uncle of Justine and her husband Tom of Riverdale, Flannery of Manhattan, and Mark of CA; he is also survived by former wife and friend Jacqueline, of New Rochelle. His family and friends will remember Gene for his incredible kindness and generosity. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Alzheimer's Association or Smile Train.

What we’re reading (and watching) on Tuesday morning.

More than a month before Paramount’s new “Star Trek” movie goes to theaters, boldly or otherwise, the studio has already signed up the creative team behind it to prepare a sequel, Variety reported. The coming “Star Trek” film, directed by J.J. Abrams (“Lost,” “Alias”) and scheduled to open on May 8, returns to the earliest adventures of Kirk, Spock and McCoy as young recruits of the Starfleet Academy. That film is written by Alex Kurtzman and Roberto Orci (“Fringe,” “Transformers”), and produced by Damon Lindelof, a creator and executive producer of “Lost;” all will be writing and producing the planned sequel. Mr. Abrams and his producing partner, Bryan Burk, will also be producing, but no director has been announced. The “Star Trek” sequel, the 12th entry in the film franchise, is planned for a summer 2011 release.

The beloved underdogs of the Dillon Panthers High School football team will play on for at least two more seasons: The Hollywood Reporter said that NBC had renewed “Friday Night Lights” for an additional 26 episodes. The struggling if well-regarded show about a fictitious Texas school and its star athletes, adapted from the Buzz Bissinger nonfiction book and the 2004 feature film, has been on the brink of cancellation before; a third season of the series was picked up in 2008 only after the satellite broadcaster DirecTV agreed to help finance it. The new seasons of “Friday Night Lights,” each 13 episodes long, will also be jointly financed by DirecTV and the shows will have their premiere there before they are on NBC. Starting dates for the coming seasons were not announced.

Hartford Stage plans to announce today that it has received one of its largest grants ever, $500,000 from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, to support the world premiere this September of “The Orphans’ Home Cycle,” a three-part, nine-play work by Horton Foote, who died early this month.

The Dead capped a marathon day of media appearances and free concerts with an expansive, energetic set at Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan that began around 11:15 on Monday night and concluded after 1 a.m. Billed as “Free the Dead: Set 3,” the Roseland performance came after an appearance on “The View” in the morning and live sets at the Angel Orensanz Center for the Arts and the Gramercy Theater. The Roseland show began with two up-tempo ballads before moving into renditions of some of the band’s most renowned improvisational vehicles (see setlist below).

“This is one of those gigs where we play soft and you listen loud,” Phil Lesh said. And with that, Mr. Lesh, Bob Weir and Warren Haynes launched into what Mr. Weir called “a work in progress” in an acoustic show at the Angel Orensanz Center for the Arts on the Lower East Side on Monday afternoon. So much of a work in progress that the three had music stands in front of them so they could check notes and words as needed.

The singer-songwriter Stew will be among the players ensuring that the course of true love doesn’t run smooth for the protagonists of Shakespeare on the Sound‘s summer production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.” In a news release, Shakespeare on the Sound, the Norwalk, Conn., theater company, said that Stew, the founder of the band the Negro Problem and a creator of his autobiographical Broadway musical “Passing Strange,” would be the composer for a coming production of the play. This new staging of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” the company said, “incorporates multiple languages in the fairy world” and will feature seven new songs by Stew. The outdoor site-specific production will be held from June 16 throuh 28 at Pinkney Park in Norwalk and from July 4 through 12 at Roger Sherman Baldwin Park in Greenwich.

Many great partnerships are forged in unusual places: Would we have airplanes today if not for Orville and Wilbur Wright’s bicycle shop in Dayton, Ohio? Would Microsoft exist if Bill Gates and Paul Allen hadn’t met in a prep-school computer club? And would we be watching “Lost,” and looking ahead to the summer reboot of “Star Trek,” if its creators hadn’t first encountered each other at a fateful Bruce Springsteen concert?

Miles C. Wilkin, who as founder of Pace Theatrical Group helped create a network of Broadway shows to tour the nation in the 1980s, is now returning as the new chief executive of the current incarnation of that organization, Broadway Across America.

Having already given the world Mr. Natural, the cartoonist Robert Crumb has finally finished his long-awaited work about another mystical gray-bearded figure — namely the Almighty — in a comic-strip retelling of the Book of Genesis, The Guardian reported. On his Web site, rcrumb.com, Mr. Crumb announced that after four years he had completed the project, adapted from the King James Bible and a translation by Robert Alter. The finished work, called “Robert Crumb’s Book of Genesis” is scheduled to be released on Oct. 19. “It’s very visual,” Mr. Crumb said, according to The Guardian. “It’s lurid. Full of all kinds of crazy, weird things that will really surprise people.”
