[UPDATE, 4/2: My print story with a bit more background has run.] Dolphin and porpoise species that have adapted to rivers and deltas around the world have long been considered some of the most vulnerable of marine mammals because of their restricted habitats. In 2007, the baiji, a river dolphin that thrived in the Yangtze River for 20 million years in today's China, was said by experts to have been driven to extinction by a mix of impacts from the nearly half billion people now living in that watershed. The vaquita, a porpoise living in brackish waters where the Colorado River empties into the Gulf of California, is critically endangered, biologists say, depleted by fishing nets and the disruptions in the great river's flow in the 20th century from dam construction.

Michelle Obama boarded Air Force One this morning wearing a white Thakoon coat and a black Michael Kors dress, and stepped off, a few hours later in London, dressed in a vivid yellow Jason Wu. Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas, President Obama's nominee for secretary of health and human services, said Tuesday that she and her husband had paid $7,040 in back taxes and $878 in interest after discovering "unintentional errors" in their tax returns for 2005-7.

A federal judge on Tuesday upheld New York City's authority to ban the placement of large commercial billboards near major highways and parkways, but found that the city's enforcement of the ban has been "inconsistent and less than vigorous."The decision by the judge, Paul A. Crotty of Federal District Court in Manhattan, was a significant legal victory for the city, but it underscored the haphazard and even erratic manner in which the city has tried to regulate the intrusion of advertising into public space.

Cherries that have been marinating for weeks are fed up to the bottling machinery at Dell's Maraschino Cherries Company in Red Hook, Brooklyn, which produces about a third of the country's maraschino cherries, according to the company's president, Arthur Mondella. Dell's, which started in 1948, still produces its entire output, about a billion cherries a year, in Brooklyn. Mr. Mondella said that modernization and computerization enabled the company to remain competitive.

Back in November, when we wanted to take NYTimes.com readers' temperature on Election Day, we developed something we called the "Word Train." Folks were asked "What One Word Describes Your Current State of Mind?" and we then took hourly snapshots of their responses. Between 6 a.m. Eastern time on Nov. 4 through 1 a.m. Nov. 5, more than 65,000 unique voters participated submitting a total of 73,400 words. (The most selected word is was hopeful, followed closely by anxious.)

Peter Dizikes's recent essay on C. P. Snow's "Two Cultures," in which Snow, some 50 years ago, lamented the Western schism between literature and science, put me immediately in mind of Vladimir Nabokov's lepidoptery. Yes, I know that Nabokov's taxonomic natural science, ultimately based on the acute observance of detail, was probably not what Snow had in mind - so call me a hopeless littérateur. In the matter of that same observance of detail, carried over into Nabokov's literature, I like the formulation of James Wood in "How Fiction Works," writing that Nabokov (along with Updike) at times freezes "detail into a cult of itself": "Nabokov wants to tell us how important it is to notice. Nabokov's fiction is always becoming propaganda on behalf of good noticing, hence on behalf of itself."

As a hatch door closed behind six would-be astronauts in Moscow on Tuesday, sealing them in for the first of 105 days of confinement in a simulated spacecraft -- as part of an experiment to see how humans might one day cope with very long trips to Mars -- word circulated that life aboard the International Space Station these days is far less fun than it used to be. The problem, it seems, is that new rules, introduced by American and Russian authorities, now forbid astronauts and cosmonauts from sharing their food with each other and even discourage them from using each other's toilets.

"Project Runway" may be on indefinite hiatus, but at Henri Bendel the hunt for new talent is still going strong. Twice a year, the store hosts its "Open See" - a casting call that allows up-and-coming designers to show their collections to buyers. Created in the 1960s by Bendel's president, Geraldine Stutz, the event has launched the careers of designers including Anna Sui, Todd Oldham and Stephen Burrows.

ShoWest, the annual gathering of the nation's cinema owners, at which the Hollywood studios try to dazzle them with peeks at their upcoming movies, is underway in Las Vegas - with the number of major premieres down a bit from previous years. Much of the early attention has gone to last weekend's huge opening for DreamWorks Animation's 3-D "Monsters vs. Aliens." A lot of the Hollywood studios are betting big on 3-D films, and the big opening, especially in the face of lackluster reviews, has raised the optimism level at the event.

This past Friday, I went online to get my admissions decision from Hamilton College, only to find that I had been wait-listed. When I checked my email two minutes later, I found that I'd also been wait-listed by Syracuse University and rejected altogether from Boston University. Oddly, I didn't feel much of anything as I read the words, so I decided I would give myself the night to sleep on it and, hopefully, awake with, well, definitive emotions. But here I am, days later and still nothing. No tears, no screaming, no...anything. I feel perfectly fine, actually. I did get into Fordham, though, and I'm wondering if that, coupled with my Emerson acceptance, has something to do with this rather mellow mood. Hopefully, I can keep this laid-back attitude up as I get my financial aid packages.

Spam, that annoying but ignorable scourge of the Web, has finally recovered from the jolt it received last November, when Internet backbone providers cut off McColo Corporation, a California Web-hosting service that spammers were using to coordinate e-mail attacks.

Expensive restaurants in New York discriminate based on race when hiring waiters, a new study has concluded. What appeared to be a murder-suicide left three children and three adults dead in Santa Clara, and the police searched for a possible motive and tried to sort out the relationships between the presumed gunman and his victims. A woman in her mid-30s managed to escape from the house where the police later found five bodies in a “very horrific” scene on Sunday night, said Capt. Mike Sellers. She was hospitalized in critical condition with multiple gunshot wounds, Captain Sellers said. Officers discovered the bodies of a 10-year-old boy, a 4-year-old girl, a man in his 30s and a woman in her early 20s scattered inside a three-story town house, all of them fatally shot, Captain Sellers said. The presumed gunman, a man in his 40s, was found on the top floor, dead from a self-inflicted wound, he said. A toddler was still alive when paramedics arrived but died later at a hospital, Captain Sellers said.

The federal government is proposing to forgive disaster loans made to coastal communities that have faced budget problems in the years after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. The proposed rules would let local governments avoid repaying some or all of their loans if their revenues for three fiscal years since the disasters had not met operating costs. Debt forgiveness would not be automatic, meaning communities would have to apply for the relief and meet established criteria. The Federal Emergency Management Agency made available nearly $1.3 billion in loans to communities in Louisiana and Mississippi after the 2005 hurricanes devastated the region. As of March 16, $831 million in loan money had been drawn down. FEMA had no estimate on how much of the loaned money might be forgiven. In 2007, Congress authorized the agency to forgive the loans under certain conditions. But the proposed rules were the first specific steps moving that process forward.

The man convicted of killing six people in the Serial Shooter attacks in Phoenix has been sentenced to two life terms plus nearly 365 years, just days after being sentenced to death. A jury on Friday gave the man, Dale Hausner, six death sentences for six murder convictions. The latest sentencing was for 74 additional charges, including attempted first-degree murder, aggravated assault and drive-by shooting. Mr. Hausner was convicted March 13 in the series of random nighttime attacks, which kept the city on edge in 2005 and 2006.

A federal judge in Scranton issued a temporary order preventing the Wyoming County district attorney from filing criminal charges against three teenage girls accused of sending nude or seminude photos on a cellphone, or “sexting.” Last week the girls and their mothers, represented by the American Civil Liberties Union of Pennsylvania, sued the district attorney, George P. Skumanick, arguing that by threatening to prosecute the girls for being in photos he considered “provocative” he was violating their constitutional rights. The judge, James M. Munley of Federal District Court, found that the girls and their mothers “are reasonably likely to succeed on the merits” in their lawsuit. He ruled that his order would be in effect at least until a June 2 hearing that could make the order permanent until the girls’ federal civil lawsuit is resolved.

LOOMIS--Chauncey Chester Jr. of Stockbridge, MA died from cancer at Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington, MA on March 17, 2009. He was born on June 1, 1930 in New York to the late Chauncey and Elizabeth McLanahan Loomis. His older brothers John (Jack) and Stanley Loomis died before him. He attended the Stockbridge Public Schools, Phillips Exeter Academy, Princeton University (A.B. '52, Ph.D.) and Columbia University (M.A.). Before attending Columbia, Chauncey enlisted in the US Army and served during the Korean conflict. After finishing school, Chauncey briefly taught English at the University of Vermont, then in 1963 moved to Dartmouth College. He retired from Dartmouth as Professor of English in 1997. In 1968, Chauncey led an expedition investigating the mysterious death of the early American explorer Charles Francis Hall, who was buried in Northern Greenland during an unsuccessful attempt to reach the North Pole. That trip resulted in Chauncey's book, Weird and Tragic Shores, recently republished by the Modern Library in the Expedition Series and which became the basis for a PBS documentary. He wrote many book reviews and articles including his innovative consideration of arctic landscapes in his essay "Arctic Sublime", published in the book Nature and the Victorian Imagination. Throughout his life, Chauncey followed his passion for exploration, conservation, photography and fly fishing. He filmed musk oxen off the coast of Alaska, searched for lost Inca civilizations in Peru, and caught (and mostly released) trout and salmon on many continents. He was always involved in his various communities and served on the boards of local and national institutions including the Housatonic Valley Association, Phillips Exeter Academy, the Hotchkiss School, the Norman Rockwell Museum, and Chesterwood. Chauncey is survived by his nephew Craig Loomis, a grand-niece Vivian Loomis, step-niece Claudine Scoville, step-nephews Reg Gignoux, Tom Gignoux, and Thayer Gignoux, and their children Denny, Simone, Alex, Christopher and Madeleine Gignoux. For all his protestations, he was welcoming and generous; he taught us much about thinking and living, about honesty and kindness. A memorial service for Chauncey Loomis will be held at the Norman Rockwell Museum, Stockbridge, Massachusetts on May 9th, at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests memorial gifts may be made to the Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation at 271 Main Street, Great Barrington, MA 01230. Please specify the Chauncey Loomis Fund; this is a fund established by Chauncey to help Berkshire County, MA high school students attend college.

BEIR--Robert L. The Calhoun community mourns the passing of Robert L. Beir, Life Trustee -- a master teacher, an unequaled philanthropist and the wisest steward this school has ever known. Few institutions are ever blessed with the unconditional affection and generosity that Bob lavished on Calhoun. He presided over the expansion of the school's main building and program in the '70s; led the acquisition and renovation of the finest early childhood facility in New York in the '80s; was the spiritual architect of the school's major building expansion in the late '90s; and ushered in the progressive mission that distinguishes Calhoun today. Because of his love, affection and remarkable generosity, there are several thousand Calhoun graduates who carry forward his passion for intellectual pursuit. There can be no greater legacy than that. We extend sincerest condolences to Bob's wife, Joan; his children Chip (Ilze), Juliette, and Lisa (Dennis); and his three grandchildren. The Calhoun School Steve Nelson, Head of School Eric Ryan and William Ginn, Board Co-Chairs

TRUBOWITZ Dr. Shelley Howard, died peacefully on Saturday in Savannah Georgia after a long, valiant battle with cancer. A longtime resident of Rowayton, Shelley was 86 years old. Shelley was born in New York City on July 10, 1922, to Israel and Sarah Trubowitz, who immigrated to the United States from Lithuania. Known affectionately as "Mookie," Shelley grew up in Brooklyn, along with his brother Sidney and sister Frummie (Florence). He attended Erasmus Hall High School and later Indiana University, where he received his B.A. Upon graduation Shelley joined the Army, serving as a TSgt. and medic in the elite World War II fighting force known as Merrill's Marauders, which fought in the jungles of Burma. After the war, Shelley opted for a career in dentistry, receiving his D.D.S. in 1950 from New York University. The following year he moved to Rowayton and shortly thereafter, married Jacqueline Vida Loeb. A distinguished maxillofacial prosthodontist, Shelley ran a successful private practice in Rowayton and was a member of the faculty at Yale New Haven Medical Center and New York University College of Dentistry. Among colleagues, Shelley was known for his clinical skills. He gave productive life back to many, many head and neck cancer victims with his elegant reconstructive, maxillofacial and orbital prostheses. Patients from Fairfield Country and beyond relied instinctively on his skill and judgment. Shelley loved life. A terrific dancer, few things gave him greater pleasure than a dance floor, a big band, and a lithe partner. He was also an avid tennis player, who with Ward Chamberlin, took home Rowayton's men's doubles trophy multiple times. A competitive swimmer from college days, Shelley often swam Rowayton's annual quarter-mile buoy race and like Rowayton's other noble "high tiders," was a regular at Bayley Beach. He is survived by his older brother and his sister-in-law, Dr. Sidney Trubowitz and Ethel Mason Trubowitz; his former wife, Jackie; seven children -- Peter, Charles, Jonathon, Seth, Amy, Phoebe, and Mitchell and their spouses; twenty healthy, boisterous grandchildren; and four nieces and a nephew and their families. Shelley's funeral will be held in Savannah March 31. A memorial service will be scheduled for later this spring in Rowayton. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Rowayton Civic Association (RCA) in memory of Shelley H. Trubowitz, PO Box 302, Rowayton, Connecticut 06853.

One-quarter of all deaths from tuberculosis are in patients also infected with the AIDS virus, twice as many as previously thought, the World Health Organization said last week. In its annual Global TB Control report, the organization said that being infected with the virus can increase the risk of developing tuberculosis by 20 times.

The long delay in starting to build the Nets' proposed arena near downtown Brooklyn is helping to cause huge financial losses. For the fiscal year that ended Jan. 31, Nets Sports and Entertainment, which owns the team and real estate in Brooklyn, had a pre-tax loss of $77.8 million. That brings the three-year total of losses to $228.2 million, according to a 10-K filing by Forest City Enterprises, the parent company of Forest City Ratner.

Janet Jagan, a daughter of a middle-class family from Chicago who became enmeshed in anticolonial politics in Guyana and rose to become the first woman to be president of that South American nation, died Saturday in Georgetown, the Guyanese capital. She was 88. Mrs. Jagan died at a government hospital after suffering an abdominal aneurysm, Guyana's health minister, Leslie Ramsammy, told Reuters.

Updated | 2:48 p.m. Even the metal band that declared “Kill ‘Em All” can forgive and forget: When Metallica takes the stage Saturday at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony in Cleveland, the group will be joined in performance by its former bassist Jason Newsted, who left the band in 2001, Billboard reported. Mr. Newsted, who was hired by Metallica in 1986 to replace Cliff Burton, who died in a tour bus accident, said he had received the invitation to reunite with his old band mates from the drummer Lars Ulrich. “He said, ‘We want you to rock with us,'” Mr. Newsted told Billboard. Mr. Newsted quit Metallica to perform with acts like Echobrain, Voivod and the Ozzy Osbourne Band. He was replaced by Robert Trujillo, who is also expected to perform at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame show.

Last week, we found ourselves marveling at the work of Sterling Beaumon, the 13-year-old actor on “Lost” who plays the junior version of Benjamin Linus, the show’s resident genius of ambiguous morality (whose grown-up incarnation is played by Michael Emerson). A few days later, in a crazy twist of fate involving time travel, smoke monsters and a helpful publicist, we found ourselves on the phone with the young actor. In this conversation with Sterling (which may contain spoilers for the uninitiated), he spoke with us about the polarizing “Lost” cliffhanger he was involved in last week, and ended up quizzing us about what we think is taking place on the show.

The Tate Modern museum in London said that a revised plan for its $309 million dollar annex had been approved by city planners, BBC News reported. In 2006, Tate Modern announced plans for an 11-story extension, a series of glass boxes stacked up to resemble a ziggurat, designed by the Swiss architectural firm Herzog & de Meuron. That plan was given the go-ahead, but was later redesigned as a giant pyramid covered in bricks, and had to be resubmitted to a London borough council for approval. The new expansion, which will lead visitors into Tate Modern’s Turbine Hall, is expected to be completed by 2012, in time for the Summer Olympics in London. Tate Modern said it had already raised about $106 million toward the cost of the extension.

Television shows including NBC’s “Saturday Night Live,” ABC’s “Lost” and HBO’s “Entourage,” as well as the YouTube Web site, were among 36 winners of Peabody Awards announced Wednesday by the University of Georgia’s Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communications.
Updated | 4:34 p.m. CBS announced Wednesday the cancellation of the longest-running scripted program in broadcasting history, the soap opera “Guiding Light.”

Three compilation albums aimed at teenage fans vied for the top spots on this week’s Billboard chart. “Now That’s What I Call Music!” Vol. 30, with songs by Lady GaGa, Britney Spears, Pussycat Dolls and others, reached No. 1 with 146,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, followed by the soundtrack to “Hannah Montana: The Movie” (Disney), with 139,000, and the “Twilight” soundtrack (Atlantic), with 102,000. Keri Hilson’s new album, “In a Perfect World …” (Interscope), opened at No. 4 with 94,000 sales, and Kelly Clarkson‘s “All I Ever Wanted” (RCA) is No. 5 with 52,000. In a week crowded with high-charting new releases, Papa Roach’s “Metamorphosis” (Interscope) reached No. 8, Jim Jones’s “Pray IV Reign” (Columbia) opened at No. 9, Martina McBride’s “Shine” (RCA Nashville) is No. 10, and Mastodon’s “Crack the Skye” (Reprise) bowed at No. 11.

Wanda Sykes is becoming the latest comedian to dip a toe into the late-night television pool, signing a deal with Fox to host a show on Saturday nights. In a news release, the network said Ms. Sykes would host a topical program, which is expected to start in the fall, that would include panel discussions about current events. Ms. Sykes’s show may act as a replacement for “Mad TV,” the sketch comedy show that was shown at 11 p.m. on Saturdays until it was canceled last year. The Fox announcement also calls into question the future of “Talk Show with Spike Feresten,” which is hosted at midnight on Saturday by Mr. Feresten, a former “Seinfeld” writer. Fox declined to comment on the status of Mr. Feresten’s show, and did not announce a time slot for Ms. Sykes’s debut.

My Thursday column is about the G20 summit in London, and the hopes that it will address all the marginalized people around the world who are being worst hit by this economic crisis. I especially hope that the G20 leaders will focus on a couple of points -- avoiding increases in malnutrition and surges in school drop-out rates. The reason is similar, for the consequences last decades. When a child is severely malnourished, the result is often a cognitive impairment that will last the entire life. And when a child is forced to drop out of school, he or she probably won't go back and will never become literate. That's a burden on the country that will linger for the next half a century.

Churchill, the former University of Colorado professor who was fired after he wrote an essay calling the victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks "little Eichmanns." The university said it fired him for shoddy research, especially on American Indians. Mr. Churchill brought a wrongful termination suit against the university, seeking monetary damages and also reinstatement to his job.

In a stunning decision, Attorney General Eric Holder moved on Wednesday to drop all charges against former Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, who had been convicted on seven felony counts of ethics violations. Mr. Holder told the federal court that the Justice Department had discovered a new instance of prosecutorial misconduct, in which federal prosecutors failed to provide information that should have been given to the defense for use at trial.

The bit started with Mos Def asking if Al Qaeda or the Taliban have ever said what its goals are, and Hitchens answered that Al Qaeda has published numerous videos and statements stating their intentions. E.B White once said that driving to Maine teaches you to spell moccasin. I feel sort of the same about the arrival of spring and forsythia. It's been a hard spring, though, for many people. Eventually you know someone who has lost his or her job. A small part of me bristles when I see an article declaring "the end of excess," because I know that lots of intelligent people already do live modestly by choice if not necessity. So who is the lecture for? Over the next year or two, the fashion industry will be significantly altered, as will coverage of the industry in glossy magazines and newspapers, which are experiencing their own traumas. If people are being more careful about what they buy, it seems to me they will also be picky about what they choose to read. What things will matter to people without trivializing the seriousness of the economy or, at the same time, being a complete downer browner and forgetting that fashion is a source of pleasure? It's also a livelihood for millions of people.

I own a one-bedroom co-op in Yonkers, and the board has rejected four buyers for my unit in the past two years. The mortgage is paid for, so I am paying the maintenance for an empty unit. The board is unsympathetic. What happens if I just walk away from the apartment?

I am on the board of a co-op building -- which I happily serve -- but the board is constantly harassed by a shareholder about decisions we make that are correct and well within the rights governing co-op boards. The shareholder also complains about the proprietary lease and the house rules. How can board members protect themselves from continued harassment from a shareholder?

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has a big problem. And we think City Room readers will have an answer. The problem: How do you market the tallest skyscraper at the World Trade Center site to prospective tenants? When readers were reminded last week that the authority had -- largely for leasing reasons -- quietly been replacing the symbolic name "Freedom Tower" with the more prosaic (but also symbolic) "1 World Trade Center," hundreds of comments followed. Many included alternative name suggestions; about which, more in a moment.This week, we'd like more than comments. Following the terrific response to our 2007 exercise in taxi logo redesign, we hope the designers among you -- amateur and pro -- will consider drawing up a hypothetical logo proposal for the new building. Image files in JPG or GIF formats are preferable, sent as e-mail attachments to cityroom@nytimes.com by 5 p.m. Friday. You're free to use whatever building name suits you, but please relate the appearance of the logo to the words. (We've prepared a few examples, to the left and below, of what we're talking about.) The best logos will be displayed on City Room next week. There is no reward other than the satisfaction of seeing your work on the site. To learn more about the building, visit the Port Authority's Web site.

Cigarettes in New York City will top $9 a pack -- and in some cases more than $10 -- starting Wednesday, as a federal tax more than doubles to $1.01 per pack. With taxes having increased last year as well, the price of each pack now carries $5.26 in government fees in New York City, making this one of the most expensive places in the country to smoke.The city's health department, which has campaigned against smoking since 2002, is using this as another opportunity.

Fiat faces a tough choice in its negotiations with Chrysler, which is up against an April 30 deadline from the United States government. If Chrysler cannot reach a deal with its Italian auto industry counterpart, bankruptcy looms.

The PGA Tour winner and rising star Dustin Johnson was arrested Monday and charged with driving under the influence in South Carolina, the police said. Johnson, 24, won the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am in February, his second career PGA Tour victory.

The Hockey Hall of Fame is changing its rules in a move that could lead to the first female player being inducted. Starting in 2010, the Hall will consider male and female candidates separately. The new bylaw will allow a maximum of four men and two women to be inducted each year. Currently there is a maximum of four player inductees, and women are judged and considered against men.

Tim Jitloff repeated as giant slalom champion at the United States Alpine Ski Championships at Alyeska Resort in Girdwood, Alaska. Tommy Ford of Bend, Ore., was second, and Warner Nickerson of Gilford, N.H., was third, the same finish order as last year. Jitloff, of Truckee, Calif., was first in both runs Tuesday and finished in a combined time of 2 minutes 17.73 seconds. Ford was fourth after the first run but finished in 2:18.48 to edge Nickerson, who finished in 2:18.67.

Danny Lee, the United States Amateur champion, defeated the British Amateur champion Reinier Saxton in the 12th annual Georgia Cup match, staged a week before the Masters Tournament. Lee broke Tiger Woods’s record by six months to become the youngest United States Amateur champion in August at the age of 18. He also won the Johnnie Walker Classic in Australia last month to become the youngest winner of a European Tour event. He sealed the win over Saxton in the 18-hole match with a par on No. 17 at the Golf Club of Georgia. Next week, Lee and Saxton will play in the Masters.

Michael Vick has agreed to pay the Atlanta Falcons at least $6.5 million as part of his bankruptcy case, clearing the way for the team to release him before training camp. The settlement was reached ahead of Vick’s bankruptcy hearing in Virginia on Thursday.

Pale and thin but still resilient, the golfer Seve Ballesteros said he has been given the mulligan of his life. Speaking for the first time about his battle with cancer, Ballesteros appeared in photos in the Spanish sports daily Marca. He has lost 33 pounds since being admitted to Madrid’s La Paz hospital in October. Ballesteros, 51, has had four operations and chemotherapy to destroy a malignant brain tumor. “This is the most important shot of my life,” he said. “I’m fighting to win my sixth major. Life has given me a second chance.”.

An article in some editions on Sunday about Villanova’s 78-76 victory over Pittsburgh in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament misspelled the surname of the Pittsburgh player who missed a 70-foot shot at the buzzer. It would have given Pittsburgh the victory; it would not have sent the game into overtime.

An article on Monday about plans to reroute the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade to avoid Broadway referred imprecisely to the parade. The Saturday Profile article about Louise Richardson, the first woman president of the University of St. Andrews in Scotland, the third-oldest university in the English-speaking world, misstated the publication year of a book she cited in her installation ceremony last week as an example of how women have advanced. An article on Saturday about reaction in Pennsylvania to a scandal in which two judges sent thousands of juveniles to two private detention centers in exchange for $2.6 million in kickbacks misspelled the hometown of one of the judges. It is Hazleton, Pa., not Hazelton.

BERGSON--Maria, died peacefully on Thursday, March 19th after a long illness. She was born in Vienna in 1914. After a brief but successful career in the theater working with Max Reinhardt, she came to America in 1940 and found a job as secretary and research assistant in the offices of Architectural Forum, a part of Time Inc. After the Managing Editor expressed unhappiness with her office layout, Maria suggested that it was "...because the designers have not paid attention to how you work." When challenged to propose something better, she redesigned that office, and then subsequently the offices of Time Inc. itself, and the firm of Maria Bergson Associates (MBA) was born. MBA revolutionized commercial office design. The old roll-top desk was replaced by interchangeable components forming work surfaces resting on different file cabinets, and her many innovations were publicized by Fortune Magazine in 1946. The firm's reputation continued to grow over a long period of time, and its business flourished with offices in New York, Los Angeles and London. In time she did work for many banks, but also for major companies in virtually all well-known industries. She even designed the Admiral's suite and the crew quarters of the first nuclear powered aircraft carrier, the Independence. Maria Bergson's family, who had all also left Vienna, were extremely important to her, and throughout her life she went to extraordinary lengths helping generations of her relatives. She is survived by her husband of 67 years, Thomas L. Brunner, and various nephews, grandnephews and grandnieces. There will be a service at 3:00pm on Friday April 3rd, at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel on Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

Mildred is survived by her loving husband, Emanuel; brother, Dr. Seymour Colby and his wife Gloria; son Steven and wife Gail; son Roy and wife Teri; daughter Judy Cocke, who with her husband Larry (of blessed memory), gave Mildred two wonderful grandchildren whom she adored, Mychal and Elana; and her nieces, nephews, and cousins.

A COUPLE of years ago, a friend took me to Taberna Toscana, in Madrid. ''We don't need a menu,'' he said. ''We'll get the veal shoulder and the tomato salad, like everyone else.'' He was both right and wrong; those dishes were amazing, and I ate them the next couple of times I went there. Finally, I took the time to explore the menu and found tortillitas. These cute little no-egg pancakes, originally from Andalusia, feature chickpea flour, shrimp or other seafood, onion, herbs and olive oil. Not much else. Yet they are a near-perfect appetizer or small meal, quickly and easily made.

A 1993 Congressional apology for the United States' role in overthrowing Hawaii's monarchy a century earlier does not prohibit Hawaiian officials from selling or transferring state land, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday. Last year the Supreme Court of Hawaii, relying on the Congressional apology, ruled that a proposed land transfer on Maui could not proceed until the claims of Native Hawaiians were resolved. The ruling affected not just the parcel immediately at issue but a total of some 1.2 million acres, almost a third of all the land in the state.

With all the Big East hype this season, the year 1985 has been invoked repeatedly. What has not been mentioned is that when three of the league's teams reached the Final Four that season, it was also a zenith for Catholic colleges, as St. John's, Georgetown and Villanova all qualified. That was not considered especially noteworthy at the time, as Catholic colleges were regularly making it to the season's last weekend. Of the 40 teams in the Final Four that decade, seven were from Catholic colleges -- Georgetown three times, St. John's, Villanova, Providence and Seton Hall.

The new ballparks in New York are packed with new amenities, including plenty of suites, restaurants and even waterless toilets. But all these extras use electricity, a lot of it. Con Edison expects the new Yankee Stadium to use about 9 megawatts of electricity during peak times, enough to power about 9,000 homes or the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Citi Field will use as much as 11 megawatts, or a shade less than the new Goldman Sachs tower near ground zero.

YOU never know where goat will take you. When I asked the smiley butcher at Jefferson Market, the grocery store near my apartment in the West Village, whether he had any goat meat, he told me: ''No. I got a leg of lamb, though -- I could trim it nice and thin to make it look like goat.'' I politely declined. We fell into conversation. I found myself telling him: ''Koreans think eating goat soup increases virility. It can lead to better sexytime.'' My new friend responded: ''My lamb does that a little. You won't want to every night, but maybe every other night.'' Reaching toward his counter to pick up a mound of hamburger, he paused to ask, ''It's for you, the goat?''

Memphis Coach John Calipari will become the new coach at the University of Kentucky, according to a longtime friend of Calipari's. An announcement could come Wednesday. Calipari planned to fly to Lexington on a private plane Tuesday night to complete the details of his contract. The Associated Press reported Tuesday night that Calipari agreed to an eight-year, $31.65 million deal, which would make him the highest-paid coach in college basketball.

Hartford Stage announced that it had received a $500,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to support the world premiere in September of ''The Orphans' Home Cycle,'' a three-part, nine-play work by Horton Foote, who died in March. Hartford Stage is producing the project with Signature Theater Company in Manhattan, which plans to run the production from early November to mid-April 2010. It will be performed in repertory at both theaters; the Hartford Stage run will conclude in late October. The plays trace the life of Horace Robedaux, a character based on Mr. Foote's father, including his experiences during World War I and the flu epidemic of 1918. Hartford Stage said the $500,000 grant was the largest it had ever received for a specific project in one season.

During the recent economic boom, rents in the priciest Manhattan office towers skyrocketed. A similar trend occurred in the city's less well-heeled office buildings, known in real estate jargon as Class B buildings. But today, vacancies are rising and rents are falling sharply in both classes of buildings, especially in Midtown. ''I think the general feeling was that Class A was going to get hit'' because the economic decline was ''first and foremost, a financial industry problem,'' and that industry tends to favor Class A buildings, said Robert L. Sammons, the managing director in charge of research at Colliers ABR. So he was surprised to notice that Class B rents were swooning just as hard -- or harder.

Ilshat Hassan's flight from China has brought refuge, a job at the consulting firm Booz Allen and an apartment in the Virginia suburbs. Mr. Hassan, an intense former college professor, is among some 300 exiles from western China's Uighur Muslim minority who live peacefully in the Washington area, where the American government has supported their pro-democracy efforts. But while the United States is hosting Mr. Hassan and the others, it has been imprisoning 17 of their countrymen in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

The singer-songwriter Stew, below,will be among those ensuring that the course of true love doesn't run smooth for the characters in Shakespeare on the Sound's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' this summer. In a news release, Shakespeare on the Sound, the Norwalk, Conn., theater company, said Stew, founder of the band the Negro Problem and a creator of ''Passing Strange,'' would be the composer for the production. This new staging of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' the company said, ''incorporates multiple languages in the fairy world'' and will feature seven new songs by Stew. The outdoor site-specific production will run from June 16 to 28 at Pinkney Park in Norwalk and July 4 to 12 at Roger Sherman Baldwin Park in Greenwich, Conn.

Bankers may be suffering, but Wall Street’s legions of legal eagles, many of whom are assembling at Tulane University’s corporate law conference in New Orleans this week, may need an extra rum swizzle, too, Breakingviews says. That’s because the decline in deal-making has also taken a bite out of their business.

Proxy season is upon us and the swath of lawyers and bankers at Tulane Law School’s Corporate Law Institute conference, sporting their pinstripes and PowerPoint presentations, are gearing up for another active year. This comes despite the broad shake-out in the hedge fund industry that has left many activist funds in tough spot.

Down in New Orleans, the 21st annual Tulane mergers conference is in full swing. We’ve heard the keynote speech from Goldman Sachs‘s Tim Ingrassia; a discussion of the state of shareholder activism; and the state of corporate deal-making.

In between panels here on Thursday morning, an M.&.A lawyer was overheard explaining why he likes doing deals. “It’s like a birth,” he said in the hallway on the opening day of Tulane’s Corporate Law Institute. “It’s the moment of conception. It’s exciting. It always holds so much promise.”

It’s fitting that the keynote speech at Tulane’s Corporate Law Institute took place on an overcast, cloudy day with a threat of rain. The presentation by Tim Ingrassia of Goldman Sachs didn’t exactly paint a sunny picture for deal-making this year.

Greetings from New Orleans, where a collection of high-powered deal-makers, deal lawyers and other luminaries of the M&A world have gathered for Tulane University Law School’s annual Corporate Law Institute.

Over the years, the key roles in “Bye Bye Birdie” have been played by their share of sexpots (Chita Rivera, Ann-Margret) and squares (Dick Van Dyke). Guess which route Roundabout Theater Company is taking for its latest revival of the musical? In a release, Roundabout said that it had cast John Stamos (of Broadway’s “Nine” and “Cabaret” and, of course, “Full House”) and Gina Gershon (of “Showgirls”) to play the roles of Albert Peterson, the publicity-seeking songwriter, and Rose Alvarez, his doting assistant. The new production, which is to be directed and choreographed by Robert Longbottom, has also cast Bill Irwin (soon to be seen in “Waiting For Godot”) as Mr. MacAfee and Jayne Houdyshell as Mrs. Peterson. The revival of “Bye Bye Birdie,” the first to play Broadway since its 1961 premiere, is scheduled for the fall.

B.B. King, Herbie Hancock, Black Eyed Peas and Lauryn Hill will be among the performers coming out to Montreux, on the Lake Geneva shoreline, at the 43rd annual Montreux Jazz Festival in Switzerland, Reuters reported. This year’s festival spans 90 concerts featuring more than 1,000 musicians from July 3 through 18, including a performance by Mr. King, who previously said that his 2006 appearance at Montreux would be his last. Mr. King’s show is scheduled for July 12 with an opening performance by Susan Tedeschi. Other highlights include a July 11 tribute to Nina Simone that features Dianne Reeves, Lizz Wright and Angelique Kidjo, and July 4 performances by the Dave Matthews Band and Steely Dan. George Benson, David Sanborn, Solomon Burke and Marianne Faithfull are also scheduled to perform.

A ruling by the city council of Vienna has set a new standard for the restitution of artworks seized during the era when Austria was under Nazi rule, Reuters reported. This week the council voted to return the painting “Pappenheim’s Death” by Hans Makart to the heirs of Herbert Gutmann, a Jewish banker who fled to Britain in 1936 after selling his art collection and other possessions. The painting, which eventually turned up in the collection of the Museum of Vienna, was sold at auction in 1934; current Austrian restitution law covers only the years between 1938 and 1945. Andreas Mailath-Pokorny, the Vienna city councilman for culture, said that the council had “a moral obligation” to overrule the time frame of existing restitution law, according to Reuters.

I’ve got a piece in today’s paper that takes a broad view of “Damages”’ second season (which I really enjoyed) but thought the season finale Wednesday night had enough noteworthy moments to keep the conversation going. Obviously Patty’s visit to see Daniel Purcell in prison, on top of all that dream-scape call to self-reckoning, had a pretty big impact on her. She looks at him as though he is insane for confessing to his wife’s murder and then eventually we see her at work deciding to pursue the last-ditch road to honorably winning her case against Walter Kendrick and U.N.R. as if suddenly we were all watching Perry Mason. (I need to nit-pick here. When Patty goes to see the show’s in-house Cocaine Addicted Wall Street Trader, Finn Garrity, she tells him that “thousands” of people have died at the hands of U.N.R’s toxic pollution. Was she making a rhetorical point or an actual one? How many people live in West Virginia anyway?)

With the recession and unpredictable ticket sales leading theater producers to tighten their belts, two New York not-for-profit theaters announced Thursday afternoon that they would co-produce a new musical, “The Burnt Part Boys,” sharing the costs as they work toward an Off-Broadway premiere next spring.

Jones in the running for individual awards.

The architect Frank Gehry has been chosen to design a memorial in Washington to honor President Dwight D. Eisenhower, The Washington Post reported. Mr. Gehry and his company, Gehry Partners, were chosen by a memorial commission from a short list of four architectural firms that also included Ron Krueck of Krueck & Sexton, Rob Rogers and Jonathan Marvel of Rogers Marvel Architects, and Peter Walker of PWP Landscape Architecture. The memorial will be built on a four-acre site between Fourth and Sixth Streets SW, south of Independence Avenue and near the Department of Education and the National Air and Space Museum. The Washington Post said that the project would cost between $90 million to $120 million and would take five years to complete. It is Mr. Gehry’s first commission in Washington since an extension he was to design for the Corcoran Gallery of Art was canceled due to a lack of funds.

Roundabout Theater Company on Wednesday announced plans for the New York premiere production of a new musical, “The Tin Pan Alley Rag,” and said that the show would run at its Laura Pels Theater at the Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater, the first musical presented in that space. The musical centers on an imagined meeting between the composer Scott Joplin and the songwriter Irving Berlin and their contributions to ragtime, among other music genres. The score will include a variety of Berlin and Joplin classics, such as Berlin’s “Alexander’s Ragtime Band” and Joplin’s “The Entertainer.” The musical was written by Mark Saltzman, a co-author of “A, My Name is Alice,” and Stafford Arima will direct. The production is scheduled to begin performances on Friday, June 12, with an opening on Tuesday, July 14.

My husband and I want to take a year off and travel around the world. We are struggling with how to structure such a trip. Do you pick 12 places and stay a month each, 52 places at a week each, or just move around at will? We are both fit, flexible, in our 50s and have traveled fairly extensively. Budget is not an issue. We do not do tour groups or any other kind of organized travel and like to make our own arrangements.

The featureless glassy screens of touch-screen phones may seem like a forbidding barrier for blind users, who often rely on tactile clues to feel their way around. But a pair of engineers at Google, T.V. Raman, who is blind, and Charles Chen, who is sighted, have developed software that makes the touch-screen T-Mobile G1, which uses Google's Android software, more accessible to blind users. They hope the technology will also be useful to anyone who needs to operate a phone without looking at the screen, like drivers.

Used to be, it was easy to ignore your mother. When the caller ID kicked in, you simply didn't pick up. If she left a message, you accidentally "forgot" to check. Not that you had anything against the dear woman who gave you birth! You just didn't have the time, that particular moment, to deal. Lately, however, as Doree Shafrir and Jessica Grose's "Love, Mom: Poignant, Goofy, Brilliant Messages from Home" attests, mothers have found a new way to break through the protective cordon that their grown children throw around their private lives. It's called e-mail; and even a mom outfoxed by Twitter can whip out an e-mail subject line with Zorro-like flourish. Here's one: "Remember Me? Your mother? Call me." And another: "hi i want grandchildren." En garde!

Updated | April 5 The following blog post about the tactics of the protesters at the G-20 summit in London last week has been modified in response to some confusion among readers of the original version. The post's headline, intended to parody news reports that focused mainly on the outlandish costumes worn by some protesters, led some readers to take it as a serious attack on the protesters, rather than as an Onionesque joke about the media's reporting on the protesters. In fact the author was trying to ask if the tactics of the demonstrators, who used costumes and acts of street theater to attract cameras, might have had the unintended effect of distracting the media from the substance of their objections to the economic policies of the world leaders gathered for the summit.

Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief of American International Group, took a defiant tone Thursday in front of a House committee hearing investigating the collapse and government rescue of the insurance giant he once led.

The Financial Accounting Standards Board voted Thursday to give more discretion to bank managements in reporting the value of mortgage securities, The New York Times's Floyd Norris reports. The changes seem likely to allow banks to report higher profits by assuming that the securities are worth more than anyone is currently willing to pay for them.

If you're thinking of swinging by the brand-new Topshop in SoHo after work, prepare for craziness - and have a Plan B. Our strategy is to take refuge in the Madewell store a few doors away. Here's why. Lately we've been coveting distressed Balmain jeans but can't justify dropping four digits on French denim. That's where Madewell comes in. Tonight the store is selling its distressed jeans, which otherwise won't be available until the fall, and they cost from $175 to $225. (They're limited edition.) When I heard that Sana Krasikov had won the Jewish Book Council's $100,000 Sami Rohr Prize a few weeks ago, for her outstanding story collection "One More Year," I had two reactions. The first was: Yay! I loved Krasikov's book, which focuses largely on Russian and Georgian immigrants in America, and I'm always happy to see short stories celebrated and rewarded. The second was: The Jewish Book Council? According to its Web site, the Sami Rohr Prize (which alternates each year between fiction and nonfiction winners) "recognizes the unique role of contemporary writers in the transmission and examination of Jewish values, and is intended to encourage and promote outstanding writing of Jewish interest."

Nancy Clarke, the chief White House florist who has bedecked the Executive Mansion with roses, tulips, sweet peas and other blossoms since the days of the Carter administration, is retiring at the end of May, officials said on Thursday.

In Russia last week, two mothers were ordered by the courts to exchange the two-year-old boys whom they had each raised from birth but who did not belong to them. A nurse  the only one on duty in the main hospital of the city Mtsensk on a night when there were 20 newborns needing care  had mixed up the children in the nursery, sending each baby home with the wrong mother. The mistake was discovered recently when one of the mothers was going through some baby memorabilia and noticed, for the first time, that another woman's name was on her son's maternity ward identification tag.

BARI, Italy -- Soccer is a serious matter in Italy. You can be told that, and get the idea, but it's only when you're here that the reality sets in. It's a matter of national and vital importance. He gave a lengthy news conference and then stood in the lobby of the media center at the San Nicola Stadium still talking to any TV reporter who showed up.

Browns wide receiver Donte’ Stallworth was charged Wednesday with killing a pedestrian in Miami last month while driving drunk after a night out at a South Beach nightspot. An arrest warrant charging Stallworth, 28, with D.U.I. manslaughter was filed in the March 14 accident that killed Mario Reyes, 59. If convicted, Stallworth would face up to 15 years in prison. Stallworth’s blood-alcohol level after the crash was .126, well above Florida’s legal limit of .08, according to results of a blood test. Parfum d'Empire is a niche Parisian label run by Marc-Antoine Corticchiato, its owner, creative director and perfumer. A Corsican, Corticchiato has a love of the intense smells of islands - hot dust, sea salt, smoke, arid maritime plants. He also has a fascination with empire, which may be genetic: Corsica has been violently traded between warring powers for centuries, and the island has enjoyed a Mediterranean-side seat to the rises and falls of numerous empires, from Greek to Roman to French. In 1769, Corsica contributed to the last of these a boy named Napoleon, the future Empereur des Français, born in the port town of Ajaccio.

President Barack Obama’s aunt will remain in the United States until at least next year as she awaits a chance to make her case before an immigration judge in her bid for asylum from her native Kenya. At a hearing in Boston, a judge set the case of Zeituni Onyango, for Feb. 4, 2010. Ms. Onyango, 56, first applied for asylum in 2002, but was rejected and ordered deported in 2004. She did not leave the country and continued to live in public housing in Boston. Her lawyer said Ms. Onyango first applied for asylum because of violence in Kenya but did not reveal what grounds she had cited in her renewed bid.

The police arrested 125 people in Toronto following a series of raids on Wednesday morning that focused on gangs. The action involved about 1,000 police officers from several forces, including Toronto's police. Bill Blair, the city's police chief, said that 68 of the people arrested were involved in ''very significant'' crimes and that the action had ''dismantled'' three criminal gangs. About 40 guns, which are relatively restricted in Canada, were seized along with drugs and cash. Concern about gang violence in Toronto increased in January when a man was shot on a busy downtown subway platform. IAN AUSTEN

EGAN--Robert J. Longtime resident of Greenwich Village since 1957, died at the age of 91 on March 26, 2009. He is survived by his wife Adele Egan and sister Nae O'Connor and brother Paul Egan, several nieces and nephews from Springfield, MA where he was born. He served five years in the US Army Air Force during WWII. He organized the 11th Street Action Block Association in the mid 1970s with the help of several residents on the block he had several trees planted. He started newspaper recycling on the block with the help of Girl Scouts. He was an artist, a translator and in his youth toured as an actor in Shakespeare's plays. He loved music and was a radio DJ in Texas during the early 1950s. He attended the University of Southern California and the Arts Students League in New York City.

LATE GOALS IN EUROPE Spain and England scored late goals to maintain their winning records in World Cup qualifiers, and Ireland denied the world champion Italy a victory with a last-minute goal by Robbie Keane. Albert Riera's stoppage-time goal gave Spain, the European champion, a 2-1 win in Turkey, and John Terry scored with five minutes to go as England beat Ukraine, 2-1. The Netherlands, the only other team with a perfect record in European qualifying, beat Macedonia, 4-0.

RATCLIFFE--Alfred James, 61, of Shamong, passed away Friday, March 27, 2009, in St. Maarten, Netherland Antilles. Born in Manhattan, NY, Alfred was raised in the Bronx and Brooklyn. He moved to Shamong 23 years ago. He was a First Lieutenant with the U.S. Army, serving during the Vietnam War. While he was in the ROTC, he graduated with a B.S. in Accounting from Fordham University in the Bronx. Upon his discharge from the U.S. Army, Alfred attended Law School at St. John's University in Queens, and finished his law degree at the University of Houston, TX. He was a member of the AICPA, and was certified from the Texas State Bar Association. He was the Treasurer for Van Eck Global Investments in NY, and was a parishioner at the Church of the Holy Eucharist in Tabernacle. Father of the late Courtney Lynn Ratcliffe; brother of the late Thomas Ratcliffe; son of the late Ralph and Catherine Ratcliffe; he is survived by his wife of 40 years, Nancy (nee Dempsey) Ratcliffe; two sons, Shane and Brandon Ratcliffe both of Shamong; his daughter, Amanda Ratcliffe of Shamong; his brother Douglas Ratcliffe of Maywood, NJ; and his grandson, Nickolas Ratcliffe of Shamong. Relatives and friends may call on Monday, April 6, 2009, from 5-8pm, and again on Tuesday, April 7 from 9:30-10:30am, at the Church of the Holy Eucharist, 520 Medford Lakes Rd., Tabernacle. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10:30am, at the church. Services are by the Mathis Funeral Home, 58 N. Main St., Medford, (609) 654-2439. Interment will follow in Brig. Gen. Wm. C. Doyle Veterans Memorial Cemetery, Arneytown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Alfred's memory to the Make-A-Wish Foundation, P.O. Box 29119, Phoenix, AZ 85038; or to the Disabled American Veterans Association, P.O. Box 14301, Cincinnati, OH 45250.

BERGSON--Maria, died peacefully on Thursday, March 19th after a long illness. She was born in Vienna in 1914. After a brief but successful career in the theater working with Max Reinhardt, she came to America in 1940 and found a job as secretary and research assistant in the offices of Architectural Forum, a part of Time Inc. After the Managing Editor expressed unhappiness with her office layout, Maria suggested that it was "...because the designers have not paid attention to how you work." When challenged to propose something better, she redesigned that office, and then subsequently the offices of Time Inc. itself, and the firm of Maria Bergson Associates (MBA) was born. MBA revolutionized commercial office design. The old roll-top desk was replaced by interchangeable components forming work surfaces resting on different file cabinets, and her many innovations were publicized by Fortune Magazine in 1946. The firm's reputation continued to grow over a long period of time, and its business flourished with offices in New York, Los Angeles and London. In time she did work for many banks, but also for major companies in virtually all well-known industries. She even designed the Admiral's suite and the crew quarters of the first nuclear powered aircraft carrier, the Independence. Maria Bergson's family, who had all also left Vienna, were extremely important to her, and throughout her life she went to extraordinary lengths helping generations of her relatives. She is survived by her husband of 67 years, Thomas L. Brunner, and various nephews, grandnephews and grandnieces. There will be a service at 3:00pm on Friday April 3rd, at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel on Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

North Korea threatened on Wednesday to shoot down American military planes it said were spying on the site of an impending rocket launching. North Korea's government has announced that it would launch a satellite into orbit between Saturday and next Wednesday. North Korea regularly accuses American surveillance aircraft of intruding into its airspace, a claim the United States military dismisses as propaganda. The United States, South Korea and Japan say that North Korea is using the launching to test its long-range missile technology, a violation of a 2006 United Nations resolution banning the country from all ballistic missile tests; North Korea denies the claim.

A community activist who was compiling data about children killed in the earthquake in Sichuan Province in May has been detained on suspicion of subversion of state policies, a human rights group said Wednesday. He was detained Saturday by the Chengdu police, according to China Human Rights Defenders. His family could not be reached for comment.

Japanese companies are caught in a double bind, facing markets at home that are shrinking with the population as well as the global downturn. Nevertheless, companies must expand foreign sales aggressively -- or face longer-term decline. Exports from the world's No. 2 economy fell an unprecedented 49 percent in February. But even as Japanese policy makers call for a renewed focus on domestic markets, companies are tying themselves more tightly to overseas markets and innovation.

Strong winds and a leaky hull caused panic aboard an overcrowded ship that capsized in the seas off of Libya on Monday, and more than 230 of the 257 migrants aboard are presumed dead, officials from the International Organization for Migration said Wednesday. Survivors, interviewed by the organization at an assessment center outside of Tripoli, the Libyan capital, said that when their boat began to leak, most of the migrants rushed to one side, causing it to capsize, according to Jemini Pandya, a spokeswoman for the organization in Geneva. The search for additional survivors was called off Tuesday. ''As usual, the ship wasn't seaworthy, and there were no life jackets were on board, and it was overloaded,'' Ms. Pandya said. Every year, tens of thousands of poverty-stricken people try to cross from Libya to Italy, a favored destination for migrants seeking to circumvent European immigration restrictions.

Missiles fired from what was believed to be an American drone struck a militant training camp in northwest Pakistan on Wednesday, killing at least 10 people in an attack apparently aimed at one of the area's most important Taliban leaders, Hakimullah Mehsud, according to news reports, militants and an intelligence official. Mr. Mehsud escaped unhurt, the intelligence official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. The attack was the first of its kind in the Orakzai region, which lies southwest of Peshawar and close to the border with Afghanistan, residents said.

LACROSSE, derived from a game played by American Indians, is among the fastest-growing sports in the country. Participation by young players grew by 500 percent from 1999 to 2007, according to the most recent survey by US Lacrosse. That growth is reflected among boys and girls in high school, men and women in college (the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I men's final drew 48,970 fans to Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Mass., last May to see Syracuse defeat Johns Hopkins) and in the presence of indoor and outdoor professional leagues. With that swelling popularity comes an appetite and expectation for new and improved equipment. The newest lacrosse gloves, smaller than ice hockey gloves but bigger and with more padding than a pair of puffy Gore-Tex mittens, are about protection and flexibility -- with a dash of flash thrown in for good measure -- and, of course, sales. Some of them look like something out of ''RoboCop.''

One of the ongoing goals of the comic book industry — besides truth, justice, the American way and lots and lots of film adaptations — is to attract young readers. And among the better-received books for fledgling readers has been “Tiny Titans,” a young-ified version of the Teen Titans team staffed by Robin, Kid Flash and other superhero sidekicks, and which enters our paperback list at no. 8. “Tiny Titans is the best book out there – that doesn’t bog you down in continuity, has no serious side, and is great for all ages. This isn’t published frequently enough!!” wrote one fan on www.newsarama.com. Older comic book fans who want to see “tiny” versions of a lot of Titans and other DC heroes should check out the Web site of Art Baltazar, the book’s artist.

John Updike’s publisher recently asked me to read the audiobook version of “Endpoint,” his last book of poems. This is a task that Updike, who was a superb reader of his own work, would have undertaken for himself had he lived, and I was apprehensive about stepping in for him. My only qualifications, if you can call them that, are that I knew Updike and that I used to read a lot to my kids. From years of fidgeting and nodding off during poetry readings, though, I know just how hard it is to read verse well. Moreover, Updike wrote many of the poems in “Endpoint” while literally on his deathbed. They’re heartbreakingly sad, and I wasn’t sure I could get through them without blubbing. In the end, I didn’t, quite, though the poem that undid me was not one of the hospital meditations but “Peggy Lutz, Fred Muth,” which is a thank-you note and a farewell to his hometown, Shillington, Pa., and his high-school classmates, who he says gave him all the world he needed to write about. What’s touching is the poem’s generosity, and its rueful suggestion that maybe we find heaven at the beginning of our lives and not at the end.

The BBC has been fined by an independent regulator for a controversial prank call that was broadcast in October and perpetrated by the comedians Russell Brand and Jonathan Ross, The Associated Press reported. The Office of Communications fined the BBC about $219,000 for the incident, which occurred during a radio show hosted by Mr. Brand, when he and Mr. Ross left a series of lewd messages on the answering machine of the actor Andrew Sachs. In the ensuing controversy, which became known as Sachsgate, the BBC received thousands of complaints from listeners and was criticized by Prime Minster Gordon Brown. Mr. Brand, the star of “Forgetting Sarah Marshall” and author of “My Booky Wook,” resigned from his show, and Mr. Ross was suspended from television and radio for 12 weeks.

Sotheby’s has canceled the sale of an artifact believed to be a valuable Muslim relic after questions were raised about its authenticity, Reuters reported. In April 2008, Sotheby’s sold at auction in London a key believed to have been made in the 12th century and used to unlock the holy Kaaba, a sacred Islamic shrine in Mecca. At that time, the item sold for nearly $13.5 million, more than 18 times its pre-sale estimate. The Art Newspaper said that the key was brought to the British Museum about two weeks after the sale, where experts raised “serious doubts” about its age. In a statement, Sotheby’s said, “In light of the divergence of academic views, Sotheby’s and the consignor decided to cancel the sale in May 2008, pending further research and scientific analysis,” according to Reuters. The key has been returned to its original owner.

Anthony Lucki, chief executive of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, the educational and trade publisher that has lately struggled financially, has announced he will retire on April 15. Mr. Lucki, 60, had worked with Harcourt for 25 years before it was merged with Houghton Mifflin in 2007. Education Media and Publishing Group, an Irish private equity concern, first bought Houghton Mifflin three years ago and then Harcourt the following year. Barry O’Callaghan, chairman of Education Media and its largest shareholder, will assume the role of chief executive at Houghton. The company, which is one of the country’s largest publishers of textbooks for the K-12 market, also operates a trade publisher whose authors include Philip Roth and Günter Grass. Last month, Education Media said that after entertaining several bids for the trade and reference division of Houghton Mifflin, it would not be selling it. Education Media is currently shouldering $7 billion in debt. A company spokesman said the company expects to restructure its balance sheets in the next 60 to 90 days to lighten the debt load.

Bollywood film producers were expected to go on strike Saturday after failing to arrive at a revenue-sharing agreement with movie theater owners, BBC News reported. Indian film producers are threatening to stop making new movies if they do not receive a 50 percent share of the revenue raised by multi-screen movie theaters; theater owners say that producers stand to make a disproportionate share of revenues, and that they will continue to show older films on their screens until the dispute is resolved. The BBC said that the $2 billion a year Indian film industry now earns as much as 70 percent of its revenue from multi-screen theaters. In October, Indian film and television production was briefly brought to a halt when a leading Bollywood union of actors, writers and technicians went on strike, demanding better working conditions.

The last time a president traveled to Europe during his first 100 days in office, perhaps the most enlightening moment of the journey had more to do with fashion than foreign policy. Stepping off the plane in Paris in February 1969, Richard Nixon had a moment of sartorial panic, according to his biographer Richard Reeves: " 'Here we go -- Vive la France!' Nixon said as he walked to the door to meet President de Gaulle at the bottom of the plane's steps. He saw that his host was wearing no coat in the bitter cold and stripped his own overcoat off before he stepped out the door."

Volkswagen has announced that it will no longer sell its bread-and-butter car in the United States as the Rabbit and will return to the Golf nameplate. The change is a reminder of how few animal names remain on cars. Yes, Impala is still going strong; it has been a Chevrolet model since 1958. But cars now often seem to carry names and numbers generated by computers. Once, there were more powerful, totemic animal names that lent cars personality.

Lox isn't really lox. Or rather, the salmon that we put on bagels and call "lox" is really just smoked salmon. True lox is salmon that's cured, packed in more salt than you can imagine and left for weeks or even months on end. It's still made, though few people eat it; it's fleshier and firmer than smoked salmon, with a saltiness that will not stop.

LOS ANGELES - The line wore black, mostly. At 6 o'clock last night, 100 or so people queued up at Taschen's in Beverly Hills to meet the legendary designer Valentino, who was scheduled to sign copies of his new book, "Valentino: A Grand Italian Epic." Ten minutes later, he breezed in, with a small entourage of equally tanned and impeccably dressed men. (It was hard to believe that just one block north, another crowd was queuing up for Frappuccinos at Starbucks.)

A couple of months ago I had the great honor to go to the West African capital of Bamako, Mali, to collaborate on a photo shoot with the renowned Malian photographer Malick Sidibe. I have admired Sidibe's work for a long time, and the idea for the shoot (which is featured in the style section of this Sunday's New York Times Magazine and online) was to dress the models (Sidibe's extended family, including many of his 17 sons and daughters) in a mix of the printed and often African-inspired clothes from the spring collections. When it came time for the actual shoot, I started selecting combinations of models for the shots and getting people dressed. Instead of the usual hundreds and hundreds of frames per shot that I had become accustomed to in this era of digital photography, Sidibe took only two or three frames for every shot. When the shoot was over, he had only shot 22 frames on his Rolleiflex! Sidibe has an infectious smile and doles out his words of wisdom to those who come to visit him at his studio in the Bagadadji neighborhood of Bamako. Below are his typically off-the-cuff responses to a few questions I sent him via e-mail after the shoot. As they say, a picture is worth a thousand words.

The Iowa Supreme Court struck down as unconstitutional the state's 1998 law limiting marriage to a man and a woman. Iowa now becomes the third state in the country, along with Massachusetts and Connecticut, to allow gay marriage. The decision is considered groundbreaking because no Midwestern state has permitted same-sex marriage, and at least six in the region have adopted constitutional amendments banning gay marriage.

Appearing today on our virtual refrigerator: Sarah, a 10th-grader in Mrs. Benjamin's Honors Crafts class at Millburn High School, created this multimedia self-portrait, using fabric, embroidery thread and textile paint. Michael A. Cardozo set a record on Friday when he became New York City's longest-serving corporation counsel since the position was permanently established in 1839. Mr. Cardozo, who has served seven years and three months, is the 55th lawyer to hold the job, and on Friday he surpassed William C. Whitney, who held the job from 1875 to 1882.

Read between the lines of a recent study out of Australia and you can see hints of a coming shift in the gender conversation. Researchers at the University of Queensland found that children born to older fathers have, on average, lower scores on tests of intelligence than those born to younger dads. Data they analyzed from more than 33,000 American children showed that the older the man when a child is conceived, the lower a child's score is likely to be on tests of concentration, memory, reasoning and reading skills, at least through age 7.

Miso is a superb thickener: whisk it into a small amount of liquid and it creates a rich, creamy consistency. When you add it with a little wine to the juices in a saute pan after searing a pork chop, it becomes a great sauce with almost no work.

"Fast and Furious," the attempt to reinvigorate the street racing franchise with the return of original stars Vin Diesel, Paul Walker, Jordana Brewster and Michelle Rodriquez is poised to dominated the weekend box-office, perhaps even providing the biggest April opening ever, Variety says. The Hollywood Reporter says the action-thriller could end up with $45 million or more at the box office. Entertainment Weekly's Hollywood Insider predicts $41 million. The Box Office Guru predicts $43 million. Meanwhile, the film is taking a drubbing from critics. Rottentomatoes.com, which keeps a tally of reviews, says that only 31 percent of the top critics it surveys gave "Fast and Furious a positive review.

For more than a century, Pullman porters were a part of luxury American train travel until the pressures of jet and car travel started the demise of high-end sleeper cars about 40 years ago. Now the last generation of porters -- who played a critical role in African-American history -- is rapidly dying off. And Amtrak is in a desperate attempt to locate the last few for National Train Day.

The two-time defending champion United States will play Honduras, Haiti and Grenada in the first round of the Concacaf Gold Cup, soccer’s championship of North and Central America and the Caribbean. The United States opens against Grenada in Group B on July 4 in Seattle, then faces Honduras on July 8 in Washington, and Haiti on July 11 at Foxborough, Mass. The top two teams from each group advance to the quarterfinals, along with the two best third-place teams. The final is July 26 at East Rutherford, N.J. Matches also will be played in Chicago, Miami, Philadelphia and Arlington, Tex. ¶Sven-Goran Eriksson was fired as Mexico’s coach, a day after a 3-1 loss to Honduras in a World Cup qualifier. Eriksson had a 6-6-1 record with Mexico, but the team had just three wins, six losses and a draw in its last 10 matches. Eriksson, a 61-year-old Swede, is a former England coach and the first foreigner to coach Mexico in 11 years. He was hired in June to replace the Mexican star Hugo Sánchez, who was fired after the country’s under-23 team failed to qualify for the Olympics. Eriksson stirred controversy inside a country fiercely loyal to its national team when he added four naturalized citizens to the roster. mexico.

Vick, who left a federal prison in Kansas last week to travel to Virginia, was in court for the first time in the case. He was scheduled to testify Friday.

A federal judge on Thursday ruled that some prisoners held by the American military in Afghanistan have a constitutional right to challenge their imprisonment in United States civilian courts, delivering a rebuke to a claim of unfettered executive power advanced by both the Bush and Obama administrations. In 53-page ruling, Judge John D. Bates of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia said that three detainees at the United States Air Force base at Bagram are ''virtually identical'' to detainees at the Navy base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and so they have the same legal rights that the Supreme Court last year granted prisoners held there.

MUNOZ Eric M.D. New Jersey has lost a leading Trauma Surgeon and State Legislator who dedicated his life to his family, helping people and protecting the most vulnerable residents of New Jersey. New Jersey State Assemblyman Eric Munoz, M.D., a Trauma Surgeon and Professor of Surgery at UMDNJ-University Hospital, Newark, died on Monday, March 30, 2009 following complications of cardiac surgery at University Hospital. Born in the Bronx, Assemblyman Munoz, M.D. graduated from The Peddie School, University of Virginia and received his Medical Doctorate from Albert Einstein College of Medicine and completed his surgical training at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Dr. Munoz, who was one of the first physicians to become actively involved in health delivery costs, quality and management as an academic discipline, had an M.B.A. in Finance from Columbia University. Assemblyman Munoz began his career serving as Councilman-at-Large for the City of Summit; and served as Chairman of the Summit City Republican Municipal Committee. In 2007 Assemblyman Munoz was elected to his fourth two-year term representing Legislative District 21 with his colleagues Senator Tom Kean and Assemblyman Jon Bramnick. He is the highest ranking Hispanic Republican in the New Jersey Legislature. Assemblyman Munoz is predeceased by his parents, William and Frances Munoz. He is survived by his devoted wife, Nancy Foster Munoz, their children, William, Eric, Alexander, Elizabeth and Maximilian, his brother Michael Munoz, M.D., and his sister Wendy Lerrick and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins.

Thousands of Greeks went on strike Thursday in an action that labor unions said was timed to coincide with the Group of 20 summit meeting in London. The 24-hour strike was the latest show of opposition to austerity measures taken by the center-right government in response to the global financial crisis. It was the second such action since the police shooting of a 15-year-old boy in December set off riots and labor unrest over the country's sharp economic downturn. The strike on Thursday grounded more than 160 domestic and international flights. Across the country, commercial ships remained anchored at harbors; in Athens, the transportation system operated briefly to allow protesters to get to the center of the city to take part in protest marches.

The Books of The Times review on Monday was about ''Saviors and Survivors: Darfur, Politics and the War on Terror,'' by Mahmood Mamdani, a professor of government at Columbia University. The review was written by Howard W. French, a former reporter for The New York Times who is now an associate professor at Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism and does not know the author. But had editors known of Mr. Mamdani's affiliation with Columbia at the time the review was assigned, the review would not have been assigned to a member of the Columbia faculty.

REISS--Alfred A. Longtime resident of Manhasset, Long Island passed on March 31, 2009 at the age of ninety-five. He is survived by his son Rob Reiss, his wife Sefra, his daughter Adrienne McCormick, her husband Brian and their daughter Carly. Alfred was also the grandfather of three wonderful dogs, Tessie, Zoey and Jake Tiberius. His wife of forty-eight years Rose passed in 1997. Alfred served in the U.S. Army during World War II stationed throughout the south Pacific and Hawaii. Professionally, he worked for Douglas Leigh and Van Wagner Communications (outdoor advertising) as a Senior Vice President. After retiring at eighty, he volunteered his time teaching ESL classes at the International School and enjoyed the comradery at the JCC in Roslyn, Long Island. He will be missed.
