A worker for the International Committee of the Red Cross who was kidnapped 11 weeks ago with two colleagues by an Islamic extremist group has been freed and is in the custody of the Philippine military, officials said Thursday. It was unclear if the worker, Mary Jean Lacaba, 37, had been rescued by the military or was released by the Islamist group, Abu Sayyaf, which is known for kidnappings. The three Red Cross workers, Ms. Lacaba of the Philippines, Andreas Notter of Switzerland and Eugenio Vagni of Italy, were abducted Jan. 15 in Sulu, an island province in the southern Philippines, after visiting a water sanitation project at a provincial jail. The military has fought the extremists in recent weeks in attempts to free the hostages.

'ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO' (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series ''Dora the Explorer'' and ''Go, Diego, Go!'' have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments, including Diego's Animal Rescue Center and Dora's Fiesta. Intended for ages 2 to 6, the interactive, bilingual displays are designed to teach language, science and music skills, as well as facts about Latin America. From 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (until 8 p.m. this Friday), Tisch Building, 212 West 83rd Street, (212) 721-1223, cmom.org. Free with museum admission: $10; $7 for 65+; free for under 1 and members; free for all from 5 to 8 p.m. this Friday.20090402 'ARCHAEOLOGY ZONE: DISCOVERING TREASURES FROM PLAYGROUNDS TO PALACES' (Sunday through Wednesday) Children will step into the shoes of an explorer like Indiana Jones in this exhibition at the Jewish Museum, but the adventures will be purely scholarly. Still, there is plenty of excitement in analyzing artifacts like a jar handle, a clay jug and a bangle and figuring out the purpose behind ancient pieces like a Greek helmet and a bull-shaped vessel. This interactive show also includes a recreated room from the Ottoman period (about 1900), where young archaeologists can dress in costume. (Through June 15.) From 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., except this Wednesday, open only until 2 p.m. The Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200, thejewishmuseum.org. Free with admission: $12; $10 for 65+; $7.50 for students; free for under 12 and members.20090402

THERE is no mystery why the Spanish development company Taylor Woodrow de España is offering fractionals after years of avoiding such plans. STEINGART--Jacob "Jack", longtime psychologist and Acting Team Leader for the Veterans Administration in East Los Angeles, died on March 26 at the age of 78. Born April 1, 1930 in New York City, Jack began to systematically pursue degrees from every available academic institution including Stuyvesant High School, City College of New York, New York University, The New School and Columbia University, where he received his doctorate in psychology. In 1974, Jack and his family moved to California where he also received an MBA from the Claremont Graduate School. Jack's career spanned from engineer at the Emerson Radio Corporation to industrial psychologist at IBM and the Atlantic Richfield Corporation. He also taught at California State University Fullerton and California State University Long Beach. Jack found his greatest happiness at the VA in East Los Angeles where he had the privilege of serving the veterans of the United States Armed Services who affectionately knew him as "Doctor Jack." He was a veteran of the United States Army as a Lieutenant in the Korean War. Jack is survived by Liz, his wife of 54 years, his son Benjamin of Oakland, CA, his son Jon and his wife Jenny of New York City, and his adoring grandchildren Leo and Ruby who loved their "Abuelito".

McCRAW--Charles B. A creative artist whose life encompassed the worlds of dance, music, and education, passed away on Tuesday, March 31, 2009. He was born in Troy, North Carolina, in 1921. A graduate of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, he was a veteran of World War ll, having served in the Navy. He is survived by his cousin Emelyn Wolford-Commins of North Carolina. McCraw was an original cast member of the Broadway production of Brigadoon in 1947. He was also a dancer in the original Broadway production of Pal Joey in 1952, as well as in subsequent revivals of these musicals. A participant in the post-war dance scene, McCraw's correspondence with the leading players is documented in the Parmenia Migel Ekstrom Archive and in the George Balanchine Archive, both housed at Harvard University. Documents at The Performing Arts Library of the New York Public Library record McCraw's work with the choreographer Agnes de Mille. McCraw's published works include "Scoreography" (1964), a study on dance notation. His musical compositions include the folk opera Trista and the choral work The Annunciation. He taught for many years at the High School of Performing Arts in New York City, and was also music director at the First Presbyterian Church in Maywood, NJ. A wake will be held Friday 5-9pm at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, New York, NY. Funeral service Saturday 1:00pm at the First Presbyterian Church, Maywood, NJ, Tel: 201-845-6005. Viewing one hour prior to service. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the performing arts organization of your choice.

Re "Bad News, and More Bad News" (March 15): Not being a 5-year-old child anymore, I'd much rather hear the truth (however grim) than a fairy tale (however rosy and upbeat).So let The Times continue to tell it like it is. Until we know, in full, what's happening, we won't be able to tell what's wrong, much less how to counteract it.I think that people who object to The Times's reporting of the whole picture are mostly those who don't want the rest of us to put two and two together and come up with four equals Bush.Tamara P. DuvallLexington, Va., March 15, 2009 ● I usually read your column with interest, if not always with agreement. But I am, after all, a consenting adult and know what I am letting myself in for when I read the Op-Ed pages of The Times. But today's column touched bottom in a way that the economy probably hasn't yet done.You excuse Peter S. Goodman, a national economics correspondent, for his use of the word "depression" in a way that strains belief. First, you quote him as saying, "My master is reality." What sort of reality is he referring to? I would hope he means an evidence-based reality, but support for his reality takes the form of the "Nine out of 10 dentists recommend Crest" advertisement - true if you pick the right 10 dentists.In Mr. Goodman's case, he refers to "two respected economists" - an easier group to assemble even than the 10 dentists - but one does worry about who is doing the respecting. These two economists volunteered, "in separate interviews" (that's important, since it implies no collusion on their part), that the use of the word "depression" was allowable (for the Mark Zandi quote) on the grounds that "the odds of a 'mild depression' were up to 25 percent."This is ambiguous. It might mean that the odds had now increased to 25 percent (one in four, presumably), having previously been lower, or that those odds were now less than or equal to 25 percent, in which case one should ask, "How much less than 25 percent could that mean?" Which of these interpretations was implied?On top of this, the other economist, Allen Sinai, saw a 20 percent chance of a "depressionlike possibility," which does tend to boggle one's mind a bit. Since a 20 percent chance is a 20 percent possibility, he sees the possibility of a possibility that resembles a depression.On these two opinions does Mr. Goodman justify himself, and you support him! Really!Anthony PoëOttawa, March 15, 2009 ● While I agree that it is not the responsibility of the news media to be a cheerleader, or to falsely represent that things are better than they perceive them to be, I think that you missed a bigger point.No one can deny that much of what is happening in this economy is psychologically driven. The psychology of a market will drive it up (think "bubbles"), and it can, as is now happening, drive a market down.I think the point is that reporting in the present situation implies that the "bad news" is independent of the personal decisions of the public. The result is that people react to the bad news, creating a cycle that becomes self-fulfilling.You should do an in-depth study focused on how many people are sitting on the sidelines waiting for the "bottom" to then get back into the market (whether it be housing, stocks, business expansions, startups, etc).I don't doubt that the bad news is real. I just think that the element of how the bad news in and of itself creates a downward spiral is missing from the coverage.Bruce GorenLos Angeles, March 15, 2009 ● I think The Times needs to tell it like it is and not sugarcoat things because there are those who want something less than the truth.I think The Times does a fine job! I do think, however, that The Times, and the media in general, did less than a fine job of sounding the warning and challenging the Bush administration on the thinking and events leading up to war in Iraq. Everyone was going easy on telling the truth because of the public mood and for fear of losing advertising dollars.We must not repeat that mistake again. A free society cannot exist without newspapers that tell the truth.Larry A. DeyssDelmar, N.Y., March 16, 2009●●Re "Those Persistent Anonymous Sources" (March 22): Since you indicate that some critics of anonymous sources were themselves insisting on anonymity, let me help with comments that are on the record:In every job I have had in 45 years of journalism, from PBS to CBS News to Westinghouse (later the same company) to ABC to NPR and even as far back as college radio, anonymous sources have done their best to obscure and mislead to serve their own (or their bosses') interests, hiding disinformation behind a cloak of anonymity. Best is to treat them just as you would treat an anonymous letter: that is where reporting should start, not stop.When I was head of NPR News, over and over again anonymous sources attempted to manipulate us in all of the usual ways. But when I insisted that NPR reporters try to get sources to go on the record, in every case - every case - the story was strengthened.For example, the anonymous source's criticisms of the F.B.I. were, stripped of anonymity, then confirmed by the F.B.I. itself. That made it a better story, no?Another anonymous source's accusations about a Supreme Court nominee were, when pressed, eventually confirmed by the judge himself - and before our deadline that afternoon. Better, don't you think?And a classic election-eve anonymous source unloading a late hit against a presidential candidate was unmasked when his information, just too good to be true, was in fact, as usual, too good to check out (which is not to say that others don't fall for that clichéd gambit).When I was a reporter, when my editors asked me to go back to my sources to insist they go on the record, my sources either relented or showed how I could document their information by other means. After all, the reason they become sources is (in almost all cases) to get the story published, right?Four decades of journalism have convinced me that anonymous sources are almost never needed. Rather, they have become the crack cocaine of the newsroom, peddled everywhere for a quick hit. It's time to break the habit.Adam Clayton Powell IIIHong Kong, March 26, 2009 ●Some of the stories by the sources you cite would be inadmissible in a trial, being mostly gossip or uncorroborated.You mention 2004 as the time that this policy was adopted. I think back to stories in The Times that helped drum up the war pre-2004. And, of course, the story that Robert D. Novak let out was and still is, I think, criminal.I've been a lifelong reader of The Times, but I don't put much faith is today's so-called journalists caring much about "the truth." Filling space and time 24/7 seems the primary need of news organizations. I have to trust my own radar to delete the gossip, misleading statements and downright lies I read and hear.J. T. HollandWashington, March 22, 2009 ● There are questionable ethics involved when The Times publishes statements by officials who request anonymity "because they are not authorized to comment publicly." These officials are breaking the rules and perhaps even the law, and The Times, by publishing their comments, is abetting them. Perhaps you could comment on this in a future column.Jim LincolnConcord, Mass., March 22, 2009 ● As a reporter who covered Washington for more than 30 years, I am increasingly annoyed by the nonattribution explanations that slow up reading The Times and other papers.Why should I care that a source was "not authorized to speak to the press"? What I care about is the information provided by the source. What I rely on is not the identity of a source but the reputation of the reporter whose byline appears on the story and the reputation for accuracy of the newspaper that publishes the report. When I was covering the Pentagon for The Washington Star and U.S. News & World Report, almost everything worth knowing was secret or above. Of course my sources for such information were anonymous, often to the chagrin of secretaries of defense and other officials who wanted to know: "How did he know that?"Often, there was no single "source" at all. Reporters covering such a Byzantine place as the Pentagon get a bit of information here and another there, putting them together into a revealing story. When I went to one source with what I thought was the basis for a story, he would tell me: "No, that's not right. Now, if you asked me . . . I would say that's classified and I can't talk about it."My non-source was thus in a position, if asked, to say truthfully that he told me he couldn't talk about that subject while, of course, he had steered me in the right direction. I know The Times and other papers have been burned by reporters who simply lied about sources or were misled by trusted sources. But the answer to that problem is not silly rules that simply slow up the reader, but the hiring of reporters and editors of the highest integrity.Orr KellyBethesda, Md., March 22, 2009● While there are certainly times when anonymity is needed or deserved, as you point out, lately the reference to those sources seems to be used too often. And that makes one wonder whether there is really any basis to what is being reported.For instance, I read with great interest "Love Was Blind," about Bank of America and Merrill Lynch (Business Day, Feb. 8) - until I hit the following paragraph: "Interviews with almost 30 current and former Bank of America and Merrill executives and employees convey just how messy the merger has been. All of them asked not to be identified because they either did not have permission from the banks to speak or because they had signed confidentially agreements with their former employers."Almost 30 people! All of whom spoke without authority to do so or broke their written word not to do so. At that point the reporters lost me. How could I believe the story when none of their almost 30 sources could be independently verified?John L. GoldmanRochester, March 23, 2009 ● Hats off to you for taking on the issue of anonymous sources. The difficulty of the challenge was obvious - again - in the very same issue in which your column appeared.At the end of a long business story about the so-called food revolution - hardly the kind of story that would seem to require cloak and dagger secrecy - "a prominent food industry lobbyist who requested anonymity because he wasn't authorized to speak to reporters" was mentioned.The earth-shattering revelation that justified this cover-up by the reporter? That the lobbyist was "amazed" to see many members of Congress carrying a best-selling book ("The Omnivore's Dilemma"). Secrecy won out in the business section on March 24, when Andrew Sorkin in the Dealbook column quotes "one senior Goldman executive who insisted on not being quoted by name for fear of crossing the Treasury Department."This in a newspaper that has constantly railed in recent months about the lack of transparency in the gargantuan financial industry bailout. Seems like the reporters and columnists are being permitted - maybe encouraged? - to be enablers of the very lack of transparency that they decry.There's little reason to think that the flood of unnamed sources will slow down much. But you shining a light on this problem at least makes the reporters and editors squirm a bit.Frank HamsherSt. Louis, March 24, 2009 ● It seems as though when discussing non-people facts, the source should be available and be willing to be quoted.When talking about opinion or theory, who cares about the source? The important aspect is for people to evaluate the message - not the messenger.All messengers are consciously or unconsciously biased anyway. And to a large extent the news media do no favors by substituting messenger evaluation for message evaluation.Paul F. HosmanKalamazoo, Mich., March 22, 2009 ● I enjoyed your column discussing the reasons informants are not identified.I've been fascinated by the endless number of explanations. I like the variety - there seems to be an obligation to come up with new excuses for granting anonymity. I particularly like it when explanations are at least somewhat factual - "feared the consequences of identifying himself," "did not have permission to speak" or "because of the sensitivity of the subject."To be really factual, how about, "We were afraid we would be sued," or "The Editor is a coward"?Dick SherwoodSouth Dartmouth, Mass., March 22, 2009 ●One major problem with the practice of offering sources anonymity is that it is simply extraordinarily contagious. People read the paper, notice the prevalence of unnamed sources, and wonder why they should speak on the record when no one else does.The reasons for desiring to remain out of the spotlight in our increasingly polarized and dangerous society are entirely understandable. Newspaper reporters certainly have a daunting task of persuading people to speak on the record added to the chore of writing a thorough and fair piece, but if editors and publishers don't enforce standards with consistency, the whole enterprise becomes indistinguishable from gossip mongering.Think for a moment of newspapers' main competition - television newscasts.How often do we see TV relying on unidentified sources? Sure, once in a while we get the blurred face, anonymous silhouette, or distorted voice, but it's remarkably rare. If you want to provide information or comment on a TV news story, you not only get your name used, but you are usually photographed. Why can't print news make the same demands?Charles ClouseSanta Barbara, Calif., March 24, 2009 ● You write, "The policy says anonymous sources should be used only as 'a last resort when the story is of compelling public interest and the information is not available any other way.'"Maybe if editors designated assignments in advance so that reporters knew which stories they would be covering would not be news of "compelling public interest," the reporters would recognize that they simply could not get certain stories published with any anonymous sources.It also seems as if reporters covering compelling news should have to justify in writing their use of anonymous sources. They should have to explain at a minimum why anonymity is a last resort, efforts they have made to get the source on the record and how their investigation has led them to conclude that the information could not be obtained from another reliable open source.Although it may not always be possible, the reporter's pledge of anonymity should be given only after the reporter has obtained prior written approval from an editor, with that editor's written conclusions as to why anonymity is being granted.While forcing reporters and editors to document in writing the grant of anonymity in each case might be somewhat burdensome at first, it seems that if the procedures were put in place as regular expectations, both reporters and editors would adapt. It is also likely that both groups would become less willing to grant anonymity, except in extraordinary cases.As with the corrections page of The Times, it is possible that the newspaper could include a daily anonymous sourcing note, explaining in which story (or stories) anonymity had been granted and why.Patrick MattimoreGex, France, March 22, 2009 ● Consider this: A reporter quotes an anonymous source in an article and a lawsuit is filed, perhaps for defamation of character or false accusations. Should the reporter have to testify and name the anonymous source who gave the information that resulted in the lawsuit?Over the last 15 years, and even more so during the last 8, I believe there are a number of factors that contributed to the rise in the use of anonymous sources: (1) A real fear that making an accusation on the record could result in losing one's job or being ostracized by a community; (2) the fast pace at which news breaks means that reporters don't always have the time to look for other sources before writing a story; and (3) a general sense that citing an anonymous source adds credibility to any story.Unfortunately, the overall acceptance of anonymous source reporting means we have now found ourselves living in a culture where all one has to do is make an anonymous accusation or give an anonymous tip and it becomes fact in newsrooms around the world. No confirmation required. Lives and careers have been destroyed as a result of that policy.Rebekah JensenMorrisville, N.C., March 22, 2009●●Re "No Comment. But You Didn't Hear It From Me" (March 29): I hope that you will take a look at The Times's policies and practices in identifying "people in the street" in articles from places with repressive governments, particularly when they make critical comments.I have the impression that too often The New York Times relies on interviewees to request anonymity rather than expecting its reporters and/or editors to provide it, even if not requested, in potentially risky situations.The exact name of a noodle salesman in Shanghai really does not add enough to a story to justify putting his freedom or even life at risk.Minot NettletonWoodbridge, Conn., March 29, 2009 ● As a onetime ink-stained wretch and later a P.R. man, your column on anonymous sources and spokesmen grabbed me. I find objectionable the widespread use of aides or P.R. people as spokesmen for decision-makers. Whatever happened to the management maxim, "The buck stops here"- the code that disapproved of leaders passing the buck down the line and shirking their duties?I was taught that the media-relations role of a P.R. person is as a liaison between management and the press: to arrange for a reporter to speak directly to the person responsible for the part of the organization in which the reporter is interested.Management people are often reluctant to speak to the press and prefer to hide behind a spokesman. Fortunately, my boss accepted my perspective and, as C.E.O., was able to insist that except for requests for commonplace information, appropriate managers, not P.R. people, speak with reporters.Hal HoldenNorth Vancouver, British Columbia, March 29, 2009 ● I don't want to know why anonymous quotes are unattributed or off the record. That answer is usually vague, vacuous and formulaic, and provides no useful context or resulting import.I want to know why these sources are talking. Every reporter should ask this every time. "Why are you telling me this?" That's the context I need to understand the information (spin?) that sources are providing.Yes, in many (most) cases you'll get hand-waving and fatuity. And in many cases the reporter knows the answer perfectly well already. But your readers don't.And if reporters don't ask the question, they are quite reasonably precluded from imputing the source's motive(s) in print. This leaves your readers to do that imputing (and they will do so) absent the context necessary to do so.If the question is asked - and pressed - every time, it could have some small effect on the culture of anonymity. Sources might have to actually ask themselves the question. Even if they spin the answer, they might not be able to do so with complete success. (Think: reporters' Spidey senses.) In some cases, the source's answer would provide a necessary context or frame or lens through which I can discern the true import of what is being reported and quoted. The source's statements, so framed, might take on a significantly different or even opposite meaning. In some cases, the frame is the story.Over time the pressure of the question being consistently asked and pressed - and the answer being reported - could result in a salutary change to the overly cozy culture in whose talons reporters so often find themselves pinioned.Steve RothSeattle, March 30, 2009

An officer who said he shot a drunken driver to save his own life was found guilty of second-degree manslaughter.
The U.S. unemployment rate reached 8.5 percent, its highest level in a quarter-century, in a sign of the severity of the downturn.

The questioning of Avigdor Lieberman, the new foreign minister of Israel, continued into Friday, as part of a longstanding investigation into suspicions of bribery, money laundering and breach of trust.
Australia’s markets watchdog is suing Fortescue Metals, and its chief, Andrew Forrest, accusing them of misleading investors over Chinese deals five years ago.
Determined to demonstrate its latest missile technology, North Korea pressed ahead with final preparations on Friday to launch a multistage rocket.
At the end of the week, markets on Wall Street managed to eke out a small gain for the day after some strong gains for the week.

When the Cubs' Aaron Miles drilled a pitch into right field Friday night, the Yankees fan Tim Maresca looked around, unsure what to do. Had Xavier Nady made a catch, or had the ball dropped fair for the first base hit at the new Yankee Stadium? The collective groan answered that question. ''I guess that landed fair,'' said Maresca, 32.

Ebbets Field opened in 1913 and closed in 1957. Shea Stadium was the site of major league baseball from 1964 to 2008. Which means that the home of the Brooklyn Dodgers and the home of the New York Mets both survived as major league venues for just 45 seasons. The coincidence is compelling because those two ballparks seem like partners these days, with Ebbets Field serving as the architectural, and even emotional, inspiration for Citi Field and Shea still fresh in people's minds as the imperfect place the Mets played imperfect baseball.

Ever since Michelle Obama departed for Europe with her husband, taking along a wardrobe of designer clothes and revealing a new hairdo, her meeting with Carla Sarkozy, the wife of the French president, had been anticipated as a fashion face-off between two stylish first ladies. Their meeting on Friday, at the Palais Rohan in Strasbourg, France, was not quite that. Indeed, Mrs. Obama and Mrs. Sarkozy looked remarkably similar, suggesting that both women know fashion -- and themselves -- pretty well. Each wore a coat with a soft bow at the neck and low-heeled shoes. Mrs. Sarkozy's gray lambskin coat was a Dior, while Mrs. Obama's Jacquard silk coat was by the American designer Thakoon Panichgul, as was her short-sleeved fuchsia dress.

The Obama administration has before it a rare opportunity to establish an aggressive -- and unified -- national standard for automobile fuel economy that could save consumers money at the pump, reduce oil dependency and greenhouse gases and help make America's car companies (or what's left of them after the present restructuring) more competitive. Doing so will require overcoming bureaucratic obstacles and harmonizing state and federal mandates. And that will mean intervention by the White House, specifically Carol Browner, the president's coordinator on energy and environmental matters, whose job description includes unraveling just this kind of knot.

It's almost as if they hadn't been away. Ten years after the release of their last recording of new material, Los Fabulosos Cadillacs, perhaps the most innovative Spanish-language rock group of the 1990s, are back: on the road, playing in stadiums; on MTV again; and with a new CD. In fact, the only real surprise about the return of the Cadillacs, who are scheduled to play on Sunday at the Hammerstein Ballroom, may be that they dropped out of sight in the first place. This Argentine band was at the peak of its popularity in Latin America and building a following in the United States when it simply stopped recording and then touring. There were no visible signs of internal squabbling, no announcement of a breakup or even of a timeout, just a sudden silence.

With 663,000 more jobs disappearing from the American economy last month, swelling the total number of jobs surrendered to the recession beyond five million, the government's response to the downturn is being put to a strenuous test. When drafting plans in January to spend roughly $800 billion to stimulate the deteriorating economy, the Obama administration operated on the assumption that the unemployment rate would reach 8.9 percent by the end of the year -- without the extra federal spending. Three months into the year, the unemployment rate has already soared to 8.5 percent, from 7.6 percent, the highest level in more than a quarter-century.

Ty Lawson raised some eyebrows on Thursday for his off-court activities in Detroit. Lawson, a junior guard for North Carolina, said he had won $250 at one of the downtown casinos. On Friday, Lawson said he found it funny how big a story his trip to the casino became.

Going once, going twice, sold to the crazed Mets fan in Queens. That is what the Mets are hoping for next week when they auction some of the last remaining seats to the team's home opener on April 13. Unable to sell about 100 of the most expensive season tickets, the team -- for the first time -- is letting fans bid on them for the home opener at Citi Field.

The green and white denizens from Michigan State have begun to flood Detroit. The coaches convention is in full swing, as evidenced by the number of tall men walking zombielike around downtown, punching their BlackBerrys and not paying attention. But what about the games? Oh, those. After a few coaches were queried, two consensus thoughts emerged. The first was that North Carolina was the runaway favorite, and that a North Carolina-Connecticut matchup Monday night would make for great theater and big ratings. The second thought was that the two games Saturday were expected to have two distinct styles, with the North Carolina-Villanova game predicted to have a faster tempo than Michigan State-Connecticut. Same-sex couples will be allowed to marry in Iowa by month's end, after a ruling on Friday by the Iowa Supreme Court that found unconstitutional a state law limiting marriage to a man and a woman. The unanimous decision moved the heated battle over same-sex marriage beyond the East and West Coasts to the nation's middle. Only Massachusetts and Connecticut now allow same-sex marriages, while California permitted them for about six months before voters approved a ban in November.

President Obama, appearing on the eve of a NATO summit meeting here, told a cheering crowd of young people on Friday that ''America is changing, but it cannot be America alone that changes.'' The gathering resembled any of the countless, similar rallies held during his presidential campaign. But this one took place in the Alsatian border region of France and Germany, not in a gymnasium in Des Moines, and Mr. Obama seemed bent on repairing soured trans-Atlantic relations that began with the American-led invasion of Iraq in 2003.

During a decade of easy credit and loose spending, American businesses built too many cars, houses, stores and factories. It turns out the country built too many restaurants, too. Now consumers are cutting back, and dining out is among the casualties. Finer restaurant chains have been hit hard, and so have the casual sit-down places that flooded suburban shopping centers and tourist districts across the country, aimed straight at middle American tastes.

The ailing economy continues to pull more Americans into bankruptcy court, where the number of troubled consumers filing for protection soared in March to its highest level since October 2005, when a new law made it more arduous and expensive to file. And as job losses continue to climb, they may well drag bankruptcy filings along with them.

Bat met ball, sending it soaring to deep left-center field, and the crowd rose and unleashed a throaty yell. History -- the Mets' first home run at Citi Field -- seemed a few seconds away, and Fernando Tatis, the answer to that trivia question, tagged first base and followed the ball's trajectory. Rather than landing in the seats, the ball ricocheted three-quarters of the way up the 15-foot wall, a good 400 feet away, and Tatis stopped at second. Nine outs into the Mets' inaugural game at Citi Field, a rain-delayed 4-3 victory against the Boston Red Sox, and a preliminary answer to their new ballpark's most pressing riddle -- how will it play? -- had emerged. The definitive verdict will not come for at least another few months, after the temperature changes and wind patterns are tracked, but the learning process had begun for Tatis and the Mets.

Dr. William B. Schwartz, a leading health economist whose studies of the effects of market forces on medicine led him to predict that unbridled costs could lead to a rationing of care, died on March 15 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 86. The cause was complications of Alzheimer's disease, his family said.

It is one thing to be an immigrant in New York City, and quite another to be an immigrant in this working-class city 175 miles to the northwest. Binghamton is the kind of upstate community where immigrants and minorities are but a fraction of the population, true foreigners in Broome County, the kind of all-American, majority-white county that is the Home of the Square Deal, as the nearby village of Endicott is known. The city has a population of 43,000, 80 percent white. Only 8 percent are foreign born.

PORTNOY--Sara Spiro, passed peacefully at home on April 3. Born January 11, 1926 to Marc Spiro, a schoolteacher and principal, and Gussie Raphael, a homemaker, Sara graduated from Hunter High School '43, Radcliffe College '46 and Columbia Law School '49. A pioneer for women in the law, Sara spent her early professional years with AT&T practicing labor and employment law. She was an active member of the Lexington Democratic Club advocating for political reform for New York City. In 1959, she married Alexander Portnoy. She and Al had two sons, William and Lawrence, and moved to White Plains where Sara volunteered her time for worthy causes. She was an attorney at and a Director of the Legal Aid Society of Westchester, a pro bono counselor to school boards and other community groups, a leader of the Westchester League of Women Voters, and a long-serving member of the City of White Plains Human Rights Commission. In 1972, Al was disabled by heart disease and he passed in 1976. Sara then returned to work, first part time for AT&T and then at Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn in the Labor and Employment Group. She was a partner there until her retirement in 1994. During her years at Proskauer, Sara represented, among others, AT&T, NBC, Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, The Metropolitan Opera, The New York Times, the New York City Ballet, The Rockefeller University and the Muscular Dystrophy Association. Sara was also an active participant in the Bar Association of the City of New York, helping to found and chair its Public Service Network programs and serving on its Committees on the Homeless and on Retirement and Pro Bono Activities. On retirement, Sara continued her pro bono and community service efforts advising many non-profits and serving as a Director of the Children's Storefront School in Harlem, the Mosholu Montefiore Community Center in the Bronx and the Muscular Dystrophy Association. She was also a Director of her much loved South Fork Country Club in Amagansett. Sara spent all of her years surrounded by loving family. Her last several years were graced by regular Sunday night dinners and vacations with her growing family, summers in Amagansett which she loved for the good friends, the cool breezes and golf. Her last weeks were spent at home in comfort with family and friends. She is survived by sons William, president of a metals distribution company, and Lawrence, an attorney, daughters-in-law Ellen Rachlin and Philippa Feldman Portnoy and grandchildren Alex, Harry and Zachary Portnoy. She lost her only sibling, a sister Cissie Aidinoff in 1984. Funeral services will be held at Temple Emanu-el of New York, 5th Ave. and 65th St. on April 5, 2009 at 11am. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Mosholu Montefiore Community Center, 3450 Dekalb Avenue, Bronx New York, 10467 (attn: D. Bluestone) or The Children's Storefront, 61 East 129th Street, New York, NY 10035 (attn: D. Brewer).

For more than half a century, America's political leaders -- Republican and Democrat -- have sought to wrap themselves in the legacy of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the man credited with replacing fear with hope and ending the Great Depression. But in recent years some writers and economists have been telling a version of this story that is quite different from the one generally taught in school or seen on the History Channel. In this interpretation Roosevelt is a well-meaning but misguided dupe who not only prolonged the Depression but also exacerbated it. For many people, it's like hearing that Little Red Riding Hood's grandmother and not the wolf is the rapacious killer.

(21) SWIMMING IN AUSCHWITZ (2008) Jon Kean's documentary, which played the festival circuit and had a theatrical run in Los Angeles last year, is about the lives of six women -- Eva Beckmann, Rena Drexler (right), Renee Firestone, Erika Jacoby, Lili Majzner and Linda Sherman -- who survived the Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp. The title comes from one woman's story of walking past a pool reserved for the Nazi guards on a hot day and impulsively jumping in for a swim. 8 A.M. (Disney) SPECIAL AGENT OSOSean Astin lends his voice to Oso, a lovable stuffed panda who helps children deal with everyday tasks in his role with Unique, otherwise known as the United Network for Investigating Quite Usual Events. This new animated series begins with back-to-back episodes in which tasks like cleaning a room or using a library are taught by breaking them down into three simple steps -- just as the organizationally challenged Oso does.

Nintendo's newest toy, the DSi, fits in your pocket and demonstrates in a simultaneously profound and giggle-inducing way that its makers may have a deeper understanding of how entertainment is evolving in the 21st century than any other company. Like Nintendo's fabulously popular Wii console, this new version of Nintendo's hand-held DS, which is being released on Sunday, succeeds because it reimagines what fun can mean. And it does so in an immediately accessible way.

PORTNOY--Sara S. The lawyers and staff of Proskauer Rose, LLP mourn the passing of Sara S. Portnoy, a retired partner in the firm's Labor and Employment Law Department. We have lost not only a colleague and a friend, but a true role model and leader who inspired young lawyers in the firm, served as a wise and sage counselor to her clients and had the respect of all with whom she worked, including her adversaries. Sara was known at Proskauer for never hesitating to offer her time, judgment and high principles to lawyers and staff and she was a highly valued advisor to the firm. In the 20 years Sara was at Proskauer, she counseled clients of all sizes on a wide variety of labor and employment-related issues. She was also an active presence in the community, serving on several boards, including the Children's Storefront School in Harlem, the Muscular Dystrophy Association and the Mosholu Montefiore Community Center in the Bronx. She was also actively involved with the New York City Bar Association, where she founded and ran its public service network programs and sat on its Committee on the Homeless and Committee on Retirement and Pro Bono Activities. Sara received her A.B. from Radcliffe College and her law degree from Columbia University School of Law, where she was a Stone Scholar. She will be greatly missed and affectionately remembered as a consummate lawyer and a devoted colleague. Allen I. Fagin Chairman, Proskauer Rose

A gunman invaded an immigration services center in downtown Binghamton, N.Y., during citizenship classes on Friday and shot 13 people to death and critically wounded 4 others before killing himself in a paroxysm of violence that turned a quiet civic setting into scenes of carnage and chaos. The killing began around 10:30 a.m. and was over in minutes, witnesses said, but the ordeal lasted up to three hours for those trapped inside the American Civic Association as heavily armed police officers, sheriff's deputies and state troopers threw up a cordon of firepower outside and waited in a silence of uncertainty.

Mr. Curley served with honor during WWII in the United States Army. SLIDESHOW: PADDLING THROUGH HISTORY The rivers in the Dordogne region of southwestern France have invited exploration and settlement since the days of the Neanderthals. Today the scenic landscape still harbors hundreds of caves containing prehistoric creations, as well as remnants of more recent history.

The LAByrinth Theater will join forces with Alchemy Theater to present “Sweet Storm” by Scott Hudson, directed by Padraic Lillis, beginning June 11 at the Kirk Theater. Jamie Dunn and Eric T. Miller starred as a newly married couple when the play was presented as part of the Public LAB series at the Public Theater last year, and will reprise those roles in the full production. … More than 100 years before Jackie Robinson broke a color barrier in professional baseball, black athletes were dominant in another sport: horseracing. The subject of slaves who were the greatest jockeys of the 18th and 19th centuries is the impetus for “Pure Confidence,” a play by Carlyle Brown that is one of five productions in the Americas Off Broadway festival, set for May 8-July 3 at 59E59 Theaters . Marion McClinton will direct the production, which comes to New York from the Mixed Blood Theater Company of Minneapolis. … Gorilla Repertory Theater Company, which presents free Shakespeare in city parks, (they did “Hamlet” at the Cloisters last summer) will offer two non-Shakespeare productions this year, though both are classically inspired (and still free). Robert Ackerman’s “Joan of Arc” will run July 9 through Aug. 2 in the Pinegrove area of Fort Tryon Park and Laura Lynn MacDonald’s new adaptation of Ibsen’s “Peer Gynt” is planned for Aug. 6-30 in Central Park, at Summit Rock near 83rd Street and Central Park West.

Half a Beatles reunion, or some approximation of it, took place Saturday night at “Change Begins Within,” a benefit concert at Radio City Music Hall for the David Lynch Foundation. Paul McCartney was headlining; Ringo Starr was also on the bill, and yes, after letting the anticipation build, the two surviving Beatles did perform together, as they did in 2002 for a memorial after the death of George Harrison.

A spokesman for the Broadway production of Neil LaBute’s “reasons to be pretty” said Sunday that the show’s producers had beefed up the security detail at the Lyceum Theater following an incident at the Saturday evening performance. During the first act, the character played by Marin Ireland (“Blasted”) lights into her ex-boyfriend, played by Thomas Sadoski (“Becky Shaw”), with a litany of all the things she believes are wrong with him. A male audience member must have felt something a bit too personal in the verbal assault because he stood, called her a bitch twice, said a few other things that cannot be printed, and stormed out of the theater. For those in attendance: No, it was not part of the show.

Up until the last hundred years or so, most humans on the planet could mark the passage of time by the monthly progression of the lunar cycle. Without electricity to turn night into day, the most obvious fact of life after sunset was the size and shape of the moon. Today, most of us live in cities. With the combination of air pollution and light pollution, the average modern person couldn't even tell you the phase of the moon today. It's waxing, near full.

GHAZALIYA-- Raad Ali, a Sunni Awakening Council leader in Baghdad's Ghazaliya neighborhood commands 326 armed men. The predominantly Sunni militias of the Awakening Councils, or Sons of Iraq, are largely credited for bringing stability to many parts of Iraq by driving Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia out of their areas. The substitute Yossi Benayoun scored during injury time, leading Liverpool to a 1-0 victory at Fulham and tightening the pressure on the defending champion Manchester United in the title race. Liverpool moved 2 points ahead in the Premier League, but United has two games in hand and hosts Aston Villa on Sunday. Liverpool routed United and Villa before the two-week international break.

The Denver Broncos’ owner, Pat Bowlen, has sent a letter to season-ticket holders explaining why the organization had to trade the Pro Bowl quarterback Jay Cutler to the Chicago Bears. Bowlen stressed team unity in the e-mail message, reiterating that he and the new coach, Josh McDaniels, had reached out many times to Cutler, who did not respond to their overtures to repair the strained relationship. “It has never been about one player, and it never will be,” wrote Bowlen, who remained largely silent during the six-week rift that ended with Thursday’s trade.

The Devils backup goalie Kevin Weekes will miss two to three weeks with what the team called a lower-body injury. The team president, Lou Lamoriello, said Weekes’s injury was not expected to be serious, though the team was still awaiting test results. Weekes was hurt in the Devils’ 5-4 overtime victory against Tampa Bay on Friday, when Evgeny Artyukin’s shot struck the goalie’s left leg.

BMW-Sauber protested the legality of cars used by the Brawn, Toyota and Williams teams at the Malaysian Grand Prix in a repeat of actions taken by others in Australia last week. Race stewards again rejected the protest, just as officials had in Melbourne. BMW-Sauber said it would appeal.

Chicago began its pitch to host the 2016 Summer Olympics in earnest Saturday with a message from the city’s most famous part-time resident, President Obama. In a four-minute video shown to the International Olympic Committee inspection team, Obama touched on themes that organizers will stress throughout the I.O.C. visit, starting with a reminder that Chicago is a global city and the home to people from all over the world. The I.O.C. faces the question of which city can be counted on to build an Olympic Village and all the sites during a worldwide recession.

Mon Mome, a 100-1 shot, won the Grand National at Aintree Racecourse in England on Saturday, capturing the world’s most famous steeplechase by 12 lengths. Mon Mome, a 9-year-old horse, was ridden by Liam Treadwell in the grueling four-and-a-half-mile test. Mon Mome was the biggest long-shot winner since Foinavon in 1967, who also went off at 100-1. The winner pulled away after jumping the last of the 30 fences in the 162nd running of the race.

The Oklahoma City Thunder announced the recall of forward D. J. White and guard Kyle Weaver from the Tulsa 66ers of the N.B.A. Development League. White has appeared in six games for the 66ers during three assignments to the D-League. He averaged 18.3 points, 7.2 rebounds and 1.5 blocked shots in 31 minutes a game while in Tulsa. Weaver saw action in two games during his first assignment to the 66ers. He averaged 17 points, 9 assists and 7.5 rebounds in 44 minutes a game.

John McEnroe has offered to help Roger Federer rediscover his form after Federer sustained a series of uncharacteristic losses this year. Federer, who is one shy of Pete Sampras’s career Grand Slam title record of 14, has failed to win a tournament or beat any of his rivals ranked in the world’s top four. After the second-ranked Federer lost to Serbia’s Novak Djokovic on Friday in the Sony Ericsson Open, McEnroe said he was willing to help.

The Olympic gold medalist gymnasts Nastia Liukin and Shawn Johnson and the North Carolina basketball star Tyler Hansbrough are among the finalists for the Sullivan Award. The other finalists for the award, which honors the nation’s top amateur athlete, are the Stanford volleyball player Cynthia Barboza and the men’s Olympic 400-meter freestyle relay team. The winner will be announced April 15 in New York.

Bo Van Pelt moved to 11 under par to take a one-shot lead through eight holes of his third round at the Shell Houston Open, before play was suspended because of darkness. Fred Couples, Paul Casey, Colt Knost and Tommy Armour III were at 10 under when the horns sounded at 7:34 p.m.

Andre Iguodala scored a season-high 31 points, Andre Miller had a triple-double with 21 points, 12 assists and 10 rebounds, and the host Philadelphia 76ers clinched a playoff spot with a 95-90 victory over the Detroit Pistons. The 76ers are fifth in the Eastern Conference. ¶Charlotte Bobcats shooting guard Raja Bell’s right calf is not injured as seriously as first thought, and he will be day-to-day. A team official said Bell has a strained calf. Bell.
An article on March 22 about the Parkdale neighborhood in Toronto misstated part of the name of a street. It is Queen Street West (not Queens).

An article on March 22 about the designer Nicole Miller and her vacations in Aspen, Colo., misidentified the mountain on which Cloud Nine Alpine Bistro is located. It is on Aspen Highlands Mountain, not Aspen Mountain.

An article on March 22 about Claudia Schwartz, the owner of Bell’occhio, a San Francisco boutique, misstated the store’s Web address. It is bellocchio.com. A picture with the article was also published in error. The photograph showed a horsehair brush used for cleaning crown moldings and bookshelves, not one for cleaning bicycles and motorcycles.
A picture credit was omitted on March 22 with an article about the fashion designer Rosita Missoni. The photograph showing her at the wheel of a sailboat was taken by Nally Bellati.
An article on March 22 about Chicago misspelled the name of a store that sells clothing, jewelry and housewares. It is Florodora, not Floradora.
An article on March 22 about Bali misspelled part of the name of a hotel. It is the Como Shambhala Estate (not Coco).
A picture on March 22 with an article about the Dubai Mall and other popular attractions in Dubai was published in error. The photograph showed the Mall of the Emirates, not the Dubai Mall.
An article last Sunday about the galleries and shops of Kent misspelled the surname of the painter whose abstract canvas at the Morrison Gallery had just been sold. He was Gary Komarin, not Komarian.

An article on March 22 about the News Corporation’s acquisition of The Brooklyn Paper misstated the reason that Aaron Short, a reporter, left The Greenpoint Courier, another newspaper owned by the corporation. Mr. Short was let go because the newspaper shut down; he was not fired.

An article last Sunday about the Queensboro Bridge, which is celebrating its 100th anniversary, referred incorrectly to the Hell Gate Bridge, designed by the same men who designed the Queensboro, Henry Hornbostel and Gustav Lindenthal. The Hell Gate links the Bronx and Queens by rail, the lines passing over Manhattan (via Randalls and Wards Islands); the bridge does not connect the Bronx and Manhattan.
